readings.title: 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17  (Epistle Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning those who have fallen asleep, lest you sorrow as others who have no hope.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who sleep in Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and remain until the coming of the Lord will by no means precede those who are asleep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of an archangel, and with the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then we who are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And thus we shall always be with the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:24-30  (Gospel Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have life in Himself,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and has given Him authority to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of Man.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will hear His voice</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and come forth – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 10:23-28  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>All things are lawful for me, but not all things are helpful; all things are lawful for me, but not all things edify.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Let no one seek his own, but each one the other’s well-being.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Eat whatever is sold in the meat market, asking no questions for conscience’ sake;</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>for “the earth is the LORD’s, and all its fullness.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>If any of those who do not believe invites you to dinner, and you desire to go, eat whatever is set before you, asking no question for conscience’ sake.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But if anyone says to you, “This was offered to idols,” do not eat it for the sake of the one who told you, and for conscience’ sake; for “the earth is the LORD’s, and all its fullness.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 21:8-9 25-27 33-36  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>And He said: “Take heed that you not be deceived. For many will come in My name, saying, ‘I am He,’ and, ‘The time has drawn near.’ Therefore do not go after them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But when you hear of wars and commotions, do not be terrified; for these things must come to pass first, but the end will not come immediately.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And there will be signs in the sun, in the moon, and in the stars; and on the earth distress of nations, with perplexity, the sea and the waves roaring;</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>men’s hearts failing them from fear and the expectation of those things which are coming on the earth, for the powers of the heavens will be shaken.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Heaven and earth will pass away, but My words will by no means pass away.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But take heed to yourselves, lest your hearts be weighed down with carousing, drunkenness, and cares of this life, and that Day come on you unexpectedly.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>For it will come as a snare on all those who dwell on the face of the whole earth.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Watch therefore, and pray always that you may be counted worthy to escape all these things that will come to pass, and to stand before the Son of Man.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 16:9-20  (3rd  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when He rose early on the first day of the week, He appeared first to Mary Magdalene, out of whom He had cast seven demons.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>She went and told those who had been with Him, as they mourned and wept.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when they heard that He was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>After that, He appeared in another form to two of them as they walked and went into the country.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And they went and told it to the rest, but they did not believe them either.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Later He appeared to the eleven as they sat at the table; and He rebuked their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they did not believe those who had seen Him after He had risen.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He who believes and is baptized will be saved; but he who does not believe will be condemned.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And these signs will follow those who believe: In My name they will cast out demons; they will speak with new tongues;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>they will take up serpents; and if they drink anything deadly, it will by no means hurt them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So then, after the Lord had spoken to them, He was received up into heaven, and sat down at the right hand of God.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And they went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming the word through the accompanying signs. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 8:8-9:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>But food does not commend us to God; for neither if we eat are we the better, nor if we do not eat are we the worse.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But beware lest somehow this liberty of yours become a stumbling block to those who are weak.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For if anyone sees you who have knowledge eating in an idol’s temple, will not the conscience of him who is weak be emboldened to eat those things offered to idols?</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And because of your knowledge shall the weak brother perish, for whom Christ died?</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But when you thus sin against the brethren, and wound their weak conscience, you sin against Christ.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore, if food makes my brother stumble, I will never again eat meat, lest I make my brother stumble.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Am I not an apostle? Am I not free? Have I not seen Jesus Christ our Lord? Are you not my work in the Lord?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>If I am not an apostle to others, yet doubtless I am to you. For you are the seal of my apostleship in the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 25:31-46  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>When the Son of Man comes in His glory, and all the holy angels with Him, then He will sit on the throne of His glory.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>All the nations will be gathered before Him, and He will separate them one from another, as a shepherd divides his sheep from the goats.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And He will set the sheep on His right hand, but the goats on the left.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then the King will say to those on His right hand, ‘Come, you blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world:</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>for I was hungry and you gave Me food; I was thirsty and you gave Me drink; I was a stranger and you took Me in;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>I was naked and you clothed Me; I was sick and you visited Me; I was in prison and you came to Me.’</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then the righteous will answer Him, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see You hungry and feed You, or thirsty and give You drink?</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>When did we see You a stranger and take You in, or naked and clothe You?</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Or when did we see You sick, or in prison, and come to You?’</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>And the King will answer and say to them, ‘Assuredly, I say to you, inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me.’</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Then He will also say to those on the left hand, ‘Depart from Me, you cursed, into the everlasting fire prepared for the devil and his angels:</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>for I was hungry and you gave Me no food; I was thirsty and you gave Me no drink;</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>I was a stranger and you did not take Me in, naked and you did not clothe Me, sick and in prison and you did not visit Me.’</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then they also will answer Him, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see You hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and did not minister to You?’</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then He will answer them, saying, ‘Assuredly, I say to you, inasmuch as you did not do it to one of the least of these, you did not do it to Me.’</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And these will go away into everlasting punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 3 John 1:1-15  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The Elder, to the beloved Gaius, whom I love in truth:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Beloved, I pray that you may prosper in all things and be in health, just as your soul prospers.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For I rejoiced greatly when brethren came and testified of the truth that is in you, just as you walk in the truth.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I have no greater joy than to hear that my children walk in truth.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Beloved, you do faithfully whatever you do for the brethren and for strangers,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>who have borne witness of your love before the church. If you send them forward on their journey in a manner worthy of God, you will do well,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>because they went forth for His name’s sake, taking nothing from the Gentiles.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>We therefore ought to receive such, that we may become fellow workers for the truth.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I wrote to the church, but Diotrephes, who loves to have the preeminence among them, does not receive us.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore, if I come, I will call to mind his deeds which he does, prating against us with malicious words. And not content with that, he himself does not receive the brethren, and forbids those who wish to, putting them out of the church.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Beloved, do not imitate what is evil, but what is good. He who does good is of God, but he who does evil has not seen God.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Demetrius has a good testimony from all, and from the truth itself. And we also bear witness, and you know that our testimony is true.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I had many things to write, but I do not wish to write to you with pen and ink;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>but I hope to see you shortly, and we shall speak face to face. Peace to you. Our friends greet you. Greet the friends by name.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 19:29-40 22:7-39  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>29</dt><dd>And it came to pass, when He drew near to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mountain called Olivet, that He sent two of His disciples,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>saying, “Go into the village opposite you, where as you enter you will find a colt tied, on which no one has ever sat. Loose it and bring it here.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And if anyone asks you, ‘Why are you loosing it?’ thus you shall say to him, ‘Because the Lord has need of it.’”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>So those who were sent went their way and found it just as He had said to them.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But as they were loosing the colt, the owners of it said to them, “Why are you loosing the colt?”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>And they said, “The Lord has need of him.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then they brought him to Jesus. And they threw their own clothes on the colt, and they set Jesus on him.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And as He went, many spread their clothes on the road.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then, as He was now drawing near the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples began to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works they had seen,</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>saying: “‘Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the LORD!’ Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And some of the Pharisees called to Him from the crowd, “Teacher, rebuke Your disciples.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But He answered and said to them, “I tell you that if these should keep silent, the stones would immediately cry out.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then came the Day of Unleavened Bread, when the Passover lamb must be killed.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And He sent Peter and John, saying, “Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So they said to Him, “Where do You want us to prepare?”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Behold, when you have entered the city, a man will meet you carrying a pitcher of water; follow him into the house which he enters.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then you shall say to the master of the house, ‘The Teacher says to you, Where is the guest room where I may eat the Passover with My disciples?’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then he will show you a large, furnished upper room; there make ready.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So they went and found it just as He had said to them, and they prepared the Passover.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>When the hour had come, He sat down, and the twelve apostles with Him.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “With fervent desire I have desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>for I say to you, I will no longer eat of it until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then He took the cup, and gave thanks, and said, “Take this and divide it among yourselves;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>for I say to you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And He took bread, gave thanks and broke it, and gave it to them, saying, “This is My body which is given for you; do this in remembrance of Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Likewise He also took the cup after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in My blood, which is shed for you.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But behold, the hand of My betrayer is with Me on the table.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And truly the Son of Man goes as it has been determined, but woe to that man by whom He is betrayed!”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then they began to question among themselves, which of them it was who would do this thing.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now there was also a dispute among them, as to which of them should be considered the greatest.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And He said to them, “The kings of the Gentiles exercise lordship over them, and those who exercise authority over them are called ‘benefactors.’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But not so among you; on the contrary, he who is greatest among you, let him be as the younger, and he who governs as he who serves.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For who is greater, he who sits at the table, or he who serves? Is it not he who sits at the table? Yet I am among you as the One who serves.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But you are those who have continued with Me in My trials.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And I bestow upon you a kingdom, just as My Father bestowed one upon Me,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>that you may eat and drink at My table in My kingdom, and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “Simon, Simon! Indeed, Satan has asked for you, that he may sift you as wheat.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>But I have prayed for you, that your faith should not fail; and when you have returned to Me, strengthen your brethren.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But he said to Him, “Lord, I am ready to go with You, both to prison and to death.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then He said, “I tell you, Peter, the rooster shall not crow this day before you will deny three times that you know Me.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And He said to them, “When I sent you without money bag, knapsack, and sandals, did you lack anything?” So they said, “Nothing.”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “But now, he who has a money bag, let him take it, and likewise a knapsack; and he who has no sword, let him sell his garment and buy one.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>For I say to you that this which is written must still be accomplished in Me: ‘And He was numbered with the transgressors.’ For the things concerning Me have an end.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>So they said, “Lord, look, here are two swords.” And He said to them, “It is enough.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Coming out, He went to the Mount of Olives, as He was accustomed, and His disciples also followed Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 1:1-10  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Jude, a bondservant of Jesus Christ, and brother of James, to those who are called, sanctified by God the Father, and preserved in Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Beloved, while I was very diligent to write to you concerning our common salvation, I found it necessary to write to you exhorting you to contend earnestly for the faith which was once for all delivered to the saints.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For certain men have crept in unnoticed, who long ago were marked out for this condemnation, ungodly men, who turn the grace of our God into lewdness and deny the only Lord God and our Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But I want to remind you, though you once knew this, that the Lord, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed those who did not believe.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the angels who did not keep their proper domain, but left their own abode, He has reserved in everlasting chains under darkness for the judgment of the great day;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>as Sodom and Gomorrah, and the cities around them in a similar manner to these, having given themselves over to sexual immorality and gone after strange flesh, are set forth as an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Likewise also these dreamers defile the flesh, reject authority, and speak evil of dignitaries.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Yet Michael the archangel, in contending with the devil, when he disputed about the body of Moses, dared not bring against him a reviling accusation, but said, “The Lord rebuke you!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But these speak evil of whatever they do not know; and whatever they know naturally, like brute beasts, in these things they corrupt themselves.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 22:39-42 45-23:1  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>39</dt><dd>Coming out, He went to the Mount of Olives, as He was accustomed, and His disciples also followed Him.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>When He came to the place, He said to them, “Pray that you may not enter into temptation.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And He was withdrawn from them about a stone’s throw, and He knelt down and prayed,</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>saying, “Father, if it is Your will, take this cup away from Me; nevertheless not My will, but Yours, be done.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>When He rose up from prayer, and had come to His disciples, He found them sleeping from sorrow.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Why do you sleep? Rise and pray, lest you enter into temptation.”</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>And while He was still speaking, behold, a multitude; and he who was called Judas, one of the twelve, went before them and drew near to Jesus to kiss Him.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>But Jesus said to him, “Judas, are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>When those around Him saw what was going to happen, they said to Him, “Lord, shall we strike with the sword?”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>And one of them struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his right ear.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>But Jesus answered and said, “Permit even this.” And He touched his ear and healed him.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to the chief priests, captains of the temple, and the elders who had come to Him, “Have you come out, as against a robber, with swords and clubs?</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>When I was with you daily in the temple, you did not try to seize Me. But this is your hour, and the power of darkness.”</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>Having arrested Him, they led Him and brought Him into the high priest’s house. But Peter followed at a distance.</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>Now when they had kindled a fire in the midst of the courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat among them.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>And a certain servant girl, seeing him as he sat by the fire, looked intently at him and said, “This man was also with Him.”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>But he denied Him, saying, “Woman, I do not know Him.”</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>And after a little while another saw him and said, “You also are of them.” But Peter said, “Man, I am not!”</dd><dt>59</dt><dd>Then after about an hour had passed, another confidently affirmed, saying, “Surely this fellow also was with Him, for he is a Galilean.”</dd><dt>60</dt><dd>But Peter said, “Man, I do not know what you are saying!” Immediately, while he was still speaking, the rooster crowed.</dd><dt>61</dt><dd>And the Lord turned and looked at Peter. Then Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how He had said to him, “Before the rooster crows, you will deny Me three times.”</dd><dt>62</dt><dd>So Peter went out and wept bitterly.</dd><dt>63</dt><dd>Now the men who held Jesus mocked Him and beat Him.</dd><dt>64</dt><dd>And having blindfolded Him, they struck Him on the face and asked Him, saying, “Prophesy! Who is the one who struck You?”</dd><dt>65</dt><dd>And many other things they blasphemously spoke against Him.</dd><dt>66</dt><dd>As soon as it was day, the elders of the people, both chief priests and scribes, came together and led Him into their council, saying,</dd><dt>67</dt><dd>“If You are the Christ, tell us.” But He said to them, “If I tell you, you will by no means believe.</dd><dt>68</dt><dd>And if I also ask you, you will by no means answer Me or let Me go. </dd><dt>69</dt><dd>Hereafter the Son of Man will sit on the right hand of the power of God.”</dd><dt>70</dt><dd>Then they all said, “Are You then the Son of God?” So He said to them, “You rightly say that I am.”</dd><dt>71</dt><dd>And they said, “What further testimony do we need? For we have heard it ourselves from His own mouth.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then the whole multitude of them arose and led Him to Pilate.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Joel 2:12-26  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>“Now, therefore,” says the Lord, “Turn to Me with all your heart, with fasting, with weeping, and with mourning.” </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So rend your heart, and not your garments; return to the Lord your God, for He is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness; and He relents from doing harm. </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Who knows if He will turn and relent, and leave a blessing behind Him – a grain offering and a drink offering for the Lord your God? </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Blow the trumpet in Zion, consecrate a fast, call a sacred assembly; </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>gather the people, sanctify the congregation, assemble the elders, gather the children and nursing babes; let the bridegroom go out from his chamber, and the bride from her dressing room. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Let the priests, who minister to the Lord, weep between the porch and the altar; let them say, “Spare Your people, O Lord, and do not give Your heritage to reproach, that the nations should rule over them. Why should they say among the peoples, ‘Where is their God?’” </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then the Lord will be zealous for His land, and pity His people. </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The Lord will answer and say to His people, “Behold, I will send you grain and new wine and oil, and you will be satisfied by them; I will no longer make you a reproach among the nations. </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But I will remove far from you the northern army, and will drive him away into a barren and desolate land, with his face toward the eastern sea and his back toward the western sea; His stench will come up, and his foul odor will rise, because he has done monstrous things.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Fear not, O land; be glad and rejoice, for the Lord has done marvelous things! </dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Do not be afraid, you beasts of the field; for the open pastures are springing up, and the tree bears its fruit; the fig tree and the vine yield their strength. </dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Be glad then, you children of Zion, and rejoice in the Lord your God; for He has given you the former rain faithfully, and He will cause the rain to come down for you – the former rain, and the latter rain in the first month.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>The threshing floors shall be full of wheat, and the vats shall overflow with new wine and oil. </dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“So I will restore to you the years that the swarming locust has eaten, the crawling locust, the consuming locust, and the chewing locust, My great army which I sent among you.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>You shall eat in plenty and be satisfied, and praise the name of the Lord your God, Who has dealt wondrously with you; and My people shall never be put to shame.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Joel 3:12-21  (Vespers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>“Let the nations be wakened, and come up to the Valley of Jehoshaphat; for there I will sit to judge all the surrounding nations.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Put in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe. Come, go down; for the winepress is full, the vats overflow – for their wickedness is great.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Multitudes, multitudes in the valley of decision! For the day of the Lord is near in the valley of decision.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The sun and moon will grow dark, and the stars will diminish their brightness.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>The Lord also will roar from Zion, and utter His voice from Jerusalem; the heavens and earth will shake; but the Lord will be a shelter for His people, and the strength of the children of Israel.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“So you shall know that I am the Lord your God, dwelling in Zion My holy mountain. Then Jerusalem shall be holy, and no aliens shall ever pass through her again.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And it will come to pass in that day that the mountains shall drip with new wine, the hills shall flow with milk, and all the brooks of Judah shall be flooded with water; a fountain shall flow from the house of the Lord and water the Valley of Acacias.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>“Egypt shall be a desolation, and Edom a desolate wilderness, because of violence against the people of Judah, for they have shed innocent blood in their land.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But Judah shall abide forever, and Jerusalem from generation to generation.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For I will acquit them of the guilt of bloodshed, whom I had not acquitted; for the Lord dwells in Zion.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 1:11-25  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Woe to them! For they have gone in the way of Cain, have run greedily in the error of Balaam for profit, and perished in the rebellion of Korah.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>These are spots in your love feasts, while they feast with you without fear, serving only themselves. They are clouds without water, carried about by the winds; late autumn trees without fruit, twice dead, pulled up by the roots;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>raging waves of the sea, foaming up their own shame; wandering stars for whom is reserved the blackness of darkness forever.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now Enoch, the seventh from Adam, prophesied about these men also, saying, “Behold, the Lord comes with ten thousands of His saints,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>to execute judgment on all, to convict all who are ungodly among them of all their ungodly deeds which they have committed in an ungodly way, and of all the harsh things which ungodly sinners have spoken against Him.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>These are grumblers, complainers, walking according to their own lusts; and they mouth great swelling words, flattering people to gain advantage.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But you, beloved, remember the words which were spoken before by the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>how they told you that there would be mockers in the last time who would walk according to their own ungodly lusts.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>These are sensual persons, who cause divisions, not having the Spirit.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But you, beloved, building yourselves up on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Spirit,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>keep yourselves in the love of God, looking for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And on some have compassion, making a distinction;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>but others save with fear, pulling them out of the fire, hating even the garment defiled by the flesh.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now to Him who is able to keep you from stumbling, and to present you faultless before the presence of His glory with exceeding joy,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>To God our Savior, Who alone is wise, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and forever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 23:2-34 44-56  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>And they began to accuse Him, saying, “We found this fellow perverting the nation, and forbidding to pay taxes to Caesar, saying that He Himself is Christ, a King.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Pilate asked Him, saying, “Are You the King of the Jews?” He answered him and said, “It is as you say.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowd, “I find no fault in this Man.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But they were the more fierce, saying, “He stirs up the people, teaching throughout all Judea, beginning from Galilee to this place.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>When Pilate heard of Galilee, he asked if the Man were a Galilean.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And as soon as he knew that He belonged to Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent Him to Herod, who was also in Jerusalem at that time.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Now when Herod saw Jesus, he was exceedingly glad; for he had desired for a long time to see Him, because he had heard many things about Him, and he hoped to see some miracle done by Him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then he questioned Him with many words, but He answered him nothing.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the chief priests and scribes stood and vehemently accused Him.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then Herod, with his men of war, treated Him with contempt and mocked Him, arrayed Him in a gorgeous robe, and sent Him back to Pilate.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>That very day Pilate and Herod became friends with each other, for previously they had been at enmity with each other.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Pilate, when he had called together the chief priests, the rulers, and the people,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>said to them, “You have brought this Man to me, as one who misleads the people. And indeed, having examined Him in your presence, I have found no fault in this Man concerning those things of which you accuse Him;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>no, neither did Herod, for I sent you back to him; and indeed nothing deserving of death has been done by Him.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>I will therefore chastise Him and release Him”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>(for it was necessary for him to release one to them at the feast). </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And they all cried out at once, saying, “Away with this Man, and release to us Barabbas” – </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>who had been thrown into prison for a certain rebellion made in the city, and for murder.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Pilate, therefore, wishing to release Jesus, again called out to them.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But they shouted, saying, “Crucify Him, crucify Him!”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then he said to them the third time, “Why, what evil has He done? I have found no reason for death in Him. I will therefore chastise Him and let Him go.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But they were insistent, demanding with loud voices that He be crucified. And the voices of these men and of the chief priests prevailed. </dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So Pilate gave sentence that it should be as they requested.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And he released to them the one they requested, who for rebellion and murder had been thrown into prison; but he delivered Jesus to their will.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Now as they led Him away, they laid hold of a certain man, Simon a Cyrenian, who was coming from the country, and on him they laid the cross that he might bear it after Jesus.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And a great multitude of the people followed Him, and women who also mourned and lamented Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But Jesus, turning to them, said, “Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for Me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For indeed the days are coming in which they will say, ‘Blessed are the barren, wombs that never bore, and breasts which never nursed!’</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then they will begin to say to the mountains, ‘Fall on us!’ and to the hills, ‘Cover us!’ </dd><dt>31</dt><dd>For if they do these things in the green wood, what will be done in the dry?”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>There were also two others, criminals, led with Him to be put to death.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And when they had come to the place called Calvary, there they crucified Him, and the criminals, one on the right hand and the other on the left.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then Jesus said, “Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they do.” And they divided His garments and cast lots.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Now it was about the sixth hour, and there was darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then the sun was darkened, and the veil of the temple was torn in two.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And when Jesus had cried out with a loud voice, He said, “Father, into Your hands I commit My spirit.” Having said this, He breathed His last.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>So when the centurion saw what had happened, he glorified God, saying, “Certainly this was a righteous Man!”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>And the whole crowd who came together to that sight, seeing what had been done, beat their breasts and returned.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>But all His acquaintances, and the women who followed Him from Galilee, stood at a distance, watching these things.</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Now behold, there was a man named Joseph, a council member, a good and just man.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>He had not consented to their decision and deed. He was from Arimathea, a city of the Jews, who himself was also waiting for the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>Then he took it down, wrapped it in linen, and laid it in a tomb that was hewn out of the rock, where no one had ever lain before.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>That day was the Preparation, and the Sabbath drew near.</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>And the women who had come with Him from Galilee followed after, and they observed the tomb and how His body was laid.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>Then they returned and prepared spices and fragrant oils. And they rested on the Sabbath according to the commandment.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Zechariah 8:7-17  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord of hosts: “Behold, I will save my people from the east country and from the west country;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>and I will bring them to dwell in the midst of Jerusalem; and they shall be my people and I will be their God, in faithfulness.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord of hosts: “Let your hands be strong, you who in these days have been hearing these words from the mouth of prophets, since the day that the foundation of the house of the Lord of hosts was laid, that the temple might be built.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For before those days there was no wage for man or any wage for beast, neither was there any safety from the foe for him who went out or came in; for I set every man against his fellow.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But now I will not deal with the remnant of this people as in the former days, says the Lord of hosts.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For there shall be a sowing of peace; the vine shall yield its fruit, and the ground shall give its increase, and the heavens shall give their dew; and I will cause the remnant of this people to possess all these things.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And as you have been a byword of cursing among the nations, O house of Judah and house of Israel, so will I save you and you shall be a blessing. Fear not, but let your hands be strong.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For thus says the Lord of hosts: “As I purposed to do evil to you, when your fathers provoked me to wrath, and I did not relent,” says the Lord of hosts,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“so again have I purposed in these days to do good to Jerusalem and to the house of Judah; fear not.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>These are the things that you shall do: Speak the truth to one another, render in your gates judgments that are true and make for peace,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>do not devise evil in your hearts against one another, and love no false oath, for all these things I hate, says the Lord.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Zechariah 8:19-23  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord of hosts: The fast of the fourth month, and the fast of the fifth, and the fast of the seventh, and the fast of the tenth, shall be to the house of Judah seasons of joy and gladness, and cheerful feasts; therefore love truth and peace.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord of Hosts: ‘Peoples shall yet come, inhabitants of many cities;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>The inhabitants of one city shall go to another, saying, “Let us continue to go and pray before the Lord, and seek the Lord of hosts. I myself will go also.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Yes, many peoples and strong nations shall come to seek the Lord of hosts in Jerusalem, and to pray before the Lord.’</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord of hosts: ‘In those days ten men from every language of the nations shall grasp the sleeve of a Jewish man, saying, Let us go with you, for we have heard that God is with you. ‘ </dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 8 - Isaiah 40 41 45 48 54  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord: “Comfort, comfort My people,” says God. “Speak to the heart of Jerusalem, you Priests, comfort her, for her humiliation is increased, her iniquity is pardoned; for she has received from the Lord’s hand double for her sins. The voice of one crying in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the Lord; make straight the paths of our God.’</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“Go up to a high mountain, you who are proclaiming glad tidings to Zion, lift up your voice with strength, O herald of good tidings to Jerusalem. Lift it up, fear not! I the Lord God, I have heard the poor of Israel and will not forsake them. I will open rivers on the mountains, and fountains in the midst of the valleys; I will make the deserts pools of water, and the thirsty land springs of water. Let the heavens rejoice from above, and let the clouds rain down righteousness; let the earth bring forth, and let it sprout forth mercy and cause righteousness to shine forth also.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Declare this with a shout of joy, and let this be known, proclaim it to the end of the earth. Say, ‘The Lord hath redeemed His servant Jacob!’ And if they thirst, he shall lead them through the desert, He shall bring forth water for them out of the rock. Rejoice, O barren one who did not bear; break forth into singing and cry loud, you who have not been in travail! For more are the children of the desolate one than of her who has a husband.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 9 - Malachi 3 4  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord Almighty: “Behold, I send My messenger before Thy face, who shall prepare Thy way before Thee, and the Lord whom ye seek, shall come into His temple. But who can endure the day of His coming? For He is coming like the fire of a furnace and like the fuller’s herb; and He shall cleanse, refining and purifying, as it were, silver and gold. And He comes to you with judgment, and will be a swift witness against the evil ones and against adulterers, and against those who swear falsely by My name, against those who withhold the hireling’s wages, against those who oppress widows and beat orphans, against those who avoid judgment in favor of strangers, and against those who do not fear him,” saith the Lord Almighty.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“For I am the Lord your God, and I change not; and you, the sons of Jacob, have turned aside from the law and have not kept it. Return to Me, therefore, and I will return to you,” saith the Lord Almighty. “And all nations shall call you blessed, and they shall understand that I am the Lord, who distinguishes between the righteous and between the transgressors on that day, in which I shall act to spare those who love Me.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Know, therefore, and remember the Law of Moses, My servant, as I commanded you at Horeb, the statutes and ordinances for all Israel. And behold, I will send to you Elijah the Tishbite before the great and glorious day of the Lord comes, who shall turn the heart of a father to his son, and the heart of a man to his neighbor, lest I come quickly and smite the earth,” saith the Lord Almighty, God, the Holy One of Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 3 - Wisdom of Solomon 4 5  (Vespers 4th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest. The righteous man who has died will judge the ungodly who are living. For they will see the end of the righteous, and will not understand what was said about him; for the Lord will cast down the ungodly speechless to the ground and shake them from the foundations; they shall become desolate to the end; they will be in sorrows, and their memory will perish. For they will come with fear at the thought of their sins, and their iniquities shall stand against them to convict them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then the righteous man will stand with great boldness before those who have afflicted him, and those who have made of no account his labors. Having seen it, they shall be troubled with much fear and they will be amazed at his most-glorious salvation. They will say within themselves in repentance, in anguish of spirit they will groan and say: “This was he whom we had sometimes in derision and a proverb of reproach – we fools! We accounted his life as madness, and his end to be without honor. How is he numbered among the sons of God? And why is his lot among the Saints?</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Therefore, we have erred from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness did not illumine us, nor did the sun shine on us. We took our fill of the paths of lawlessness and destruction, and we walked impassable pathways, but the way of the Lord we have not known.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:17-30  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And this report about Him went throughout all Judea and all the surrounding region.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then the disciples of John reported to him concerning all these things.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And John, calling two of his disciples to him, sent them to Jesus, saying, “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>When the men had come to Him, they said, “John the Baptist has sent us to You, saying, ‘Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?’”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And that very hour He cured many of infirmities, afflictions, and evil spirits; and to many blind He gave sight.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “Go and tell John the things you have seen and heard: that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, the poor have the gospel preached to them.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When the messengers of John had departed, He began to speak to the multitudes concerning John: “What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A man clothed in soft garments? Indeed those who are gorgeously appareled and live in luxury are in kings’ courts.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I say to you, and more than a prophet.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>This is he of whom it is written: ‘Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, Who will prepare Your way before You.’ </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For I say to you, among those born of women there is not a greater prophet than John the Baptist; but he who is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And when all the people heard Him, even the tax collectors justified God, having been baptized with the baptism of John.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But the Pharisees and lawyers rejected the will of God for themselves, not having been baptized by him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 4:6-15  (Epistle Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>For it is the God who commanded light to shine out of darkness, who has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellence of the power may be of God and not of us.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>We are hard-pressed on every side, yet not crushed; we are perplexed, but not in despair;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>persecuted, but not forsaken; struck down, but not destroyed – </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>always carrying about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus, that the life of Jesus also may be manifested in our body.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For we who live are always delivered to death for Jesus’ sake, that the life of Jesus also may be manifested in our mortal flesh.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So then death is working in us, but life in you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And since we have the same spirit of faith, according to what is written, “I believed and therefore I spoke,” we also believe and therefore speak,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>knowing that He who raised up the Lord Jesus will also raise us up with Jesus, and will present us with you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For all things are for your sakes, that grace, having spread through the many, may cause thanksgiving to abound to the glory of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:2-15  (Gospel Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>And when John had heard in prison about the works of Christ, he sent two of his disciples</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said to Him, “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “Go and tell John the things which you hear and see:</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The blind see and the lame walk; the lepers are cleansed and the deaf hear; the dead are raised up and the poor have the gospel preached to them.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>As they departed, Jesus began to say to the multitudes concerning John: “What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A man clothed in soft garments? Indeed, those who wear soft clothing are in kings’ houses.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I say to you, and more than a prophet.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For this is he of whom it is written: ‘Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, who will prepare Your way before You.’ </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, among those born of women there has not risen one greater than John the Baptist; but he who is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And from the days of John the Baptist until now the kingdom of heaven suffers violence, and the violent take it by force.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And if you are willing to receive it, he is Elijah who is to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He who has ears to hear, let him hear!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Gospel Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 14:19-23 16:25-27  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Therefore let us pursue the things which make for peace and the things by which one may edify another.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Do not destroy the work of God for the sake of food. All things indeed are pure, but it is evil for the man who eats with offense.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>It is good neither to eat meat nor drink wine nor do anything by which your brother stumbles or is offended or is made weak. </dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Do you have faith? Have it to yourself before God. Happy is he who does not condemn himself in what he approves.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But he who doubts is condemned if he eats, because he does not eat from faith; for whatever is not from faith is sin. </dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Now to Him who is able to establish you according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery kept secret since the world began</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>but now made manifest, and by the prophetic Scriptures made known to all nations, according to the commandment of the everlasting God, for obedience to the faith – </dd><dt>27</dt><dd>to God, alone wise, be glory through Jesus Christ forever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 6:1-13  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Take heed that you do not do your charitable deeds before men, to be seen by them. Otherwise you have no reward from your Father in heaven.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Therefore, when you do a charitable deed, do not sound a trumpet before you as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets, that they may have glory from men. Assuredly, I say to you, they have their reward.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But when you do a charitable deed, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>that your charitable deed may be in secret; and your Father who sees in secret will Himself reward you openly. </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And when you pray, you shall not be like the hypocrites. For they love to pray standing in the synagogues and on the corners of the streets, that they may be seen by men. Assuredly, I say to you, they have their reward.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But you, when you pray, go into your room, and when you have shut your door, pray to your Father who is in the secret place; and your Father who sees in secret will reward you openly. </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And when you pray, do not use vain repetitions as the heathen do. For they think that they will be heard for their many words.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore do not be like them. For your Father knows the things you have need of before you ask Him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>In this manner, therefore, pray: Our Father in heaven, hallowed be Your name.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Your kingdom come. Your will be done on earth as it is in heaven.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Give us this day our daily bread.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And do not lead us into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one. For Yours is the kingdom and the power and the glory forever. Amen. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:1-12  (4th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they, and certain other women with them, came to the tomb bringing the spices which they had prepared.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But they found the stone rolled away from the tomb.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they went in and did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And it happened, as they were greatly perplexed about this, that behold, two men stood by them in shining garments.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then, as they were afraid and bowed their faces to the earth, they said to them, “Why do you seek the living among the dead?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>He is not here, but is risen! Remember how He spoke to you when He was still in Galilee,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>saying, ‘The Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and the third day rise again.’”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they remembered His words.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then they returned from the tomb and told all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and the other women with them, who told these things to the apostles.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And their words seemed to them like idle tales, and they did not believe them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Peter arose and ran to the tomb; and stooping down, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves; and he departed, marveling to himself at what had happened.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 13:11-14:4  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>And do this, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep; for now our salvation is nearer than when we first believed.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The night is far spent, the day is at hand. Therefore let us cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armor of light.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Let us walk properly, as in the day, not in revelry and drunkenness, not in lewdness and lust, not in strife and envy.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh, to fulfill its lusts.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Receive one who is weak in the faith, but not to disputes over doubtful things.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For one believes he may eat all things, but he who is weak eats only vegetables.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Let not him who eats despise him who does not eat, and let not him who does not eat judge him who eats; for God has received him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Who are you to judge another’s servant? To his own master he stands or falls. Indeed, he will be made to stand, for God is able to make him stand.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 6:14-21  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>For if you forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But if you do not forgive men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Moreover, when you fast, do not be like the hypocrites, with a sad countenance. For they disfigure their faces that they may appear to men to be fasting. Assuredly, I say to you, they have their reward.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But you, when you fast, anoint your head and wash your face,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>so that you do not appear to men to be fasting, but to your Father who is in the secret place; and your Father who sees in secret will reward you openly. </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Do not lay up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and rust destroy and where thieves break in and steal;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>but lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust destroys and where thieves do not break in and steal.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 1:1-20  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth! For the Lord has spoken: “I have nourished and brought up children, and they have rebelled against Me;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>the ox knows its owner and the donkey its master’s crib; but Israel does not know, my people do not consider.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Alas, sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity, a brood of evildoers, children who are corrupters! They have forsaken the Lord, they have provoked to anger the Holy One of Israel, they have turned away backward. </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Why should you be stricken again? You will revolt more and more. The whole head is sick, and the whole heart faints.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>From the sole of the foot even to the head, there is no soundness in it, but wounds and bruises and putrefying sores; they have not been closed or bound up, or soothed with ointment.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Your country is desolate, your cities are burned with fire; strangers devour your land in your presence; and it is desolate, as overthrown by strangers.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So the daughter of Zion is left as a booth in a vineyard, as a hut in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieged city.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Unless the Lord of hosts had left to us a very small remnant, we would have become like Sodom, we would have been made like Gomorrah.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Hear the word of the Lord, you rulers of Sodom; give ear to the law of our God, you people of Gomorrah:</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“To what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices to Me?” says the Lord. “I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams and the fat of fed cattle. I do not delight in the blood of bulls, or of lambs or goats.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>“When you come to appear before Me, who has required this from your hand, to trample My courts?</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Bring no more futile sacrifices; incense is an abomination to Me. The New Moons, the Sabbaths, and the calling of assemblies – I cannot endure iniquity and the sacred meeting.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Your New Moons and your appointed feasts My soul hates; they are a trouble to Me, I am weary of bearing them.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>When you spread out your hands, I will hide My eyes from you; even though you make many prayers, I will not hear. Your hands are full of blood.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“Wash yourselves, make yourselves clean; put away the evil of your doings from before My eyes. Cease to do evil, </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>learn to do good; seek justice, rebuke the oppressor; defend the fatherless, plead for the widow. </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“Come now, and let us reason together,” says the Lord, “Though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they are red like crimson, they shall be as wool.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>If you are willing and obedient, you shall eat the good of the land; </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>but if you refuse and rebel, you shall be devoured by the sword”; for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 1:1-13  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The earth was without form, and void; and darkness was on the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the face of the waters.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be light”; and there was light.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And God saw the light, that it was good; and God divided the light from the darkness.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>God called the light Day, and the darkness He called Night. So the evening and the morning were the first day.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Thus God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament; and it was so.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And God called the firmament Heaven. So the evening and the morning were the second day.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the waters under the heavens be gathered together into one place, and let the dry land appear”; and it was so.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And God called the dry land Earth, and the gathering together of the waters He called Seas. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb that yields seed, and the fruit tree that yields fruit according to its kind, whose seed is in itself, on the earth”; and it was so.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the earth brought forth grass, the herb that yields seed according to its kind, and the tree that yields fruit, whose seed is in itself according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So the evening and the morning were the third day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 1:1-20  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, king of Israel:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>To know wisdom and instruction, to perceive the words of understanding,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>to receive the instruction of wisdom, justice, judgment, and equity;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>to give prudence to the simple, to the young man knowledge and discretion – </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>a wise man will hear and increase learning, and a man of understanding will attain wise counsel,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>to understand a proverb and an enigma, the words of the wise and their riddles.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, but fools despise wisdom and instruction.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>My son, hear the instruction of your father, </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>for they will be a graceful ornament on your head, and chains about your neck.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>My son, if sinners entice you, do not consent.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>If they say, “Come with us, let us lie in wait to shed blood; let us lurk secretly for the innocent without cause; </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>let us swallow them alive like Sheol, and whole, like those who go down to the Pit;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>we shall find all kinds of precious possessions, we shall fill our houses with spoil;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>cast in your lot among us, let us all have one purse” – </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>my son, do not walk in the way with them, keep your foot from their path;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>for their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed blood.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Surely, in vain the net is spread in the sight of any bird;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>but they lie in wait for their own blood, they lurk secretly for their own lives.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So are the ways of everyone who is greedy for gain; it takes away the life of its owners.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Wisdom calls aloud outside; she raises her voice in the open squares.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 2 - Proverbs 10 3 8  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The memory of the righteous is with praise and the blessing of the Lord is upon his head. Blessed is the man who has found wisdom and the mortal who has understanding. For it is better to purchase her than treasuries of gold and silver. She is more precious than precious stones and all that is precious is unworthy of her. For length of days and years of life are in her right hand; and in her left hand are riches and glory. Out of her mouth proceeds righteousness and she bears law and mercy upon her tongue.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Hear me, O child, for I will speak noble things. Blessed is the man who keeps my ways, for my ways are the ways of life, and in them is prepared favor from the Lord. Therefore, I pray thee, and utter my voice to the sons of men: For I, wisdom, have dwelt with counsel and knowledge and I have called upon understanding. Counsel and safety are mine, understanding and strength are mine. I love those who love me and those seeking me shall find grace.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Understand craftiness, O you who are simple, and imbibe knowledge, you who are untaught. Hear me again, for I will speak noble things: I will open my mouth and from my lips shall come what is right. For my throat shall meditate truth; false lips are an abomination before me. All the words of my mouth are righteous; there is nothing in them that is twisted or perverse. They are all straight to him who understands and right to those who find knowledge.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I shall instruct you in truth, so that your hope will be in the Lord and you shall be filled with the Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 10:31-11:12  (Vespers 4th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut out.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked what is perverse.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Dishonest scales are an abomination to the Lord, but a just weight is His delight.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>When pride comes, then comes shame; but with the humble is wisdom.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The integrity of the upright will guide them, but the perversity of the unfaithful will destroy them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The righteousness of the blameless will direct his way aright, but the wicked will fall by his own wickedness.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The righteousness of the upright will deliver them, but the unfaithful will be caught by their lust.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When a wicked man dies, his expectation will perish, and the hope of the unjust perishes.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The righteous is delivered from trouble, and it comes to the wicked instead.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The hypocrite with his mouth destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge the righteous will be delivered.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices; and when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted, but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>He who is devoid of wisdom despises his neighbor, but a man of understanding holds his peace.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 5th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:1-9  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 13:17-21  (Epistle St Raphael)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Obey those who rule over you, and be submissive, for they watch out for your souls, as those who must give account. Let them do so with joy and not with grief, for that would be unprofitable for you.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Pray for us; for we are confident that we have a good conscience, in all things desiring to live honorably.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I especially urge you to do this, that I may be restored to you the sooner.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now may the God of peace who brought up our Lord Jesus from the dead, that great Shepherd of the sheep, through the blood of the everlasting covenant,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>make you complete in every good work to do His will, working in you what is well pleasing in His sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Gospel St Raphael)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 1:19-2:4  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>If you are willing and obedient, you shall eat the good of the land; </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>but if you refuse and rebel, you shall be devoured by the sword”; for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>How the faithful city has become a harlot! It was full of justice; righteousness lodged in it, but now murderers.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Your silver has become dross, your wine mixed with water.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Your princes are rebellious, and companions of thieves; everyone loves bribes, and follows after rewards. They do not defend the fatherless, nor does the cause of the widow come before them.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore the Lord says, the Lord of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel, “Ah, I will rid Myself of My adversaries, and take vengeance on My enemies.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>I will turn My hand against you, and thoroughly purge away your dross, and take away all your alloy.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>I will restore your judges as at the first, and your counselors as at the beginning. Afterward you shall be called the city of righteousness, the faithful city.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Zion shall be redeemed with justice, and her penitents with righteousness.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>The destruction of transgressors and of sinners shall be together, and those who forsake the Lord shall be consumed.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For they shall be ashamed of the terebinth trees which you have desired; and you shall be embarrassed because of the gardens which you have chosen.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For you shall be as a terebinth whose leaf fades, and as a garden that has no water.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>The strong shall be as tinder, and the work of it as a spark; both will burn together, and no one shall quench them.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>The word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Now it shall come to pass in the latter days that the mountain of the Lord’s house shall be established on the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills; and all nations shall flow to it.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Many people shall come and say, “Come, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob; He will teach us His ways, and we shall walk in His paths.” For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>He shall judge between the nations, and rebuke many people; they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks; nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 1:14-23  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be lights in the firmament of the heavens to divide the day from the night; and let them be for signs and seasons, and for days and years;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“and let them be for lights in the firmament of the heavens to give light on the earth”; and it was so.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then God made two great lights: the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night. He made the stars also.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>God set them in the firmament of the heavens to give light on the earth,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>and to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So the evening and the morning were the fourth day.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the waters abound with an abundance of living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the face of the firmament of the heavens.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So God created great sea creatures and every living thing that moves, with which the waters abounded, according to their kind, and every winged bird according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And God blessed them, saying, “Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let birds multiply on the earth.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So the evening and the morning were the fifth day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 1:20-33  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>Wisdom calls aloud outside; she raises her voice in the open squares.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>She cries out in the chief concourses, at the openings of the gates in the city she speaks her words: </dd><dt>22</dt><dd>“How long, you simple ones, will you love simplicity? For scorners delight in their scorning, and fools hate knowledge. </dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Turn at my rebuke; surely I will pour out my spirit on you; I will make my words known to you.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Because I have called and you refused, I have stretched out my hand and no one regarded,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Because you disdained all my counsel, and would have none of my rebuke,</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>I also will laugh at your calamity; I will mock when your terror comes,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>when your terror comes like a storm, and your destruction comes like a whirlwind, when distress and anguish come upon you.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>“Then they will call on me, but I will not answer; they will seek me diligently, but they will not find me.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Because they hated knowledge and did not choose the fear of the Lord,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>they would have none of my counsel and despised my every rebuke.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore they shall eat the fruit of their own way, and be filled to the full with their own fancies.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>For the turning away of the simple will slay them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them;</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>but whoever listens to me will dwell safely, and will be secure, without fear of evil.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 2:3-11  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Many people shall come and say, “Come, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob; He will teach us His ways, and we shall walk in His paths.” For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>He shall judge between the nations, and rebuke many people; they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks; nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>O house of Jacob, come and let us walk in the light of the Lord.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For You have forsaken Your people, the house of Jacob, because they are filled with eastern ways; they are soothsayers like the Philistines, and they are pleased with the children of foreigners. </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Their land is also full of silver and gold, and there is no end to their treasures; their land is also full of horses, and there is no end to their chariots.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Their land is also full of idols; they worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers have made.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>People bow down, and each man humbles himself; therefore do not forgive them.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Enter into the rock, and hide in the dust, from the terror of the Lord and the glory of His majesty.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>The lofty looks of man shall be humbled, the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down, and the Lord alone shall be exalted in that day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 1:24-2:3  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the earth bring forth the living creature according to its kind: cattle and creeping thing and beast of the earth, each according to its kind”; and it was so.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And God made the beast of the earth according to its kind, cattle according to its kind, and everything that creeps on the earth according to its kind.
