And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let Us make man in Our image, according to Our likeness; let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, over the birds of the air, and over the cattle, over all the earth and over every creeping thing that creeps on the earth.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>So God created man in His own image; in the image of God He created him; male and female He created them.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then God blessed them, and God said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply; fill the earth and subdue it; have dominion over the fish of the sea, over the birds of the air, and over every living thing that moves on the earth.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And God said, “See, I have given you every herb that yields seed which is on the face of all the earth, and every tree whose fruit yields seed; to you it shall be for food.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>“Also, to every beast of the earth, to every bird of the air, and to everything that creeps on the earth, in which there is life, I have given every green herb for food”; and it was so.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then God saw everything that He had made, and indeed it was very good. So the evening and the morning were the sixth day.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus the heavens and the earth, and all the host of them, were finished.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And on the seventh day God ended His work which He had done, and He rested on the seventh day from all His work which He had done.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then God blessed the seventh day and sanctified it, because in it He rested from all His work which God had created and made.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 2:1-22  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>My son, if you receive my words, and treasure my commands within you,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>so that you incline your ear to wisdom, and apply your heart to understanding;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>yes, if you cry out for discernment, and lift up your voice for understanding,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>if you seek her as silver, and search for her as for hidden treasures;</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>then you will understand the fear of the Lord, and find the knowledge of God.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For the Lord gives wisdom; from His mouth come knowledge and understanding;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>he stores up sound wisdom for the upright; he is a shield to those who walk uprightly;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>he guards the paths of justice, and preserves the way of His saints.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then you will understand righteousness and justice, equity and every good path.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When wisdom enters your heart, and knowledge is pleasant to your soul,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>discretion will preserve you; understanding will keep you,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>to deliver you from the way of evil, from the man who speaks perverse things,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>from those who leave the paths of uprightness to walk in the ways of darkness;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>who rejoice in doing evil, and delight in the perversity of the wicked;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>whose ways are crooked, and who are devious in their paths;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to deliver you from the immoral woman, from the seductress who flatters with her words, </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>who forsakes the companion of her youth, and forgets the covenant of her God.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For her house leads down to death, and her paths to the dead;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>none who go to her return, nor do they regain the paths of life – </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>so you may walk in the way of goodness, and keep to the paths of righteousness.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For the upright will dwell in the land, and the blameless will remain in it;</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>but the wicked will be cut off from the earth, and the unfaithful will be uprooted from it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 2:11-21  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>The lofty looks of man shall be humbled, the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down, and the Lord alone shall be exalted in that day.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the day of the Lord of hosts shall come upon everything proud and lofty, upon everything lifted up – and it shall be brought low – </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>upon all the cedars of Lebanon that are high and lifted up, and upon all the oaks of Bashan; </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>upon all the high mountains, and upon all the hills that are lifted up;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>upon every high tower, and upon every fortified wall;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>upon all the ships of Tarshish, and upon all the beautiful sloops.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The loftiness of man shall be bowed down, and the haughtiness of men shall be brought low; the Lord alone will be exalted in that day,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>but the idols He shall utterly abolish. </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>They shall go into the holes of the rocks, and into the caves of the earth, from the terror of the Lord and the glory of His majesty, when He arises to shake the earth mightily.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>In that day a man will cast away his idols of silver and his idols of gold, which they made, each for himself to worship, to the moles and bats,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>to go into the clefts of the rocks, and into the crags of the rugged rocks, from the terror of the Lord and the glory of His majesty, when He arises to shake the earth mightily.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 2:4-19  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>This is the history of the heavens and the earth when they were created, in the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>before any plant of the field was in the earth and before any herb of the field had grown. For the Lord God had not caused it to rain on the earth, and there was no man to till the ground;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>but a mist went up from the earth and watered the whole face of the ground.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living being.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The Lord God planted a garden eastward in Eden, and there He put the man whom He had formed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And out of the ground the Lord God made every tree grow that is pleasant to the sight and good for food. The tree of life was also in the midst of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Now a river went out of Eden to water the garden, and from there it parted and became four riverheads.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>The name of the first is Pishon; it is the one which skirts the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the gold of that land is good. Bdellium and the onyx stone are there.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The name of the second river is Gihon; it is the one which goes around the whole land of Cush.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>The name of the third river is Hiddekel; it is the one which goes toward the east of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the Lord God took the man and put him in the garden of Eden to tend and keep it.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And the Lord God commanded the man, saying, “Of every tree of the garden you may freely eat;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat, for in the day that you eat of it you shall surely die.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And the Lord God said, “It is not good that man should be alone; I will make him a helper comparable to him.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Out of the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field and every bird of the air, and brought them to Adam to see what he would call them. And whatever Adam called each living creature, that was its name.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 3:1-18  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>My son, do not forget my law, but let your heart keep my commands;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>for length of days and long life and peace they will add to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Let not mercy and truth forsake you; bind them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart, </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>and so find favor and high esteem in the sight of God and man.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Trust in the Lord with all your heart, and lean not on your own understanding;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>in all your ways acknowledge Him, and He shall direct your paths.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the Lord and depart from evil.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>It will be health to your flesh, and strength to your bones.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Honor the Lord with your possessions, and with the firstfruits of all your increase;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>so your barns will be filled with plenty, and your vats will overflow with new wine.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>My son, do not despise the chastening of the Lord, nor detest His correction;</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>for whom the Lord loves He corrects, just as a father the son in whom he delights.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Happy is the man who finds wisdom, and the man who gains understanding;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for her proceeds are better than the profits of silver, and her gain than fine gold.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>She is more precious than rubies, and all the things you may desire cannot compare with her.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Length of days is in her right hand, in her left hand riches and honor.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>She is a tree of life to those who take hold of her, and happy are all who retain her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 3:1-15  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>For behold, the Lord, the Lord of hosts, takes away from Jerusalem and from Judah the stock and the store, the whole supply of bread and the whole supply of water; </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>the mighty man and the man of war, the judge and the prophet, and the diviner and the elder;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>the captain of fifty and the honorable man, the counselor and the skillful artisan, and the expert enchanter.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“I will give children to be their princes, and babes shall rule over them. </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The people will be oppressed, every one by another and every one by his neighbor; the child will be insolent toward the elder, and the base toward the honorable.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>When a man takes hold of his brother in the house of his father, saying, “You have clothing; you be our ruler, and let these ruins be under your power,”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>in that day he will protest, saying, “I cannot cure your ills, for in my house is neither food nor clothing; do not make me a ruler of the people.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For Jerusalem stumbled, and Judah is fallen, because their tongue and their doings are against the Lord, to provoke the eyes of His glory.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The look on their countenance witnesses against them, and they declare their sin as Sodom; they do not hide it. Woe to their soul! For they have brought evil upon themselves.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“Say to the righteous that it shall be well with them, for they shall eat the fruit of their doings. </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Woe to the wicked! It shall be ill with him, for the reward of his hands shall be given him.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>As for My people, children are their oppressors, and women rule over them. O My people! Those who lead you cause you to err, and destroy the way of your paths.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The Lord stands up to plead, and stands to judge the people.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>The Lord will enter into judgment with the elders of His people and His princes: “For you have eaten up the vineyard; the plunder of the poor is in your houses.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>What do you mean by crushing My people and grinding the faces of the poor?” says the Lord God of hosts.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 2:20-3:20  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>So Adam gave names to all cattle, to the birds of the air, and to every beast of the field. But for Adam there was not found a helper comparable to him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall on Adam, and he slept; and He took one of his ribs, and closed up the flesh in its place.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then the rib which the Lord God had taken from man He made into a woman, and He brought her to the man.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And Adam said: “This is now bone of my bones And flesh of my flesh; She shall be called Woman, Because she was taken out of Man.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and they shall become one flesh.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And they were both naked, the man and his wife, and were not ashamed.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the serpent was more cunning than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made. And he said to the woman, “Has God indeed said, ‘You shall not eat of every tree of the garden’?”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the woman said to the serpent, “We may eat the fruit of the trees of the garden;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“but of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, God has said, ‘You shall not eat it, nor shall you touch it, lest you die.’”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then the serpent said to the woman, “You will not surely die.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“For God knows that in the day you eat of it your eyes will be opened, and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So when the woman saw that the tree was good for food, that it was pleasant to the eyes, and a tree desirable to make one wise, she took of its fruit and ate. She also gave to her husband with her, and he ate.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then the eyes of both of them were opened, and they knew that they were naked; and they sewed fig leaves together and made themselves coverings.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they heard the sound of the Lord God walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and Adam and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then the Lord God called to Adam and said to him, “Where are you?”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>So he said, “I heard Your voice in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked; and I hid myself.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And He said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree of which I commanded you that you should not eat?”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then the man said, “The woman whom You gave to be with me, she gave me of the tree, and I ate.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And the Lord God said to the woman, “What is this you have done?” The woman said, “The serpent deceived me, and I ate.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So the Lord God said to the serpent: “Because you have done this, you are cursed more than all cattle, and more than every beast of the field; on your belly you shall go, and you shall eat dust all the days of your life. </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And I will put enmity between you and the woman, and between your seed and her Seed; He shall bruise your head, and you shall bruise His heel.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>To the woman He said: “I will greatly multiply your sorrow and your conception; in pain you shall bring forth children; your desire shall be for your husband, and he shall rule over you.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then to Adam He said, “Because you have heeded the voice of your wife, and have eaten from the tree of which I commanded you, saying, ‘You shall not eat of it’: “Cursed is the ground for your sake; in toil you shall eat of it all the days of your life.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Both thorns and thistles it shall bring forth for you, and you shall eat the herb of the field.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>In the sweat of your face you shall eat bread till you return to the ground. For out of it you were taken; for dust you are, and to dust you shall return.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And Adam called his wife’s name Eve, because she was the mother of all living.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 3:19-34  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>The Lord by wisdom founded the earth; by understanding He established the heavens;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>by His knowledge the depths were broken up, and clouds drop down the dew.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>My son, let them not depart from your eyes – keep sound wisdom and discretion;</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So they will be life to your soul and grace to your neck.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then you will walk safely in your way, and your foot will not stumble.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When you lie down, you will not be afraid; yes, you will lie down and your sleep will be sweet.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Do not be afraid of sudden terror, nor of trouble from the wicked when it comes;</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For the Lord will be your confidence, and will keep your foot from being caught.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in the power of your hand to do so.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not say to your neighbor, “Go, and come back, and tomorrow I will give it,” when you have it with you. </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Do not devise evil against your neighbor, for he dwells by you for safety’s sake.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Do not strive with a man without cause, if he has done you no harm.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Do not envy the oppressor, and choose none of his ways;</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>for the perverse person is an abomination to the Lord, but His secret counsel is with the upright.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>The curse of the Lord is on the house of the wicked, but He blesses the home of the just. </dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Surely He scorns the scornful, but gives grace to the humble.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Timothy 2:1-10  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>You therefore, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the things that you have heard from me among many witnesses, commit these to faithful men who will be able to teach others also.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>You therefore must endure hardship as a good soldier of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>No one engaged in warfare entangles himself with the affairs of this life, that he may please him who enlisted him as a soldier.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And also if anyone competes in athletics, he is not crowned unless he competes according to the rules.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The hardworking farmer must be first to partake of the crops.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Consider what I say, and may the Lord give you understanding in all things.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Remember that Jesus Christ, of the seed of David, was raised from the dead according to my gospel,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>for which I suffer trouble as an evildoer, even to the point of chains; but the word of God is not chained.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore I endure all things for the sake of the elect, that they also may obtain the salvation which is in Christ Jesus with eternal glory.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 15:17-16:2  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>These things I command you, that you love one another.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>If the world hates you, you know that it hated Me before it hated you.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>If you were of the world, the world would love its own. Yet because you are not of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Remember the word that I said to you, ‘A servant is not greater than his master.’ If they persecuted Me, they will also persecute you. If they kept My word, they will keep yours also.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But all these things they will do to you for My name’s sake, because they do not know Him who sent Me.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>If I had not come and spoken to them, they would have no sin, but now they have no excuse for their sin.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>He who hates Me hates My Father also.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>If I had not done among them the works which no one else did, they would have no sin; but now they have seen and also hated both Me and My Father.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But this happened that the word might be fulfilled which is written in their law, ‘They hated Me without a cause.’ </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But when the Helper comes, whom I shall send to you from the Father, the Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father, He will testify of Me.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And you also will bear witness, because you have been with Me from the beginning.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>These things I have spoken to you, that you should not be made to stumble.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>They will put you out of the synagogues; yes, the time is coming that whoever kills you will think that he offers God service.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 1:1-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>God, who at various times and in various ways spoke in time past to the fathers by the prophets,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>has in these last days spoken to us by His Son, whom He has appointed heir of all things, through whom also He made the worlds;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>who being the brightness of His glory and the express image of His person, and upholding all things by the word of His power, when He had by Himself purged our sins, sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>having become so much better than the angels, as He has by inheritance obtained a more excellent name than they.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For to which of the angels did He ever say: “You are My Son, today I have begotten You”? And again: “I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to Me a Son”?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But when He again brings the firstborn into the world, He says: “Let all the angels of God worship Him.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And of the angels He says: “Who makes His angels spirits and His ministers a flame of fire.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But to the Son He says: “Your throne, O God, is forever and ever; a scepter of righteousness is the scepter of Your kingdom.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>You have loved righteousness and hated lawlessness; therefore God, Your God, has anointed You with the oil of gladness more than Your companions.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And: “You, LORD, in the beginning laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the work of Your hands.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>They will perish, but You remain; and they will all grow old like a garment;</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>like a cloak You will fold them up, and they will be changed. But You are the same, and Your years will not fail.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 2:23-3:5  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Now it happened that He went through the grainfields on the Sabbath; and as they went His disciples began to pluck the heads of grain.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And the Pharisees said to Him, “Look, why do they do what is not lawful on the Sabbath?”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But He said to them, “Have you never read what David did when he was in need and hungry, he and those with him:</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>how he went into the house of God in the days of Abiathar the high priest, and ate the showbread, which is not lawful to eat except for the priests, and also gave some to those who were with him?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And He said to them, “The Sabbath was made for man, and not man for the Sabbath.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore the Son of Man is also Lord of the Sabbath.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And He entered the synagogue again, and a man was there who had a withered hand.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>So they watched Him closely, whether He would heal him on the Sabbath, so that they might accuse Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And He said to the man who had the withered hand, “Step forward.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” But they kept silent.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And when He had looked around at them with anger, being grieved by the hardness of their hearts, He said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” And he stretched it out, and his hand was restored as whole as the other. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:12-35  (5th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>But Peter arose and ran to the tomb; and stooping down, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves; and he departed, marveling to himself at what had happened.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Now behold, two of them were traveling that same day to a village called Emmaus, which was seven miles from Jerusalem.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And they talked together of all these things which had happened.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So it was, while they conversed and reasoned, that Jesus Himself drew near and went with them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But their eyes were restrained, so that they did not know Him.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And He said to them, “What kind of conversation is this that you have with one another as you walk and are sad?” </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then the one whose name was Cleopas answered and said to Him, “Are You the only stranger in Jerusalem, and have You not known the things which happened there in these days?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And He said to them, “What things?” So they said to Him, “The things concerning Jesus of Nazareth, who was a Prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and how the chief priests and our rulers delivered Him to be condemned to death, and crucified Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But we were hoping that it was He who was going to redeem Israel. Indeed, besides all this, today is the third day since these things happened.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Yes, and certain women of our company, who arrived at the tomb early, astonished us.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>When they did not find His body, they came saying that they had also seen a vision of angels who said He was alive.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And certain of those who were with us went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said; but Him they did not see.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “O foolish ones, and slow of heart to believe in all that the prophets have spoken!</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Ought not the Christ to have suffered these things and to enter into His glory?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And beginning at Moses and all the Prophets, He expounded to them in all the Scriptures the things concerning Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then they drew near to the village where they were going, and He indicated that He would have gone farther.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But they constrained Him, saying, “Abide with us, for it is toward evening, and the day is far spent.” And He went in to stay with them.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, as He sat at the table with them, that He took bread, blessed and broke it, and gave it to them.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then their eyes were opened and they knew Him; and He vanished from their sight.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And they said to one another, “Did not our heart burn within us while He talked with us on the road, and while He opened the Scriptures to us?”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>So they rose up that very hour and returned to Jerusalem, and found the eleven and those who were with them gathered together,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>saying, “The Lord is risen indeed, and has appeared to Simon!”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And they told about the things that had happened on the road, and how He was known to them in the breaking of bread.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 11:24-26 32-12:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>By faith Moses, when he became of age, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God than to enjoy the passing pleasures of sin,</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures in Egypt; for he looked to the reward.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And what more shall I say? For the time would fail me to tell of Gideon and Barak and Samson and Jephthah, also of David and Samuel and the prophets:</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>who through faith subdued kingdoms, worked righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakness were made strong, became valiant in battle, turned to flight the armies of the aliens.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Women received their dead raised to life again. Others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Still others had trial of mockings and scourgings, yes, and of chains and imprisonment.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>They were stoned, they were sawn in two, were tempted, were slain with the sword. They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented – </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>of whom the world was not worthy. They wandered in deserts and mountains, in dens and caves of the earth.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And all these, having obtained a good testimony through faith, did not receive the promise,</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>God having provided something better for us, that they should not be made perfect apart from us.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore we also, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which so easily ensnares us, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 1:43-51  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>43</dt><dd>The following day Jesus wanted to go to Galilee, and He found Philip and said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Now Philip was from Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Philip found Nathanael and said to him, “We have found Him of whom Moses in the law, and also the prophets, wrote – Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.”</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And Nathanael said to him, “Can anything good come out of Nazareth?” Philip said to him, “Come and see.”</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward Him, and said of him, “Behold, an Israelite indeed, in whom is no deceit!”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Nathanael said to Him, “How do You know me?” Jesus answered and said to him, “Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Nathanael answered and said to Him, “Rabbi, You are the Son of God! You are the King of Israel!”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to him, “Because I said to you, ‘I saw you under the fig tree,’ do you believe? You will see greater things than these.”</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>And He said to him, “Most assuredly, I say to you, hereafter you shall see heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of Man.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 4:2-5:7  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>In that day the Branch of the Lord shall be beautiful and glorious; and the fruit of the earth shall be excellent and appealing for those of Israel who have escaped.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And it shall come to pass that he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy – everyone who is recorded among the living in Jerusalem.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion, and purged the blood of Jerusalem from her midst, by the spirit of judgment and by the spirit of burning,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>then the Lord will create above every dwelling place of Mount Zion, and above her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day and the shining of a flaming fire by night. For over all the glory there will be a covering.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And there will be a tabernacle for shade in the daytime from the heat, for a place of refuge, and for a shelter from storm and rain.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now let me sing to my Well-beloved a song of my Beloved regarding His vineyard: My Well-beloved has a vineyard on a very fruitful hill.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>He dug it up and cleared out its stones, and planted it with the choicest vine. He built a tower in its midst, and also made a winepress in it; so He expected it to bring forth good grapes, but it brought forth wild grapes.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“And now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, Judge, please, between Me and My vineyard.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>What more could have been done to My vineyard that I have not done in it? Why then, when I expected it to bring forth good grapes, did it bring forth wild grapes?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And now, please let Me tell you what I will do to My vineyard: I will take away its hedge, and it shall be burned; and break down its wall, and it shall be trampled down.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>I will lay it waste; it shall not be pruned or dug, but there shall come up briers and thorns. I will also command the clouds that they rain no rain on it.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah are His pleasant plant. He looked for justice, but behold, oppression; for righteousness, but behold, a cry for help. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 3:21-4:7  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>Also for Adam and his wife the Lord God made tunics of skin, and clothed them.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then the Lord God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of Us, to know good and evil. And now, lest he put out his hand and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live forever” – </dd><dt>23</dt><dd>therefore the Lord God sent him out of the garden of Eden to till the ground from which he was taken.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So He drove out the man; and He placed cherubim at the east of the garden of Eden, and a flaming sword which turned every way, to guard the way to the tree of life.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now Adam knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and bore Cain, and said, “I have acquired a man from the Lord.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then she bore again, this time his brother Abel. Now Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And in the process of time it came to pass that Cain brought an offering of the fruit of the ground to the Lord.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Abel also brought of the firstborn of his flock and of their fat. And the Lord respected Abel and his offering,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>but He did not respect Cain and his offering. And Cain was very angry, and his countenance fell.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So the Lord said to Cain, “Why are you angry? And why has your countenance fallen?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>If you do well, will you not be accepted? And if you do not do well, sin lies at the door. And its desire is for you, but you should rule over it.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 3:34-4:22  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>34</dt><dd>Surely He scorns the scornful, but gives grace to the humble.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>The wise shall inherit glory, but shame shall be the legacy of fools.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Hear, my children, the instruction of a father, and give attention to know understanding;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For I give you good doctrine: do not forsake my law.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>When I was my father’s son, tender and the only one in the sight of my mother,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>he also taught me, and said to me: “Let your heart retain my words; keep my commands, and live.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Get wisdom! Get understanding! Do not forget, nor turn away from the words of my mouth. </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Do not forsake her, and she will preserve you; love her, and she will keep you.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Wisdom is the principal thing; therefore get wisdom. And in all your getting, get understanding.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Exalt her, and she will promote you; she will bring you honor, when you embrace her.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>She will place on your head an ornament of grace; a crown of glory she will deliver to you.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Hear, my son, and receive my sayings, and the years of your life will be many.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I have taught you in the way of wisdom; I have led you in right paths.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>When you walk, your steps will not be hindered, and when you run, you will not stumble.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Take firm hold of instruction, do not let go; keep her, for she is your life.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Do not enter the path of the wicked, and do not walk in the way of evil.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Avoid it, do not travel on it; turn away from it and pass on.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For they do not sleep unless they have done evil; and their sleep is taken away unless they make someone fall.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For they eat the bread of wickedness, and drink the wine of violence.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But the path of the just is like the shining sun, that shines ever brighter unto the perfect day.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The way of the wicked is like darkness; they do not know what makes them stumble.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>My son, give attention to my words; incline your ear to my sayings.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Do not let them depart from your eyes; keep them in the midst of your heart;</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For they are life to those who find them, and health to all their flesh.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 5:7-16  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah are His pleasant plant. He looked for justice, but behold, oppression; for righteousness, but behold, a cry for help. </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Woe to those who join house to house; they add field to field, till there is no place where they may dwell alone in the midst of the land!</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>In my hearing the Lord of hosts said, “Truly, many houses shall be desolate, great and beautiful ones, without inhabitant. </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath, and a homer of seed shall yield one ephah.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Woe to those who rise early in the morning, that they may follow intoxicating drink; who continue until night, till wine inflames them! </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The harp and the strings, the tambourine and flute, and wine are in their feasts; but they do not regard the work of the Lord, nor consider the operation of His hands.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore my people have gone into captivity, because they have no knowledge; their honorable men are famished, and their multitude dried up with thirst.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore Sheol has enlarged itself and opened its mouth beyond measure; their glory and their multitude and their pomp, and he who is jubilant, shall descend into it.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>People shall be brought down, each man shall be humbled, and the eyes of the lofty shall be humbled.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But the Lord of hosts shall be exalted in judgment, and God who is holy shall be hallowed in righteousness. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 4:8-15  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>Now Cain talked with Abel his brother; and it came to pass, when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother and killed him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Cain, “Where is Abel your brother?” He said, “I do not know. Am I my brother’s keeper?”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And He said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood cries out to Me from the ground.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So now you are cursed from the earth, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>When you till the ground, it shall no longer yield its strength to you. A fugitive and a vagabond you shall be on the earth.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And Cain said to the Lord, “My punishment is greater than I can bear!</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Surely You have driven me out this day from the face of the ground; I shall be hidden from Your face; I shall be a fugitive and a vagabond on the earth, and it will happen that anyone who finds me will kill me.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And the Lord said to him, “Therefore, whoever kills Cain, vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold.” And the Lord set a mark on Cain, lest anyone finding him should kill him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 5:1-15  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>My son, pay attention to my wisdom; lend your ear to my understanding,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>that you may preserve discretion, and your lips may keep knowledge.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For the lips of an immoral woman drip honey, and her mouth is smoother than oil;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>but in the end she is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a two-edged sword.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Her feet go down to death, her steps lay hold of hell.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Lest you ponder her path of life – her ways are unstable; you do not know them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore hear me now, my children, and do not depart from the words of my mouth.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Remove your way far from her, and do not go near the door of her house,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>lest you give your honor to others, and your years to the cruel one;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>lest aliens be filled with your wealth, and your labors go to the house of a foreigner;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>and you mourn at last, when your flesh and your body are consumed,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>and say: “How I have hated instruction, and my heart despised correction!”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I have not obeyed the voice of my teachers, nor inclined my ear to those who instructed me!</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I was on the verge of total ruin, in the midst of the assembly and congregation.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Drink water from your own cistern, and running water from your own well.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 5:16-25  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>But the Lord of hosts shall be exalted in judgment, and God who is holy shall be hallowed in righteousness. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then the lambs shall feed in their pasture, and in the waste places of the fat ones strangers shall eat.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of vanity, and sin as if with a cart rope; </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>that say, “Let Him make speed and hasten His work, that we may see it; and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw near and come, that we may know it.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil; who put darkness for light, and light for darkness; who put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes, and prudent in their own sight!</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Woe to men mighty at drinking wine, woe to men valiant for mixing intoxicating drink, </dd><dt>23</dt><dd>who justify the wicked for a bribe, and take away justice from the righteous man!</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore, as the fire devours the stubble, and the flame consumes the chaff, so their root will be as rottenness, and their blossom will ascend like dust; because they have rejected the law of the Lord of hosts, and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Therefore the anger of the Lord is aroused against His people; He has stretched out His hand against them and stricken them, and the hills trembled. Their carcasses were as refuse in the midst of the streets. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 4:16-26  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Cain went out from the presence of the Lord and dwelt in the land of Nod on the east of Eden.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And Cain knew his wife, and she conceived and bore Enoch. And he built a city, and called the name of the city after the name of his son – Enoch.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>To Enoch was born Irad; and Irad begot Mehujael, and Mehujael begot Methushael, and Methushael begot Lamech.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then Lamech took for himself two wives: the name of one was Adah, and the name of the second was Zillah.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And Adah bore Jabal. He was the father of those who dwell in tents and have livestock.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>His brother’s name was Jubal. He was the father of all those who play the harp and flute.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And as for Zillah, she also bore Tubal-Cain, an instructor of every craftsman in bronze and iron. And the sister of Tubal-Cain was Naamah.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then Lamech said to his wives: “Adah and Zillah, hear my voice; wives of Lamech, listen to my speech! For I have killed a man for wounding me, even a young man for hurting me.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>If Cain shall be avenged sevenfold, then Lamech seventy-sevenfold.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And Adam knew his wife again, and she bore a son and named him Seth, “For God has appointed another seed for me instead of Abel, whom Cain killed.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And as for Seth, to him also a son was born; and he named him Enosh. Then men began to call on the name of the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>Drink water from your own cistern, and running water from your own well.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Should your fountains be dispersed abroad, streams of water in the streets?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Let them be only your own, and not for strangers with you.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Let your fountain be blessed, and rejoice with the wife of your youth.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>As a loving deer and a graceful doe, let her breasts satisfy you at all times; and always be enraptured with her love.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For why should you, my son, be enraptured by an immoral woman, and be embraced in the arms of a seductress?</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For the ways of man are before the eyes of the Lord, and He ponders all his paths.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>His own iniquities entrap the wicked man, and he is caught in the cords of his sin.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>He shall die for lack of instruction, and in the greatness of his folly he shall go astray.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>My son, if you become surety for your friend, if you have shaken hands in pledge for a stranger,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>you are snared by the words of your mouth; you are taken by the words of your mouth.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So do this, my son, and deliver yourself; for you have come into the hand of your friend: go and humble yourself; plead with your friend.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 6:1-12  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and lifted up, and the train of His robe filled the temple.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Above it stood seraphim; each one had six wings: with two he covered his face, with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And one cried to another and said: “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts; the whole earth is full of His glory!” </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And the posts of the door were shaken by the voice of him who cried out, and the house was filled with smoke.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>So I said: “Woe is me, for I am undone! Because I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of hosts.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then one of the seraphim flew to me, having in his hand a live coal which he had taken with the tongs from the altar.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And he touched my mouth with it, and said: “Behold, this has touched your lips; your iniquity is taken away, and your sin purged.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Also I heard the voice of the Lord, saying: “Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?” Then I said, “Here am I! Send me.” </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And He said, “Go, and tell this people: ‘Keep on hearing, but do not understand; keep on seeing, but do not perceive.’</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“Make the heart of this people dull, and their ears heavy, and shut their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and return and be healed.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then I said, “Lord, how long?” And He answered: “Until the cities are laid waste and without inhabitant, the houses are without a man, the land is utterly desolate,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The Lord has removed men far away, and the forsaken places are many in the midst of the land. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 5:1-24  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>This is the book of the genealogy of Adam. In the day that God created man, He made him in the likeness of God.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>He created them male and female, and blessed them and called them Mankind in the day they were created.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And Adam lived one hundred and thirty years, and begot a son in his own likeness, after his image, and named him Seth.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>After he begot Seth, the days of Adam were eight hundred years; and he had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>So all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty years; and he died.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Seth lived one hundred and five years, and begot Enosh.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>After he begot Enosh, Seth lived eight hundred and seven years, and had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years; and he died.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Enosh lived ninety years, and begot Cainan.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>After he begot Cainan, Enosh lived eight hundred and fifteen years, and had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So all the days of Enosh were nine hundred and five years; and he died.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Cainan lived seventy years, and begot Mahalalel.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>After he begot Mahalalel, Cainan lived eight hundred and forty years, and had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So all the days of Cainan were nine hundred and ten years; and he died.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Mahalalel lived sixty-five years, and begot Jared.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>After he begot Jared, Mahalalel lived eight hundred and thirty years, and had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So all the days of Mahalalel were eight hundred and ninety-five years; and he died.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Jared lived one hundred and sixty-two years, and begot Enoch.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>After he begot Enoch, Jared lived eight hundred years, and had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>So all the days of Jared were nine hundred and sixty-two years; and he died.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Enoch lived sixty-five years, and begot Methuselah.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>After he begot Methuselah, Enoch walked with God three hundred years, and had sons and daughters.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So all the days of Enoch were three hundred and sixty-five years.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And Enoch walked with God; and he was not, for God took him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 6:3-20  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>So do this, my son, and deliver yourself; for you have come into the hand of your friend: go and humble yourself; plead with your friend.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Give no sleep to your eyes, nor slumber to your eyelids.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Deliver yourself like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter, and like a bird from the hand of the fowler.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Go to the ant, you sluggard! Consider her ways and be wise,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>which, having no captain, overseer or ruler,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>provides her supplies in the summer, and gathers her food in the harvest.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>How long will you slumber, O sluggard? When will you rise from your sleep?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep – </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>so shall your poverty come on you like a prowler, and your need like an armed man.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>A worthless person, a wicked man, walks with a perverse mouth;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>he winks with his eyes, he shuffles his feet, he points with his fingers;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>perversity is in his heart, he devises evil continually, he sows discord.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore his calamity shall come suddenly; suddenly he shall be broken without remedy.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>These six things the Lord hates, yes, seven are an abomination to Him:</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>A proud look, a lying tongue, </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>a heart that devises wicked plans, feet that are swift in running to evil,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>a false witness who speaks lies, and one who sows discord among brethren.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>My son, keep your father’s command, and do not forsake the law of your mother.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 43:9-14  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Let all the nations be gathered together, and let the people be assembled. Who among them can declare this, and show us former things? Let them bring out their witnesses, that they may be justified; or let them hear and say, “It is truth.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“You are My witnesses,” says the Lord, “And My servant whom I have chosen, that you may know and believe Me, and understand that I am He. Before Me there was no God formed, nor shall there be after Me.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I, even I, am the Lord, and besides Me there is no savior. </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I have declared and saved, I have proclaimed, and there was no foreign god among you; therefore you are My witnesses,” says the Lord, “that I am God.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Indeed before the day was, I am He; and there is no one who can deliver out of My hand; I work, and who will reverse it?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: “For your sake I will send to Babylon, and bring them all down as fugitives – the Chaldeans, who rejoice in their ships.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 4th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 5th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 21:12-19  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>But before all these things, they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues and prisons. You will be brought before kings and rulers for My name’s sake.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But it will turn out for you as an occasion for testimony.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore settle it in your hearts not to meditate beforehand on what you will answer;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>for I will give you a mouth and wisdom which all your adversaries will not be able to contradict or resist.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>You will be betrayed even by parents and brothers, relatives and friends; and they will put some of you to death.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And you will be hated by all for My name’s sake.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But not a hair of your head shall be lost.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>By your patience possess your souls.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 12:1-10  (Epistle Martyrs)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore we also, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which so easily ensnares us, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For consider Him who endured such hostility from sinners against Himself, lest you become weary and discouraged in your souls.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>You have not yet resisted to bloodshed, striving against sin.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And you have forgotten the exhortation which speaks to you as to sons: “My son, do not despise the chastening of the LORD, nor be discouraged when you are rebuked by Him;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>for whom the LORD loves He chastens, and scourges every son whom He receives.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>If you endure chastening, God deals with you as with sons; for what son is there whom a father does not chasten?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But if you are without chastening, of which all have become partakers, then you are illegitimate and not sons.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Furthermore, we have had human fathers who corrected us, and we paid them respect. Shall we not much more readily be in subjection to the Father of spirits and live?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For they indeed for a few days chastened us as seemed best to them, but He for our profit, that we may be partakers of His holiness.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 20:1-16  (Gospel Martyrs)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>For the kingdom of heaven is like a landowner who went out early in the morning to hire laborers for his vineyard.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Now when he had agreed with the laborers for a denarius a day, he sent them into his vineyard.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And he went out about the third hour and saw others standing idle in the marketplace,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>and said to them, ‘You also go into the vineyard, and whatever is right I will give you.’ So they went.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Again he went out about the sixth and the ninth hour, and did likewise.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And about the eleventh hour he went out and found others standing idle, and said to them, ‘Why have you been standing here idle all day?’</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>They said to him, ‘Because no one hired us.’ He said to them, ‘You also go into the vineyard, and whatever is right you will receive.’ </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So when evening had come, the owner of the vineyard said to his steward, ‘Call the laborers and give them their wages, beginning with the last to the first.’</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And when those came who were hired about the eleventh hour, they each received a denarius.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But when the first came, they supposed that they would receive more; and they likewise received each a denarius.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when they had received it, they complained against the landowner,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>saying, ‘These last men have worked only one hour, and you made them equal to us who have borne the burden and the heat of the day.’</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But he answered one of them and said, ‘Friend, I am doing you no wrong. Did you not agree with me for a denarius?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Take what is yours and go your way. I wish to give to this last man the same as to you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Is it not lawful for me to do what I wish with my own things? Or is your eye evil because I am good?’</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So the last will be first, and the first last. For many are called, but few chosen.’” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 7:1-15  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin king of Syria and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to make war against it, but could not prevail against it.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And it was told to the house of David, saying, “Syria’s forces are deployed in Ephraim.” So his heart and the heart of his people were moved as the trees of the woods are moved with the wind.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out now to meet Ahaz, you and Shear-Jashub your son, at the end of the aqueduct from the upper pool, on the highway to the Fuller’s Field,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“and say to him: ‘Take heed, and be quiet; do not fear or be fainthearted for these two stubs of smoking firebrands, for the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria, and the son of Remaliah.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>‘Because Syria, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah have plotted evil against you, saying,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“Let us go up against Judah and trouble it, and let us make a gap in its wall for ourselves, and set a king over them, the son of Tabel” – </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>‘thus says the Lord God: “It shall not stand, nor shall it come to pass.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For the head of Syria is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin. Within sixty-five years Ephraim will be broken, so that it will not be a people.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is Remaliah’s son. If you will not believe, surely you shall not be established.”’”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Moreover the Lord spoke again to Ahaz, saying, </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Ask a sign for yourself from the Lord your God; ask it either in the depth or in the height above.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, nor will I test the Lord!”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then he said, “Hear now, O house of David! Is it a small thing for you to weary men, but will you weary my God also?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a Son, and shall call His name Immanuel.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Curds and honey He shall eat, that He may know to refuse the evil and choose the good.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 5:32-6:8  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>And Noah was five hundred years old, and Noah begot Shem, Ham, and Japheth.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, when men began to multiply on the face of the earth, and daughters were born to them,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>that the sons of God saw the daughters of men, that they were beautiful; and they took wives for themselves of all whom they chose.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “My Spirit shall not strive with man forever, for he is indeed flesh; yet his days shall be one hundred and twenty years.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>There were giants on the earth in those days, and also afterward, when the sons of God came in to the daughters of men and they bore children to them. Those were the mighty men who were of old, men of renown.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then the Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every intent of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the Lord was sorry that He had made man on the earth, and He was grieved in His heart.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So the Lord said, “I will destroy man whom I have created from the face of the earth, both man and beast, creeping thing and birds of the air, for I am sorry that I have made them.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But Noah found grace in the eyes of the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 6:20-7:1  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>My son, keep your father’s command, and do not forsake the law of your mother.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>bind them continually upon your heart; tie them around your neck.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>When you roam, they will lead you; when you sleep, they will keep you; and when you awake, they will speak with you.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For the commandment is a lamp, and the law a light; reproofs of instruction are the way of life,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>to keep you from the evil woman, from the flattering tongue of a seductress.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Do not lust after her beauty in your heart, nor let her allure you with her eyelids.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For by means of a harlot a man is reduced to a crust of bread; and an adulteress will prey upon his precious life.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Can a man take fire to his bosom, and his clothes not be burned?</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Can one walk on hot coals, and his feet not be seared?</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>So is he who goes in to his neighbor’s wife; whoever touches her shall not be innocent.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>People do not despise a thief if he steals to satisfy himself when he is starving.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Yet when he is found, he must restore sevenfold; he may have to give up all the substance of his house.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Whoever commits adultery with a woman lacks understanding; he who does so destroys his own soul.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Wounds and dishonor he will get, and his reproach will not be wiped away.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>For jealousy is a husband’s fury; therefore he will not spare in the day of vengeance.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>He will accept no recompense, nor will he be appeased though you give many gifts.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>My son, keep my words, and treasure my commands within you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17  (Epistle Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning those who have fallen asleep, lest you sorrow as others who have no hope.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who sleep in Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and remain until the coming of the Lord will by no means precede those who are asleep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of an archangel, and with the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then we who are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And thus we shall always be with the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:24-30  (Gospel Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have life in Himself,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and has given Him authority to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of Man.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will hear His voice</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and come forth – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 3:12-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Beware, brethren, lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief in departing from the living God;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>but exhort one another daily, while it is called “Today,” lest any of you be hardened through the deceitfulness of sin.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For we have become partakers of Christ if we hold the beginning of our confidence steadfast to the end,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>while it is said: “Today, if you will hear His voice, do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For who, having heard, rebelled? Indeed, was it not all who came out of Egypt, led by Moses?</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 1:35-44  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>Now in the morning, having risen a long while before daylight, He went out and departed to a solitary place; and there He prayed.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And Simon and those who were with Him searched for Him.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>When they found Him, they said to Him, “Everyone is looking for You.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But He said to them, “Let us go into the next towns, that I may preach there also, because for this purpose I have come forth.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And He was preaching in their synagogues throughout all Galilee, and casting out demons.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Now a leper came to Him, imploring Him, kneeling down to Him and saying to Him, “If You are willing, You can make me clean.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Then Jesus, moved with compassion, stretched out His hand and touched him, and said to him, “I am willing; be cleansed.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>As soon as He had spoken, immediately the leprosy left him, and he was cleansed.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>And He strictly warned him and sent him away at once,</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>and said to him, “See that you say nothing to anyone; but go your way, show yourself to the priest, and offer for your cleansing those things which Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:36-53  (6th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>Now as they said these things, Jesus Himself stood in the midst of them, and said to them, “Peace to you.”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But they were terrified and frightened, and supposed they had seen a spirit.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Why are you troubled? And why do doubts arise in your hearts?</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Behold My hands and My feet, that it is I Myself. Handle Me and see, for a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see I have.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His feet. </dd><dt>41</dt><dd>But while they still did not believe for joy, and marveled, He said to them, “Have you any food here?”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>So they gave Him a piece of a broiled fish and some honeycomb. </dd><dt>43</dt><dd>And He took it and ate in their presence.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “These are the words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that all things must be fulfilled which were written in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms concerning Me.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>And He opened their understanding, that they might comprehend the Scriptures.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Thus it is written, and thus it was necessary for the Christ to suffer and to rise from the dead the third day,</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>and that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in His name to all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>And you are witnesses of these things.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Behold, I send the Promise of My Father upon you; but tarry in the city of Jerusalem until you are endued with power from on high.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>And He led them out as far as Bethany, and He lifted up His hands and blessed them.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, while He blessed them, that He was parted from them and carried up into heaven.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>And they worshiped Him, and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>and were continually in the temple praising and blessing God. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:26-8:2  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For such a High Priest was fitting for us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and has become higher than the heavens;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>who does not need daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for his own sins and then for the people’s, for this He did once for all when He offered up Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the law appoints as high priests men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints the Son who has been perfected forever.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the main point of the things we are saying: We have such a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>a Minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord erected, and not man.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 1:10-2:3  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>And: “You, LORD, in the beginning laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the work of Your hands.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>They will perish, but You remain; and they will all grow old like a garment;</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>like a cloak You will fold them up, and they will be changed. But You are the same, and Your years will not fail.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But to which of the angels has He ever said: “Sit at My right hand, till I make Your enemies Your footstool”?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Are they not all ministering spirits sent forth to minister for those who will inherit salvation?</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore we must give the more earnest heed to the things we have heard, lest we drift away.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For if the word spoken through angels proved steadfast, and every transgression and disobedience received a just reward,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>how shall we escape if we neglect so great a salvation, which at the first began to be spoken by the Lord, and was confirmed to us by those who heard Him,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 2:1-12  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And again He entered Capernaum after some days, and it was heard that He was in the house.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Immediately many gathered together, so that there was no longer room to receive them, not even near the door. And He preached the word to them.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they came to Him, bringing a paralytic who was carried by four men.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when they could not come near Him because of the crowd, they uncovered the roof where He was. So when they had broken through, they let down the bed on which the paralytic was lying.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>When Jesus saw their faith, He said to the paralytic, “Son, your sins are forgiven you.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And some of the scribes were sitting there and reasoning in their hearts,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“Why does this Man speak blasphemies like this? Who can forgive sins but God alone?”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But immediately, when Jesus perceived in His spirit that they reasoned thus within themselves, He said to them, “Why do you reason about these things in your hearts?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Which is easier, to say to the paralytic, ‘Your sins are forgiven you,’ or to say, ‘Arise, take up your bed and walk’?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But that you may know that the Son of Man has power on earth to forgive sins” – He said to the paralytic,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“I say to you, arise, take up your bed, and go to your house.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Immediately he arose, took up the bed, and went out in the presence of them all, so that all were amazed and glorified God, saying, “We never saw anything like this!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 8:13-9:7  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>The Lord of hosts, Him you shall hallow; let Him be your fear, and let Him be your dread.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>He will be as a sanctuary, but a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense to both the houses of Israel, as a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And many among them shall stumble; they shall fall and be broken, be snared and taken.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Bind up the testimony, seal the law among my disciples.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And I will wait on the Lord, Who hides His face from the house of Jacob; and I will hope in Him.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Here am I and the children whom the Lord has given me! We are for signs and wonders in Israel from the Lord of Hosts, Who dwells in Mount Zion.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And when they say to you, “Seek those who are mediums and wizards, who whisper and mutter,” should not a people seek their God? Should they seek the dead on behalf of the living?</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>To the law and to the testimony!
