If they do not speak according to this word, it is because there is no light in them.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>They will pass through it hard-pressed and hungry; and it shall happen, when they are hungry, that they will be enraged and curse their king and their God, and look upward.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then they will look to the earth, and see trouble and darkness, gloom of anguish; and they will be driven into darkness.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Nevertheless the gloom will not be upon her who is distressed, as when at first He lightly esteemed the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, and afterward more heavily oppressed her, by the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, in Galilee of the Gentiles.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light; those who dwelt in the land of the shadow of death, upon them a light has shined.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>You have multiplied the nation and increased its joy; they rejoice before You according to the joy of harvest, as men rejoice when they divide the spoil.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For You have broken the yoke of his burden and the staff of his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor, as in the day of Midian.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For every warrior’s sandal from the noisy battle, and garments rolled in blood, will be used for burning and fuel of fire.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For unto us a Child is born, unto us a Son is given; and the government will be upon His shoulder. And His Name will be called Wonderful, Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Of the increase of His government and peace there will be no end, upon the throne of David and over His kingdom, to order it and establish it with judgment and justice from that time forward, even forever. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will perform this.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 6:9-22  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>This is the genealogy of Noah. Noah was a just man, perfect in his generations. Noah walked with God.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And Noah begot three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>The earth also was corrupt before God, and the earth was filled with violence.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So God looked upon the earth, and indeed it was corrupt; for all flesh had corrupted their way on the earth.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And God said to Noah, “The end of all flesh has come before Me, for the earth is filled with violence through them; and behold, I will destroy them with the earth.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Make yourself an ark of gopherwood; make rooms in the ark, and cover it inside and outside with pitch.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“And this is how you shall make it: The length of the ark shall be three hundred cubits, its width fifty cubits, and its height thirty cubits.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“You shall make a window for the ark, and you shall finish it to a cubit from above; and set the door of the ark in its side. You shall make it with lower, second, and third decks.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“And behold, I Myself am bringing floodwaters on the earth, to destroy from under heaven all flesh in which is the breath of life; everything that is on the earth shall die.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“But I will establish My covenant with you; and you shall go into the ark – you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives with you.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>“And of every living thing of all flesh you shall bring two of every sort into the ark, to keep them alive with you; they shall be male and female.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>“Of the birds after their kind, of animals after their kind, and of every creeping thing of the earth after its kind, two of every kind will come to you to keep them alive.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>“And you shall take for yourself of all food that is eaten, and you shall gather it to yourself; and it shall be food for you and for them.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Thus Noah did; according to all that God commanded him, so he did.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 8:1-21  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Does not wisdom cry out, And understanding lift up her voice?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>She takes her stand on the top of the high hill, beside the way, where the paths meet.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>She cries out by the gates, at the entry of the city, at the entrance of the doors:</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“To you, O men, I call, and my voice is to the sons of men.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>O you simple ones, understand prudence, and you fools, be of an understanding heart.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Listen, for I will speak of excellent things, and from the opening of my lips will come right things;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>for my mouth will speak truth; wickedness is an abomination to my lips.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All the words of my mouth are with righteousness; nothing crooked or perverse is in them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>They are all plain to him who understands, and right to those who find knowledge.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Receive my instruction, and not silver, and knowledge rather than choice gold;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>for wisdom is better than rubies, and all the things one may desire cannot be compared with her.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>“I, wisdom, dwell with prudence, and find out knowledge and discretion.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is to hate evil; pride and arrogance and the evil way and the perverse mouth I hate.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Counsel is mine, and sound wisdom; I am understanding, I have strength.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>By me kings reign, and rulers decree justice.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>By me princes rule, and nobles, all the judges of the earth.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>I love those who love me, and those who seek me diligently will find me.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Riches and honor are with me, enduring riches and righteousness.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>My fruit is better than gold, yes, than fine gold, and my revenue than choice silver.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>I traverse the way of righteousness, in the midst of the paths of justice,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>that I may cause those who love me to inherit wealth, that I may fill their treasuries.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 9:9-10:4  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>All the people will know – Ephraim and the inhabitant of Samaria – who say in pride and arrogance of heart: </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“The bricks have fallen down, but we will rebuild with hewn stones; the sycamores are cut down, but we will replace them with cedars.” </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore the Lord shall set up the adversaries of Rezin against him, and spur his enemies on,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>the Syrians before and the Philistines behind; and they shall devour Israel with an open mouth. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For the people do not turn to Him who strikes them, nor do they seek the Lord of hosts.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore the Lord will cut off head and tail from Israel, palm branch and bulrush in one day.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The elder and honorable, he is the head; the prophet who teaches lies, he is the tail.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For the leaders of this people cause them to err, and those who are led by them are destroyed.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore the Lord will have no joy in their young men, nor have mercy on their fatherless and widows; for everyone is a hypocrite and an evildoer, and every mouth speaks folly. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For wickedness burns as the fire; it shall devour the briers and thorns, and kindle in the thickets of the forest; they shall mount up like rising smoke.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Through the wrath of the Lord of hosts the land is burned up, and the people shall be as fuel for the fire; no man shall spare his brother.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And he shall snatch on the right hand and be hungry; he shall devour on the left hand and not be satisfied; every man shall eat the flesh of his own arm.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Manasseh shall devour Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh; together they shall be against Judah. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>“Woe to those who decree unrighteous decrees, who write misfortune, which they have prescribed </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>to rob the needy of justice, and to take what is right from the poor of My people, that widows may be their prey, and that they may rob the fatherless.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>What will you do in the day of punishment, and in the desolation which will come from afar? To whom will you flee for help? And where will you leave your glory?</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Without Me they shall bow down among the prisoners, and they shall fall among the slain.” For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 7:1-15  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Noah, “Come into the ark, you and all your household, because I have seen that you are righteous before Me in this generation.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“You shall take with you seven each of every clean animal, a male and his female; two each of animals that are unclean, a male and his female;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“also seven each of birds of the air, male and female, to keep the species alive on the face of all the earth.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“For after seven more days I will cause it to rain on the earth forty days and forty nights, and I will destroy from the face of the earth all living things that I have made.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And Noah did according to all that the Lord commanded him.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Noah was six hundred years old when the floodwaters were on the earth.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So Noah, with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives, went into the ark because of the waters of the flood.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Of clean animals, of animals that are unclean, of birds, and of everything that creeps on the earth,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>two by two they went into the ark to Noah, male and female, as God had commanded Noah.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And it came to pass after seven days that the waters of the flood were on the earth.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, the seventeenth day of the month, on that day all the fountains of the great deep were broken up, and the windows of heaven were opened.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the rain was on the earth forty days and forty nights.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>On the very same day Noah and Noah’s sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, and Noah’s wife and the three wives of his sons with them, entered the ark – </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>they and every beast after its kind, all cattle after their kind, every creeping thing that creeps on the earth after its kind, and every bird after its kind, every bird of every sort.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And they went into the ark to Noah, two by two, of all flesh in which is the breath of life.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 8:32-9:11  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>“Now therefore, listen to me, my children, for blessed are those who keep my ways.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Hear instruction and be wise, and do not disdain it.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Blessed is the man who listens to me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>For whoever finds me finds life, and obtains favor from the Lord;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>but he who sins against me wrongs his own soul; all those who hate me love death.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Wisdom has built her house, she has hewn out her seven pillars;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>she has slaughtered her meat, she has mixed her wine, she has also furnished her table.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>She has sent out her maidens, she cries out from the highest places of the city,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!” as for him who lacks understanding, she says to him,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“Come, eat of my bread and drink of the wine I have mixed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Forsake foolishness and live, and go in the way of understanding.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>He who corrects a scoffer gets shame for himself, and he who rebukes a wicked man only harms himself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Do not correct a scoffer, lest he hate you; </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>give instruction to a wise man, and he will be still wiser; teach a just man, and he will increase in learning.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For by me your days will be multiplied, and years of life will be added to you.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 10:12-20  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore it shall come to pass, when the Lord has performed all His work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, that He will say, “I will punish the fruit of the arrogant heart of the king of Assyria, and the glory of his haughty looks.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For he says: “By the strength of my hand I have done it, and by my wisdom, for I am prudent; also I have removed the boundaries of the people, and have robbed their treasuries; so I have put down the inhabitants like a valiant man.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>My hand has found like a nest the riches of the people, and as one gathers eggs that are left, I have gathered all the earth; and there was no one who moved his wing, nor opened his mouth with even a peep.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Shall the ax boast itself against him who chops with it? Or shall the saw exalt itself against him who saws with it? As if a rod could wield itself against those who lift it up, or as if a staff could lift up, as if it were not wood! </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore the Lord, the Lord of hosts, will send leanness among his fat ones; and under his glory He will kindle a burning like the burning of a fire.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So the Light of Israel will be for a fire, and his Holy One for a flame; it will burn and devour His thorns and his briers in one day.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And it will consume the glory of his forest and of his fruitful field, both soul and body; and they will be as when a sick man wastes away.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then the rest of the trees of his forest will be so few in number that at child may write them. </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And it shall come to pass in that day that the remnant of Israel, and such as have escaped of the house of Jacob, will never again depend on him who defeated them, but will depend on the Lord, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 7:6-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>Noah was six hundred years old when the floodwaters were on the earth.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So Noah, with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives, went into the ark because of the waters of the flood.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Of clean animals, of animals that are unclean, of birds, and of everything that creeps on the earth,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>two by two they went into the ark to Noah, male and female, as God had commanded Noah.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 9:12-18  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>If you are wise, you are wise for yourself, and if you scoff, you will bear it alone.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>A foolish woman is clamorous; she is simple, and knows nothing.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For she sits at the door of her house, on a seat by the highest places of the city,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>to call to those who pass by, who go straight on their way:</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“Whoever is simple, let him turn in here”; and as for him who lacks understanding, she says to him,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“Stolen water is sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But he does not know that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of hell.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 11:10-12:2  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>“And in that day there shall be a Root of Jesse, who shall stand as a banner to the people; for the Gentiles shall seek Him, and His resting place shall be glorious.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>It shall come to pass in that day that the Lord shall set His hand again the second time to recover the remnant of His people who are left, from Assyria and Egypt, from Pathros and Cush, from Elam and Shinar, from Hamath and the islands of the sea.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>He will set up a banner for the nations, and will assemble the outcasts of Israel, and gather together the dispersed of Judah from the four corners of the earth.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Also the envy of Ephraim shall depart, and the adversaries of Judah shall be cut off; Ephraim shall not envy Judah, and Judah shall not harass Ephraim.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But they shall fly down upon the shoulder of the Philistines toward the west; together they shall plunder the people of the East; they shall lay their hand on Edom and Moab; and the people of Ammon shall obey them.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The Lord will utterly destroy the tongue of the Sea of Egypt; with His mighty wind He will shake His fist over the River, and strike it in the seven streams, and make men cross over dry-shod.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>There will be a highway for the remnant of His people who will be left from Assyria, as it was for Israel in the day that he came up from the land of Egypt.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And in that day you will say: “O Lord, I will praise You; though You were angry with me, Your anger is turned away, and You comfort me.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Behold, God is my salvation, I will trust and not be afraid; ‘For Yah, the Lord, is my strength and song; He also has become my salvation.’”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 7:11-8:3  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, the seventeenth day of the month, on that day all the fountains of the great deep were broken up, and the windows of heaven were opened.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the rain was on the earth forty days and forty nights.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>On the very same day Noah and Noah’s sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, and Noah’s wife and the three wives of his sons with them, entered the ark – </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>they and every beast after its kind, all cattle after their kind, every creeping thing that creeps on the earth after its kind, and every bird after its kind, every bird of every sort.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And they went into the ark to Noah, two by two, of all flesh in which is the breath of life.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So those that entered, male and female of all flesh, went in as God had commanded him; and the Lord shut him in.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Now the flood was on the earth forty days. The waters increased and lifted up the ark, and it rose high above the earth.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>The waters prevailed and greatly increased on the earth, and the ark moved about on the surface of the waters.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the waters prevailed exceedingly on the earth, and all the high hills under the whole heaven were covered.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>The waters prevailed fifteen cubits upward, and the mountains were covered.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And all flesh died that moved on the earth: birds and cattle and beasts and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth, and every man.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>All in whose nostrils was the breath of the spirit of life, all that was on the dry land, died.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So He destroyed all living things which were on the face of the ground: both man and cattle, creeping thing and bird of the air. They were destroyed from the earth. Only Noah and those who were with him in the ark remained alive.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And the waters prevailed on the earth one hundred and fifty days.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then God remembered Noah, and every living thing, and all the animals that were with him in the ark. And God made a wind to pass over the earth, and the waters subsided.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The fountains of the deep and the windows of heaven were also stopped, and the rain from heaven was restrained.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And the waters receded continually from the earth. At the end of the hundred and fifty days the waters decreased.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 10:1-22  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son makes a glad father, but a foolish son is the grief of his mother.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Treasures of wickedness profit nothing, but righteousness delivers from death.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The Lord will not allow the righteous soul to famish, but He casts away the desire of the wicked.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>He who has a slack hand becomes poor, but the hand of the diligent makes rich.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>He who gathers in summer is a wise son; he who sleeps in harvest is a son who causes shame.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Blessings are on the head of the righteous, but violence covers the mouth of the wicked.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>The memory of the righteous is blessed, but the name of the wicked will rot.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The wise in heart will receive commands, but a prating fool will fall.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>He who walks with integrity walks securely, but he who perverts his ways will become known.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>He who winks with the eye causes trouble, but a prating fool will fall.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous is a well of life, but violence covers the mouth of the wicked.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Hatred stirs up strife, but love covers all sins.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Wisdom is found on the lips of him who has understanding, but a rod is for the back of him who is devoid of understanding.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Wise people store up knowledge, but the mouth of the foolish is near destruction.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The rich man’s wealth is his strong city; the destruction of the poor is their poverty.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>The labor of the righteous leads to life, the wages of the wicked to sin.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He who keeps instruction is in the way of life, but he who refuses correction goes astray.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Whoever hides hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>In the multitude of words sin is not lacking, but he who restrains his lips is wise.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>The tongue of the righteous is choice silver; the heart of the wicked is worth little.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>The lips of the righteous feed many, but fools die for lack of wisdom.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>The blessing of the Lord makes one rich, and He adds no sorrow with it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 13:2-13  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>“Lift up a banner on the high mountain, raise your voice to them; wave your hand, that they may enter the gates of the nobles.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>I have commanded My sanctified ones; I have also called My mighty ones for My anger – those who rejoice in My exaltation.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>The noise of a multitude in the mountains, like that of many people! A tumultuous noise of the kingdoms of nations gathered together! The Lord of hosts musters the army for battle.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>They come from a far country, from the end of heaven – the Lord and His weapons of indignation, to destroy the whole land.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Wail, for the day of the Lord is at hand! It will come as destruction from the Almighty.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore all hands will be limp, every man’s heart will melt,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they will be afraid. Pangs and sorrows will take hold of them; they will be in pain as a woman in childbirth; they will be amazed at one another; their faces will be like flames.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Behold, the day of the Lord comes, cruel, with both wrath and fierce anger, to lay the land desolate; and He will destroy its sinners from it.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For the stars of heaven and their constellations will not give their light; the sun will be darkened in its going forth, and the moon will not cause its light to shine.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“I will punish the world for its evil, and the wicked for their iniquity; I will halt the arrogance of the proud, and will lay low the haughtiness of the terrible.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I will make a mortal more rare than fine gold, a man more than the golden wedge of Ophir. </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore I will shake the heavens, and the earth will move out of her place, in the wrath of the Lord of hosts and in the day of His fierce anger.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 8:4-21  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>Then the ark rested in the seventh month, the seventeenth day of the month, on the mountains of Ararat.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And the waters decreased continually until the tenth month. In the tenth month, on the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains were seen.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So it came to pass, at the end of forty days, that Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then he sent out a raven, which kept going to and fro until the waters had dried up from the earth.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He also sent out from himself a dove, to see if the waters had receded from the face of the ground.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But the dove found no resting place for the sole of her foot, and she returned into the ark to him, for the waters were on the face of the whole earth. So he put out his hand and took her, and drew her into the ark to himself.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And he waited yet another seven days, and again he sent the dove out from the ark.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then the dove came to him in the evening, and behold, a freshly plucked olive leaf was in her mouth; and Noah knew that the waters had receded from the earth.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So he waited yet another seven days and sent out the dove, which did not return again to him anymore.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And it came to pass in the six hundred and first year, in the first month, the first day of the month, that the waters were dried up from the earth; and Noah removed the covering of the ark and looked, and indeed the surface of the ground was dry.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And in the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dried.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then God spoke to Noah, saying,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“Go out of the ark, you and your wife, and your sons and your sons’ wives with you.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“Bring out with you every living thing of all flesh that is with you: birds and cattle and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth, so that they may abound on the earth, and be fruitful and multiply on the earth.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>So Noah went out, and his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives with him.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Every animal, every creeping thing, every bird, and whatever creeps on the earth, according to their families, went out of the ark.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Noah built an altar to the Lord, and took of every clean animal and of every clean bird, and offered burnt offerings on the altar.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And the Lord smelled a soothing aroma. Then the Lord said in His heart, “I will never again curse the ground for man’s sake, although the imagination of man’s heart is evil from his youth; nor will I again destroy every living thing as I have done.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 10:31-11:12  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut out.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked what is perverse.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Dishonest scales are an abomination to the Lord, but a just weight is His delight.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>When pride comes, then comes shame; but with the humble is wisdom.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The integrity of the upright will guide them, but the perversity of the unfaithful will destroy them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The righteousness of the blameless will direct his way aright, but the wicked will fall by his own wickedness.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The righteousness of the upright will deliver them, but the unfaithful will be caught by their lust.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When a wicked man dies, his expectation will perish, and the hope of the unjust perishes.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The righteous is delivered from trouble, and it comes to the wicked instead.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The hypocrite with his mouth destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge the righteous will be delivered.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices; and when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted, but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>He who is devoid of wisdom despises his neighbor, but a man of understanding holds his peace.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17  (Epistle Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning those who have fallen asleep, lest you sorrow as others who have no hope.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who sleep in Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and remain until the coming of the Lord will by no means precede those who are asleep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of an archangel, and with the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then we who are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And thus we shall always be with the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:24-30  (Gospel Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have life in Himself,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and has given Him authority to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of Man.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will hear His voice</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and come forth – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 10:32-38  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>But recall the former days in which, after you were illuminated, you endured a great struggle with sufferings:</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>partly while you were made a spectacle both by reproaches and tribulations, and partly while you became companions of those who were so treated;</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>for you had compassion on me in my chains, and joyfully accepted the plundering of your goods, knowing that you have a better and an enduring possession for yourselves in heaven.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Therefore do not cast away your confidence, which has great reward.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>For you have need of endurance, so that after you have done the will of God, you may receive the promise:</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>“For yet a little while, and He who is coming will come and will not tarry.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Now the just shall live by faith; but if anyone draws back, my soul has no pleasure in him.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 2:14-17  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>As He passed by, He saw Levi the son of Alphaeus sitting at the tax office. And He said to him, “Follow Me.” So he arose and followed Him.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Now it happened, as He was dining in Levi’s house, that many tax collectors and sinners also sat together with Jesus and His disciples; for there were many, and they followed Him.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And when the scribes and Pharisees saw Him eating with the tax collectors and sinners, they said to His disciples, “How is it that He eats and drinks with tax collectors and sinners?”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>When Jesus heard it, He said to them, “Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick. I did not come to call the righteous, but sinners, to repentance.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:1-10  (7th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week Mary Magdalene went to the tomb early, while it was still dark, and saw that the stone had been taken away from the tomb.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then she ran and came to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple, whom Jesus loved, and said to them, “They have taken away the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid Him.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Peter therefore went out, and the other disciple, and were going to the tomb.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So they both ran together, and the other disciple outran Peter and came to the tomb first.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And he, stooping down and looking in, saw the linen cloths lying there; yet he did not go in.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then Simon Peter came, following him, and went into the tomb; and he saw the linen cloths lying there,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>and the handkerchief that had been around His head, not lying with the linen cloths, but folded together in a place by itself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then the other disciple, who came to the tomb first, went in also; and he saw and believed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For as yet they did not know the Scripture, that He must rise again from the dead.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the disciples went away again to their own homes.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 4:14-5:6  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Seeing then that we have a great High Priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast our confession.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For we do not have a High Priest who cannot sympathize with our weaknesses, but was in all points tempted as we are, yet without sin.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Let us therefore come boldly to the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy and find grace to help in time of need.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>For every high priest taken from among men is appointed for men in things pertaining to God, that he may offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>He can have compassion on those who are ignorant and going astray, since he himself is also subject to weakness.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Because of this he is required as for the people, so also for himself, to offer sacrifices for sins.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And no man takes this honor to himself, but he who is called by God, just as Aaron was.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>So also Christ did not glorify Himself to become High Priest, but it was He who said to Him: “You are My Son, today I have begotten You.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>As He also says in another place: “You are a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek”;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 8:34-9:1  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>34</dt><dd>When He had called the people to Himself, with His disciples also, He said to them, “Whoever desires to come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow Me.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>For whoever desires to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for My sake and the gospel’s will save it.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>For what will it profit a man if he gains the whole world, and loses his own soul?</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Or what will a man give in exchange for his soul?</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>For whoever is ashamed of Me and My words in this adulterous and sinful generation, of him the Son of Man also will be ashamed when He comes in the glory of His Father with the holy angels.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Assuredly, I say to you that there are some standing here who will not taste death till they see the kingdom of God present with power.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 14:24-32  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>The Lord of hosts has sworn, saying, “Surely, as I have thought, so it shall come to pass, and as I have purposed, so it shall stand:</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>That I will break the Assyrian in My land, and on My mountains tread him underfoot. Then his yoke shall be removed from them, and his burden removed from their shoulders.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>This is the purpose that is purposed against the whole earth, and this is the hand that is stretched out over all the nations. </dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For the Lord of hosts has purposed, and who will annul it? His hand is stretched out, and who will turn it back?”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>This is the burden which came in the year that King Ahaz died. </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>“Do not rejoice, all you of Philistia, because the rod that struck you is broken; for out of the serpent’s roots will come forth a viper, and its offspring will be a fiery flying serpent.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>The firstborn of the poor will feed, and the needy will lie down in safety; I will kill your roots with famine, and it will slay your remnant.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Wail, O gate! Cry, O city! All you of Philistia are dissolved; for smoke will come from the north, and no one will be alone in his appointed times.”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>What will they answer the messengers of the nation? That the Lord has founded Zion, and the poor of His people shall take refuge in it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 8:21-9:7  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>And the Lord smelled a soothing aroma. Then the Lord said in His heart, “I will never again curse the ground for man’s sake, although the imagination of man’s heart is evil from his youth; nor will I again destroy every living thing as I have done.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>While the earth remains, seedtime and harvest, cold and heat, winter and summer, and day and night shall not cease.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>So God blessed Noah and his sons, and said to them: “Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth. </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“And the fear of you and the dread of you shall be on every beast of the earth, on every bird of the air, on all that move on the earth, and on all the fish of the sea. They are given into your hand.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Every moving thing that lives shall be food for you. I have given you all things, even as the green herbs.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But you shall not eat flesh with its life, that is, its blood.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Surely for your lifeblood I will demand a reckoning; from the hand of every beast I will require it, and from the hand of man. From the hand of every man’s brother I will require the life of man.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Whoever sheds man’s blood, by man his blood shall be shed; for in the image of God He made man.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And as for you, be fruitful and multiply; bring forth abundantly in the earth and multiply in it.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 11:19-12:6  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>As righteousness leads to life, so he who pursues evil pursues it to his own death.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Those who are of a perverse heart are an abomination to the Lord, but the blameless in their ways are His delight.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Though they join forces, the wicked will not go unpunished; but the posterity of the righteous will be delivered.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>As a ring of gold in a swine’s snout, so is a lovely woman who lacks discretion.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>The desire of the righteous is only good, but the expectation of the wicked is wrath.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>There is one who scatters, yet increases more; and there is one who withholds more than is right, but it leads to poverty.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The generous soul will be made rich, and he who waters will also be watered himself.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>The people will curse him who withholds grain, but blessing will be on the head of him who sells it.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>He who earnestly seeks good finds favor, but trouble will come to him who seeks evil.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>He who trusts in his riches will fall, but the righteous will flourish like foliage.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>He who troubles his own house will inherit the wind, and the fool will be servant to the wise of heart.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he who wins souls is wise.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>If the righteous will be recompensed on the earth, how much more the ungodly and the sinner.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Whoever loves instruction loves knowledge, but he who hates correction is stupid.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>A good man obtains favor from the Lord, but a man of wicked intentions He will condemn.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>A man is not established by wickedness, but the root of the righteous cannot be moved.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>An excellent wife is the crown of her husband, but she who causes shame is like rottenness in his bones.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The thoughts of the righteous are right, but the counsels of the wicked are deceitful.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The words of the wicked are, “Lie in wait for blood,” but the mouth of the upright will deliver them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 25:1-9  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>O Lord, You are my God. I will exalt You, I will praise Your name, for You have done wonderful things; Your counsels of old are faithfulness and truth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For You have made a city a ruin, a fortified city a ruin, a palace of foreigners to be a city no more; it will never be rebuilt.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore the strong people will glorify You; the city of the terrible nations will fear You.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For You have been a strength to the poor, a strength to the needy in his distress, a refuge from the storm, a shade from the heat; for the blast of the terrible ones is as a storm against the wall.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>You will reduce the noise of aliens, as heat in a dry place; as heat in the shadow of a cloud, the song of the terrible ones will be diminished.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And in this mountain the Lord of hosts will make for all people a feast of choice pieces, a feast of wines on the lees, of fat things full of marrow, of well-refined wines on the lees.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And He will destroy on this mountain the surface of the covering cast over all people, and the veil that is spread over all nations.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He will swallow up death forever, and the Lord God will wipe away tears from all faces; the rebuke of His people He will take away from all the earth; for the Lord has spoken.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And it will be said in that day: “Behold, this is our God; we have waited for Him, and He will save us. This is the Lord; we have waited for Him; we will be glad and rejoice in His salvation.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 9:8-17  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>Then God spoke to Noah and to his sons with him, saying:</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“And as for Me, behold, I establish My covenant with you and with your descendants after you,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>and with every living creature that is with you: the birds, the cattle, and every beast of the earth with you, of all that go out of the ark, every beast of the earth.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Thus I establish My covenant with you: Never again shall all flesh be cut off by the waters of the flood; never again shall there be a flood to destroy the earth.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And God said: “This is the sign of the covenant which I make between Me and you, and every living creature that is with you, for perpetual generations:</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I set My rainbow in the cloud, and it shall be for the sign of the covenant between Me and the earth.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>It shall be, when I bring a cloud over the earth, that the rainbow shall be seen in the cloud;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and I will remember My covenant which is between Me and you and every living creature of all flesh; the waters shall never again become a flood to destroy all flesh.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>The rainbow shall be in the cloud, and I will look on it to remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is on the earth.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And God said to Noah, “This is the sign of the covenant which I have established between Me and all flesh that is on the earth.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 12:8-22  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>A man will be commended according to his wisdom, but he who is of a perverse heart will be despised.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Better is the one who is slighted but has a servant, than he who honors himself but lacks bread.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>A righteous man regards the life of his animal, but the tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He who tills his land will be satisfied with bread, but he who follows frivolity is devoid of understanding.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The wicked covet the catch of evil men, but the root of the righteous yields fruit.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The wicked is ensnared by the transgression of his lips, but the righteous will come through trouble.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>A man will be satisfied with good by the fruit of his mouth, and the recompense of a man’s hands will be rendered to him.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but he who heeds counsel is wise.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>A fool’s wrath is known at once, but a prudent man covers shame.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He who speaks truth declares righteousness, but a false witness, deceit.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>There is one who speaks like the piercings of a sword, but the tongue of the wise promotes health.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The truthful lip shall be established forever, but a lying tongue is but for a moment.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evil, but counselors of peace have joy.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>No grave trouble will overtake the righteous, but the wicked shall be filled with evil.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Lying lips are an abomination to the Lord, but those who deal truthfully are His delight.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 26:21-27:9  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>For behold, the Lord comes out of His place to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity; the earth will also disclose her blood, and will no more cover her slain.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>In that day the Lord with His severe sword, great and strong, will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent, Leviathan that twisted serpent; and He will slay the reptile that is in the sea. </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In that day sing to her, “A vineyard of red wine!</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>I, the Lord, keep it, I water it every moment; lest any hurt it, I keep it night and day.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Fury is not in Me. Who would set briers and thorns against Me in battle? I would go through them, I would burn them together.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Or let him take hold of My strength, that he may make peace with Me; and he shall make peace with Me.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Those who come He shall cause to take root in Jacob; Israel shall blossom and bud, and fill the face of the world with fruit.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Has He struck Israel as He struck those who struck him? Or has He been slain according to the slaughter of those who were slain by Him?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>In measure, by sending it away, you contended with it. He removes it by His rough wind in the day of the east wind.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Therefore by this the iniquity of Jacob will be covered; and this is all the fruit of taking away his sin: when he makes all the stones of the altar like chalkstones that are beaten to dust, wooden images and incense altars shall not stand.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 9:18-10:1  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Now the sons of Noah who went out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. And Ham was the father of Canaan.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>These three were the sons of Noah, and from these the whole earth was populated.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And Noah began to be a farmer, and he planted a vineyard.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then he drank of the wine and was drunk, and became uncovered in his tent.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the nakedness of his father, and told his two brothers outside.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But Shem and Japheth took a garment, laid it on both their shoulders, and went backward and covered the nakedness of their father. Their faces were turned away, and they did not see their father’s nakedness.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So Noah awoke from his wine, and knew what his younger son had done to him.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then he said: “Cursed be Canaan; A servant of servants He shall be to his brethren.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And he said: “Blessed be the Lord, The God of Shem, And may Canaan be his servant.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>May God enlarge Japheth, And may he dwell in the tents of Shem; And may Canaan be his servant.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And Noah lived after the flood three hundred and fifty years.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>So all the days of Noah were nine hundred and fifty years; and he died.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the genealogy of the sons of Noah: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. And sons were born to them after the flood.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 12:23-13:9  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>A prudent man conceals knowledge, but the heart of fools proclaims foolishness.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>The hand of the diligent will rule, but the lazy man will be put to forced labor.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Anxiety in the heart of man causes depression, but a good word makes it glad.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>The righteous should choose his friends carefully, for the way of the wicked leads them astray.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>The lazy man does not roast what he took in hunting, but diligence is man’s precious possession.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>In the way of righteousness is life, and in its pathway there is no death.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>A wise son heeds his father’s instruction, but a scoffer does not listen to rebuke.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>A man shall eat well by the fruit of his mouth, but the soul of the unfaithful feeds on violence.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>He who guards his mouth preserves his life, but he who opens wide his lips shall have destruction.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>The soul of a lazy man desires, and has nothing; but the soul of the diligent shall be made rich.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>A righteous man hates lying, but a wicked man is loathsome and comes to shame.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Righteousness guards him whose way is blameless, but wickedness overthrows the sinner.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>There is one who makes himself rich, yet has nothing; And one who makes himself poor, yet has great riches.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The ransom of a man’s life is his riches, but the poor does not hear rebuke.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The light of the righteous rejoices, but the lamp of the wicked shall be extinguished.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 28:14-22  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore hear the word of the Lord, you scornful men, who rule this people who are in Jerusalem,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>because you have said, “We have made a covenant with death, and with Sheol we are in agreement. When the overflowing scourge passes through, it will not come to us, for we have made lies our refuge, and under falsehood we have hidden ourselves.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore thus says the Lord God: “Behold, I lay in Zion a stone for a foundation, a tried stone, a precious cornerstone, a sure foundation; whoever believes will not act hastily.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Also I will make justice the measuring line, and righteousness the plummet; the hail will sweep away the refuge of lies, and the waters will overflow the hiding place.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Your covenant with death will be annulled, and your agreement with Sheol will not stand; when the overflowing scourge passes through, then you will be trampled down by it.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>As often as it goes out it will take you; for morning by morning it will pass over, and by day and by night; it will be a terror just to understand the report.” </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For the bed is too short to stretch out on, and the covering so narrow that one cannot wrap himself in it. </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For the Lord will rise up as at Mount Perazim, He will be angry as in the Valley of Gibeon – that He may do His work, His awesome work, and bring to pass His act, His unusual act.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Now therefore, do not be mockers, lest your bonds be made strong; for I have heard from the Lord God of hosts, a destruction determined even upon the whole earth. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 10:32-11:9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>These were the families of the sons of Noah, according to their generations, in their nations; and from these the nations were divided on the earth after the flood.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the whole earth had one language and one speech.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And it came to pass, as they journeyed from the east, that they found a plain in the land of Shinar, and they dwelt there.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they said to one another, “Come, let us make bricks and bake them thoroughly.” They had brick for stone, and they had asphalt for mortar.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And they said, “Come, let us build ourselves a city, and a tower whose top is in the heavens; let us make a name for ourselves, lest we be scattered abroad over the face of the whole earth.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But the Lord came down to see the city and the tower which the sons of men had built.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “Indeed the people are one and they all have one language, and this is what they begin to do; now nothing that they propose to do will be withheld from them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“Come, let Us go down and there confuse their language, that they may not understand one another’s speech.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So the Lord scattered them abroad from there over the face of all the earth, and they ceased building the city.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Therefore its name is called Babel, because there the Lord confused the language of all the earth; and from there the Lord scattered them abroad over the face of all the earth.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 13:19-14:6  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>A desire accomplished is sweet to the soul, but it is an abomination to fools to depart from evil.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>He who walks with wise men will be wise, but the companion of fools will be destroyed.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Evil pursues sinners, but to the righteous, good shall be repaid.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>A good man leaves an inheritance to his children’s children, but the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the righteous.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Much food is in the fallow ground of the poor, and for lack of justice there is waste.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>He who spares his rod hates his son, but he who loves him disciplines him promptly.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The righteous eats to the satisfying of his soul, but the stomach of the wicked shall be in want.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>The wise woman builds her house, but the foolish pulls it down with her hands.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>He who walks in his uprightness fears the Lord, but he who is perverse in his ways despises Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>In the mouth of a fool is a rod of pride, but the lips of the wise will preserve them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Where no oxen are, the trough is clean; but much increase comes by the strength of an ox.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>A faithful witness does not lie, but a false witness will utter lies.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>A scoffer seeks wisdom and does not find it, but knowledge is easy to him who understands.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 29:13-23  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore the Lord said: “Inasmuch as these people draw near with their mouths and honor Me with their lips, but have removed their hearts far from Me, and their fear toward Me is taught by the commandment of men,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>therefore, behold, I will again do a marvelous work among this people, a marvelous work and a wonder; for the wisdom of their wise men shall perish, and the understanding of their prudent men shall be hidden.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Woe to those who seek deep to hide their counsel far from the Lord, and their works are in the dark; they say, “Who sees us?” and, “Who knows us?” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Surely you have things turned around! Shall the potter be esteemed as the clay; for shall the thing made say of him who made it, “He did not make me”? Or shall the thing formed say of him who formed it, “He has no understanding”?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Is it not yet a very little while till Lebanon shall be turned into a fruitful field, and the fruitful field be esteemed as a forest? </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>In that day the deaf shall hear the words of the book, and the eyes of the blind shall see out of obscurity and out of darkness.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The humble also shall increase their joy in the Lord, and the poor among men shall rejoice in the Holy One of Israel.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For the terrible one is brought to nothing, the scornful one is consumed, and all who watch for iniquity are cut off – </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>who make a man an offender by a word, and lay a snare for him who reproves in the gate, and turn aside the just by empty words.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Therefore thus says the Lord, who redeemed Abraham, concerning the house of Jacob: “Jacob shall not now be ashamed, nor shall his face now grow pale; </dd><dt>23</dt><dd>but when he sees his children, the work of My hands, in his midst, they will hallow My name, and hallow the Holy One of Jacob, and fear the God of Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 12:1-7  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the Lord had said to Abram: “Get out of your country, from your family and from your father’s house, to a land that I will show you. </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>I will make you a great nation; I will bless you and make your name great; and you shall be a blessing. </dd><dt>3</dt><dd>I will bless those who bless you, and I will curse him who curses you; and in you all the families of the earth shall be blessed.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So Abram departed as the Lord had spoken to him, and Lot went with him. And Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed from Haran.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Abram took Sarai his wife and Lot his brother’s son, and all their possessions that they had gathered, and the people whom they had acquired in Haran, and they departed to go to the land of Canaan. So they came to the land of Canaan.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Abram passed through the land to the place of Shechem, as far as the terebinth tree of Moreh. And the Canaanites were then in the land.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then the Lord appeared to Abram and said, “To your descendants I will give this land.” And there he built an altar to the Lord, who had appeared to him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 14:15-26  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>The simple believes every word, but the prudent considers well his steps.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>A wise man fears and departs from evil, but a fool rages and is self-confident.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>A quick-tempered man acts foolishly, and a man of wicked intentions is hated.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>The simple inherit folly, but the prudent are crowned with knowledge.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The evil will bow before the good, and the wicked at the gates of the righteous.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>The poor man is hated even by his own neighbor, but the rich has many friends.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He who despises his neighbor sins; but he who has mercy on the poor, happy is he.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Do they not go astray who devise evil? But mercy and truth belong to those who devise good.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>In all labor there is profit, but idle chatter leads only to poverty.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>The crown of the wise is their riches, but the foolishness of fools is folly.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>A true witness delivers souls, but a deceitful witness speaks lies.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>In the fear of the Lord there is strong confidence, and His children will have a place of refuge.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 28:10-17  (Vespers 3rd  reading Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Now Jacob went out from Beersheba and went toward Haran.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So he came to a certain place and stayed there all night, because the sun had set. And he took one of the stones of that place and put it at his head, and he lay down in that place to sleep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then he dreamed, and behold, a ladder was set up on the earth, and its top reached to heaven; and there the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And behold, the Lord stood above it and said: “I am the Lord God of Abraham your father and the God of Isaac; the land on which you lie I will give to you and your descendants.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Also your descendants shall be as the dust of the earth; you shall spread abroad to the west and the east, to the north and the south; and in you and in your seed all the families of the earth shall be blessed.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Behold, I am with you and will keep you wherever you go, and will bring you back to this land; for I will not leave you until I have done what I have spoken to you.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Jacob awoke from his sleep and said, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I did not know it.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And he was afraid and said, “How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 43:27-44:4  (Vespers 4th  reading Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>‘When these days are over it shall be, on the eighth day and thereafter, that the priests shall offer your burnt offerings and your peace offerings on the altar; and I will accept you,’ says the Lord God.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then He brought me back to the outer gate of the sanctuary which faces toward the east, but it was shut.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the Lord said to me, “This gate shall be shut; it shall not be opened, and no man shall enter by it, because the Lord God of Israel has entered by it; therefore it shall be shut.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“As for the prince, because he is the prince, he may sit in it to eat bread before the Lord; he shall enter by way of the vestibule of the gateway, and go out the same way.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Also He brought me by way of the north gate to the front of the temple; so I looked, and behold, the glory of the Lord filled the house of the Lord; and I fell on my face.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 9:1-11  (Vespers 5th  reading Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Wisdom has built her house, she has hewn out her seven pillars;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>she has slaughtered her meat, she has mixed her wine, she has also furnished her table.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>She has sent out her maidens, she cries out from the highest places of the city,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!” as for him who lacks understanding, she says to him,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“Come, eat of my bread and drink of the wine I have mixed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Forsake foolishness and live, and go in the way of understanding.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>He who corrects a scoffer gets shame for himself, and he who rebukes a wicked man only harms himself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Do not correct a scoffer, lest he hate you; </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>give instruction to a wise man, and he will be still wiser; teach a just man, and he will increase in learning.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For by me your days will be multiplied, and years of life will be added to you.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 3:1-8  (Vespers 1st  reading Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now Moses was tending the flock of Jethro his father-in-law, the priest of Midian. And he led the flock to the back of the desert, and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the Angel of the Lord appeared to him in a flame of fire from the midst of a bush. So he looked, and behold, the bush was burning with fire, but the bush was not consumed.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Moses said, “I will now turn aside and see this great sight, why the bush does not burn.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So when the Lord saw that he turned aside to look, God called to him from the midst of the bush and said, “Moses, Moses!” And he said, “Here I am.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then He said, “Do not draw near this place. Take your sandals off your feet, for the place where you stand is holy ground.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Moreover He said, “I am the God of your father – the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” And Moses hid his face, for he was afraid to look upon God.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And the Lord said: “I have surely seen the oppression of My people who are in Egypt, and have heard their cry because of their taskmasters, for I know their sorrows.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“So I have come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians, and to bring them up from that land to a good and large land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanites and the Hittites and the Amorites and the Perizzites</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 8:22-30  (Vespers 2nd  reading Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>“The Lord possessed me at the beginning of His way, before His works of old.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>I have been established from everlasting, from the beginning, before there was ever an earth.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When there were no depths I was brought forth, when there were no fountains abounding with water.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Before the mountains were settled, before the hills, I was brought forth;</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>while as yet He had not made the earth or the fields, or the primal dust of the world.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>When He prepared the heavens, I was there, when He drew a circle on the face of the deep,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>when He established the clouds above, when He strengthened the fountains of the deep,</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>when He assigned to the sea its limit, so that the waters would not transgress His command, when He marked out the foundations of the earth,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>then I was beside Him as a master craftsman; and I was daily His delight, rejoicing always before Him,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 1:39-49 56  (Matins Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>39</dt><dd>Now Mary arose in those days and went into the hill country with haste, to a city of Judah,</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>and entered the house of Zacharias and greeted Elizabeth.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And it happened, when Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, that the babe leaped in her womb; and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Then she spoke out with a loud voice and said, “Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your womb!</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>But why is this granted to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>For indeed, as soon as the voice of your greeting sounded in my ears, the babe leaped in my womb for joy.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Blessed is she who believed, for there will be a fulfillment of those things which were told her from the Lord.”</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And Mary said: “My soul magnifies the Lord,</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>and my spirit has rejoiced in God my Savior.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>For He has regarded the lowly state of His maidservant; for behold, henceforth all generations will call me blessed.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>For He who is mighty has done great things for me, and holy is His name.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>And Mary remained with her about three months, and returned to her house.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 6:9-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>But, beloved, we are confident of better things concerning you, yes, things that accompany salvation, though we speak in this manner.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For God is not unjust to forget your work and labor of love which you have shown toward His name, in that you have ministered to the saints, and do minister.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And we desire that each one of you show the same diligence to the full assurance of hope until the end,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>that you do not become sluggish, but imitate those who through faith and patience inherit the promises.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 7:31-37  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>Again, departing from the region of Tyre and Sidon, He came through the midst of the region of Decapolis to the Sea of Galilee.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then they brought to Him one who was deaf and had an impediment in his speech, and they begged Him to put His hand on him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And He took him aside from the multitude, and put His fingers in his ears, and He spat and touched his tongue.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then, looking up to heaven, He sighed, and said to him, “Ephphatha,” that is, “Be opened.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Immediately his ears were opened, and the impediment of his tongue was loosed, and he spoke plainly.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then He commanded them that they should tell no one; but the more He commanded them, the more widely they proclaimed it.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And they were astonished beyond measure, saying, “He has done all things well. He makes both the deaf to hear and the mute to speak.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 2:11-18  (Epistle Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>For both He who sanctifies and those who are being sanctified are all of one, for which reason He is not ashamed to call them brethren,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>saying: “I will declare Your name to My brethren; in the midst of the assembly I will sing praise to You.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And again: “I will put My trust in Him.” And again: “Here am I and the children whom God has given Me.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Inasmuch then as the children have partaken of flesh and blood, He Himself likewise shared in the same, that through death He might destroy him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and release those who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For indeed He does not give aid to angels, but He does give aid to the seed of Abraham.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, in all things He had to be made like His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things pertaining to God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For in that He Himself has suffered, being tempted, He is able to aid those who are tempted.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 1:24-38  (Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Now after those days his wife Elizabeth conceived; and she hid herself five months, saying,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“Thus the Lord has dealt with me, in the days when He looked on me, to take away my reproach among people.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Now in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent by God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David. The virgin’s name was Mary.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And having come in, the angel said to her, “Rejoice, highly favored one, the Lord is with you; blessed are you among women!” </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But when she saw him, she was troubled at his saying, and considered what manner of greeting this was.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then the angel said to her, “Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And behold, you will conceive in your womb and bring forth a Son, and shall call His name JESUS.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>He will be great, and will be called the Son of the Highest; and the Lord God will give Him the throne of His father David.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And He will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of His kingdom there will be no end.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then Mary said to the angel, “How can this be, since I do not know a man?”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And the angel answered and said to her, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Highest will overshadow you; therefore, also, that Holy One who is to be born will be called the Son of God.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Now indeed, Elizabeth your relative has also conceived a son in her old age; and this is now the sixth month for her who was called barren.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>For with God nothing will be impossible.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then Mary said, “Behold the maidservant of the Lord! Let it be to me according to your word.” And the angel departed from her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:11-18  (8th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But Mary stood outside by the tomb weeping, and as she wept she stooped down and looked into the tomb.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And she saw two angels in white sitting, one at the head and the other at the feet, where the body of Jesus had lain.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then they said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping?” She said to them, “Because they have taken away my Lord, and I do not know where they have laid Him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing there, and did not know that it was Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?” She, supposing Him to be the gardener, said to Him, “Sir, if You have carried Him away, tell me where You have laid Him, and I will take Him away.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Mary!” She turned and said to Him, “Rabboni!” (which is to say, Teacher).</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Do not cling to Me, for I have not yet ascended to My Father; but go to My brethren and say to them, ‘I am ascending to My Father and your Father, and to My God and your God.’”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Mary Magdalene came and told the disciples that she had seen the Lord, and that He had spoken these things to her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 2:11-18  (Epistle Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>For both He who sanctifies and those who are being sanctified are all of one, for which reason He is not ashamed to call them brethren,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>saying: “I will declare Your name to My brethren; in the midst of the assembly I will sing praise to You.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And again: “I will put My trust in Him.” And again: “Here am I and the children whom God has given Me.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Inasmuch then as the children have partaken of flesh and blood, He Himself likewise shared in the same, that through death He might destroy him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and release those who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For indeed He does not give aid to angels, but He does give aid to the seed of Abraham.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, in all things He had to be made like His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things pertaining to God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For in that He Himself has suffered, being tempted, He is able to aid those who are tempted.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 1:24-38  (Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Now after those days his wife Elizabeth conceived; and she hid herself five months, saying,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“Thus the Lord has dealt with me, in the days when He looked on me, to take away my reproach among people.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Now in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent by God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David. The virgin’s name was Mary.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And having come in, the angel said to her, “Rejoice, highly favored one, the Lord is with you; blessed are you among women!” </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But when she saw him, she was troubled at his saying, and considered what manner of greeting this was.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then the angel said to her, “Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And behold, you will conceive in your womb and bring forth a Son, and shall call His name JESUS.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>He will be great, and will be called the Son of the Highest; and the Lord God will give Him the throne of His father David.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And He will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of His kingdom there will be no end.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then Mary said to the angel, “How can this be, since I do not know a man?”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And the angel answered and said to her, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Highest will overshadow you; therefore, also, that Holy One who is to be born will be called the Son of God.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Now indeed, Elizabeth your relative has also conceived a son in her old age; and this is now the sixth month for her who was called barren.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>For with God nothing will be impossible.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then Mary said, “Behold the maidservant of the Lord! Let it be to me according to your word.” And the angel departed from her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 5:9-19  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>(for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, righteousness, and truth),</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>finding out what is acceptable to the Lord.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather expose them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For it is shameful even to speak of those things which are done by them in secret.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But all things that are exposed are made manifest by the light, for whatever makes manifest is light.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore He says: “Awake, you who sleep, arise from the dead, and Christ will give you light.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>See then that you walk circumspectly, not as fools but as wise,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>redeeming the time, because the days are evil.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore do not be unwise, but understand what the will of the Lord is.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And do not be drunk with wine, in which is dissipation; but be filled with the Spirit,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>speaking to one another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 4:25-5:12  (Gospel Saint)
