readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>25</dt><dd>Great multitudes followed Him – from Galilee, and from Decapolis, Jerusalem, Judea, and beyond the Jordan.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And seeing the multitudes, He went up on a mountain, and when He was seated His disciples came to Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He opened His mouth and taught them, saying:</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be filled.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Blessed are the merciful, for they shall obtain mercy.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Blessed are you when they revile and persecute you, and say all kinds of evil against you falsely for My sake.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Rejoice and be exceedingly glad, for great is your reward in heaven, for so they persecuted the prophets who were before you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 6:13-20  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>For when God made a promise to Abraham, because He could swear by no one greater, He swore by Himself,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>saying, “Surely blessing I will bless you, and multiplying I will multiply you.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And so, after he had patiently endured, he obtained the promise.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For men indeed swear by the greater, and an oath for confirmation is for them an end of all dispute.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Thus God, determining to show more abundantly to the heirs of promise the immutability of His counsel, confirmed it by an oath,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>that by two immutable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we might have strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to lay hold of the hope set before us.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>This hope we have as an anchor of the soul, both sure and steadfast, and which enters the Presence behind the veil,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>where the forerunner has entered for us, even Jesus, having become High Priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 9:17-31  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Then one of the crowd answered and said, “Teacher, I brought You my son, who has a mute spirit.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And wherever it seizes him, it throws him down; he foams at the mouth, gnashes his teeth, and becomes rigid. So I spoke to Your disciples, that they should cast it out, but they could not.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>He answered him and said, “O faithless generation, how long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you? Bring him to Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then they brought him to Him. And when he saw Him, immediately the spirit convulsed him, and he fell on the ground and wallowed, foaming at the mouth.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So He asked his father, “How long has this been happening to him?” And he said, “From childhood.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And often he has thrown him both into the fire and into the water to destroy him. But if You can do anything, have compassion on us and help us.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If you can believe, all things are possible to him who believes.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Immediately the father of the child cried out and said with tears, “Lord, I believe; help my unbelief!”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>When Jesus saw that the people came running together, He rebuked the unclean spirit, saying to it: “Deaf and dumb spirit, I command you, come out of him and enter him no more!”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then the spirit cried out, convulsed him greatly, and came out of him. And he became as one dead, so that many said, “He is dead.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But Jesus took him by the hand and lifted him up, and he arose.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And when He had come into the house, His disciples asked Him privately, “Why could we not cast it out?”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>So He said to them, “This kind can come out by nothing but prayer and fasting.” </dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then they departed from there and passed through Galilee, and He did not want anyone to know it.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>For He taught His disciples and said to them, “The Son of Man is being betrayed into the hands of men, and they will kill Him. And after He is killed, He will rise the third day.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 37:33-38:6  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>“Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: ‘He shall not come into this city, nor shoot an arrow there, nor come before it with shield, nor build a siege mound against it. </dd><dt>34</dt><dd>By the way that he came, by the same shall he return; and he shall not come into this city,’ says the Lord.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>‘For I will defend this city, to save it for My own sake and for My servant David’s sake.’” </dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then the angel of the Lord went out, and killed in the camp of the Assyrians one hundred and eighty-five thousand; and when people arose early in the morning, there were the corpses – all dead.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>So Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and went away, returned home, and remained at Nineveh.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, as he was worshiping in the house of Nisroch his god, that his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with the sword; and they escaped into the land of Ararat. Then Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>In those days Hezekiah was sick and near death. And Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, went to him and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: ‘Set your house in order, for you shall die and not live.’”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall, and prayed to the Lord,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said, “Remember now, O Lord, I pray, how I have walked before You in truth and with a loyal heart, and have done what is good in Your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And the word of the Lord came to Isaiah, saying,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“Go and tell Hezekiah, ‘Thus says the Lord, the God of David your father: “I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears; surely I will add to your days fifteen years.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria, and I will defend this city.”’</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 13:12-18  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Abram dwelt in the land of Canaan, and Lot dwelt in the cities of the plain and pitched his tent even as far as Sodom.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But the men of Sodom were exceedingly wicked and sinful against the Lord.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Abram, after Lot had separated from him: “Lift your eyes now and look from the place where you are northward, southward, eastward, and westward;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“for all the land which you see I give to you and your descendants forever.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“And I will make your descendants as the dust of the earth; so that if a man could number the dust of the earth, then your descendants also could be numbered.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“Arise, walk in the land through its length and its width, for I give it to you.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then Abram moved his tent, and went and dwelt by the terebinth trees of Mamre, which are in Hebron, and built an altar there to the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 14:27-15:4  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life, to turn one away from the snares of death.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>In a multitude of people is a king’s honor, but in the lack of people is the downfall of a prince.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>He who is slow to wrath has great understanding, but he who is impulsive exalts folly.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>A sound heart is life to the body, but envy is rottenness to the bones.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>He who oppresses the poor reproaches his Maker, but he who honors Him has mercy on the needy.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>The wicked is banished in his wickedness, but the righteous has a refuge in his death.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Wisdom rests in the heart of him who has understanding, but what is in the heart of fools is made known.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a reproach to any people.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>The king’s favor is toward a wise servant, but his wrath is against him who causes shame.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>A soft answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The tongue of the wise uses knowledge rightly, but the mouth of fools pours forth foolishness.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The eyes of the Lord are in every place, keeping watch on the evil and the good.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>A wholesome tongue is a tree of life, but perverseness in it breaks the spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 40:18-31  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>To whom then will you liken God? Or what likeness will you compare to Him?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The workman molds an image, the goldsmith overspreads it with gold, and the silversmith casts silver chains.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Whoever is too impoverished for such a contribution chooses a tree that will not rot; he seeks for himself a skillful workman to prepare a carved image that will not totter.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Have you not known? Have you not heard? Has it not been told you from the beginning? Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth? </dd><dt>22</dt><dd>It is He who sits above the circle of the earth, and its inhabitants are like grasshoppers, Who stretches out the heavens like a curtain, and spreads them out like a tent to dwell in.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>He brings the princes to nothing; He makes the judges of the earth useless.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Scarcely shall they be planted, scarcely shall they be sown, scarcely shall their stock take root in the earth, when He will also blow on them, and they will wither, and the whirlwind will take them away like stubble. </dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“To whom then will you liken Me, or to whom shall I be equal?” says the Holy One. </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Lift up your eyes on high, and see Who has created these things, Who brings out their host by number; He calls them all by name, by the greatness of His might and the strength of His power; not one is missing.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Why do you say, O Jacob, and speak, O Israel: “My way is hidden from the Lord, and my just claim is passed over by my God”? </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Have you not known? Have you not heard? The everlasting God, the Lord, the Creator of the ends of the earth, neither faints nor is weary. His understanding is unsearchable.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>He gives power to the weak, and to those who have no might He increases strength. </dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Even the youths shall faint and be weary, and the young men shall utterly fall, </dd><dt>31</dt><dd>but those who wait on the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings like eagles, they shall run and not be weary, they shall walk and not faint.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 15:1-15  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>After these things the word of the Lord came to Abram in a vision, saying, “Do not be afraid, Abram. I am your shield, your exceedingly great reward.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But Abram said, “Lord God, what will You give me, seeing I go childless, and the heir of my house is Eliezer of Damascus?”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Abram said, “Look, You have given me no offspring; indeed one born in my house is my heir!”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And behold, the word of the Lord came to him, saying, “This one shall not be your heir, but one who will come from your own body shall be your heir.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then He brought him outside and said, “Look now toward heaven, and count the stars if you are able to number them.” And He said to him, “So shall your descendants be.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And he believed in the Lord, and He accounted it to him for righteousness.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then He said to him, “I am the Lord, who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you this land to inherit it.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And he said, “Lord God, how shall I know that I will inherit it?”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So He said to him, “Bring Me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then he brought all these to Him and cut them in two, down the middle, and placed each piece opposite the other; but he did not cut the birds in two.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when the vultures came down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Now when the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell upon Abram; and behold, horror and great darkness fell upon him.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then He said to Abram: “Know certainly that your descendants will be strangers in a land that is not theirs, and will serve them, and they will afflict them four hundred years.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“And also the nation whom they serve I will judge; afterward they shall come out with great possessions.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Now as for you, you shall go to your fathers in peace; you shall be buried at a good old age.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 15:7-19  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>The lips of the wise disperse knowledge, but the heart of the fool does not do so.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord, but the prayer of the upright is His delight.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The way of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord, but He loves him who follows righteousness.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Harsh discipline is for him who forsakes the way, and he who hates correction will die.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Hell and Destruction are before the Lord; so how much more the hearts of the sons of men.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>A scoffer does not love one who corrects him, nor will he go to the wise.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>A merry heart makes a cheerful countenance, but by sorrow of the heart the spirit is broken.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>The heart of him who has understanding seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on foolishness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>All the days of the afflicted are evil, but he who is of a merry heart has a continual feast.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Better is a little with the fear of the Lord, than great treasure with trouble.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a fatted calf with hatred.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>A wrathful man stirs up strife, but he who is slow to anger allays contention.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The way of the lazy man is like a hedge of thorns, but the way of the upright is a highway.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 41:4-14  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>Who has performed and done it, calling the generations from the beginning? ‘I, the Lord, am the first; and with the last I am He.’”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The coastlands saw it and feared, the ends of the earth were afraid; they drew near and came.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Everyone helped his neighbor, and said to his brother, “Be of good courage!”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So the craftsman encouraged the goldsmith; he who smooths with the hammer inspired him who strikes the anvil, Saying, “It is ready for the soldering”; then he fastened it with pegs, that it might not totter.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“But you, Israel, are My servant, Jacob whom I have chosen, the descendants of Abraham My friend.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>You whom I have taken from the ends of the earth, and called from its farthest regions, and said to you, ‘You are My servant, I have chosen you and have not cast you away:</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>fear not, for I am with you; be not dismayed, for I am your God. I will strengthen you, yes, I will help you, I will uphold you with My righteous right hand.’</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Behold, all those who were incensed against you shall be ashamed and disgraced; they shall be as nothing, and those who strive with you shall perish.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>You shall seek them and not find them – those who contended with you. Those who war against you shall be as nothing, as a nonexistent thing.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’ </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Fear not, you worm Jacob, you men of Israel! I will help you, says the Lord and your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 17:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the Lord appeared to Abram and said to him, “I am Almighty God; walk before Me and be blameless.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“And I will make My covenant between Me and you, and will multiply you exceedingly.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Abram fell on his face, and God talked with him, saying:</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“As for Me, behold, My covenant is with you, and you shall be a father of many nations.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“No longer shall your name be called Abram, but your name shall be Abraham; for I have made you a father of many nations.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“I will make you exceedingly fruitful; and I will make nations of you, and kings shall come from you.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“And I will establish My covenant between Me and you and your descendants after you in their generations, for an everlasting covenant, to be God to you and your descendants after you.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“Also I give to you and your descendants after you the land in which you are a stranger, all the land of Canaan, as an everlasting possession; and I will be their God.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And God said to Abraham: “As for you, you shall keep My covenant, you and your descendants after you throughout their generations.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 15:20-16:9  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>A wise son makes a father glad, but a foolish man despises his mother.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Folly is joy to him who is destitute of discernment, but a man of understanding walks uprightly.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Without counsel, plans go awry, but in the multitude of counselors they are established.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>A man has joy by the answer of his mouth, and a word spoken in due season, how good it is!</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>The way of life winds upward for the wise, that he may turn away from hell below.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The Lord will destroy the house of the proud, but He will establish the boundary of the widow.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>The thoughts of the wicked are an abomination to the Lord, but the words of the pure are pleasant.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>He who is greedy for gain troubles his own house, but he who hates bribes will live.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>The heart of the righteous studies how to answer, but the mouth of the wicked pours forth evil.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>The Lord is far from the wicked, but He hears the prayer of the righteous.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>The light of the eyes rejoices the heart, and a good report makes the bones healthy.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>The ear that hears the rebukes of life will abide among the wise.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>He who disdains instruction despises his own soul, but he who heeds rebuke gets understanding.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is the instruction of wisdom, and before honor is humility.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>The preparations of the heart belong to man, but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>All the ways of a man are pure in his own eyes, but the Lord weighs the spirits.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Commit your works to the Lord, and your thoughts will be established.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>The Lord has made all for Himself, yes, even the wicked for the day of doom.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Everyone proud in heart is an abomination to the Lord; though they join forces, none will go unpunished.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>In mercy and truth Atonement is provided for iniquity; and by the fear of the Lord one departs from evil.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When a man’s ways please the Lord, he makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Better is a little with righteousness, than vast revenues without justice.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>A man’s heart plans his way, but the Lord directs his steps.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 42:5-16  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Thus says God the Lord, Who created the heavens and stretched them out, Who spread forth the earth and that which comes from it, Who gives breath to the people on it, and spirit to those who walk on it:</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“I, the Lord, have called You in righteousness, and will hold Your hand; I will keep You and give You as a covenant to the people, as a light to the Gentiles,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>to open blind eyes, to bring out prisoners from the prison, those who sit in darkness from the prison house.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>I am the Lord, that is My name; and My glory I will not give to another, nor My praise to carved images.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Behold, the former things have come to pass, and new things I declare; before they spring forth I tell you of them.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Sing to the Lord a new song, and His praise from the ends of the earth, you who go down to the sea, and all that is in it, you coastlands and you inhabitants of them!</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Let the wilderness and its cities lift up their voice, the villages that Kedar inhabits. Let the inhabitants of Sela sing, let them shout from the top of the mountains.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Let them give glory to the Lord, and declare His praise in the coastlands.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The Lord shall go forth like a mighty man; He shall stir up His zeal like a man of war. He shall cry out, yes, shout aloud; He shall prevail against His enemies.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“I have held My peace a long time, I have been still and restrained Myself. Now I will cry like a woman in labor, I will pant and gasp at once.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>I will lay waste the mountains and hills, and dry up all their vegetation; I will make the rivers coastlands, and I will dry up the pools.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>I will bring the blind by a way they did not know; I will lead them in paths they have not known. I will make darkness light before them, and crooked places straight. These things I will do for them, and not forsake them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 18:20-33  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “Because the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and because their sin is very grave,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>“I will go down now and see whether they have done altogether according to the outcry against it that has come to Me; and if not, I will know.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then the men turned away from there and went toward Sodom, but Abraham still stood before the Lord.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And Abraham came near and said, “Would You also destroy the righteous with the wicked?</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>“Suppose there were fifty righteous within the city; would You also destroy the place and not spare it for the fifty righteous that were in it?</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“Far be it from You to do such a thing as this, to slay the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous should be as the wicked; far be it from You! Shall not the Judge of all the earth do right?”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>So the Lord said, “If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I will spare all the place for their sakes.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then Abraham answered and said, “Indeed now, I who am but dust and ashes have taken it upon myself to speak to the Lord:</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>“Suppose there were five less than the fifty righteous; would You destroy all of the city for lack of five?” So He said, “If I find there forty-five, I will not destroy it.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And he spoke to Him yet again and said, “Suppose there should be forty found there?” So He said, “I will not do it for the sake of forty.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then he said, “Let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak: Suppose thirty should be found there?” So He said, “I will not do it if I find thirty there.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And he said, “Indeed now, I have taken it upon myself to speak to the Lord: Suppose twenty should be found there?” So He said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of twenty.”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then he said, “Let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak but once more: Suppose ten should be found there?” And He said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of ten.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>So the Lord went His way as soon as He had finished speaking with Abraham; and Abraham returned to his place.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 16:17-17:17  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>The highway of the upright is to depart from evil; he who keeps his way preserves his soul.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Better to be of a humble spirit with the lowly, than to divide the spoil with the proud.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>He who heeds the word wisely will find good, and whoever trusts in the Lord, happy is he.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>The wise in heart will be called prudent, and sweetness of the lips increases learning.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Understanding is a wellspring of life to him who has it. But the correction of fools is folly.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>The heart of the wise teaches his mouth, and adds learning to his lips.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Pleasant words are like a honeycomb, sweetness to the soul and health to the bones.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way of death.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>The person who labors, labors for himself, for his hungry mouth drives him on.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>An ungodly man digs up evil, and it is on his lips like a burning fire.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>A perverse man sows strife, and a whisperer separates the best of friends.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>A violent man entices his neighbor, and leads him in a way that is not good.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>He winks his eye to devise perverse things; he purses his lips and brings about evil.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>The silver-haired head is a crown of glory, if it is found in the way of righteousness.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>He who is slow to anger is better than the mighty, and he who rules his spirit than he who takes a city.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>The lot is cast into the lap, but its every decision is from the Lord.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Better is a dry morsel with quietness, than a house full of feasting with strife.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>A wise servant will rule over a son who causes shame, and will share an inheritance among the brothers.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The refining pot is for silver and the furnace for gold, but the Lord tests the hearts.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>An evildoer gives heed to false lips; a liar listens eagerly to a spiteful tongue.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>He who mocks the poor reproaches his Maker; he who is glad at calamity will not go unpunished.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Children’s children are the crown of old men, and the glory of children is their father.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Excellent speech is not becoming to a fool, much less lying lips to a prince.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>A present is a precious stone in the eyes of its possessor; wherever he turns, he prospers.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>He who covers a transgression seeks love, but he who repeats a matter separates friends.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Rebuke is more effective for a wise man than a hundred blows on a fool.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>An evil man seeks only rebellion; Therefore a cruel messenger will be sent against him.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Let a man meet a bear robbed of her cubs, rather than a fool in his folly.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Whoever rewards evil for good, evil will not depart from his house.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>The beginning of strife is like releasing water; therefore stop contention before a quarrel starts.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He who justifies the wicked, and he who condemns the just, both of them alike are an abomination to the Lord.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Why is there in the hand of a fool the purchase price of wisdom, since he has no heart for it?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 45:11-17  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord, The Holy One of Israel, and his Maker: “Ask Me of things to come concerning My sons; and concerning the work of My hands, you command Me.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I have made the earth, and created man on it. I – My hands – stretched out the heavens, and all their host I have commanded.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I have raised him up in righteousness, and I will direct all his ways; He shall build My city and let My exiles go free, not for price nor reward,” says the Lord of hosts.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord: “The labor of Egypt and merchandise of Cush and of the Sabeans, men of stature, shall come over to you, and they shall be yours; they shall walk behind you, they shall come over in chains; and they shall bow down to you. They will make supplication to you, saying, ‘God is with you only, and there is no other; no god besides Him.’</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Truly You are God, who hide Yourself, O God of Israel, the Savior! </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>They shall be ashamed and also disgraced, all of them; they shall go in confusion together, who are makers of idols.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But Israel shall be saved by the Lord with an everlasting salvation; you shall not be ashamed or disgraced forever and ever.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 22:1-18  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass after these things that God tested Abraham, and said to him, “Abraham!” And he said, “Here I am.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He said, “Take now your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah, and offer him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains of which I shall tell you.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So Abraham rose early in the morning and saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him, and Isaac his son; and he split the wood for the burnt offering, and arose and went to the place of which God had told him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then on the third day Abraham lifted his eyes and saw the place afar off.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And Abraham said to his young men, “Stay here with the donkey; the lad and I will go yonder and worship, and we will come back to you.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So Abraham took the wood of the burnt offering and laid it on Isaac his son; and he took the fire in his hand, and a knife, and the two of them went together.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But Isaac spoke to Abraham his father and said, “My father!” And he said, “Here I am, my son.” Then he said, “Look, the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for a burnt offering?”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And Abraham said, “My son, God will provide for Himself the lamb for a burnt offering.” So the two of them went together.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then they came to the place of which God had told him. And Abraham built an altar there and placed the wood in order; and he bound Isaac his son and laid him on the altar, upon the wood.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And Abraham stretched out his hand and took the knife to slay his son.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But the Angel of the Lord called to him from heaven and said, “Abraham, Abraham!” So he said, “Here I am.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And He said, “Do not lay your hand on the lad, or do anything to him; for now I know that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only son, from Me.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Abraham lifted his eyes and looked, and there behind him was a ram caught in a thicket by its horns. So Abraham went and took the ram, and offered it up for a burnt offering instead of his son.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And Abraham called the name of the place, The-Lord-Will-Provide; as it is said to this day, “In the Mount of the Lord it shall be provided.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the Angel of the Lord called to Abraham a second time out of heaven,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>and said: “By Myself I have sworn, says the Lord, because you have done this thing, and have not withheld your son, your only son – </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“blessing I will bless you, and multiplying I will multiply your descendants as the stars of the heaven and as the sand which is on the seashore; and your descendants shall possess the gate of their enemies.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“In your seed all the nations of the earth shall be blessed, because you have obeyed My voice.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 17:17-18:5  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>A man devoid of understanding shakes hands in a pledge, and becomes surety for his friend.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>He who loves transgression loves strife, and he who exalts his gate seeks destruction.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>He who has a deceitful heart finds no good, and he who has a perverse tongue falls into evil.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He who begets a scoffer does so to his sorrow, and the father of a fool has no joy.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>A merry heart does good, like medicine, but a broken spirit dries the bones.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>A wicked man accepts a bribe behind the back to pervert the ways of justice.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Wisdom is in the sight of him who has understanding, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>A foolish son is a grief to his father, and bitterness to her who bore him.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Also, to punish the righteous is not good, nor to strike princes for their uprightness.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>He who has knowledge spares his words, and a man of understanding is of a calm spirit.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Even a fool is counted wise when he holds his peace; when he shuts his lips, he is considered perceptive.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>A man who isolates himself seeks his own desire; he rages against all wise judgment.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>A fool has no delight in understanding, but in expressing his own heart.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>When the wicked comes, contempt comes also; and with dishonor comes reproach.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters; the wellspring of wisdom is a flowing brook.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>It is not good to show partiality to the wicked, or to overthrow the righteous in judgment.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 2  (Vespers 3rd  reading Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The memory of the righteous is with praise and the blessing of the Lord is upon his head. Blessed is the man who has found wisdom and the mortal who has understanding. For it is better to purchase her than treasuries of gold and silver. She is more precious than precious stones and all that is precious is unworthy of her. For length of days and years of life are in her right hand; and in her left hand are riches and glory. Out of her mouth proceeds righteousness and she bears law and mercy upon her tongue.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Hear me, O child, for I will speak noble things. Blessed is the man who keeps my ways, for my ways are the ways of life, and in them is prepared favor from the Lord. Therefore, I pray thee, and utter my voice to the sons of men: For I, wisdom, have dwelt with counsel and knowledge and I have called upon understanding. Counsel and safety are mine, understanding and strength are mine. I love those who love me and those seeking me shall find grace.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Understand craftiness, O you who are simple, and imbibe knowledge, you who are untaught. Hear me again, for I will speak noble things: I will open my mouth and from my lips shall come what is right. For my throat shall meditate truth; false lips are an abomination before me. All the words of my mouth are righteous; there is nothing in them that is twisted or perverse. They are all straight to him who understands and right to those who find knowledge.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I shall instruct you in truth, so that your hope will be in the Lord and you shall be filled with the Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 3  (Vespers 4th  reading Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest. The righteous man who has died will judge the ungodly who are living. For they will see the end of the righteous, and will not understand what was said about him; for the Lord will cast down the ungodly speechless to the ground and shake them from the foundations; they shall become desolate to the end; they will be in sorrows, and their memory will perish. For they will come with fear at the thought of their sins, and their iniquities shall stand against them to convict them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then the righteous man will stand with great boldness before those who have afflicted him, and those who have made of no account his labors. Having seen it, they shall be troubled with much fear and they will be amazed at his most-glorious salvation. They will say within themselves in repentance, in anguish of spirit they will groan and say: “This was he whom we had sometimes in derision and a proverb of reproach – we fools! We accounted his life as madness, and his end to be without honor. How is he numbered among the sons of God? And why is his lot among the Saints?</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Therefore, we have erred from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness did not illumine us, nor did the sun shine on us. We took our fill of the paths of lawlessness and destruction, and we walked impassable pathways, but the way of the Lord we have not known.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 4  (Vespers 5th  reading Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous bringeth forth wisdom; the lips of the wise man know grace. The mouth of the wise speaketh wisdom, and the truth delivereth them from death. If a righteous man dies, hope doth not, for the son of the righteous is born to life, and in his own good things he acquireth the fruit of righteousness. There is always light for the righteous and they obtain grace and glory from the Lord. The tongue of the wise is a good sister-in-law, and in their hearts resteth wisdom. The Lord loveth the hearts of the holy, and acceptable to Him are all the undefiled in the way.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The wisdom of the Lord illumineth the faces of the wise. For she takes hold of those desiring her by making herself first known to them. She is easily seen by those who love her. He who rises early to seek her shall have no difficulty, and those keeping vigil for the sake of her shall quickly be without sorrows. For she goeth about seeking those worthy of her, and graciously revealeth herself in the pathways. Against wisdom evil doth not prevail.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore I was a lover of her beauty; I loved her and sought her out from my youth. I desired to make her my bride, and even the Master of All loved her. For she is an initiate in the knowledge of God, and a discoverer of His works. Her labors are virtues, for she teaches temperance and prudence, justice and courage; nothing in life is more necessary for men than these. And if anyone desireth much knowledge, she knoweth the things of old, and beholdeth things to come; she understandeth turns of speech and the solution of riddles; she has foreknowledge of signs and wonders and the outcome of times and seasons. She is a mediator of good things for all, for immortality is in her, and glory in the company of her words.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Therefore I appealed to the Lord and prayed to Him, and said to Him with all my heart: “O God of my fathers and Lord of mercy, Who hast made all things by Thy word, and by Thy wisdom hast fashioned man that he should have dominion over the creatures made by Thee, that he should rule the world in holiness and righteousness: Give me wisdom that sits by Thy throne, and cast me not away from among Thy children, for I am Thy servant and the son of Thy handmaid. Send her forth from the heavens, from Thy holy abode, and from the throne of Thy glory, that she may be with me, and instruct me in what is pleasing to Thee. And she shall guide me in understanding, and preserve me in her glory. For the thoughts of mortals are miserable, and their intentions likely to fail.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:1-9  (Matins Gospel St Innocent)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:26-8:2  (Epistle St Innocent)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For such a High Priest was fitting for us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and has become higher than the heavens;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>who does not need daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for his own sins and then for the people’s, for this He did once for all when He offered up Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the law appoints as high priests men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints the Son who has been perfected forever.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the main point of the things we are saying: We have such a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>a Minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord erected, and not man.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Gospel St Innocent)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 9:1-7  (Epistle Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then indeed, even the first covenant had ordinances of divine service and the earthly sanctuary.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For a tabernacle was prepared: the first part, in which was the lampstand, the table, and the showbread, which is called the sanctuary;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and behind the second veil, the part of the tabernacle which is called the Holiest of All,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>which had the golden censer and the ark of the covenant overlaid on all sides with gold, in which were the golden pot that had the manna, Aaron’s rod that budded, and the tablets of the covenant;</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>and above it were the cherubim of glory overshadowing the mercy seat. Of these things we cannot now speak in detail.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Now when these things had been thus prepared, the priests always went into the first part of the tabernacle, performing the services.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But into the second part the high priest went alone once a year, not without blood, which he offered for himself and for the people’s sins committed in ignorance;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:38-42 11:27-28  (Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>38</dt><dd>Now it happened as they went that He entered a certain village; and a certain woman named Martha welcomed Him into her house.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And she had a sister called Mary, who also sat at Jesus’ feet and heard His word.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But Martha was distracted with much serving, and she approached Him and said, “Lord, do You not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Therefore tell her to help me.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to her, “Martha, Martha, you are worried and troubled about many things.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>But one thing is needed, and Mary has chosen that good part, which will not be taken away from her.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And it happened, as He spoke these things, that a certain woman from the crowd raised her voice and said to Him, “Blessed is the womb that bore You, and the breasts which nursed You!”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But He said, “More than that, blessed are those who hear the word of God and keep it!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 9:24-28  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>For Christ has not entered the holy places made with hands, which are copies of the true, but into heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God for us;</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>not that He should offer Himself often, as the high priest enters the Most Holy Place every year with blood of another – </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>He then would have had to suffer often since the foundation of the world; but now, once at the end of the ages, He has appeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of Himself.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And as it is appointed for men to die once, but after this the judgment,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>so Christ was offered once to bear the sins of many. To those who eagerly wait for Him He will appear a second time, apart from sin, for salvation.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 8:27-31  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>Now Jesus and His disciples went out to the towns of Caesarea Philippi; and on the road He asked His disciples, saying to them, “Who do men say that I am?”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So they answered, “John the Baptist; but some say, Elijah; and others, one of the prophets.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>He said to them, “But who do you say that I am?” Peter answered and said to Him, “You are the Christ.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then He strictly warned them that they should tell no one about Him.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And He began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and after three days rise again.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:19-31  (9th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Then, the same day at evening, being the first day of the week, when the doors were shut where the disciples were assembled, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood in the midst, and said to them, “Peace be with you.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His side. Then the disciples were glad when they saw the Lord.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So Jesus said to them again, “Peace to you! As the Father has sent Me, I also send you.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And when He had said this, He breathed on them, and said to them, “Receive the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven them; if you retain the sins of any, they are retained.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now Thomas, called the Twin, one of the twelve, was not with them when Jesus came.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The other disciples therefore said to him, “We have seen the Lord.” So he said to them, “Unless I see in His hands the print of the nails, and put my finger into the print of the nails, and put my hand into His side, I will not believe.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And after eight days His disciples were again inside, and Thomas with them. Jesus came, the doors being shut, and stood in the midst, and said, “Peace to you!”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then He said to Thomas, “Reach your finger here, and look at My hands; and reach your hand here, and put it into My side. Do not be unbelieving, but believing.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And Thomas answered and said to Him, “My Lord and my God!”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “Thomas, because you have seen Me, you have believed. Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And truly Jesus did many other signs in the presence of His disciples, which are not written in this book;</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>but these are written that you may believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and that believing you may have life in His name.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 3:23-29  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>But before faith came, we were kept under guard by the law, kept for the faith which would afterward be revealed.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore the law was our tutor to bring us to Christ, that we might be justified by faith.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But after faith has come, we are no longer under a tutor.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For as many of you as were baptized into Christ have put on Christ.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is neither male nor female; for you are all one in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And if you are Christ’s, then you are Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:36-50  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>Then one of the Pharisees asked Him to eat with him. And He went to the Pharisee’s house, and sat down to eat.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And behold, a woman in the city who was a sinner, when she knew that Jesus sat at the table in the Pharisee’s house, brought an alabaster flask of fragrant oil,</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>and stood at His feet behind Him weeping; and she began to wash His feet with her tears, and wiped them with the hair of her head; and she kissed His feet and anointed them with the fragrant oil.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Now when the Pharisee who had invited Him saw this, he spoke to himself, saying, “This Man, if He were a prophet, would know who and what manner of woman this is who is touching Him, for she is a sinner.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to him, “Simon, I have something to say to you.” So he said, “Teacher, say it.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>“There was a certain creditor who had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And when they had nothing with which to repay, he freely forgave them both. Tell Me, therefore, which of them will love him more?”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>Simon answered and said, “I suppose the one whom he forgave more.” And He said to him, “You have rightly judged.”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then He turned to the woman and said to Simon, “Do you see this woman? I entered your house; you gave Me no water for My feet, but she has washed My feet with her tears and wiped them with the hair of her head.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>You gave Me no kiss, but this woman has not ceased to kiss My feet since the time I came in.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>You did not anoint My head with oil, but this woman has anointed My feet with fragrant oil.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Therefore I say to you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven, for she loved much. But to whom little is forgiven, the same loves little.”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Then He said to her, “Your sins are forgiven.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>And those who sat at the table with Him began to say to themselves, “Who is this who even forgives sins?”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Then He said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you. Go in peace.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 9:11-14  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But Christ came as High Priest of the good things to come, with the greater and more perfect tabernacle not made with hands, that is, not of this creation.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Not with the blood of goats and calves, but with His own blood He entered the Most Holy Place once for all, having obtained eternal redemption.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For if the blood of bulls and goats and the ashes of a heifer, sprinkling the unclean, sanctifies for the purifying of the flesh,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>how much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered Himself without spot to God, cleanse your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 10:32-45  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Now they were on the road, going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was going before them; and they were amazed. And as they followed they were afraid. Then He took the twelve aside again and began to tell them the things that would happen to Him:</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>“Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be betrayed to the chief priests and to the scribes; and they will condemn Him to death and deliver Him to the Gentiles;</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>and they will mock Him, and scourge Him, and spit on Him, and kill Him. And the third day He will rise again.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came to Him, saying, “Teacher, we want You to do for us whatever we ask.”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And He said to them, “What do you want Me to do for you?”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>They said to Him, “Grant us that we may sit, one on Your right hand and the other on Your left, in Your glory.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But Jesus said to them, “You do not know what you ask. Are you able to drink the cup that I drink, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>They said to Him, “We are able.” So Jesus said to them, “You will indeed drink the cup that I drink, and with the baptism I am baptized with you will be baptized;</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>but to sit on My right hand and on My left is not Mine to give, but it is for those for whom it is prepared.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And when the ten heard it, they began to be greatly displeased with James and John.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>But Jesus called them to Himself and said to them, “You know that those who are considered rulers over the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>Yet it shall not be so among you; but whoever desires to become great among you shall be your servant.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>And whoever of you desires to be first shall be slave of all.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give His life a ransom for many.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 48:17-49:4  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: “I am the Lord your God, Who teaches you to profit, Who leads you by the way you should go.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Oh, that you had heeded My commandments! Then your peace would have been like a river, and your righteousness like the waves of the sea.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Your descendants also would have been like the sand, and the offspring of your body like the grains of sand; his name would not have been cut off nor destroyed from before Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Go forth from Babylon! Flee from the Chaldeans! With a voice of singing, declare, proclaim this, utter it to the end of the earth; say, “The Lord has redeemed His servant, Jacob!”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And they did not thirst when He led them through the deserts; He caused the waters to flow from the rock for them; He also split the rock, and the waters gushed out.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>“There is no peace,” says the Lord, “for the wicked.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>“Listen, O coastlands, to me, and take heed, you peoples from afar! The Lord has called me from the womb; from the matrix of my mother he has made mention of my name.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And He has made my mouth like a sharp sword; in the shadow of His hand He has hidden me, and made me a polished shaft; in His quiver He has hidden me.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“And He said to me, ‘You are My servant, O Israel, in whom I will be glorified.’ </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then I said, ‘I have labored in vain, I have spent my strength for nothing and in vain; yet surely my just reward is with the Lord, and my work with my God.’”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 27:1-41  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, when Isaac was old and his eyes were so dim that he could not see, that he called Esau his older son and said to him, “My son.” And he answered him, “Here I am.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then he said, “Behold now, I am old. I do not know the day of my death.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Now therefore, please take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field and hunt game for me.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“And make me savory food, such as I love, and bring it to me that I may eat, that my soul may bless you before I die.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now Rebekah was listening when Isaac spoke to Esau his son. And Esau went to the field to hunt game and to bring it.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So Rebekah spoke to Jacob her son, saying, “Indeed I heard your father speak to Esau your brother, saying,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>‘Bring me game and make savory food for me, that I may eat it and bless you in the presence of the Lord before my death.’</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“Now therefore, my son, obey my voice according to what I command you.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“Go now to the flock and bring me from there two choice kids of the goats, and I will make savory food from them for your father, such as he loves.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“Then you shall take it to your father, that he may eat it, and that he may bless you before his death.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, “Look, Esau my brother is a hairy man, and I am a smooth-skinned man.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>“Perhaps my father will feel me, and I shall seem to be a deceiver to him; and I shall bring a curse on myself and not a blessing.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But his mother said to him, “Let your curse be on me, my son; only obey my voice, and go, get them for me.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and his mother made savory food, such as his father loved.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then Rebekah took the choice clothes of her elder son Esau, which were with her in the house, and put them on Jacob her younger son.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And she put the skins of the kids of the goats on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then she gave the savory food and the bread, which she had prepared, into the hand of her son Jacob.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>So he went to his father and said, “My father.” And he said, “Here I am. Who are you, my son?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn; I have done just as you told me; please arise, sit and eat of my game, that your soul may bless me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But Isaac said to his son, “How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?” And he said, “Because the Lord your God brought it to me.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Please come near, that I may feel you, my son, whether you are really my son Esau or not.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So Jacob went near to Isaac his father, and he felt him and said, “The voice is Jacob’s voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And he did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy like his brother Esau’s hands; so he blessed him.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then he said, “Are you really my son Esau?” He said, “I am.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>He said, “Bring it near to me, and I will eat of my son’s game, so that my soul may bless you.” So he brought it near to him, and he ate; and he brought him wine, and he drank.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come near now and kiss me, my son.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And he came near and kissed him; and he smelled the smell of his clothing, and blessed him and said: “Surely, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field which the Lord has blessed.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore may God give you of the dew of heaven, of the fatness of the earth, and plenty of grain and wine.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Let peoples serve you, and nations bow down to you. Be master over your brethren, and let your mother’s sons bow down to you. Cursed be everyone who curses you, and blessed be those who bless you!” </dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now it happened, as soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had scarcely gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, that Esau his brother came in from his hunting.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>He also had made savory food, and brought it to his father, and said to his father, “Let my father arise and eat of his son’s game, that your soul may bless me.”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And his father Isaac said to him, “Who are you?” So he said, “I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Then Isaac trembled exceedingly, and said, “Who? Where is the one who hunted game and brought it to me? I ate all of it before you came, and I have blessed him – and indeed he shall be blessed.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried with an exceedingly great and bitter cry, and said to his father, “Bless me – me also, O my father!”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>But he said, “Your brother came with deceit and has taken away your blessing.”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And Esau said, “Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has supplanted me these two times. He took away my birthright, and now look, he has taken away my blessing!” And he said, “Have you not reserved a blessing for me?”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then Isaac answered and said to Esau, “Indeed I have made him your master, and all his brethren I have given to him as servants; with grain and wine I have sustained him. What shall I do now for you, my son?”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And Esau said to his father, “Have you only one blessing, my father? Bless me – me also, O my father!” And Esau lifted up his voice and wept.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Then Isaac his father answered and said to him: “Behold, your dwelling shall be of the fatness of the earth, and of the dew of heaven from above.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>By your sword you shall live, and you shall serve your brother; and it shall come to pass, when you become restless, that you shall break his yoke from your neck.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>So Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father blessed him, and Esau said in his heart, “The days of mourning for my father are at hand; then I will kill my brother Jacob.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 19:16-25  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>He who keeps the commandment keeps his soul, but he who is careless of his ways will die.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He who has pity on the poor lends to the Lord, and He will pay back what he has given.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Chasten your son while there is hope, and do not set your heart on his destruction.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>A man of great wrath will suffer punishment; for if you rescue him, you will have to do it again.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Listen to counsel and receive instruction, that you may be wise in your latter days.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>There are many plans in a man’s heart, nevertheless the Lord’s counsel – that will stand.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>What is desired in a man is kindness, and a poor man is better than a liar.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord leads to life, and he who has it will abide in satisfaction; he will not be visited with evil.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>A lazy man buries his hand in the bowl, and will not so much as bring it to his mouth again.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Strike a scoffer, and the simple will become wary; rebuke one who has understanding, and he will discern knowledge.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 49:6-10  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>Indeed He says, ‘It is too small a thing that You should be My Servant to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and to restore the preserved ones of Israel; I will also give You as a light to the Gentiles, that You should be My salvation to the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord, the Redeemer of Israel, their Holy One, to Him whom man despises, to Him Whom the nation abhors, to the servant of rulers: “Kings shall see and arise, princes also shall worship, because of the Lord Who is faithful, the Holy One of Israel, Who has chosen You.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord: “In an acceptable time I have heard You, and in the day of salvation I have helped You; I will preserve You and give You as a covenant to the people, to restore the earth, to cause them to inherit the desolate heritages;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>that You may say to the prisoners, ‘Go forth,’ to those who are in darkness, ‘Show yourselves.’ “They shall feed along the roads, and their pastures shall be on all desolate heights. </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>They shall neither hunger nor thirst, neither heat nor sun shall strike them; for He who has mercy on them will lead them, even by the springs of water He will guide them. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 31:3-16  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your fathers and to your family, and I will be with you.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field, to his flock,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>and said to them, “I see your father’s countenance, that it is not favorable toward me as before; but the God of my father has been with me.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“And you know that with all my might I have served your father.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“Yet your father has deceived me and changed my wages ten times, but God did not allow him to hurt me.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“If he said thus: ‘The speckled shall be your wages,’ then all the flocks bore speckled. And if he said thus: ‘The streaked shall be your wages,’ then all the flocks bore streaked.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“So God has taken away the livestock of your father and given them to me.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“And it happened, at the time when the flocks conceived, that I lifted my eyes and saw in a dream, and behold, the rams which leaped upon the flocks were streaked, speckled, and gray-spotted.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Then the Angel of God spoke to me in a dream, saying, ‘Jacob.’ And I said, ‘Here I am.’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>“And He said, ‘Lift your eyes now and see, all the rams which leap on the flocks are streaked, speckled, and gray-spotted; for I have seen all that Laban is doing to you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>‘I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed the pillar and where you made a vow to Me. Now arise, get out of this land, and return to the land of your family.’”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then Rachel and Leah answered and said to him, “Is there still any portion or inheritance for us in our father’s house?</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Are we not considered strangers by him? For he has sold us, and also completely consumed our money.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“For all these riches which God has taken from our father are really ours and our children’s; now then, whatever God has said to you, do it.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 21:3-21  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>To do righteousness and justice is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>A haughty look, a proud heart, and the plowing of the wicked are sin.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The plans of the diligent lead surely to plenty, but those of everyone who is hasty, surely to poverty.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Getting treasures by a lying tongue is the fleeting fantasy of those who seek death.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>The violence of the wicked will destroy them, because they refuse to do justice.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The way of a guilty man is perverse; but as for the pure, his work is right.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Better to dwell in a corner of a housetop, than in a house shared with a contentious woman.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The soul of the wicked desires evil; his neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>When the scoffer is punished, the simple is made wise; but when the wise is instructed, he receives knowledge.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The righteous God wisely considers the house of the wicked, overthrowing the wicked for their wickedness.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Whoever shuts his ears to the cry of the poor will also cry himself and not be heard.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>A gift in secret pacifies anger, and a bribe behind the back, strong wrath.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>It is a joy for the just to do justice, but destruction will come to the workers of iniquity.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>A man who wanders from the way of understanding will rest in the assembly of the dead.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He who loves pleasure will be a poor man; he who loves wine and oil will not be rich.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>The wicked shall be a ransom for the righteous, and the unfaithful for the upright.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Better to dwell in the wilderness, than with a contentious and angry woman.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>There is desirable treasure, and oil in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish man squanders it.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He who follows righteousness and mercy finds life, righteousness, and honor.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 58:1-11  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>“Cry aloud, spare not; lift up your voice like a trumpet; tell My people their transgression, and the house of Jacob their sins. </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Yet they seek Me daily, and delight to know My ways, as a nation that did righteousness, and did not forsake the ordinance of their God. They ask of Me the ordinances of justice; they take delight in approaching God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>‘Why have we fasted,’ they say, ‘and you have not seen? Why have we afflicted our souls, and you take no notice?’ “In fact, in the day of your fast you find pleasure, and exploit all your laborers.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Indeed you fast for strife and debate, and to strike with the fist of wickedness. You will not fast as you do this day, to make your voice heard on high.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Is it a fast that I have chosen, a day for a man to afflict his soul? Is it to bow down his head like a bulrush, and to spread out sackcloth and ashes? Would you call this a fast, and an acceptable day to the Lord?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“Is this not the fast that I have chosen: to loose the bonds of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens, to let the oppressed go free, and that you break every yoke?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Is it not to share your bread with the hungry, and that you bring to your house the poor who are cast out; when you see the naked, that you cover him, and not hide yourself from your own flesh? </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then your light shall break forth like the morning, your healing shall spring forth speedily, and your righteousness shall go before you; the glory of the Lord shall be your rear guard. </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then you shall call, and the Lord will answer; you shall cry, and He will say, ‘Here I am.’ “If you take away the yoke from your midst, the pointing of the finger, and speaking wickedness, </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>If you extend your soul to the hungry and satisfy the afflicted soul, then your light shall dawn in the darkness, and your darkness shall be as the noonday.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>The Lord will guide you continually, and satisfy your soul in drought, and strengthen your bones; you shall be like a watered garden, and like a spring of water, whose waters do not fail.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 43:26-31 45:1-16  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>And when Joseph came home, they brought him the present which was in their hand into the house, and bowed down before him to the earth.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then he asked them about their well-being, and said, “Is your father well, the old man of whom you spoke? Is he still alive?”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And they answered, “Your servant our father is in good health; he is still alive.” And they bowed their heads down and prostrated themselves.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then he lifted his eyes and saw his brother Benjamin, his mother’s son, and said, “Is this your younger brother of whom you spoke to me?” And he said, “God be gracious to you, my son.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now his heart yearned for his brother; so Joseph made haste and sought somewhere to weep. And he went into his chamber and wept there.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then he washed his face and came out; and he restrained himself, and said, “Serve the bread.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Joseph could not restrain himself before all those who stood by him, and he cried out, “Make everyone go out from me!” So no one stood with him while Joseph made himself known to his brothers.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And he wept aloud, and the Egyptians and the house of Pharaoh heard it.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph; does my father still live?” But his brothers could not answer him, for they were dismayed in his presence.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And Joseph said to his brothers, “Please come near to me.” So they came near. Then he said: “I am Joseph your brother, whom you sold into Egypt.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“But now, do not therefore be grieved or angry with yourselves because you sold me here; for God sent me before you to preserve life.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“For these two years the famine has been in the land, and there are still five years in which there will be neither plowing nor harvesting.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“And God sent me before you to preserve a posterity for you in the earth, and to save your lives by a great deliverance.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“So now it was not you who sent me here, but God; and He has made me a father to Pharaoh, and lord of all his house, and a ruler throughout all the land of Egypt.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“Hurry and go up to my father, and say to him, ‘Thus says your son Joseph: “God has made me lord of all Egypt; come down to me, do not tarry.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“You shall dwell in the land of Goshen, and you shall be near to me, you and your children, your children’s children, your flocks and your herds, and all that you have.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“There I will provide for you, lest you and your household, and all that you have, come to poverty; for there are still five years of famine.”’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>“And behold, your eyes and the eyes of my brother Benjamin see that it is my mouth that speaks to you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>“So you shall tell my father of all my glory in Egypt, and of all that you have seen; and you shall hurry and bring my father down here.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then he fell on his brother Benjamin’s neck and wept, and Benjamin wept on his neck.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Moreover he kissed all his brothers and wept over them, and after that his brothers talked with him.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Now the report of it was heard in Pharaoh’s house, saying, “Joseph’s brothers have come.” So it pleased Pharaoh and his servants well.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 21:23-22:4  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Whoever guards his mouth and tongue keeps his soul from troubles.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>A proud and haughty man – “Scoffer” is his name; he acts with arrogant pride.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The desire of the lazy man kills him, for his hands refuse to labor.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>He covets greedily all day long, but the righteous gives and does not spare.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; how much more when he brings it with wicked intent!</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>A false witness shall perish, but the man who hears him will speak endlessly.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>A wicked man hardens his face, but as for the upright, he establishes his way.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>There is no wisdom or understanding or counsel against the Lord.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>The horse is prepared for the day of battle, but deliverance is of the Lord.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>A good name is to be chosen rather than great riches, loving favor rather than silver and gold.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The rich and the poor have this in common, the Lord is the maker of them all.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>A prudent man foresees evil and hides himself, but the simple pass on and are punished.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>By humility and the fear of the Lord are riches and honor and life.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 65:8-16  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord: “As the new wine is found in the cluster, and one says, ‘Do not destroy it, for a blessing is in it,’ so will I do for My servants’ sake, that I may not destroy them all.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I will bring forth descendants from Jacob, and from Judah an heir of My mountains; My elect shall inherit it, and My servants shall dwell there.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Sharon shall be a fold of flocks, and the Valley of Achor a place for herds to lie down, for My people who have sought Me. </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“But you are those who forsake the Lord, who forget My holy mountain, who prepare a table for Gad, and who furnish a drink offering for Meni.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore I will number you for the sword, and you shall all bow down to the slaughter; because, when I called, you did not answer; when I spoke, you did not hear, but did evil before My eyes, and chose that in which I do not delight.” </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore thus says the Lord God: “Behold, My servants shall eat, but you shall be hungry; behold, My servants shall drink, but you shall be thirsty; Behold, My servants shall rejoice, but you shall be ashamed;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Behold, My servants shall sing for joy of heart, but you shall cry for sorrow of heart, and wail for grief of spirit.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>You shall leave your name as a curse to My chosen; for the Lord God will slay you, and call His servants by another name; </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>so that he who blesses himself in the earth shall bless himself in the God of truth; and he who swears in the earth shall swear by the God of truth; because the former troubles are forgotten, and because they are hidden from My eyes.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 46:1-7  (Vespers 1st  reading)
