readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>So Israel took his journey with all that he had, and came to Beersheba, and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then God spoke to Israel in the visions of the night, and said, “Jacob, Jacob!” And he said, “Here I am.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So He said, “I am God, the God of your father; do not fear to go down to Egypt, for I will make of you a great nation there.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also surely bring you up again; and Joseph will put his hand on your eyes.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Jacob arose from Beersheba; and the sons of Israel carried their father Jacob, their little ones, and their wives, in the carts which Pharaoh had sent to carry him.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So they took their livestock and their goods, which they had acquired in the land of Canaan, and went to Egypt, Jacob and all his descendants with him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>His sons and his sons’ sons, his daughters and his sons’ daughters, and all his descendants he brought with him to Egypt.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 23:15-24:5  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will rejoice – indeed, I myself;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>yes, my inmost being will rejoice when your lips speak right things.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Do not let your heart envy sinners, but be zealous for the fear of the Lord all the day;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>for surely there is a hereafter, and your hope will not be cut off.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Hear, my son, and be wise; and guide your heart in the way.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Do not mix with winebibbers, or with gluttonous eaters of meat;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>for the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, and drowsiness will clothe a man with rags.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Listen to your father who begot you, and do not despise your mother when she is old.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Buy the truth, and do not sell it, also wisdom and instruction and understanding.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>The father of the righteous will greatly rejoice, and he who begets a wise child will delight in him.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Let your father and your mother be glad, and let her who bore you rejoice.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For a harlot is a deep pit, and a seductress is a narrow well.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>She also lies in wait as for a victim, and increases the unfaithful among men.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has contentions? Who has complaints? Who has wounds without cause? Who has redness of eyes?</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Those who linger long at the wine, those who go in search of mixed wine.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Do not look on the wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup, when it swirls around smoothly;</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>at the last it bites like a serpent, and stings like a viper.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Your eyes will see strange things, and your heart will utter perverse things.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Yes, you will be like one who lies down in the midst of the sea, or like one who lies at the top of the mast, saying:</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>“They have struck me, but I was not hurt; they have beaten me, but I did not feel it. When shall I awake, that I may seek another drink?”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Do not be envious of evil men, nor desire to be with them;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For their heart devises violence, and their lips talk of troublemaking.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Through wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>By knowledge the rooms are filled with all precious and pleasant riches.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>A wise man is strong, yes, a man of knowledge increases strength;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 66:10-24  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>“Rejoice with Jerusalem, and be glad with her, all you who love her; rejoice for joy with her, all you who mourn for her; </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>That you may feed and be satisfied with the consolation of her bosom, that you may drink deeply and be delighted with the abundance of her glory.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For thus says the Lord: “Behold, I will extend peace to her like a river, and the glory of the Gentiles like a flowing stream. Then you shall feed; on her sides shall you be carried, and be dandled on her knees.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>As one whom his mother comforts, so I will comfort you; and you shall be comforted in Jerusalem.” </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>When you see this, your heart shall rejoice, and your bones shall flourish like grass; the hand of the Lord shall be known to His servants, and His indignation to His enemies.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For behold, the Lord will come with fire and with His chariots, like a whirlwind, to render His anger with fury, and His rebuke with flames of fire.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For by fire and by His sword the Lord will judge all flesh; and the slain of the Lord shall be many.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“Those who sanctify themselves and purify themselves, to go to the gardens after an idol in the midst, eating swine’s flesh and the abomination and the mouse, shall be consumed together,” says the Lord.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“For I know their works and their thoughts. It shall be that I will gather all nations and tongues; and they shall come and see My glory.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>“I will set a sign among them; and those among them who escape I will send to the nations: to Tarshish and Pul and Lud, who draw the bow, and Tubal and Javan, to the coastlands afar off who have not heard My fame nor seen My glory. And they shall declare My glory among the Gentiles.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>“Then they shall bring all your brethren for an offering to the Lord out of all nations, on horses and in chariots and in litters, on mules and on camels, to My holy mountain Jerusalem,” says the Lord, “as the children of Israel bring an offering in a clean vessel into the house of the Lord.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>“And I will also take some of them for priests and Levites,” says the Lord.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>“For as the new heavens and the new earth which I will make shall remain before Me,” says the Lord, “so shall your descendants and your name remain.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And it shall come to pass that from one New Moon to another, and from one Sabbath to another, all flesh shall come to worship before Me,” says the Lord. </dd><dt>24</dt><dd>“And they shall go forth and look upon the corpses of the men Who have transgressed against Me. For their worm does not die, and their fire is not quenched. They shall be an abhorrence to all flesh.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 49:33-50:26  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>And when Jacob had finished commanding his sons, he drew his feet up into the bed and breathed his last, and was gathered to his people.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Joseph fell on his father’s face, and wept over him, and kissed him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And Joseph commanded his servants the physicians to embalm his father. So the physicians embalmed Israel.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Forty days were required for him, for such are the days required for those who are embalmed; and the Egyptians mourned for him seventy days.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Now when the days of his mourning were past, Joseph spoke to the household of Pharaoh, saying, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, please speak in the hearing of Pharaoh, saying,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>‘My father made me swear, saying, “Behold, I am dying; in my grave which I dug for myself in the land of Canaan, there you shall bury me.” Now therefore, please let me go up and bury my father, and I will come back.’”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And Pharaoh said, “Go up and bury your father, as he made you swear.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So Joseph went up to bury his father; and with him went up all the servants of Pharaoh, the elders of his house, and all the elders of the land of Egypt,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>as well as all the house of Joseph, his brothers, and his father’s house. Only their little ones, their flocks, and their herds they left in the land of Goshen.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And there went up with him both chariots and horsemen, and it was a very great gathering.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then they came to the threshing floor of Atad, which is beyond the Jordan, and they mourned there with a great and very solemn lamentation. He observed seven days of mourning for his father.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “This is a deep mourning of the Egyptians.” Therefore its name was called Abel Mizraim, which is beyond the Jordan.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So his sons did for him just as he had commanded them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For his sons carried him to the land of Canaan, and buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, before Mamre, which Abraham bought with the field from Ephron the Hittite as property for a burial place.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And after he had buried his father, Joseph returned to Egypt, he and his brothers and all who went up with him to bury his father.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “Perhaps Joseph will hate us, and may actually repay us for all the evil which we did to him.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So they sent messengers to Joseph, saying, “Before your father died he commanded, saying,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>‘Thus you shall say to Joseph: “I beg you, please forgive the trespass of your brothers and their sin; for they did evil to you.”’ Now, please, forgive the trespass of the servants of the God of your father.” And Joseph wept when they spoke to him.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then his brothers also went and fell down before his face, and they said, “Behold, we are your servants.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Joseph said to them, “Do not be afraid, for am I in the place of God?</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>“But as for you, you meant evil against me; but God meant it for good, in order to bring it about as it is this day, to save many people alive.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>“Now therefore, do not be afraid; I will provide for you and your little ones.” And he comforted them and spoke kindly to them.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So Joseph dwelt in Egypt, he and his father’s household. And Joseph lived one hundred and ten years.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Joseph saw Ephraim’s children to the third generation. The children of Machir, the son of Manasseh, were also brought up on Joseph’s knees.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And Joseph said to his brethren, “I am dying; but God will surely visit you, and bring you out of this land to the land of which He swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then Joseph took an oath from the children of Israel, saying, “God will surely visit you, and you shall carry up my bones from here.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>So Joseph died, being one hundred and ten years old; and they embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 31:8-31  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>Open your mouth for the speechless, in the cause of all who are appointed to die.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Open your mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and needy.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Who can find a virtuous wife? For her worth is far above rubies.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>The heart of her husband safely trusts her; so he will have no lack of gain.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>She does him good and not evil all the days of her life.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>She seeks wool and flax, And willingly works with her hands.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>She is like the merchant ships, she brings her food from afar.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>She also rises while it is yet night, and provides food for her household, and a portion for her maidservants.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>She considers a field and buys it; from her profits she plants a vineyard.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>She girds herself with strength, and strengthens her arms.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>She perceives that her merchandise is good, and her lamp does not go out by night.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>She stretches out her hands to the distaff, and her hand holds the spindle.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>She extends her hand to the poor, yes, she reaches out her hands to the needy.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>She is not afraid of snow for her household, for all her household is clothed with scarlet.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>She makes tapestry for herself; her clothing is fine linen and purple.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Her husband is known in the gates, when he sits among the elders of the land.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>She makes linen garments and sells them, and supplies sashes for the merchants.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Strength and honor are her clothing; she shall rejoice in time to come.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>She opens her mouth with wisdom, and on her tongue is the law of kindness.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>She watches over the ways of her household, and does not eat the bread of idleness.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praises her:</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>“Many daughters have done well, but you excel them all.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Charm is deceitful and beauty is passing, but a woman who fears the Lord, she shall be praised.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Give her of the fruit of her hands, and let her own works praise her in the gates.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 4th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 5th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:1-9  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:26-8:2  (Epistle St Tikhon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For such a High Priest was fitting for us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and has become higher than the heavens;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>who does not need daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for his own sins and then for the people’s, for this He did once for all when He offered up Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the law appoints as high priests men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints the Son who has been perfected forever.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the main point of the things we are saying: We have such a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>a Minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord erected, and not man.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Gospel St Tikhon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 12:28-13:8  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore, since we are receiving a kingdom which cannot be shaken, let us have grace, by which we may serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For our God is a consuming fire.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Let brotherly love continue.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Do not forget to entertain strangers, for by so doing some have unwittingly entertained angels.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Remember the prisoners as if chained with them – those who are mistreated – since you yourselves are in the body also.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Marriage is honorable among all, and the bed undefiled; but fornicators and adulterers God will judge.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Let your conduct be without covetousness; be content with such things as you have. For He Himself has said, “I will never leave you nor forsake you.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So we may boldly say: “The LORD is my helper; I will not fear. What can man do to me?”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd> Remember those who rule over you, who have spoken the word of God to you, whose faith follow, considering the outcome of their conduct.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 11:1-45  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now a certain man was sick, Lazarus of Bethany, the town of Mary and her sister Martha.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>It was that Mary who anointed the Lord with fragrant oil and wiped His feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore the sisters sent to Him, saying, “Lord, behold, he whom You love is sick.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>When Jesus heard that, He said, “This sickness is not unto death, but for the glory of God, that the Son of God may be glorified through it.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So, when He heard that he was sick, He stayed two more days in the place where He was.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then after this He said to the disciples, “Let us go to Judea again.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The disciples said to Him, “Rabbi, lately the Jews sought to stone You, and are You going there again?”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Jesus answered, “Are there not twelve hours in the day? If anyone walks in the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But if one walks in the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>These things He said, and after that He said to them, “Our friend Lazarus sleeps, but I go that I may wake him up.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then His disciples said, “Lord, if he sleeps he will get well.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>However, Jesus spoke of his death, but they thought that He was speaking about taking rest in sleep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them plainly, “Lazarus is dead.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And I am glad for your sakes that I was not there, that you may believe. Nevertheless let us go to him.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Thomas, who is called the Twin, said to his fellow disciples, “Let us also go, that we may die with Him.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So when Jesus came, He found that he had already been in the tomb four days.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, about two miles away.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And many of the Jews had joined the women around Martha and Mary, to comfort them concerning their brother.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Martha, as soon as she heard that Jesus was coming, went and met Him, but Mary was sitting in the house.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Now Martha said to Jesus, “Lord, if You had been here, my brother would not have died.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But even now I know that whatever You ask of God, God will give You.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Your brother will rise again.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Martha said to Him, “I know that he will rise again in the resurrection at the last day.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “I am the resurrection and the life. He who believes in Me, though he may die, he shall live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die. Do you believe this?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>She said to Him, “Yes, Lord, I believe that You are the Christ, the Son of God, who is to come into the world.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And when she had said these things, she went her way and secretly called Mary her sister, saying, “The Teacher has come and is calling for you.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>As soon as she heard that, she arose quickly and came to Him.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now Jesus had not yet come into the town, but was in the place where Martha met Him.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then the Jews who were with her in the house, and comforting her, when they saw that Mary rose up quickly and went out, followed her, saying, “She is going to the tomb to weep there.” </dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then, when Mary came where Jesus was, and saw Him, she fell down at His feet, saying to Him, “Lord, if You had been here, my brother would not have died.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Therefore, when Jesus saw her weeping, and the Jews who came with her weeping, He groaned in the spirit and was troubled.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>And He said, “Where have you laid him?” They said to Him, “Lord, come and see.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Jesus wept.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then the Jews said, “See how He loved him!”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And some of them said, “Could not this Man, who opened the eyes of the blind, also have kept this man from dying?”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then Jesus, again groaning in Himself, came to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone lay against it.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Jesus said, “Take away the stone.” Martha, the sister of him who was dead, said to Him, “Lord, by this time there is a stench, for he has been dead four days.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Did I not say to you that if you would believe you would see the glory of God?”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Then they took away the stone from the place where the dead man was lying. And Jesus lifted up His eyes and said, “Father, I thank You that You have heard Me.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And I know that You always hear Me, but because of the people who are standing by I said this, that they may believe that You sent Me.”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>Now when He had said these things, He cried with a loud voice, “Lazarus, come forth!”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>And he who had died came out bound hand and foot with graveclothes, and his face was wrapped with a cloth. Jesus said to them, “Loose him, and let him go.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then many of the Jews who had come to Mary, and had seen the things Jesus did, believed in Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 49:1-28-12  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And Jacob called his sons and said, “Gather together, that I may tell you what shall befall you in the last days:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“Gather together and hear, you sons of Jacob, And listen to Israel your father.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“Judah, you are he whom your brothers shall praise; Your hand shall be on the neck of your enemies; Your father’s children shall bow down before you.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Judah is a lion’s whelp; From the prey, my son, you have gone up. He bows down, he lies down as a lion; And as a lion, who shall rouse him?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The scepter shall not depart from Judah, Nor a lawgiver from between his feet, Until Shiloh comes; And to Him shall be the obedience of the people.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Binding his donkey to the vine, And his donkey’s colt to the choice vine, He washed his garments in wine, And his clothes in the blood of grapes.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>His eyes are darker than wine, And his teeth whiter than milk.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Zephaniah 3:14-19  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Sing, O daughter of Zion! Shout, O Israel! Be glad and rejoice with all your heart, O daughter of Jerusalem!</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The Lord has taken away your judgments, He has cast out your enemy. The King of Israel, the Lord, is in your midst; You shall see disaster no more.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>In that day it shall be said to Jerusalem: “Do not fear; Zion, let not your hands be weak.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord your God in your midst, The Mighty One, will save; He will rejoice over you with gladness, He will quiet you with His love, He will rejoice over you with singing.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“I will gather those who sorrow over the appointed assembly, Who are among you, To whom its reproach is a burden.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Behold, at that time I will deal with all who afflict you; I will save the lame, And gather those who were driven out; I will appoint them for praise and fame In every land where they were put to shame.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Zechariah 9:9-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>“Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion! Shout, O daughter of Jerusalem! Behold, your King is coming to you; He is just and having salvation, Lowly and riding on a donkey, A colt, the foal of a donkey.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And he shall destroy the chariots out of Ephraim, and the horse out of Jerusalem, and the bow of war shall be utterly destroyed; and there shall be abundance and peace out of the nations. And he shall rule over the waters from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And you, by the blood of your covenant, have sent forth your prisoners out of the pit that has no water.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>You shall sit in strongholds, you prisoners of the assembly; and for one day of your sojourning I will recompense you double.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For I have bent you for Myself like a bow, O Judah, I have filled it with Ephraim; and I will raise up your children, O Zion, against the children of the Greeks, and handle you like the sword of a warrior.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And the Lord shall be over them, and His arrow shall go forth like lightning. And the Lord God Almighty shall sound the trumpet and go forth in the noise of His threatening.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The Lord Almighty shall defend them!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:1-11 15-17  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when they drew near Jerusalem, and came to Bethphage, at the Mount of Olives, then Jesus sent two disciples,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>saying to them, “Go into the village opposite you, and immediately you will find a donkey tied, and a colt with her. Loose them and bring them to Me.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And if anyone says anything to you, you shall say, ‘The Lord has need of them,’ and immediately he will send them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>All this was done that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Tell the daughter of Zion, ‘Behold, your King is coming to you, lowly, and sitting on a donkey, a colt, the foal of a donkey.’” </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So the disciples went and did as Jesus commanded them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>They brought the donkey and the colt, laid their clothes on them, and set Him on them.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And a very great multitude spread their clothes on the road; others cut down branches from the trees and spread them on the road.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then the multitudes who went before and those who followed cried out, saying: “Hosanna to the Son of David! ‘Blessed is He who comes in the name of the LORD!’ Hosanna in the highest!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And when He had come into Jerusalem, all the city was moved, saying, “Who is this?”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So the multitudes said, “This is Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth of Galilee.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when the chief priests and scribes saw the wonderful things that He did, and the children crying out in the temple and saying, “Hosanna to the Son of David!” they were indignant</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>and said to Him, “Do You hear what these are saying?” And Jesus said to them, “Yes. Have you never read, ‘Out of the mouth of babes and nursing infants You have perfected praise’?” </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then He left them and went out of the city to Bethany, and He lodged there.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 4:4-9  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>Rejoice in the Lord always. Again I will say, rejoice!</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Let your gentleness be known to all men. The Lord is at hand.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Be anxious for nothing, but in everything by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>and the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Finally, brethren, whatever things are true, whatever things are noble, whatever things are just, whatever things are pure, whatever things are lovely, whatever things are of good report, if there is any virtue and if there is anything praiseworthy – meditate on these things.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The things which you learned and received and heard and saw in me, these do, and the God of peace will be with you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 12:1-18  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then, six days before the Passover, Jesus came to Bethany, where Lazarus was who had been dead, whom He had raised from the dead.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>There they made Him a supper; and Martha served, but Lazarus was one of those who sat at the table with Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Mary took a pound of very costly oil of spikenard, anointed the feet of Jesus, and wiped His feet with her hair. And the house was filled with the fragrance of the oil.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But one of His disciples, Judas Iscariot, Simon’s son, who would betray Him, said,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Why was this fragrant oil not sold for three hundred denarii and given to the poor?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>This he said, not that he cared for the poor, but because he was a thief, and had the money box; and he used to take what was put in it.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But Jesus said, “Let her alone; she has kept this for the day of My burial.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For the poor you have with you always, but Me you do not have always.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now a great many of the Jews knew that He was there; and they came, not for Jesus’ sake only, but that they might also see Lazarus, whom He had raised from the dead.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But the chief priests plotted to put Lazarus to death also,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>because on account of him many of the Jews went away and believed in Jesus.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The next day a great multitude that had come to the feast, when they heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>took branches of palm trees and went out to meet Him, and cried out: “Hosanna! ‘Blessed is He who comes in the name of the LORD!’ The King of Israel!”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then Jesus, when He had found a young donkey, sat on it; as it is written:</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Fear not, daughter of Zion; behold, your King is coming, sitting on a donkey’s colt.” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>His disciples did not understand these things at first; but when Jesus was glorified, then they remembered that these things were written about Him and that they had done these things to Him.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore the people, who were with Him when He called Lazarus out of his tomb and raised him from the dead, bore witness.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For this reason the people also met Him, because they heard that He had done this sign.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 1:1-20  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year, in the fourth month, on the fifth day of the month, as I was among the captives by the River Chebar, that the heavens were opened and I saw visions of God.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>On the fifth day of the month, which was in the fifth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>the word of the Lord came expressly to Ezekiel the priest, the son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans by the River Chebar; and the hand of the Lord was upon him there.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then I looked, and behold, a whirlwind was coming out of the north, a great cloud with raging fire engulfing itself; and brightness was all around it and radiating out of its midst like the color of amber, out of the midst of the fire.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Also from within it came the likeness of four living creatures. And this was their appearance: they had the likeness of a man.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Each one had four faces, and each one had four wings.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Their legs were straight, and the soles of their feet were like the soles of calves’ feet. They sparkled like the color of burnished bronze.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The hands of a man were under their wings on their four sides; and each of the four had faces and wings.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Their wings touched one another. The creatures did not turn when they went, but each one went straight forward.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>As for the likeness of their faces, each had the face of a man; each of the four had the face of a lion on the right side, each of the four had the face of an ox on the left side, and each of the four had the face of an eagle.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Thus were their faces. Their wings stretched upward; two wings of each one touched one another, and two covered their bodies.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And each one went straight forward; they went wherever the spirit wanted to go, and they did not turn when they went.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>As for the likeness of the living creatures, their appearance was like burning coals of fire, like the appearance of torches going back and forth among the living creatures. The fire was bright, and out of the fire went lightning.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And the living creatures ran back and forth, in appearance like a flash of lightning.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Now as I looked at the living creatures, behold, a wheel was on the earth beside each living creature with its four faces.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>The appearance of the wheels and their workings was like the color of beryl, and all four had the same likeness. The appearance of their workings was, as it were, a wheel in the middle of a wheel.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>When they moved, they went toward any one of four directions; they did not turn aside when they went.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>As for their rims, they were so high they were awesome; and their rims were full of eyes, all around the four of them.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>When the living creatures went, the wheels went beside them; and when the living creatures were lifted up from the earth, the wheels were lifted up.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Wherever the spirit wanted to go, they went, because there the spirit went; and the wheels were lifted together with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 1:1-20  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt; each man and his household came with Jacob:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>All those who were descendants of Jacob were seventy persons (for Joseph was in Egypt already).</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And Joseph died, all his brothers, and all that generation.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But the children of Israel were fruitful and increased abundantly, multiplied and grew exceedingly mighty; and the land was filled with them.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Now there arose a new king over Egypt, who did not know Joseph.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And he said to his people, “Look, the people of the children of Israel are more and mightier than we;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“come, let us deal shrewdly with them, lest they multiply, and it happen, in the event of war, that they also join our enemies and fight against us, and so go up out of the land.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore they set taskmasters over them to afflict them with their burdens. And they built for Pharaoh supply cities, Pithom and Raamses.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and grew. And they were in dread of the children of Israel.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So the Egyptians made the children of Israel serve with rigor.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And they made their lives bitter with hard bondage – in mortar, in brick, and in all manner of service in the field. All their service in which they made them serve was with rigor.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, of whom the name of one was Shiphrah and the name of the other Puah;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>and he said, “When you do the duties of a midwife for the Hebrew women, and see them on the birthstools, if it is a son, then you shall kill him; but if it is a daughter, then she shall live.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But the midwives feared God, and did not do as the king of Egypt commanded them, but saved the male children alive.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>So the king of Egypt called for the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this thing, and saved the male children alive?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women; for they are lively and give birth before the midwives come to them.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Therefore God dealt well with the midwives, and the people multiplied and grew very mighty.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Job 1:1-12  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was blameless and upright, and one who feared God and shunned evil.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And seven sons and three daughters were born to him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Also, his possessions were seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large household, so that this man was the greatest of all the people of the East.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And his sons would go and feast in their houses, each on his appointed day, and would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>So it was, when the days of feasting had run their course, that Job would send and sanctify them, and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my sons have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did continually.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came among them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Satan, “From where do you come?” So Satan answered the Lord and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil?”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So Satan answered the Lord and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“Have You not made a hedge around him, around his household, and around all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“But now, stretch out Your hand and touch all that he has, and he will surely curse You to Your face!”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is in your power; only do not lay a hand on his person.” So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:18-43  (Gospel Matins)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Now in the morning, as He returned to the city, He was hungry.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And seeing a fig tree by the road, He came to it and found nothing on it but leaves, and said to it, “Let no fruit grow on you ever again.” Immediately the fig tree withered away.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And when the disciples saw it, they marveled, saying, “How did the fig tree wither away so soon?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So Jesus answered and said to them, “Assuredly, I say to you, if you have faith and do not doubt, you will not only do what was done to the fig tree, but also if you say to this mountain, ‘Be removed and be cast into the sea,’ it will be done.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And whatever things you ask in prayer, believing, you will receive.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Now when He came into the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people confronted Him as He was teaching, and said, “By what authority are You doing these things? And who gave You this authority?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>But Jesus answered and said to them, “I also will ask you one thing, which if you tell Me, I likewise will tell you by what authority I do these things:</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The baptism of John – where was it from? From heaven or from men?” And they reasoned among themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ He will say to us, ‘Why then did you not believe him?’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But if we say, ‘From men,’ we fear the multitude, for all count John as a prophet.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>So they answered Jesus and said, “We do not know.” And He said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But what do you think? A man had two sons, and he came to the first and said, ‘Son, go, work today in my vineyard.’</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>He answered and said, ‘I will not,’ but afterward he regretted it and went.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then he came to the second and said likewise. And he answered and said, ‘I go, sir,’ but he did not go.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Which of the two did the will of his father?” They said to Him, “The first.” Jesus said to them, “Assuredly, I say to you that tax collectors and harlots enter the kingdom of God before you.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>For John came to you in the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him; but tax collectors and harlots believed him; and when you saw it, you did not afterward relent and believe him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Hear another parable: There was a certain landowner who planted a vineyard and set a hedge around it, dug a winepress in it and built a tower. And he leased it to vinedressers and went into a far country.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Now when vintage-time drew near, he sent his servants to the vinedressers, that they might receive its fruit.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And the vinedressers took his servants, beat one, killed one, and stoned another.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Again he sent other servants, more than the first, and they did likewise to them.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then last of all he sent his son to them, saying, ‘They will respect my son.’</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But when the vinedressers saw the son, they said among themselves, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance.’</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>So they took him and cast him out of the vineyard and killed him.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Therefore, when the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those vinedressers?”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>They said to Him, “He will destroy those wicked men miserably, and lease his vineyard to other vinedressers who will render to him the fruits in their seasons.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Have you never read in the Scriptures: ‘The stone which the builders rejected Has become the chief cornerstone. This was the LORD’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes’? </dd><dt>43</dt><dd>Therefore I say to you, the kingdom of God will be taken from you and given to a nation bearing the fruits of it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 24:3-35  (Gospel Presanctified)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Now as He sat on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to Him privately, saying, “Tell us, when will these things be? And what will be the sign of Your coming, and of the end of the age?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to them: “Take heed that no one deceives you.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For many will come in My name, saying, ‘I am the Christ,’ and will deceive many.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And you will hear of wars and rumors of wars. See that you are not troubled; for all these things must come to pass, but the end is not yet.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. And there will be famines, pestilences, and earthquakes in various places.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All these are the beginning of sorrows.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then they will deliver you up to tribulation and kill you, and you will be hated by all nations for My name’s sake.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And then many will be offended, will betray one another, and will hate one another.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then many false prophets will rise up and deceive many.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And because lawlessness will abound, the love of many will grow cold.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But he who endures to the end shall be saved.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And this gospel of the kingdom will be preached in all the world as a witness to all the nations, and then the end will come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore when you see the ‘abomination of desolation,’ spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place (whoever reads, let him understand),</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Let him who is on the housetop not go down to take anything out of his house.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And let him who is in the field not go back to get his clothes.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing babies in those days!</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And pray that your flight may not be in winter or on the Sabbath.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been since the beginning of the world until this time, no, nor ever shall be.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And unless those days were shortened, no flesh would be saved; but for the elect’s sake those days will be shortened.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then if anyone says to you, ‘Look, here is the Christ!’ or ‘There!’ do not believe it.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For false christs and false prophets will rise and show great signs and wonders to deceive, if possible, even the elect.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>See, I have told you beforehand.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Therefore if they say to you, ‘Look, He is in the desert!’ do not go out; or ‘Look, He is in the inner rooms!’ do not believe it.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For as the lightning comes from the east and flashes to the west, so also will the coming of the Son of Man be.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For wherever the carcass is, there the eagles will be gathered together.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Immediately after the tribulation of those days the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light; the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven, and then all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And He will send His angels with a great sound of a trumpet, and they will gather together His elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Now learn this parable from the fig tree: When its branch has already become tender and puts forth leaves, you know that summer is near.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>So you also, when you see all these things, know that it is near – at the doors!</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, this generation will by no means pass away till all these things take place.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Heaven and earth will pass away, but My words will by no means pass away.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 1:21-28 (1:1-282:1 LXX)  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>When those went, these went; when those stood, these stood; and when those were lifted up from the earth, the wheels were lifted up together with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>The likeness of the firmament above the heads of the living creatures was like the color of an awesome crystal, stretched out over their heads.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And under the firmament their wings spread out straight, one toward another. Each one had two which covered one side, and each one had two which covered the other side of the body.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When they went, I heard the noise of their wings, like the noise of many waters, like the voice of the Almighty, a tumult like the noise of an army; and when they stood still, they let down their wings.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>A voice came from above the firmament that was over their heads; whenever they stood, they let down their wings.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And above the firmament over their heads was the likeness of a throne, in appearance like a sapphire stone; on the likeness of the throne was a likeness with the appearance of a man high above it.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Also from the appearance of His waist and upward I saw, as it were, the color of amber with the appearance of fire all around within it; and from the appearance of His waist and downward I saw, as it were, the appearance of fire with brightness all around</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Like the appearance of a rainbow in a cloud on a rainy day, so was the appearance of the brightness all around it. This was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 2:5-10  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Then the daughter of Pharaoh came down to bathe at the river. And her maidens walked along the riverside; and when she saw the ark among the reeds, she sent her maid to get it.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And when she opened it, she saw the child, and behold, the baby wept. So she had compassion on him, and said, “This is one of the Hebrews’ children.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Shall I go and call a nurse for you from the Hebrew women, that she may nurse the child for you?”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Go.” So the maiden went and called the child’s mother.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child away and nurse him for me, and I will give you your wages.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the child grew, and she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. So she called his name Moses, saying, “Because I drew him out of the water.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Job 1:13-22  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Now there was a day when his sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>and a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“when the Sabeans raided them and took them away – indeed they have killed the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants, and consumed them; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three bands, raided the camels and took them away, yes, and killed the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>“and suddenly a great wind came from across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young people, and they are dead; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Job arose, tore his robe, and shaved his head; and he fell to the ground and worshiped.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And he said: “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, And naked shall I return there. The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away; Blessed be the name of the Lord.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>In all this Job did not sin nor charge God with wrong.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 22:15-23:39  (Gospel Matins)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees went and plotted how they might entangle Him in His talk.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And they sent to Him their disciples with the Herodians, saying, “Teacher, we know that You are true, and teach the way of God in truth; nor do You care about anyone, for You do not regard the person of men.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Tell us, therefore, what do You think? Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But Jesus perceived their wickedness, and said, “Why do you test Me, you hypocrites?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Show Me the tax money.” So they brought Him a denarius.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Whose image and inscription is this?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>They said to Him, “Caesar’s.” And He said to them, “Render therefore to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>When they had heard these words, they marveled, and left Him and went their way.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>The same day the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to Him and asked Him,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>saying: “Teacher, Moses said that if a man dies, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife and raise up offspring for his brother.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Now there were with us seven brothers. The first died after he had married, and having no offspring, left his wife to his brother.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Likewise the second also, and the third, even to the seventh.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Last of all the woman died also.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore, in the resurrection, whose wife of the seven will she be? For they all had her.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “You are mistaken, not knowing the Scriptures nor the power of God.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels of God in heaven.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what was spoken to you by God, saying,</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>’I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And when the multitudes heard this, they were astonished at His teaching.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But when the Pharisees heard that He had silenced the Sadducees, they gathered together.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then one of them, a lawyer, asked Him a question, testing Him, and saying,</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>“Teacher, which is the great commandment in the law?”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “’You shall love the LORD your God with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your mind.’ </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>This is the first and great commandment.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And the second is like it: ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’ </dd><dt>40</dt><dd>On these two commandments hang all the Law and the Prophets.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them,</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>saying, “What do you think about the Christ? Whose Son is He?” They said to Him, “The Son of David.”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>He said to them, “How then does David in the Spirit call Him ‘Lord,’ saying:</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>‘The LORD said to my Lord, sit at My right hand, till I make Your enemies Your footstool’? </dd><dt>45</dt><dd>If David then calls Him ‘Lord,’ how is He his Son?”</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And no one was able to answer Him a word, nor from that day on did anyone dare question Him anymore.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Jesus spoke to the multitudes and to His disciples,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>saying: “The scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses’ seat.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore whatever they tell you to observe, that observe and do, but do not do according to their works; for they say, and do not do.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For they bind heavy burdens, hard to bear, and lay them on men’s shoulders; but they themselves will not move them with one of their fingers.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But all their works they do to be seen by men. They make their phylacteries broad and enlarge the borders of their garments.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>They love the best places at feasts, the best seats in the synagogues,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>greetings in the marketplaces, and to be called by men, ‘Rabbi, Rabbi.’</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But you, do not be called ‘Rabbi’; for One is your Teacher, the Christ, and you are all brethren.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Do not call anyone on earth your father; for One is your Father, He who is in heaven.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And do not be called teachers; for One is your Teacher, the Christ.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But he who is greatest among you shall be your servant.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you shut up the kingdom of heaven against men; for you neither go in yourselves, nor do you allow those who are entering to go in.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you devour widows’ houses, and for a pretense make long prayers. Therefore you will receive greater condemnation. </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you travel land and sea to win one proselyte, and when he is won, you make him twice as much a son of hell as yourselves.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Woe to you, blind guides, who say, ‘Whoever swears by the temple, it is nothing; but whoever swears by the gold of the temple, he is obliged to perform it.’</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Fools and blind! For which is greater, the gold or the temple that sanctifies the gold?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And, ‘Whoever swears by the altar, it is nothing; but whoever swears by the gift that is on it, he is obliged to perform it.’</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Fools and blind! For which is greater, the gift or the altar that sanctifies the gift?</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Therefore he who swears by the altar, swears by it and by all things on it.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He who swears by the temple, swears by it and by Him who dwells in it.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And he who swears by heaven, swears by the throne of God and by Him who sits on it.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you pay tithe of mint and anise and cummin, and have neglected the weightier matters of the law: justice and mercy and faith. These you ought to have done, without leaving the others undone.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Blind guides, who strain out a gnat and swallow a camel!</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you cleanse the outside of the cup and dish, but inside they are full of extortion and self-indulgence. </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Blind Pharisee, first cleanse the inside of the cup and dish, that the outside of them may be clean also.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs which indeed appear beautiful outwardly, but inside are full of dead men’s bones and all uncleanness.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Even so you also outwardly appear righteous to men, but inside you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because you build the tombs of the prophets and adorn the monuments of the righteous,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>and say, ‘If we had lived in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets.’</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore you are witnesses against yourselves that you are sons of those who murdered the prophets.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Fill up, then, the measure of your fathers’ guilt.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Serpents, brood of vipers! How can you escape the condemnation of hell?</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Therefore, indeed, I send you prophets, wise men, and scribes: some of them you will kill and crucify, and some of them you will scourge in your synagogues and persecute from city to city,</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>that on you may come all the righteous blood shed on the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah, son of Berechiah, whom you murdered between the temple and the altar.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, all these things will come upon this generation.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the one who kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to her! How often I wanted to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing!</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>See! Your house is left to you desolate;</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>for I say to you, you shall see Me no more till you say, ‘Blessed is He who comes in the name of the LORD!’” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 24:36-26:2  (Gospel Presanctified)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>But of that day and hour no one knows, not even the angels of heaven, but My Father only.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But as the days of Noah were, so also will the coming of the Son of Man be.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>For as in the days before the flood, they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day that Noah entered the ark,</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>and did not know until the flood came and took them all away, so also will the coming of the Son of Man be.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Then two men will be in the field: one will be taken and the other left.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Two women will be grinding at the mill: one will be taken and the other left.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Watch therefore, for you do not know what hour your Lord is coming.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>But know this, that if the master of the house had known what hour the thief would come, he would have watched and not allowed his house to be broken into.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Therefore you also be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Who then is a faithful and wise servant, whom his master made ruler over his household, to give them food in due season?</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Blessed is that servant whom his master, when he comes, will find so doing.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you that he will make him ruler over all his goods.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>But if that evil servant says in his heart, ‘My master is delaying his coming,’ </dd><dt>49</dt><dd>and begins to beat his fellow servants, and to eat and drink with the drunkards,</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>the master of that servant will come on a day when he is not looking for him and at an hour that he is not aware of,</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>and will cut him in two and appoint him his portion with the hypocrites. There shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then the kingdom of heaven shall be likened to ten virgins who took their lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Now five of them were wise, and five were foolish.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Those who were foolish took their lamps and took no oil with them,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>but the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But while the bridegroom was delayed, they all slumbered and slept.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And at midnight a cry was heard: ‘Behold, the bridegroom is coming; go out to meet him!’</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then all those virgins arose and trimmed their lamps.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And the foolish said to the wise, ‘Give us some of your oil, for our lamps are going out.’</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But the wise answered, saying, ‘No, lest there should not be enough for us and you; but go rather to those who sell, and buy for yourselves.’</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And while they went to buy, the bridegroom came, and those who were ready went in with him to the wedding; and the door was shut.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Afterward the other virgins came also, saying, ‘Lord, Lord, open to us!’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But he answered and said, ‘Assuredly, I say to you, I do not know you.’</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Watch therefore, for you know neither the day nor the hour in which the Son of Man is coming.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For the kingdom of heaven is like a man traveling to a far country, who called his own servants and delivered his goods to them.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And to one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one, to each according to his own ability; and immediately he went on a journey.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then he who had received the five talents went and traded with them, and made another five talents.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And likewise he who had received two gained two more also.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But he who had received one went and dug in the ground, and hid his lord’s money.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>After a long time the lord of those servants came and settled accounts with them.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>So he who had received five talents came and brought five other talents, saying, ‘Lord, you delivered to me five talents; look, I have gained five more talents besides them.’</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>His lord said to him, ‘Well done, good and faithful servant; you were faithful over a few things, I will make you ruler over many things. Enter into the joy of your lord.’</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>He also who had received two talents came and said, ‘Lord, you delivered to me two talents; look, I have gained two more talents besides them.’</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>His lord said to him, ‘Well done, good and faithful servant; you have been faithful over a few things, I will make you ruler over many things. Enter into the joy of your lord.’</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then he who had received the one talent came and said, ‘Lord, I knew you to be a hard man, reaping where you have not sown, and gathering where you have not scattered seed.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And I was afraid, and went and hid your talent in the ground. Look, there you have what is yours.’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But his lord answered and said to him, ‘You wicked and lazy servant, you knew that I reap where I have not sown, and gather where I have not scattered seed.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>So you ought to have deposited my money with the bankers, and at my coming I would have received back my own with interest.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore take the talent from him, and give it to him who has ten talents.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For to everyone who has, more will be given, and he will have abundance; but from him who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And cast the unprofitable servant into the outer darkness. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>When the Son of Man comes in His glory, and all the holy angels with Him, then He will sit on the throne of His glory.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>All the nations will be gathered before Him, and He will separate them one from another, as a shepherd divides his sheep from the goats.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And He will set the sheep on His right hand, but the goats on the left.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then the King will say to those on His right hand, ‘Come, you blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world:</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>for I was hungry and you gave Me food; I was thirsty and you gave Me drink; I was a stranger and you took Me in;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>I was naked and you clothed Me; I was sick and you visited Me; I was in prison and you came to Me.’</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then the righteous will answer Him, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see You hungry and feed You, or thirsty and give You drink?</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>When did we see You a stranger and take You in, or naked and clothe You?</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Or when did we see You sick, or in prison, and come to You?’</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>And the King will answer and say to them, ‘Assuredly, I say to you, inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me.’</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Then He will also say to those on the left hand, ‘Depart from Me, you cursed, into the everlasting fire prepared for the devil and his angels:</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>for I was hungry and you gave Me no food; I was thirsty and you gave Me no drink;</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>I was a stranger and you did not take Me in, naked and you did not clothe Me, sick and in prison and you did not visit Me.’</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then they also will answer Him, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see You hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and did not minister to You?’</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then He will answer them, saying, ‘Assuredly, I say to you, inasmuch as you did not do it to one of the least of these, you did not do it to Me.’</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And these will go away into everlasting punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, when Jesus had finished all these sayings, that He said to His disciples,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“You know that after two days is the Passover, and the Son of Man will be delivered up to be crucified.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 2:3-3:3  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>And He said to me: “Son of man, I am sending you to the children of Israel, to a rebellious nation that has rebelled against Me; they and their fathers have transgressed against Me to this very day.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“For they are impudent and stubborn children. I am sending you to them, and you shall say to them, ‘Thus says the Lord God.’</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“As for them, whether they hear or whether they refuse – for they are a rebellious house – yet they will know that a prophet has been among them.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“And you, son of man, do not be afraid of them nor be afraid of their words, though briers and thorns are with you and you dwell among scorpions; do not be afraid of their words or dismayed by their looks, though they are a rebellious house.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“You shall speak My words to them, whether they hear or whether they refuse, for they are rebellious.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“But you, son of man, hear what I say to you. Do not be rebellious like that rebellious house; open your mouth and eat what I give you.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when I looked, there was a hand stretched out to me; and behold, a scroll of a book was in it.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then He spread it before me; and there was writing on the inside and on the outside, and written on it were lamentations and mourning and woe.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Moreover He said to me, “Son of man, eat what you find; eat this scroll, and go, speak to the house of Israel.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>So I opened my mouth, and He caused me to eat that scroll.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And He said to me, “Son of man, feed your belly, and fill your stomach with this scroll that I give you.” So I ate, and it was in my mouth like honey in sweetness.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 2:11-22  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Now it came to pass in those days, when Moses was grown, that he went out to his brethren and looked at their burdens. And he saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his brethren.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So he looked this way and that way, and when he saw no one, he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And when he went out the second day, behold, two Hebrew men were fighting, and he said to the one who did the wrong, “Why are you striking your companion?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then he said, “Who made you a prince and a judge over us? Do you intend to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?” So Moses feared and said, “Surely this thing is known!”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>When Pharaoh heard of this matter, he sought to kill Moses. But Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh and dwelt in the land of Midian; and he sat down by a well.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters. And they came and drew water, and they filled the troughs to water their father’s flock.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then the shepherds came and drove them away; but Moses stood up and helped them, and watered their flock.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>When they came to Reuel their father, he said, “How is it that you have come so soon today?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And they said, “An Egyptian delivered us from the hand of the shepherds, and he also drew enough water for us and watered the flock.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>So he said to his daughters, “And where is he? Why is it that you have left the man? Call him, that he may eat bread.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then Moses was content to live with the man, and he gave Zipporah his daughter to Moses.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And she bore him a son. He called his name Gershom, for he said, “I have been a stranger in a foreign land.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Job 2:1-10  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Again there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan came also among them to present himself before the Lord.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Satan, “From where do you come?” So Satan answered the Lord and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil? And still he holds fast to his integrity, although you incited Me against him, to destroy him without cause.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So Satan answered the Lord and said, “Skin for skin! Yes, all that a man has he will give for his life.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“But stretch out Your hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will surely curse You to Your face!”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Satan, “Behold, he is in your hand, but spare his life.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord, and struck Job with painful boils from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And he took for himself a potsherd with which to scrape himself while he sat in the midst of the ashes.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast to your integrity? Curse God and die!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women speaks. Shall we indeed accept good from God, and shall we not accept adversity?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 12:17-50  (Gospel Matins)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore the people, who were with Him when He called Lazarus out of his tomb and raised him from the dead, bore witness.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For this reason the people also met Him, because they heard that He had done this sign.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The Pharisees therefore said among themselves, “You see that you are accomplishing nothing.
