readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>But God forbid that I should boast except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision avails anything, but a new creation.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And as many as walk according to this rule, peace and mercy be upon them, and upon the Israel of God.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>From now on let no one trouble me, for I bear in my body the marks of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Brethren, the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 27:1-56  (1st Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>When morning came, all the chief priests and elders of the people plotted against Jesus to put Him to death.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And when they had bound Him, they led Him away and delivered Him to Pontius Pilate the governor.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Judas, His betrayer, seeing that He had been condemned, was remorseful and brought back the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>saying, “I have sinned by betraying innocent blood.” And they said, “What is that to us? You see to it!”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then he threw down the pieces of silver in the temple and departed, and went and hanged himself.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But the chief priests took the silver pieces and said, “It is not lawful to put them into the treasury, because they are the price of blood.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And they consulted together and bought with them the potter’s field, to bury strangers in.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore that field has been called the Field of Blood to this day.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then was fulfilled what was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, saying, “And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the value of Him who was priced, whom they of the children of Israel priced,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>and gave them for the potter’s field, as the LORD directed me.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now Jesus stood before the governor. And the governor asked Him, saying, “Are You the King of the Jews?” Jesus said to him, “It is as you say.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And while He was being accused by the chief priests and elders, He answered nothing.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Pilate said to Him, “Do You not hear how many things they testify against You?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But He answered him not one word, so that the governor marveled greatly.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Now at the feast the governor was accustomed to releasing to the multitude one prisoner whom they wished.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And at that time they had a notorious prisoner called Barabbas. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, when they had gathered together, Pilate said to them, “Whom do you want me to release to you? Barabbas, or Jesus who is called Christ?”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For he knew that they had handed Him over because of envy.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent to him, saying, “Have nothing to do with that just Man, for I have suffered many things today in a dream because of Him.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitudes that they should ask for Barabbas and destroy Jesus.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>The governor answered and said to them, “Which of the two do you want me to release to you?” They said, “Barabbas!”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Pilate said to them, “What then shall I do with Jesus who is called Christ?” They all said to him, “Let Him be crucified!”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then the governor said, “Why, what evil has He done?” But they cried out all the more, saying, “Let Him be crucified!”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When Pilate saw that he could not prevail at all, but rather that a tumult was rising, he took water and washed his hands before the multitude, saying, “I am innocent of the blood of this just Person. You see to it.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And all the people answered and said, “His blood be on us and on our children.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then he released Barabbas to them; and when he had scourged Jesus, he delivered Him to be crucified.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the Praetorium and gathered the whole garrison around Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And they stripped Him and put a scarlet robe on Him.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>When they had twisted a crown of thorns, they put it on His head, and a reed in His right hand. And they bowed the knee before Him and mocked Him, saying, “Hail, King of the Jews!”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then they spat on Him, and took the reed and struck Him on the head.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And when they had mocked Him, they took the robe off Him, put His own clothes on Him, and led Him away to be crucified.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Now as they came out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name. Him they compelled to bear His cross.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And when they had come to a place called Golgotha, that is to say, Place of a Skull,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>they gave Him sour wine mingled with gall to drink. But when He had tasted it, He would not drink.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then they crucified Him, and divided His garments, casting lots, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet: “They divided My garments among them, and for My clothing they cast lots.” </dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Sitting down, they kept watch over Him there.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And they put up over His head the accusation written against Him: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then two robbers were crucified with Him, one on the right and another on the left.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And those who passed by blasphemed Him, wagging their heads</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>and saying, “You who destroy the temple and build it in three days, save Yourself! If You are the Son of God, come down from the cross.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Likewise the chief priests also, mocking with the scribes and elders, said,</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>“He saved others; Himself He cannot save. If He is the King of Israel, let Him now come down from the cross, and we will believe Him. </dd><dt>43</dt><dd>He trusted in God; let Him deliver Him now if He will have Him; for He said, ‘I am the Son of God.’”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Even the robbers who were crucified with Him reviled Him with the same thing.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Now from the sixth hour until the ninth hour there was darkness over all the land.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And about the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, “Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani?” that is, “My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?” </dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Some of those who stood there, when they heard that, said, “This Man is calling for Elijah!”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Immediately one of them ran and took a sponge, filled it with sour wine and put it on a reed, and offered it to Him to drink.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>The rest said, “Let Him alone; let us see if Elijah will come to save Him.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>And Jesus cried out again with a loud voice, and yielded up His spirit.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Then, behold, the veil of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom; and the earth quaked, and the rocks were split,</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>and the graves were opened; and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised;</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>and coming out of the graves after His resurrection, they went into the holy city and appeared to many.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>So when the centurion and those with him, who were guarding Jesus, saw the earthquake and the things that had happened, they feared greatly, saying, “Truly this was the Son of God!”</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>And many women who followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering to Him, were there looking on from afar,</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>among whom were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of Zebedee’s sons.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 50:4-11  (3rd Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>“The Lord God has given Me the tongue of the learned, that I should know how to speak a word in season to him who is weary. He awakens Me morning by morning, He awakens My ear to hear as the learned.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The Lord God has opened My ear; and I was not rebellious, nor did I turn away.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>I gave My back to those who struck Me, and My cheeks to those who plucked out the beard; I did not hide My face from shame and spitting. </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“For the Lord God will help Me; therefore I will not be disgraced; therefore I have set My face like a flint, and I know that I will not be ashamed.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He is near who justifies Me; who will contend with Me? Let us stand together. Who is My adversary? Let him come near Me.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Surely the Lord God will help Me; who is he who will condemn Me? Indeed they will all grow old like a garment; the moth will eat them up.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“Who among you fears the Lord? Who obeys the voice of His Servant? Who walks in darkness and has no light? Let him trust in the name of the Lord and rely upon his God.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Look, all you who kindle a fire, who encircle yourselves with sparks: Walk in the light of your fire and in the sparks you have kindled – this you shall have from My hand: you shall lie down in torment.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 5:6-11  (3rd Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>For when we were still without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For scarcely for a righteous man will one die; yet perhaps for a good man someone would even dare to die.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But God demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Much more then, having now been justified by His blood, we shall be saved from wrath through Him.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, having been reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And not only that, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received the reconciliation.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 15:16-41  (3rd Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Then the soldiers led Him away into the hall called Praetorium, and they called together the whole garrison.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And they clothed Him with purple; and they twisted a crown of thorns, put it on His head,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>and began to salute Him, “Hail, King of the Jews!”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then they struck Him on the head with a reed and spat on Him; and bowing the knee, they worshiped Him.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And when they had mocked Him, they took the purple off Him, put His own clothes on Him, and led Him out to crucify Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then they compelled a certain man, Simon a Cyrenian, the father of Alexander and Rufus, as he was coming out of the country and passing by, to bear His cross.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And they brought Him to the place Golgotha, which is translated, Place of a Skull.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then they gave Him wine mingled with myrrh to drink, but He did not take it.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And when they crucified Him, they divided His garments, casting lots for them to determine what every man should take.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Now it was the third hour, and they crucified Him.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And the inscription of His accusation was written above: THE KING OF THE JEWS.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>With Him they also crucified two robbers, one on His right and the other on His left.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So the Scripture was fulfilled which says, “And He was numbered with the transgressors.” </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And those who passed by blasphemed Him, wagging their heads and saying, “Aha! You who destroy the temple and build it in three days,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>save Yourself, and come down from the cross!”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Likewise the chief priests also, mocking among themselves with the scribes, said, “He saved others; Himself He cannot save.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Let the Christ, the King of Israel, descend now from the cross, that we may see and believe.” Even those who were crucified with Him reviled Him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Now when the sixth hour had come, there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>And at the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, “Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?” which is translated, “My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?” </dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Some of those who stood by, when they heard that, said, “Look, He is calling for Elijah!”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then someone ran and filled a sponge full of sour wine, put it on a reed, and offered it to Him to drink, saying, “Let Him alone; let us see if Elijah will come to take Him down.”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And Jesus cried out with a loud voice, and breathed His last.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then the veil of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>So when the centurion, who stood opposite Him, saw that He cried out like this and breathed His last, he said, “Truly this Man was the Son of God!”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>There were also women looking on from afar, among whom were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James the Less and of Joses, and Salome,</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>who also followed Him and ministered to Him when He was in Galilee, and many other women who came up with Him to Jerusalem.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 52:13-54:1  (6th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Behold, My Servant shall deal prudently; He shall be exalted and extolled and be very high. </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Just as many were astonished at you, so His visage was marred more than any man, and His form more than the sons of men; </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>so shall He sprinkle many nations. Kings shall shut their mouths at Him; for what had not been told them they shall see, and what they had not heard they shall consider.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Who has believed our report? And to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For He shall grow up before Him as a tender plant, and as a root out of dry ground. He has no form or comeliness; and when we see Him, there is no beauty that we should desire Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>He is despised and rejected by men, a Man of sorrows and acquainted with grief. and we hid, as it were, our faces from Him; He was despised, and we did not esteem Him. </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Surely He has borne our griefs and carried our sorrows; yet we esteemed Him stricken, smitten by God, and afflicted.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities; the chastisement for our peace was upon Him, and by His stripes we are healed. </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned, every one, to his own way; and the Lord has laid on Him the iniquity of us all. </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>He was oppressed and He was afflicted, yet He opened not His mouth; He was led as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before its shearers is silent, so He opened not His mouth.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He was taken from prison and from judgment, and who will declare His generation? For He was cut off from the land of the living; for the transgressions of My people He was stricken.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And they made His grave with the wicked – but with the rich at His death, because He had done no violence, nor was any deceit in His mouth.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Yet it pleased the Lord to bruise Him; He has put Him to grief. When You make His soul an offering for sin, He shall see His seed, He shall prolong His days, and the pleasure of the Lord shall prosper in His hand.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He shall see the labor of His soul, and be satisfied. By His knowledge My righteous servant shall justify many, for He shall bear their iniquities.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore I will divide Him a portion with the great, and He shall divide the spoil with the strong, because He poured out His soul unto death, and He was numbered with the transgressors, and He bore the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>“Sing, O barren, you who have not borne! Break forth into singing, and cry aloud, you who have not labored with child! For more are the children of the desolate than the children of the married woman,” says the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Amos 8:9-12  (6th Hour alternate)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>“And it shall come to pass in that day,” says the Lord God, “That I will make the sun go down at noon, And I will darken the earth in broad daylight;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>I will turn your feasts into mourning, And all your songs into lamentation; I will bring sackcloth on every waist, And baldness on every head; I will make it like mourning for an only son, And its end like a bitter day.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Behold, the days are coming,” says the Lord God, “That I will send a famine on the land, Not a famine of bread, Nor a thirst for water, But of hearing the words of the Lord.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>They shall wander from sea to sea, And from north to east; They shall run to and fro, seeking the word of the Lord, But shall not find it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 2:11-18  (6th Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>For both He who sanctifies and those who are being sanctified are all of one, for which reason He is not ashamed to call them brethren,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>saying: “I will declare Your name to My brethren; in the midst of the assembly I will sing praise to You.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And again: “I will put My trust in Him.” And again: “Here am I and the children whom God has given Me.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Inasmuch then as the children have partaken of flesh and blood, He Himself likewise shared in the same, that through death He might destroy him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and release those who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For indeed He does not give aid to angels, but He does give aid to the seed of Abraham.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, in all things He had to be made like His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things pertaining to God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For in that He Himself has suffered, being tempted, He is able to aid those who are tempted.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 23:32-49  (6th Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>There were also two others, criminals, led with Him to be put to death.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And when they had come to the place called Calvary, there they crucified Him, and the criminals, one on the right hand and the other on the left.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then Jesus said, “Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they do.” And they divided His garments and cast lots.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And the people stood looking on. But even the rulers with them sneered, saying, “He saved others; let Him save Himself if He is the Christ, the chosen of God.”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>The soldiers also mocked Him, coming and offering Him sour wine,</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>and saying, “If You are the King of the Jews, save Yourself.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And an inscription also was written over Him in letters of Greek, Latin, and Hebrew: THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Then one of the criminals who were hanged blasphemed Him, saying, “If You are the Christ, save Yourself and us.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But the other, answering, rebuked him, saying, “Do you not even fear God, seeing you are under the same condemnation?</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And we indeed justly, for we receive the due reward of our deeds; but this Man has done nothing wrong.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Then he said to Jesus, “Lord, remember me when You come into Your kingdom.”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>And Jesus said to him, “Assuredly, I say to you, today you will be with Me in Paradise.”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Now it was about the sixth hour, and there was darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then the sun was darkened, and the veil of the temple was torn in two.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And when Jesus had cried out with a loud voice, He said, “Father, into Your hands I commit My spirit.” Having said this, He breathed His last.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>So when the centurion saw what had happened, he glorified God, saying, “Certainly this was a righteous Man!”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>And the whole crowd who came together to that sight, seeing what had been done, beat their breasts and returned.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>But all His acquaintances, and the women who followed Him from Galilee, stood at a distance, watching these things.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jeremiah 11:18-12:5 9:11 14-15  (9th Hour)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>The Lord made it known to me and I knew; then thou didst show me their evil deeds.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But, I was like a gentle lamb led to the slaughter. I did not know it was against me they devised schemes, saying, “Let us destroy the tree with its fruit, let us cut him off from the land of the living, that his name be remembered no more.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But, O Lord of hosts, who judgest righteously, who triest the heart and the mind, let me see thy vengeance upon them, for to thee have I committed my cause.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the men of An’athoth, who seek your life, and say, “Do not prophesy in the name of the Lord, or you will die by our hand”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>therefore, thus says the Lord of hosts: “Behold, I will punish them; the young men shall die by the sword; their sons and their daughters shall die by famine;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>and none of them shall be left. For I will bring evil upon men of An’athoth, the year of their punishment.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Righteous art thou, O Lord, when I complain to thee; yet I would plead my case before thee. Why does the way of the wicked prosper? Why do all who are treacherous thrive?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Thou plantest them, and they take root; they grow and bring forth fruit; thou art near in their mouth and far from their heart.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But thou, O Lord, knowest me; thou seest me, and triest my mind toward thee. Pull them out like sheep for the slaughter, and set them apart for the day of slaughter.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>How long will the land mourn, and the grass of every field wither? For the wickedness of those who dwell in it the beasts and the birds are swept away, because men said, “He will not see our latter end.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>If you have raced with men on foot, and they have wearied you, how will you compete with horses? And if in a safe land you fall down, how will you do in the jungle of the Jordan?</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 10:19-31  (9th Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Therefore, brethren, having boldness to enter the Holiest by the blood of Jesus,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>by a new and living way which He consecrated for us, through the veil, that is, His flesh,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>and having a High Priest over the house of God,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience and our bodies washed with pure water.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Let us hold fast the confession of our hope without wavering, for He who promised is faithful.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And let us consider one another in order to stir up love and good works,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as is the manner of some, but exhorting one another, and so much the more as you see the Day approaching.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For if we sin willfully after we have received the knowledge of the truth, there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>but a certain fearful expectation of judgment, and fiery indignation which will devour the adversaries.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Anyone who has rejected Moses’ law dies without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Of how much worse punishment, do you suppose, will he be thought worthy who has trampled the Son of God underfoot, counted the blood of the covenant by which he was sanctified a common thing, and insulted the Spirit of grace?</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For we know Him who said, “Vengeance is Mine, I will repay,” says the Lord. And again, “The LORD will judge His people.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 18:28-19:37  (9th Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>Then they led Jesus from Caiaphas to the Praetorium, and it was early morning. But they themselves did not go into the Praetorium, lest they should be defiled, but that they might eat the Passover.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Pilate then went out to them and said, “What accusation do you bring against this Man?”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>They answered and said to him, “If He were not an evildoer, we would not have delivered Him up to you.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then Pilate said to them, “You take Him and judge Him according to your law.” Therefore the Jews said to him, “It is not lawful for us to put anyone to death,”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>that the saying of Jesus might be fulfilled which He spoke, signifying by what death He would die.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Then Pilate entered the Praetorium again, called Jesus, and said to Him, “Are You the King of the Jews?”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Jesus answered him, “Are you speaking for yourself about this, or did others tell you this concerning Me?”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Pilate answered, “Am I a Jew? Your own nation and the chief priests have delivered You to me. What have You done?”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Jesus answered, “My kingdom is not of this world. If My kingdom were of this world, My servants would fight, so that I should not be delivered to the Jews; but now My kingdom is not from here.”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Pilate therefore said to Him, “Are You a king then?” Jesus answered, “You say rightly that I am a king. For this cause I was born, and for this cause I have come into the world, that I should bear witness to the truth. Everyone who is of the truth hears My voice.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Pilate said to Him, “What is truth?” And when he had said this, he went out again to the Jews, and said to them, “I find no fault in Him at all.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But you have a custom that I should release someone to you at the Passover. Do you therefore want me to release to you the King of the Jews?”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Then they all cried again, saying, “Not this Man, but Barabbas!” Now Barabbas was a robber.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>So then Pilate took Jesus and scourged Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the soldiers twisted a crown of thorns and put it on His head, and they put on Him a purple robe.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they said, “Hail, King of the Jews!” And they struck Him with their hands.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Pilate then went out again, and said to them, “Behold, I am bringing Him out to you, that you may know that I find no fault in Him.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Jesus came out, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. And Pilate said to them, “Behold the Man!”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Therefore, when the chief priests and officers saw Him, they cried out, saying, “Crucify Him, crucify Him!” Pilate said to them, “You take Him and crucify Him, for I find no fault in Him.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>The Jews answered him, “We have a law, and according to our law He ought to die, because He made Himself the Son of God.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore, when Pilate heard that saying, he was the more afraid,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>and went again into the Praetorium, and said to Jesus, “Where are You from?” But Jesus gave him no answer.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then Pilate said to Him, “Are You not speaking to me? Do You not know that I have power to crucify You, and power to release You?”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Jesus answered, “You could have no power at all against Me unless it had been given you from above. Therefore the one who delivered Me to you has the greater sin.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>From then on Pilate sought to release Him, but the Jews cried out, saying, “If you let this Man go, you are not Caesar’s friend. Whoever makes himself a king speaks against Caesar.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>When Pilate therefore heard that saying, he brought Jesus out and sat down in the judgment seat in a place that is called The Pavement, but in Hebrew, Gabbatha.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now it was the Preparation Day of the Passover, and about the sixth hour. And he said to the Jews, “Behold your King!”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But they cried out, “Away with Him, away with Him! Crucify Him!” Pilate said to them, “Shall I crucify your King?” The chief priests answered, “We have no king but Caesar!”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then he delivered Him to them to be crucified. So they took Jesus and led Him away. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And He, bearing His cross, went out to a place called the Place of a Skull, which is called in Hebrew, Golgotha,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>where they crucified Him, and two others with Him, one on either side, and Jesus in the center.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Now Pilate wrote a title and put it on the cross. And the writing was: JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWS.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then many of the Jews read this title, for the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city; and it was written in Hebrew, Greek, and Latin.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Therefore the chief priests of the Jews said to Pilate, “Do not write, ‘The King of the Jews,’ but, ‘He said, “I am the King of the Jews.”’”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Pilate answered, “What I have written, I have written.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then the soldiers, when they had crucified Jesus, took His garments and made four parts, to each soldier a part, and also the tunic. Now the tunic was without seam, woven from the top in one piece.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>They said therefore among themselves, “Let us not tear it, but cast lots for it, whose it shall be,” that the Scripture might be fulfilled which says: They divided My garments among them, and for My clothing they cast lots.” Therefore the soldiers did this.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Now there stood by the cross of Jesus His mother, and His mother’s sister, Mary the wife of Clopas, and Mary Magdalene.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>When Jesus therefore saw His mother, and the disciple whom He loved standing by, He said to His mother, “Woman, behold your son!”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then He said to the disciple, “Behold your mother!” And from that hour that disciple took her to his own home.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>After this, Jesus, knowing that all things were now accomplished, that the Scripture might be fulfilled, said, “I thirst!”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Now a vessel full of sour wine was sitting there; and they filled a sponge with sour wine, put it on hyssop, and put it to His mouth.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>So when Jesus had received the sour wine, He said, “It is finished!” And bowing His head, He gave up His spirit.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore, because it was the Preparation Day, that the bodies should not remain on the cross on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath was a high day), the Jews asked Pilate that their legs might be broken, and that they might be taken away.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first and of the other who was crucified with Him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But when they came to Jesus and saw that He was already dead, they did not break His legs.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But one of the soldiers pierced His side with a spear, and immediately blood and water came out.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And he who has seen has testified, and his testimony is true; and he knows that he is telling the truth, so that you may believe.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>For these things were done that the Scripture should be fulfilled, “Not one of His bones shall be broken.” </dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And again another Scripture says, “They shall look on Him whom they pierced.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 33:11-23  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>So the Lord spoke to Moses face to face, as a man speaks to his friend. And he would return to the camp, but his servant Joshua the son of Nun, a young man, did not depart from the tabernacle.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then Moses said to the Lord, “See, You say to me, ‘Bring up this people.’ But You have not let me know whom You will send with me. Yet You have said, ‘I know you by name, and you have also found grace in My sight.’</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>“Now therefore, I pray, if I have found grace in Your sight, show me now Your way, that I may know You and that I may find grace in Your sight. And consider that this nation is Your people.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And He said, “My Presence will go with you, and I will give you rest.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then he said to Him, “If Your Presence does not go with us, do not bring us up from here.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“For how then will it be known that Your people and I have found grace in Your sight, except You go with us? So we shall be separate, Your people and I, from all the people who are upon the face of the earth.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So the Lord said to Moses, “I will also do this thing that you have spoken; for you have found grace in My sight, and I know you by name.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And he said, “Please, show me Your glory.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then He said, “I will make all My goodness pass before you, and I will proclaim the name of the Lord before you. I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But He said, “You cannot see My face; for no man shall see Me, and live.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “Here is a place by Me, and you shall stand on the rock.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>“So it shall be, while My glory passes by, that I will put you in the cleft of the rock, and will cover you with My hand while I pass by.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>“Then I will take away My hand, and you shall see My back; but My face shall not be seen.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Job 42:12-17 LXX  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Now the Lord blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning; for he had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand yoke of oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>He also had seven sons and three daughters.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And he called the name of the first Jemimah, the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-Happuch.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>In all the land were found no women so beautiful as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>After this Job lived one hundred and forty years, and saw his children and grandchildren for four generations.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So Job died, old and full of days. And it was also written that he will rise with those whom our Lord shall raise.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 52:13-54:1  (Vespers 3rd  reading Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Behold, My Servant shall deal prudently; He shall be exalted and extolled and be very high. </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Just as many were astonished at you, so His visage was marred more than any man, and His form more than the sons of men; </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>so shall He sprinkle many nations. Kings shall shut their mouths at Him; for what had not been told them they shall see, and what they had not heard they shall consider.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Who has believed our report? And to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For He shall grow up before Him as a tender plant, and as a root out of dry ground. He has no form or comeliness; and when we see Him, there is no beauty that we should desire Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>He is despised and rejected by men, a Man of sorrows and acquainted with grief. and we hid, as it were, our faces from Him; He was despised, and we did not esteem Him. </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Surely He has borne our griefs and carried our sorrows; yet we esteemed Him stricken, smitten by God, and afflicted.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities; the chastisement for our peace was upon Him, and by His stripes we are healed. </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned, every one, to his own way; and the Lord has laid on Him the iniquity of us all. </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>He was oppressed and He was afflicted, yet He opened not His mouth; He was led as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before its shearers is silent, so He opened not His mouth.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He was taken from prison and from judgment, and who will declare His generation? For He was cut off from the land of the living; for the transgressions of My people He was stricken.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And they made His grave with the wicked – but with the rich at His death, because He had done no violence, nor was any deceit in His mouth.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Yet it pleased the Lord to bruise Him; He has put Him to grief. When You make His soul an offering for sin, He shall see His seed, He shall prolong His days, and the pleasure of the Lord shall prosper in His hand.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He shall see the labor of His soul, and be satisfied. By His knowledge My righteous servant shall justify many, for He shall bear their iniquities.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore I will divide Him a portion with the great, and He shall divide the spoil with the strong, because He poured out His soul unto death, and He was numbered with the transgressors, and He bore the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>“Sing, O barren, you who have not borne! Break forth into singing, and cry aloud, you who have not labored with child! For more are the children of the desolate than the children of the married woman,” says the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 1:18-2:2  (Epistle Vespers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>For the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For it is written:</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Where is the wise? Where is the scribe? Where is the disputer of this age? Has not God made foolish the wisdom of this world?</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For since, in the wisdom of God, the world through wisdom did not know God, it pleased God through the foolishness of the message preached to save those who believe.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For Jews request a sign, and Greeks seek after wisdom;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>but we preach Christ crucified, to the Jews a stumbling block and to the Greeks foolishness,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>but to those who are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Because the foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For you see your calling, brethren, that not many wise according to the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are called.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But God has chosen the foolish things of the world to put to shame the wise, and God has chosen the weak things of the world to put to shame the things which are mighty;</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>and the base things of the world and the things which are despised God has chosen, and the things which are not, to bring to nothing the things that are,</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>that no flesh should glory in His presence.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But of Him you are in Christ Jesus, who became for us wisdom from God – and righteousness and sanctification and redemption – </dd><dt>31</dt><dd>that, as it is written, “He who glories, let him glory in the LORD.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And I, brethren, when I came to you, did not come with excellence of speech or of wisdom declaring to you the testimony of God.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For I determined not to know anything among you except Jesus Christ and Him crucified.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matt 27:1-38 Luke 23:39-43 Matt 27:39-54 John 19:31-37 Matt 27:55-61  (Gospel Composite)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>When morning came, all the chief priests and elders of the people plotted against Jesus to put Him to death.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And when they had bound Him, they led Him away and delivered Him to Pontius Pilate the governor.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Judas, His betrayer, seeing that He had been condemned, was remorseful and brought back the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>saying, “I have sinned by betraying innocent blood.” And they said, “What is that to us? You see to it!”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then he threw down the pieces of silver in the temple and departed, and went and hanged himself.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But the chief priests took the silver pieces and said, “It is not lawful to put them into the treasury, because they are the price of blood.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And they consulted together and bought with them the potter’s field, to bury strangers in.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore that field has been called the Field of Blood to this day.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then was fulfilled what was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, saying, “And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the value of Him who was priced, whom they of the children of Israel priced,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>and gave them for the potter’s field, as the LORD directed me.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now Jesus stood before the governor. And the governor asked Him, saying, “Are You the King of the Jews?” Jesus said to him, “It is as you say.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And while He was being accused by the chief priests and elders, He answered nothing.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Pilate said to Him, “Do You not hear how many things they testify against You?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But He answered him not one word, so that the governor marveled greatly.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Now at the feast the governor was accustomed to releasing to the multitude one prisoner whom they wished.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And at that time they had a notorious prisoner called Barabbas. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, when they had gathered together, Pilate said to them, “Whom do you want me to release to you? Barabbas, or Jesus who is called Christ?”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For he knew that they had handed Him over because of envy.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent to him, saying, “Have nothing to do with that just Man, for I have suffered many things today in a dream because of Him.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitudes that they should ask for Barabbas and destroy Jesus.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>The governor answered and said to them, “Which of the two do you want me to release to you?” They said, “Barabbas!”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Pilate said to them, “What then shall I do with Jesus who is called Christ?” They all said to him, “Let Him be crucified!”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then the governor said, “Why, what evil has He done?” But they cried out all the more, saying, “Let Him be crucified!”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When Pilate saw that he could not prevail at all, but rather that a tumult was rising, he took water and washed his hands before the multitude, saying, “I am innocent of the blood of this just Person. You see to it.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And all the people answered and said, “His blood be on us and on our children.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then he released Barabbas to them; and when he had scourged Jesus, he delivered Him to be crucified.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the Praetorium and gathered the whole garrison around Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And they stripped Him and put a scarlet robe on Him.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>When they had twisted a crown of thorns, they put it on His head, and a reed in His right hand. And they bowed the knee before Him and mocked Him, saying, “Hail, King of the Jews!”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then they spat on Him, and took the reed and struck Him on the head.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And when they had mocked Him, they took the robe off Him, put His own clothes on Him, and led Him away to be crucified.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Now as they came out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name. Him they compelled to bear His cross.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And when they had come to a place called Golgotha, that is to say, Place of a Skull,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>they gave Him sour wine mingled with gall to drink. But when He had tasted it, He would not drink.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then they crucified Him, and divided His garments, casting lots, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet: “They divided My garments among them, and for My clothing they cast lots.” </dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Sitting down, they kept watch over Him there.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And they put up over His head the accusation written against Him: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then two robbers were crucified with Him, one on the right and another on the left.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Then one of the criminals who were hanged blasphemed Him, saying, “If You are the Christ, save Yourself and us.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But the other, answering, rebuked him, saying, “Do you not even fear God, seeing you are under the same condemnation?</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And we indeed justly, for we receive the due reward of our deeds; but this Man has done nothing wrong.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Then he said to Jesus, “Lord, remember me when You come into Your kingdom.”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>And Jesus said to him, “Assuredly, I say to you, today you will be with Me in Paradise.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And those who passed by blasphemed Him, wagging their heads</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>and saying, “You who destroy the temple and build it in three days, save Yourself! If You are the Son of God, come down from the cross.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Likewise the chief priests also, mocking with the scribes and elders, said,</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>“He saved others; Himself He cannot save. If He is the King of Israel, let Him now come down from the cross, and we will believe Him. </dd><dt>43</dt><dd>He trusted in God; let Him deliver Him now if He will have Him; for He said, ‘I am the Son of God.’”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Even the robbers who were crucified with Him reviled Him with the same thing.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Now from the sixth hour until the ninth hour there was darkness over all the land.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And about the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, “Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani?” that is, “My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?” </dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Some of those who stood there, when they heard that, said, “This Man is calling for Elijah!”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Immediately one of them ran and took a sponge, filled it with sour wine and put it on a reed, and offered it to Him to drink.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>The rest said, “Let Him alone; let us see if Elijah will come to save Him.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>And Jesus cried out again with a loud voice, and yielded up His spirit.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Then, behold, the veil of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom; and the earth quaked, and the rocks were split,</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>and the graves were opened; and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised;</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>and coming out of the graves after His resurrection, they went into the holy city and appeared to many.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>So when the centurion and those with him, who were guarding Jesus, saw the earthquake and the things that had happened, they feared greatly, saying, “Truly this was the Son of God!”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore, because it was the Preparation Day, that the bodies should not remain on the cross on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath was a high day), the Jews asked Pilate that their legs might be broken, and that they might be taken away.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first and of the other who was crucified with Him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But when they came to Jesus and saw that He was already dead, they did not break His legs.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But one of the soldiers pierced His side with a spear, and immediately blood and water came out.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And he who has seen has testified, and his testimony is true; and he knows that he is telling the truth, so that you may believe.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>For these things were done that the Scripture should be fulfilled, “Not one of His bones shall be broken.” </dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And again another Scripture says, “They shall look on Him whom they pierced.” </dd><dt>55</dt><dd>And many women who followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering to Him, were there looking on from afar,</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>among whom were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of Zebedee’s sons.</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>Now when evening had come, there came a rich man from Arimathea, named Joseph, who himself had also become a disciple of Jesus.</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded the body to be given to him.</dd><dt>59</dt><dd>When Joseph had taken the body, he wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,</dd><dt>60</dt><dd>and laid it in his new tomb which he had hewn out of the rock; and he rolled a large stone against the door of the tomb, and departed.</dd><dt>61</dt><dd>And Mary Magdalene was there, and the other Mary, sitting opposite the tomb.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 37:1-14  (Matins)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The hand of the Lord came upon me and brought me out in the Spirit of the Lord, and set me down in the midst of the valley; and it was full of bones.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He caused me to pass by them all around, and behold, there were very many in the open valley; and indeed they were very dry.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And He said to me, “Son of man, can these bones live?” So I answered, “O Lord God, You know.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Again He said to me, “Prophesy to these bones, and say to them, ‘O dry bones, hear the word of the Lord!</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord God to these bones: “Surely I will cause breath to enter into you, and you shall live.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>I will put sinews on you and bring flesh upon you, cover you with skin and put breath in you; and you shall live. Then you shall know that I am the Lord.”’”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So I prophesied as I was commanded; and as I prophesied, there was a noise, and suddenly a rattling; and the bones came together, bone to bone.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Indeed, as I looked, the sinews and the flesh came upon them, and the skin covered them over; but there was no breath in them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Also He said to me, “Prophesy to the breath, prophesy, son of man, and say to the breath, ‘Thus says the Lord God: “Come from the four winds, O breath, and breathe on these slain, that they may live.”’”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>So I prophesied as He commanded me, and breath came into them, and they lived, and stood upon their feet, an exceedingly great army.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then He said to me, “Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel. They indeed say, ‘Our bones are dry, our hope is lost, and we ourselves are cut off!’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore prophesy and say to them, ‘Thus says the Lord God: “Behold, O My people, I will open your graves and cause you to come up from your graves, and bring you into the land of Israel.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then you shall know that I am the Lord, when I have opened your graves, O My people, and brought you up from your graves.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I will put My Spirit in you, and you shall live, and I will place you in your own land. Then you shall know that I, the Lord, have spoken it and performed it,” says the Lord.’”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 5:6-8 Galatians 3:13-14  (Matins Epistle composite)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>Your glorying is not good. Do you not know that a little leaven leavens the whole lump?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore purge out the old leaven, that you may be a new lump, since you truly are unleavened. For indeed Christ, our Passover, was sacrificed for us.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore let us keep the feast, not with old leaven, nor with the leaven of malice and wickedness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Christ has redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us (for it is written, “Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree”),</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>that the blessing of Abraham might come upon the Gentiles in Christ Jesus, that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 27:62-66  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>62</dt><dd>On the next day, which followed the Day of Preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees gathered together to Pilate,</dd><dt>63</dt><dd>saying, “Sir, we remember, while He was still alive, how that deceiver said, ‘After three days I will rise.’</dd><dt>64</dt><dd>Therefore command that the tomb be made secure until the third day, lest His disciples come by night and steal Him away, and say to the people, ‘He has risen from the dead.’ So the last deception will be worse than the first.”</dd><dt>65</dt><dd>Pilate said to them, “You have a guard; go your way, make it as secure as you know how.”</dd><dt>66</dt><dd>So they went and made the tomb secure, sealing the stone and setting the guard.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 1:1-13  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The earth was without form, and void; and darkness was on the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the face of the waters.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be light”; and there was light.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And God saw the light, that it was good; and God divided the light from the darkness.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>God called the light Day, and the darkness He called Night. So the evening and the morning were the first day.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Thus God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament; and it was so.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And God called the firmament Heaven. So the evening and the morning were the second day.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the waters under the heavens be gathered together into one place, and let the dry land appear”; and it was so.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And God called the dry land Earth, and the gathering together of the waters He called Seas. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb that yields seed, and the fruit tree that yields fruit according to its kind, whose seed is in itself, on the earth”; and it was so.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the earth brought forth grass, the herb that yields seed according to its kind, and the tree that yields fruit, whose seed is in itself according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So the evening and the morning were the third day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 60:1-16  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Arise, shine; for your light has come! And the glory of the Lord is risen upon you. </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For behold, the darkness shall cover the earth, and deep darkness the people; but the Lord will arise over you, and His glory will be seen upon you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The Gentiles shall come to your light, and kings to the brightness of your rising.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“Lift up your eyes all around, and see: They all gather together, they come to you; your sons shall come from afar, and your daughters shall be nursed at your side.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then you shall see and become radiant, and your heart shall swell with joy; because the abundance of the sea shall be turned to you, the wealth of the Gentiles shall come to you.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The multitude of camels shall cover your land, the dromedaries of Midian and Ephah; all those from Sheba shall come; they shall bring gold and incense, and they shall proclaim the praises of the Lord. </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>All the flocks of Kedar shall be gathered together to you, the rams of Nebaioth shall minister to you; they shall ascend with acceptance on My altar, and I will glorify the house of My glory.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“Who are these who fly like a cloud, and like doves to their roosts?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Surely the coastlands shall wait for Me; and the ships of Tarshish will come first, to bring your sons from afar, their silver and their gold with them, to the name of the Lord your God, and to the Holy One of Israel, because He has glorified you.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“The sons of foreigners shall build up your walls, and their kings shall minister to you; for in My wrath I struck you, but in My favor I have had mercy on you.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore your gates shall be open continually; they shall not be shut day or night, that men may bring to you the wealth of the Gentiles, and their kings in procession.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the nation and kingdom which will not serve you shall perish, and those nations shall be utterly ruined.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>“The glory of Lebanon shall come to you, the cypress, the pine, and the box tree together, to beautify the place of My sanctuary; and I will make the place of My feet glorious.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Also the sons of those who afflicted you shall come bowing to you, and all those who despised you shall fall prostrate at the soles of your feet; and they shall call you the City of the Lord, Zion of the Holy One of Israel.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Whereas you have been forsaken and hated, so that no one went through you, I will make you an eternal excellence, a joy of many generations.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>You shall drink the milk of the Gentiles, and milk the breast of kings; you shall know that I, the Lord, am your Savior and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 12:1-11  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt, saying,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“This month shall be your beginning of months; it shall be the first month of the year to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Speak to all the congregation of Israel, saying: ‘On the tenth of this month every man shall take for himself a lamb, according to the house of his father, a lamb for a household.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>‘And if the household is too small for the lamb, let him and his neighbor next to his house take it according to the number of the persons; according to each man’s need you shall make your count for the lamb.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>‘Your lamb shall be without blemish, a male of the first year. You may take it from the sheep or from the goats.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>‘Now you shall keep it until the fourteenth day of the same month. Then the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall kill it at twilight.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>‘And they shall take some of the blood and put it on the two doorposts and on the lintel of the houses where they eat it.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>‘Then they shall eat the flesh on that night; roasted in fire, with unleavened bread and with bitter herbs they shall eat it.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>‘Do not eat it raw, nor boiled at all with water, but roasted in fire – its head with its legs and its entrails.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>‘You shall let none of it remain until morning, and what remains of it until morning you shall burn with fire.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>‘And thus you shall eat it: with a belt on your waist, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. So you shall eat it in haste. It is the Lord’s Passover.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jonah 1:1-4:11  (Vespers 4th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the word of the Lord came to Jonah the son of Amit’tai, saying</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and cry against it; for their wickedness has come up before me.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But Jonah rose to flee to Tarshish from presence of the Lord. He went down to Joppa and found a ship going to Tarshish; so he paid the fare, and went on board, to go with them to Tarshish, away from the presence of the Lord.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But the Lord hurled a great wind upon the sea, and there was a mighty tempest on the sea, so that he ship threatened to break up.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then the mariners were afraid, and each cried to his god; and they threw the wares that were in the ship onto the sea, to lighten it for them. But Jonah had gone down into the inner part of the ship and lad lain down, and was fast asleep.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So the captain came and said to him, “What do you mean, you sleeper? Arise, call upon your god! Perhaps the god will give a thought to us, that we do not perish.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And they said to one another, “Come, let us cast lots, that we may know on whose account this evil has come upon us.” So they cast lots, and the lot fell upon Jonah.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then they said to him, “Tell us, on whose account this evil has come upon us? What is your occupation? And whence do you come? What is your country? And of what people are you?”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And he said to them, “I am a Hebrew; and I fear the Lord, the God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the men were exceedingly afraid, and said to him, “What is this that you have done!” For the men knew that he was fleeing from the presence of the Lord, because he had told them.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then they said to him, “What shall we do to you, that the sea may quite down for us?” For the sea grew more and more tempestuous.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>He said to them, “Take me up and throw me into the sea; then the sea will quiet down for you; for I know its because of me that this great tempest has come upon you.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Nevertheless the men rowed hard to bring the ship back to land, but they could not, for the sea grew more and more tempestuous against them.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore they cried to the Lord, “We beseech thee, O Lord, let us not perish for this man’s life, and lay noit on us innocent blood; for thou, O Lord, hast done as it pleased thee.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So they took up Jonah and threw him into the sea; and the sea ceased from its raging.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then the men feared the Lord exceedingly, and they offered a sacrifice to the Lord and made vows.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And the Lord appointed a great fish to swallow up Jonah; and Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Jonah prayed to the Lord his God from the belly of the fish,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>saying, “I called to the Lord, out of my distress, and he answered me; out of the belly of Sheol I cried, and thou didst hear my voice.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For thou didst cast me into the deep, into the heart of the seas, and the flood was round about me; all thy waves and thy billows passed over me.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then I said, ‘I am cast out from my presence; how shall I again look upon thy holy temple?’</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The waters closed in over me, the deep was round about me; weeds were wrapped about my head</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>at the roots of the mountains. I went down to the land whose bars closed upon me for ever; yet thou didst bring up my life from the Pit, O Lord my God.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When my soul fainted within me, I remembered the Lord; and my prayer came to thee, into the holy temple.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Those who pay regard to vain idols forsake their true loyalty.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But I with the voice of Thanksgiving will sacrifice to thee; what I have vowed I will pay. Deliverance belongs to the Lord!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the Lord spoke to the fish, and it vomited out Jonah upon the dry land.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then the word of the Lord came to Jonah the second time, saying,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Arise, go to Nin’eveh, that great city, and proclaim to it the message that I tell you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So Jonah arose and went to Nin’eveh, according to the word of the Lord. Now Nin’eveh was an exceedingly great city, three days’ journey in breadth.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Jonah began to go into the city, going a day’s journey. And he cried, “yet forty days, Nin’eveh shall be overthrown!”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And the people of Nin’eveh believed God; they proclaimed a fast, and put on sackcloth. From the greatest of them to the least of them.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The tidings reached the king of Nin’eveh, and he arose from his throne, removed his robe, and covered himself with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And he made proclamation and published through Nin’eveh, “By the decree of the king and his nobles: Let neither man nor beast, herd nor flock, taste anything; let them not feed, or drink water,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>but let man and beast be covered with sackcloth, and let them cry mightily to God; yea, let every one turn from his evil way and from the violence which his is in his hands.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Who knows, God may yet repent and turn from his fierce anger, so that we perish not?”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When God saw what they did, how they turned from their evil way, God repented of the evil which he had said he would do to them; and he did not do it.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>But it displeased Jonah exceedingly, and he was angry.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And he prayed to the Lord and said, “I pray thee, Lord, is not this what I said when I was yet in my country? That is why I made haste to flee to Tarshish; for I knew that thou art a gracious God and merciful, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast lo</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore now, O Lord, take my life from me, I beseech thee, for it is better for me to die than live.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And the Lord, “Do you do well to be angry?”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Jonah went out of the city and sat to the east of the city, and made a booth for himself there. He sat under it in shade, till he should see what would become of the city.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the Lord God appointed a plant, and made it come up over Jonah, that it might be shade over his head, to save him from his discomfort. So Jonah was exceedingly glad because of the plant.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But when dawn came up the next day, God appointed a worm which attacked the plant, so that it withered.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And it happened, when the sun arose, that God prepared a vehement east wind; and the sun beat on Jonah’s head, so that he grew faint. Then he wished death for himself, and said, “It is better for me to die than to live.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But God said to Jonah, “Do you do well to be angry for the plant?” And he said, “I do well to be angry, angry enough to die.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “you pity the plant, for which you did not labor, nor did you make it grow, which came into being in a night, and perished in a night.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And should I not pity Nin’eveh, that great city, in which there are more than a hundred and twenty thousand persons who do not know their right hand from their left, and also much cattle?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Joshua 5:10-15  (Vespers 5th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Now the children of Israel camped in Gilgal, and kept the Passover on the fourteenth day of the month at twilight on the plains of Jericho. </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And they ate of the produce of the land on the day after the Passover, unleavened bread and parched grain, on the very same day. </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then the manna ceased on the day after they had eaten the produce of the land; and the children of Israel no longer had manna, but they ate the food of the land of Canaan that year. </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And it came to pass, when Joshua was by Jericho, that he lifted his eyes and looked, and behold, a Man stood opposite him with His sword drawn in His hand. And Joshua went to Him and said to Him, “Are You for us or for our adversaries?” </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So He said, “No, but as Commander of the army of the Lord I have now come.” And Joshua fell on his face to the earth and worshiped, and said to Him, “What does my Lord say to His servant?” </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the Commander of the Lord’s army said to Joshua, “Take your sandal off your foot, for the place where you stand is holy.” And Joshua did so. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 13:20-15:19  (Vespers 6th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>So they took their journey from Succoth and camped in Etham at the edge of the wilderness.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And the Lord went before them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so as to go by day and night.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>He did not take away the pillar of cloud by day or the pillar of fire by night from before the people.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“Speak to the children of Israel, that they turn and camp before Pi Hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, opposite Baal Zephon; you shall camp before it by the sea.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“For Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel, ‘They are bewildered by the land; the wilderness has closed them in.’</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“Then I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, so that he will pursue them; and I will gain honor over Pharaoh and over all his army, that the Egyptians may know that I am the Lord.” And they did so.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now it was told the king of Egypt that the people had fled, and the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people; and they said, “Why have we done this, that we have let Israel go from serving us?”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So he made ready his chariot and took his people with him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Also, he took six hundred choice chariots, and all the chariots of Egypt with captains over every one of them.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he pursued the children of Israel; and the children of Israel went out with boldness.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So the Egyptians pursued them, all the horses and chariots of Pharaoh, his horsemen and his army, and overtook them camping by the sea beside Pi Hahiroth, before Baal Zephon.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And when Pharaoh drew near, the children of Israel lifted their eyes, and behold, the Egyptians marched after them. So they were very afraid, and the children of Israel cried out to the Lord.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then they said to Moses, “Because there were no graves in Egypt, have you taken us away to die in the wilderness? Why have you so dealt with us, to bring us up out of Egypt?</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>“Is this not the word that we told you in Egypt, saying, ‘Let us alone that we may serve the Egyptians’? For it would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than that we should die in the wilderness.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid. Stand still, and see the salvation of the Lord, which He will accomplish for you today. For the Egyptians whom you see today, you shall see again no more forever.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“The Lord will fight for you, and you shall hold your peace.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Moses, “Why do you cry to Me? Tell the children of Israel to go forward.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“But lift up your rod, and stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it. And the children of Israel shall go on dry ground through the midst of the sea.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“And I indeed will harden the hearts of the Egyptians, and they shall follow them. So I will gain honor over Pharaoh and over all his army, his chariots, and his horsemen.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“Then the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord, when I have gained honor for Myself over Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the Angel of God, who went before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them; and the pillar of cloud went from before them and stood behind them.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>So it came between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel. Thus it was a cloud and darkness to the one, and it gave light by night to the other, so that the one did not come near the other all that night.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea; and the Lord caused the sea to go back by a strong east wind all that night, and made the sea into dry land, and the waters were divided.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So the children of Israel went into the midst of the sea on the dry ground, and the waters were a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And the Egyptians pursued and went after them into the midst of the sea, all Pharaoh’s horses, his chariots, and his horsemen.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, in the morning watch, that the Lord looked down upon the army of the Egyptians through the pillar of fire and cloud, and He troubled the army of the Egyptians.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And He took off their chariot wheels, so that they drove them with difficulty; and the Egyptians said, “Let us flee from the face of Israel, for the Lord fights for them against the Egyptians.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea, that the waters may come back upon the Egyptians, on their chariots, and on their horsemen.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And Moses stretched out his hand over the sea; and when the morning appeared, the sea returned to its full depth, while the Egyptians were fleeing into it. So the Lord overthrew the Egyptians in the midst of the sea.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then the waters returned and covered the chariots, the horsemen, and all the army of Pharaoh that came into the sea after them. Not so much as one of them remained.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But the children of Israel had walked on dry land in the midst of the sea, and the waters were a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>So the Lord saved Israel that day out of the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Thus Israel saw the great work which the Lord had done in Egypt; so the people feared the Lord, and believed the Lord and His servant Moses.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord, and spoke, saying: “I will sing to the Lord, For He has triumphed gloriously! The horse and its rider He has thrown into the sea!</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The Lord is my strength and song, And He has become my salvation; He is my God, and I will praise Him; My father’s God, and I will exalt Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The Lord is a man of war; The Lord is His name.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Pharaoh’s chariots and his army He has cast into the sea; His chosen captains also are drowned in the Red Sea. </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The depths have covered them; They sank to the bottom like a stone.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“Your right hand, O Lord, has become glorious in power; Your right hand, O Lord, has dashed the enemy in pieces.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And in the greatness of Your excellence You have overthrown those who rose against You; You sent forth Your wrath; It consumed them like stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And with the blast of Your nostrils The waters were gathered together; The floods stood upright like a heap; The depths congealed in the heart of the sea.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The enemy said, ‘I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoil; My desire shall be satisfied on them. I will draw my sword, My hand shall destroy them.’</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>You blew with Your wind, The sea covered them; They sank like lead in the mighty waters.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Who is like You, O Lord, among the gods? Who is like You, glorious in holiness, Fearful in praises, doing wonders? </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>You stretched out Your right hand; The earth swallowed them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>You in Your mercy have led forth The people whom You have redeemed; You have guided them in Your strength To Your holy habitation.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“The people will hear and be afraid; Sorrow will take hold of the inhabitants of Philistia.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the chiefs of Edom will be dismayed; The mighty men of Moab, Trembling will take hold of them; All the inhabitants of Canaan will melt away.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Fear and dread will fall on them; By the greatness of Your arm They will be as still as a stone, Till Your people pass over, O Lord, Till the people pass over Whom You have purchased.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>You will bring them in and plant them In the mountain of Your inheritance, In the place, O Lord, which You have made For Your own dwelling, The sanctuary, O Lord, which Your hands have established.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“The Lord shall reign forever and ever.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For the horses of Pharaoh went with his chariots and his horsemen into the sea, and the Lord brought back the waters of the sea upon them. But the children of Israel went on dry land in the midst of the sea.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Zephaniah 3:8-15  (Vespers 7th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>“Therefore wait for Me,” says the Lord, “Until the day I rise up for plunder; My determination is to gather the nations To My assembly of kingdoms, To pour on them My indignation, All my fierce anger; All the earth shall be devoured With the fire of My jealousy.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“For then I will restore to the peoples a pure language, That they all may call on the name of the Lord, To serve Him with one accord.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>From beyond the rivers of Ethiopia My worshipers, The daughter of My dispersed ones, Shall bring My offering.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>In that day you shall not be shamed for any of your deeds In which you transgress against Me; For then I will take away from your midst Those who rejoice in your pride, And you shall no longer be haughty In My holy mountain.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I will leave in your midst A meek and humble people, And they shall trust in the name of the Lord.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The remnant of Israel shall do no unrighteousness And speak no lies, Nor shall a deceitful tongue be found in their mouth; For they shall feed their flocks and lie down, And no one shall make them afraid.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Sing, O daughter of Zion! Shout, O Israel! Be glad and rejoice with all your heart, O daughter of Jerusalem!</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The Lord has taken away your judgments, He has cast out your enemy. The King of Israel, the Lord, is in your midst; You shall see disaster no more.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 3[1] Kings 17:8-24  (Vespers 8th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>Then the word of the Lord came to him, saying, </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Arise, go to Zarephath, which belongs to Sidon, and dwell there. See, I have commanded a widow there to provide for you. </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>So he arose and went to Zarephath. And when he came to the gate of the city, indeed a widow was there gathering sticks.
