readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>James, a bondservant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scattered abroad: Greetings.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>My brethren, count it all joy when you fall into various trials,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>knowing that the testing of your faith produces patience.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But let patience have its perfect work, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all liberally and without reproach, and it will be given to him.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But let him ask in faith, with no doubting, for he who doubts is like a wave of the sea driven and tossed by the wind.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For let not that man suppose that he will receive anything from the Lord;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>he is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Let the lowly brother glory in his exaltation,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>but the rich in his humiliation, because as a flower of the field he will pass away.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For no sooner has the sun risen with a burning heat than it withers the grass; its flower falls, and its beautiful appearance perishes. So the rich man also will fade away in his pursuits.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Blessed is the man who endures temptation; for when he has been approved, he will receive the crown of life which the Lord has promised to those who love Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: James 1:13-27  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Let no one say when he is tempted, “I am tempted by God”; for God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does He Himself tempt anyone.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But each one is tempted when he is drawn away by his own desires and enticed.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then, when desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin; and sin, when it is full-grown, brings forth death.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Do not be deceived, my beloved brethren.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and comes down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow of turning.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Of His own will He brought us forth by the word of truth, that we might be a kind of firstfruits of His creatures.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So then, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>for the wrath of man does not produce the righteousness of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Therefore lay aside all filthiness and overflow of wickedness, and receive with meekness the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But be doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving yourselves.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For if anyone is a hearer of the word and not a doer, he is like a man observing his natural face in a mirror;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>for he observes himself, goes away, and immediately forgets what kind of man he was.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But he who looks into the perfect law of liberty and continues in it, and is not a forgetful hearer but a doer of the work, this one will be blessed in what he does.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>If anyone among you thinks he is religious, and does not bridle his tongue but deceives his own heart, this one’s religion is useless.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Pure and undefiled religion before God and the Father is this: to visit orphans and widows in their trouble, and to keep oneself unspotted from the world.</dd></dl>

readings.title: James 2:1-13  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>My brethren, do not hold the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Lord of glory, with partiality.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For if there should come into your assembly a man with gold rings, in fine apparel, and there should also come in a poor man in filthy clothes,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and you pay attention to the one wearing the fine clothes and say to him, “You sit here in a good place,” and say to the poor man, “You stand there,” or, “Sit here at my footstool,”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>have you not shown partiality among yourselves, and become judges with evil thoughts?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Listen, my beloved brethren: Has God not chosen the poor of this world to be rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom which He promised to those who love Him?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But you have dishonored the poor man. Do not the rich oppress you and drag you into the courts?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Do they not blaspheme that noble name by which you are called?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>If you really fulfill the royal law according to the Scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you do well;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but if you show partiality, you commit sin, and are convicted by the law as transgressors.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For whoever shall keep the whole law, and yet stumble in one point, he is guilty of all.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For He who said, “Do not commit adultery,” also said, “Do not murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery, but you do murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So speak and so do as those who will be judged by the law of liberty.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For judgment is without mercy to the one who has shown no mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:1-15  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>After these things the Lord appointed seventy others also, and sent them two by two before His face into every city and place where He Himself was about to go.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “The harvest truly is great, but the laborers are few; therefore pray the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into His harvest.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Go your way; behold, I send you out as lambs among wolves.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Carry neither money bag, knapsack, nor sandals; and greet no one along the road.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But whatever house you enter, first say, ‘Peace to this house.’</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And if a son of peace is there, your peace will rest on it; if not, it will return to you.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And remain in the same house, eating and drinking such things as they give, for the laborer is worthy of his wages. Do not go from house to house.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Whatever city you enter, and they receive you, eat such things as are set before you.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And heal the sick there, and say to them, ‘The kingdom of God has come near to you.’</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But whatever city you enter, and they do not receive you, go out into its streets and say,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>‘The very dust of your city which clings to us we wipe off against you. Nevertheless know this, that the kingdom of God has come near you.’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But I say to you that it will be more tolerable in that Day for Sodom than for that city.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And you, Capernaum, who are exalted to heaven, will be brought down to Hades. </dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 5:6-14  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>Therefore humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due time,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>casting all your care upon Him, for He cares for you.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil walks about like a roaring lion, seeking whom he may devour.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Resist him, steadfast in the faith, knowing that the same sufferings are experienced by your brotherhood in the world.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But may the God of all grace, who called us to His eternal glory by Christ Jesus, after you have suffered a while, perfect, establish, strengthen, and settle you.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>To Him be the glory and the dominion forever and ever. Amen.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>By Silvanus, our faithful brother as I consider him, I have written to you briefly, exhorting and testifying that this is the true grace of God in which you stand.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>She who is in Babylon, elect together with you, greets you; and so does Mark my son.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Greet one another with a kiss of love. Peace to you all who are in Christ Jesus. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 6:7-13  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>And He called the twelve to Himself, and began to send them out two by two, and gave them power over unclean spirits.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He commanded them to take nothing for the journey except a staff – no bag, no bread, no copper in their money belts – </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but to wear sandals, and not to put on two tunics.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Also He said to them, “In whatever place you enter a house, stay there till you depart from that place.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And whoever will not receive you nor hear you, when you depart from there, shake off the dust under your feet as a testimony against them. Assuredly, I say to you, it will be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomorrah in the day of judgment than for that city!”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So they went out and preached that people should repent.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And they cast out many demons, and anointed with oil many who were sick, and healed them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 4:1-10  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now as they spoke to the people, the priests, the captain of the temple, and the Sadducees came upon them,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>being greatly disturbed that they taught the people and preached in Jesus the resurrection from the dead.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And they laid hands on them, and put them in custody until the next day, for it was already evening.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>However, many of those who heard the word believed; and the number of the men came to be about five thousand.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And it came to pass, on the next day, that their rulers, elders, and scribes,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>as well as Annas the high priest, Caiaphas, John, and Alexander, and as many as were of the family of the high priest, were gathered together at Jerusalem.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And when they had set them in the midst, they asked, “By what power or by what name have you done this?”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, “Rulers of the people and elders of Israel:</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>If we this day are judged for a good deed done to a helpless man, by what means he has been made well,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>let it be known to you all, and to all the people of Israel, that by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified, whom God raised from the dead, by Him this man stands here before you whole.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 3:16-21  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>For God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have everlasting life.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For God did not send His Son into the world to condemn the world, but that the world through Him might be saved.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>He who believes in Him is not condemned; but he who does not believe is condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And this is the condemnation, that the light has come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For everyone practicing evil hates the light and does not come to the light, lest his deeds should be exposed.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But he who does the truth comes to the light, that his deeds may be clearly seen, that they have been done in God.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 4:13-22  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, and perceived that they were uneducated and untrained men, they marveled. And they realized that they had been with Jesus.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And seeing the man who had been healed standing with them, they could say nothing against it.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when they had commanded them to go aside out of the council, they conferred among themselves,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>saying, “What shall we do to these men? For, indeed, that a notable miracle has been done through them is evident to all who dwell in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But so that it spreads no further among the people, let us severely threaten them, that from now on they speak to no man in this name.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>So they called them and commanded them not to speak at all nor teach in the name of Jesus.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But Peter and John answered and said to them, “Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you more than to God, you judge.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For we cannot but speak the things which we have seen and heard.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So when they had further threatened them, they let them go, finding no way of punishing them, because of the people, since they all glorified God for what had been done.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For the man was over forty years old on whom this miracle of healing had been performed.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:17-24  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>But Jesus answered them, “My Father has been working until now, and I have been working.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Therefore the Jews sought all the more to kill Him, because He not only broke the Sabbath, but also said that God was His Father, making Himself equal with God.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then Jesus answered and said to them, “Most assuredly, I say to you, the Son can do nothing of Himself, but what He sees the Father do; for whatever He does, the Son also does in like manner.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For the Father loves the Son, and shows Him all things that He Himself does; and He will show Him greater works than these, that you may marvel.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For as the Father raises the dead and gives life to them, even so the Son gives life to whom He will.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For the Father judges no one, but has committed all judgment to the Son,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>that all should honor the Son just as they honor the Father. He who does not honor the Son does not honor the Father who sent Him.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 4:23-31  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>And being let go, they went to their own companions and reported all that the chief priests and elders had said to them.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So when they heard that, they raised their voice to God with one accord and said: “Lord, You are God, who made heaven and earth and the sea, and all that is in them,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>who by the mouth of Your servant David have said: ‘Why did the nations rage, and the people plot vain things?</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>The kings of the earth took their stand, and the rulers were gathered together against the LORD and against His Christ.’ </dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For truly against Your holy Servant Jesus, whom You anointed, both Herod and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles and the people of Israel, were gathered together</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>to do whatever Your hand and Your purpose determined before to be done.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Now, Lord, look on their threats, and grant to Your servants that with all boldness they may speak Your word,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>by stretching out Your hand to heal, and that signs and wonders may be done through the name of Your holy Servant Jesus.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And when they had prayed, the place where they were assembled together was shaken; and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and they spoke the word of God with boldness.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:24-30  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have life in Himself,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and has given Him authority to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of Man.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will hear His voice</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and come forth – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 5:1-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But a certain man named Ananias, with Sapphira his wife, sold a possession.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And he kept back part of the proceeds, his wife also being aware of it, and brought a certain part and laid it at the apostles’ feet.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But Peter said, “Ananias, why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and keep back part of the price of the land for yourself?</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>While it remained, was it not your own? And after it was sold, was it not in your own control? Why have you conceived this thing in your heart? You have not lied to men but to God.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Ananias, hearing these words, fell down and breathed his last. So great fear came upon all those who heard these things.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the young men arose and wrapped him up, carried him out, and buried him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Now it was about three hours later when his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And Peter answered her, “Tell me whether you sold the land for so much?” She said, “Yes, for so much.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then Peter said to her, “How is it that you have agreed together to test the Spirit of the Lord? Look, the feet of those who have buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then immediately she fell down at his feet and breathed her last. And the young men came in and found her dead, and carrying her out, buried her by her husband.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So great fear came upon all the church and upon all who heard these things.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:30-6:2  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>If I bear witness of Myself, My witness is not true.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>There is another who bears witness of Me, and I know that the witness which He witnesses of Me is true.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>You have sent to John, and he has borne witness to the truth.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Yet I do not receive testimony from man, but I say these things that you may be saved.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>He was the burning and shining lamp, and you were willing for a time to rejoice in his light.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>But I have a greater witness than John’s; for the works which the Father has given Me to finish – the very works that I do – bear witness of Me, that the Father has sent Me.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And the Father Himself, who sent Me, has testified of Me. You have neither heard His voice at any time, nor seen His form.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But you do not have His word abiding in you, because whom He sent, Him you do not believe.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>You search the Scriptures, for in them you think you have eternal life; and these are they which testify of Me.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But you are not willing to come to Me that you may have life.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>I do not receive honor from men.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>But I know you, that you do not have the love of God in you.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>I have come in My Father’s name, and you do not receive Me; if another comes in his own name, him you will receive.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>How can you believe, who receive honor from one another, and do not seek the honor that comes from the only God?</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Do not think that I shall accuse you to the Father; there is one who accuses you – Moses, in whom you trust.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>For if you believed Moses, you would believe Me; for he wrote about Me.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>But if you do not believe his writings, how will you believe My words?”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>After these things Jesus went over the Sea of Galilee, which is the Sea of Tiberias.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then a great multitude followed Him, because they saw His signs which He performed on those who were diseased.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 5:21-33  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>And when they heard that, they entered the temple early in the morning and taught. But the high priest and those with him came and called the council together, with all the elders of the children of Israel, and sent to the prison to have them brought.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But when the officers came and did not find them in the prison, they returned and reported,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>saying, “Indeed we found the prison shut securely, and the guards standing outside before the doors; but when we opened them, we found no one inside!”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now when the high priest, the captain of the temple, and the chief priests heard these things, they wondered what the outcome would be.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>So one came and told them, saying, “Look, the men whom you put in prison are standing in the temple and teaching the people!”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then the captain went with the officers and brought them without violence, for they feared the people, lest they should be stoned.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And when they had brought them, they set them before the council. And the high priest asked them,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>saying, “Did we not strictly command you not to teach in this name? And look, you have filled Jerusalem with your doctrine, and intend to bring this Man’s blood on us!”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But Peter and the other apostles answered and said: “We ought to obey God rather than men.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>The God of our fathers raised up Jesus whom you murdered by hanging on a tree.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Him God has exalted to His right hand to be Prince and Savior, to give repentance to Israel and forgiveness of sins.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And we are His witnesses to these things, and so also is the Holy Spirit whom God has given to those who obey Him.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>When they heard this, they were furious and plotted to kill them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 6:14-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Then those men, when they had seen the sign that Jesus did, said, “This is truly the Prophet who is to come into the world.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore when Jesus perceived that they were about to come and take Him by force to make Him king, He departed again to the mountain by Himself alone.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Now when evening came, His disciples went down to the sea,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>got into the boat, and went over the sea toward Capernaum. And it was already dark, and Jesus had not come to them.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then the sea arose because a great wind was blowing.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So when they had rowed about three or four miles, they saw Jesus walking on the sea and drawing near the boat; and they were afraid.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But He said to them, “It is I; do not be afraid.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then they willingly received Him into the boat, and immediately the boat was at the land where they were going.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>On the following day, when the people who were standing on the other side of the sea saw that there was no other boat there, except that one which His disciples had entered, and that Jesus had not entered the boat with His disciples, but His disciples had gone away alone –</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>however, other boats came from Tiberias, near the place where they ate bread after the Lord had given thanks – </dd><dt>24</dt><dd>when the people therefore saw that Jesus was not there, nor His disciples, they also got into boats and came to Capernaum, seeking Jesus.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And when they found Him on the other side of the sea, they said to Him, “Rabbi, when did You come here?”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Jesus answered them and said, “Most assuredly, I say to you, you seek Me, not because you saw the signs, but because you ate of the loaves and were filled.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Do not labor for the food which perishes, but for the food which endures to everlasting life, which the Son of Man will give you, because God the Father has set His seal on Him.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: James 1:1-12  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>James, a bondservant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scattered abroad: Greetings.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>My brethren, count it all joy when you fall into various trials,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>knowing that the testing of your faith produces patience.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But let patience have its perfect work, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all liberally and without reproach, and it will be given to him.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But let him ask in faith, with no doubting, for he who doubts is like a wave of the sea driven and tossed by the wind.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For let not that man suppose that he will receive anything from the Lord;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>he is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Let the lowly brother glory in his exaltation,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>but the rich in his humiliation, because as a flower of the field he will pass away.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For no sooner has the sun risen with a burning heat than it withers the grass; its flower falls, and its beautiful appearance perishes. So the rich man also will fade away in his pursuits.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Blessed is the man who endures temptation; for when he has been approved, he will receive the crown of life which the Lord has promised to those who love Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: James 1:13-27  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Let no one say when he is tempted, “I am tempted by God”; for God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does He Himself tempt anyone.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But each one is tempted when he is drawn away by his own desires and enticed.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then, when desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin; and sin, when it is full-grown, brings forth death.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Do not be deceived, my beloved brethren.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and comes down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow of turning.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Of His own will He brought us forth by the word of truth, that we might be a kind of firstfruits of His creatures.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So then, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>for the wrath of man does not produce the righteousness of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Therefore lay aside all filthiness and overflow of wickedness, and receive with meekness the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But be doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving yourselves.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For if anyone is a hearer of the word and not a doer, he is like a man observing his natural face in a mirror;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>for he observes himself, goes away, and immediately forgets what kind of man he was.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But he who looks into the perfect law of liberty and continues in it, and is not a forgetful hearer but a doer of the work, this one will be blessed in what he does.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>If anyone among you thinks he is religious, and does not bridle his tongue but deceives his own heart, this one’s religion is useless.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Pure and undefiled religion before God and the Father is this: to visit orphans and widows in their trouble, and to keep oneself unspotted from the world.</dd></dl>

readings.title: James 2:1-13  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>My brethren, do not hold the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Lord of glory, with partiality.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For if there should come into your assembly a man with gold rings, in fine apparel, and there should also come in a poor man in filthy clothes,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and you pay attention to the one wearing the fine clothes and say to him, “You sit here in a good place,” and say to the poor man, “You stand there,” or, “Sit here at my footstool,”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>have you not shown partiality among yourselves, and become judges with evil thoughts?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Listen, my beloved brethren: Has God not chosen the poor of this world to be rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom which He promised to those who love Him?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But you have dishonored the poor man. Do not the rich oppress you and drag you into the courts?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Do they not blaspheme that noble name by which you are called?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>If you really fulfill the royal law according to the Scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you do well;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but if you show partiality, you commit sin, and are convicted by the law as transgressors.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For whoever shall keep the whole law, and yet stumble in one point, he is guilty of all.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For He who said, “Do not commit adultery,” also said, “Do not murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery, but you do murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So speak and so do as those who will be judged by the law of liberty.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For judgment is without mercy to the one who has shown no mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 16:9-20  (3rd  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when He rose early on the first day of the week, He appeared first to Mary Magdalene, out of whom He had cast seven demons.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>She went and told those who had been with Him, as they mourned and wept.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when they heard that He was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>After that, He appeared in another form to two of them as they walked and went into the country.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And they went and told it to the rest, but they did not believe them either.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Later He appeared to the eleven as they sat at the table; and He rebuked their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they did not believe those who had seen Him after He had risen.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He who believes and is baptized will be saved; but he who does not believe will be condemned.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And these signs will follow those who believe: In My name they will cast out demons; they will speak with new tongues;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>they will take up serpents; and if they drink anything deadly, it will by no means hurt them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So then, after the Lord had spoken to them, He was received up into heaven, and sat down at the right hand of God.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And they went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming the word through the accompanying signs. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 12:1-11  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now about that time Herod the king stretched out his hand to harass some from the church.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then he killed James the brother of John with the sword.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And because he saw that it pleased the Jews, he proceeded further to seize Peter also. Now it was during the Days of Unleavened Bread.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So when he had arrested him, he put him in prison, and delivered him to four squads of soldiers to keep him, intending to bring him before the people after Passover.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Peter was therefore kept in prison, but constant prayer was offered to God for him by the church.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And when Herod was about to bring him out, that night Peter was sleeping, bound with two chains between two soldiers; and the guards before the door were keeping the prison.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Now behold, an angel of the Lord stood by him, and a light shone in the prison; and he struck Peter on the side and raised him up, saying, “Arise quickly!” And his chains fell off his hands.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then the angel said to him, “Gird yourself and tie on your sandals”; and so he did. And he said to him, “Put on your garment and follow me.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So he went out and followed him, and did not know that what was done by the angel was real, but thought he was seeing a vision.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When they were past the first and the second guard posts, they came to the iron gate that leads to the city, which opened to them of its own accord; and they went out and went down one street, and immediately the angel departed from him.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when Peter had come to himself, he said, “Now I know for certain that the Lord has sent His angel, and has delivered me from the hand of Herod and from all the expectation of the Jewish people.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 5:1-11  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>So it was, as the multitude pressed about Him to hear the word of God, that He stood by the Lake of Gennesaret,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and saw two boats standing by the lake; but the fishermen had gone from them and were washing their nets.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then He got into one of the boats, which was Simon’s, and asked him to put out a little from the land. And He sat down and taught the multitudes from the boat.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>When He had stopped speaking, He said to Simon, “Launch out into the deep and let down your nets for a catch.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But Simon answered and said to Him, “Master, we have toiled all night and caught nothing; nevertheless at Your word I will let down the net.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And when they had done this, they caught a great number of fish, and their net was breaking.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So they signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. And they came and filled both the boats, so that they began to sink.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>When Simon Peter saw it, he fell down at Jesus’ knees, saying, “Depart from me, for I am a sinful man, O Lord!”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For he and all who were with him were astonished at the catch of fish which they had taken;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>and so also were James and John, the sons of Zebedee, who were partners with Simon. And Jesus said to Simon, “Do not be afraid. From now on you will catch men.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So when they had brought their boats to land, they forsook all and followed Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 6:1-7  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now in those days, when the number of the disciples was multiplying, there arose a complaint against the Hebrews by the Hellenists, because their widows were neglected in the daily distribution.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then the twelve summoned the multitude of the disciples and said, “It is not desirable that we should leave the word of God and serve tables.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore, brethren, seek out from among you seven men of good reputation, full of the Holy Spirit and wisdom, whom we may appoint over this business;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>but we will give ourselves continually to prayer and to the ministry of the word.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And the saying pleased the whole multitude. And they chose Stephen, a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, and Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas, a proselyte from Antioch,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>whom they set before the apostles; and when they had prayed, they laid hands on them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then the word of God spread, and the number of the disciples multiplied greatly in Jerusalem, and a great many of the priests were obedient to the faith.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 15:43-16:8  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>43</dt><dd>Joseph of Arimathea, a prominent council member, who was himself waiting for the kingdom of God, coming and taking courage, went in to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Pilate marveled that He was already dead; and summoning the centurion, he asked him if He had been dead for some time.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>So when he found out from the centurion, he granted the body to Joseph.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Then he bought fine linen, took Him down, and wrapped Him in the linen. And he laid Him in a tomb which had been hewn out of the rock, and rolled a stone against the door of the tomb.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>And Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses observed where He was laid.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when the Sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices, that they might come and anoint Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Very early in the morning, on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb when the sun had risen.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And they said among themselves, “Who will roll away the stone from the door of the tomb for us?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But when they looked up, they saw that the stone had been rolled away – for it was very large.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And entering the tomb, they saw a young man clothed in a long white robe sitting on the right side; and they were alarmed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But he said to them, “Do not be alarmed. You seek Jesus of Nazareth, who was crucified. He is risen! He is not here. See the place where they laid Him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But go, tell His disciples – and Peter – that He is going before you into Galilee; there you will see Him, as He said to you.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So they went out quickly and fled from the tomb, for they trembled and were amazed. And they said nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 6:8-7:5 47-60  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>And Stephen, full of faith and power, did great wonders and signs among the people.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then there arose some from what is called the Synagogue of the Freedmen (Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and Asia), disputing with Stephen.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And they were not able to resist the wisdom and the Spirit by which he spoke.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then they secretly induced men to say, “We have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses and God.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And they stirred up the people, the elders, and the scribes; and they came upon him, seized him, and brought him to the council.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>They also set up false witnesses who said, “This man does not cease to speak blasphemous words against this holy place and the law;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for we have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs which Moses delivered to us.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And all who sat in the council, looking steadfastly at him, saw his face as the face of an angel.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then the high priest said, “Are these things so?”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And he said, “Brethren and fathers, listen: The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Haran,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said to him, ‘Get out of your country and from your relatives, and come to a land that I will show you.’ </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then he came out of the land of the Chaldeans and dwelt in Haran. And from there, when his father was dead, He moved him to this land in which you now dwell.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And God gave him no inheritance in it, not even enough to set his foot on. But even when Abraham had no child, He promised to give it to him for a possession, and to his descendants after him.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>But Solomon built Him a house.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>However, the Most High does not dwell in temples made with hands, as the prophet says:</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>‘Heaven is My throne, and earth is My footstool. What house will you build for Me? says the LORD, or what is the place of My rest?</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Has My hand not made all these things?’ </dd><dt>51</dt><dd>You stiff-necked and uncircumcised in heart and ears! You always resist the Holy Spirit; as your fathers did, so do you.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>Which of the prophets did your fathers not persecute? And they killed those who foretold the coming of the Just One, of whom you now have become the betrayers and murderers,</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>who have received the law by the direction of angels and have not kept it.”</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>When they heard these things they were cut to the heart, and they gnashed at him with their teeth.</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>But he, being full of the Holy Spirit, gazed into heaven and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God,</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>and said, “Look! I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God!”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>Then they cried out with a loud voice, stopped their ears, and ran at him with one accord;</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>and they cast him out of the city and stoned him. And the witnesses laid down their clothes at the feet of a young man named Saul.</dd><dt>59</dt><dd>And they stoned Stephen as he was calling on God and saying, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”</dd><dt>60</dt><dd>Then he knelt down and cried out with a loud voice, “Lord, do not charge them with this sin.” And when he had said this, he fell asleep.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 4:46-54  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>46</dt><dd>So Jesus came again to Cana of Galilee where He had made the water wine. And there was a certain nobleman whose son was sick at Capernaum.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>When he heard that Jesus had come out of Judea into Galilee, he went to Him and implored Him to come down and heal his son, for he was at the point of death.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to him, “Unless you people see signs and wonders, you will by no means believe.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>The nobleman said to Him, “Sir, come down before my child dies!”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “Go your way; your son lives.” So the man believed the word that Jesus spoke to him, and he went his way.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>And as he was now going down, his servants met him and told him, saying, “Your son lives!”</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>Then he inquired of them the hour when he got better. And they said to him, “Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.”</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>So the father knew that it was at the same hour in which Jesus said to him, “Your son lives.” And he himself believed, and his whole household.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>This again is the second sign Jesus did when He had come out of Judea into Galilee.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 8:5-17  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Philip went down to the city of Samaria and preached Christ to them.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the multitudes with one accord heeded the things spoken by Philip, hearing and seeing the miracles which he did.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For unclean spirits, crying with a loud voice, came out of many who were possessed; and many who were paralyzed and lame were healed.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And there was great joy in that city.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But there was a certain man called Simon, who previously practiced sorcery in the city and astonished the people of Samaria, claiming that he was someone great,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>to whom they all gave heed, from the least to the greatest, saying, “This man is the great power of God.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And they heeded him because he had astonished them with his sorceries for a long time.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But when they believed Philip as he preached the things concerning the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, both men and women were baptized.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Simon himself also believed; and when he was baptized he continued with Philip, and was amazed, seeing the miracles and signs which were done.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when the apostles who were at Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent Peter and John to them,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>who, when they had come down, prayed for them that they might receive the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For as yet He had fallen upon none of them. They had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then they laid hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 6:27-33  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>Do not labor for the food which perishes, but for the food which endures to everlasting life, which the Son of Man will give you, because God the Father has set His seal on Him.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then they said to Him, “What shall we do, that we may work the works of God?”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “This is the work of God, that you believe in Him whom He sent.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Therefore they said to Him, “What sign will You perform then, that we may see it and believe You? What work will You do?</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Our fathers ate the manna in the desert; as it is written, ‘He gave them bread from heaven to eat.’” </dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “Most assuredly, I say to you, Moses did not give you the bread from heaven, but My Father gives you the true bread from heaven.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>For the bread of God is He who comes down from heaven and gives life to the world.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 13:7-16  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd> Remember those who rule over you, who have spoken the word of God to you, whose faith follow, considering the outcome of their conduct.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Do not be carried about with various and strange doctrines. For it is good that the heart be established by grace, not with foods which have not profited those who have been occupied with them.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>We have an altar from which those who serve the tabernacle have no right to eat.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For the bodies of those animals, whose blood is brought into the sanctuary by the high priest for sin, are burned outside the camp.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore Jesus also, that He might sanctify the people with His own blood, suffered outside the gate.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore let us go forth to Him, outside the camp, bearing His reproach.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For here we have no continuing city, but we seek the one to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore by Him let us continually offer the sacrifice of praise to God, that is, the fruit of our lips, giving thanks to His name.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But do not forget to do good and to share, for with such sacrifices God is well pleased.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 8:18-25  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>And when Simon saw that through the laying on of the apostles’ hands the Holy Spirit was given, he offered them money,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>saying, “Give me this power also, that anyone on whom I lay hands may receive the Holy Spirit.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But Peter said to him, “Your money perish with you, because you thought that the gift of God could be purchased with money!</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>You have neither part nor portion in this matter, for your heart is not right in the sight of God.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Repent therefore of this your wickedness, and pray God if perhaps the thought of your heart may be forgiven you.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For I see that you are poisoned by bitterness and bound by iniquity.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then Simon answered and said, “Pray to the Lord for me, that none of the things which you have spoken may come upon me.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>So when they had testified and preached the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, preaching the gospel in many villages of the Samaritans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 6:35-39  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>And Jesus said to them, “I am the bread of life. He who comes to Me shall never hunger, and he who believes in Me shall never thirst.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>But I said to you that you have seen Me and yet do not believe.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>All that the Father gives Me will come to Me, and the one who comes to Me I will by no means cast out.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>For I have come down from heaven, not to do My own will, but the will of Him who sent Me.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>This is the will of the Father who sent Me, that of all He has given Me I should lose nothing, but should raise it up at the last day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 8:26-39  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>Now an angel of the Lord spoke to Philip, saying, “Arise and go toward the south along the road which goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza.” This is desert.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>So he arose and went. And behold, a man of Ethiopia, a eunuch of great authority under Candace the queen of the Ethiopians, who had charge of all her treasury, and had come to Jerusalem to worship,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>was returning. And sitting in his chariot, he was reading Isaiah the prophet.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then the Spirit said to Philip, “Go near and overtake this chariot.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>So Philip ran to him, and heard him reading the prophet Isaiah, and said, “Do you understand what you are reading?”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And he said, “How can I, unless someone guides me?” And he asked Philip to come up and sit with him.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>The place in the Scripture which he read was this: “He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; and as a lamb before its shearer is silent, so He opened not His mouth.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>In His humiliation His justice was taken away, and who will declare His generation? For His life is taken from the earth.” </dd><dt>34</dt><dd>So the eunuch answered Philip and said, “I ask you, of whom does the prophet say this, of himself or of some other man?”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then Philip opened his mouth, and beginning at this Scripture, preached Jesus to him.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Now as they went down the road, they came to some water. And the eunuch said, “See, here is water. What hinders me from being baptized?”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then Philip said, “If you believe with all your heart, you may.” And he answered and said, “I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.” </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>So he commanded the chariot to stand still. And both Philip and the eunuch went down into the water, and he baptized him.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Now when they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught Philip away, so that the eunuch saw him no more; and he went on his way rejoicing.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 6:40-44  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>40</dt><dd>And this is the will of Him who sent Me, that everyone who sees the Son and believes in Him may have everlasting life; and I will raise him up at the last day.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>The Jews then complained about Him, because He said, “I am the bread which came down from heaven.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And they said, “Is not this Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? How is it then that He says, ‘I have come down from heaven’?”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>Jesus therefore answered and said to them, “Do not murmur among yourselves.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>No one can come to Me unless the Father who sent Me draws him; and I will raise him up at the last day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 8:40-9:19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>40</dt><dd>But Philip was found at Azotus. And passing through, he preached in all the cities till he came to Caesarea.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Saul, still breathing threats and murder against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and asked letters from him to the synagogues of Damascus, so that if he found any who were of the Way, whether men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>As he journeyed he came near Damascus, and suddenly a light shone around him from heaven.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then he fell to the ground, and heard a voice saying to him, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me?”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And he said, “Who are You, Lord?” Then the Lord said, “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting. It is hard for you to kick against the goads.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So he, trembling and astonished, said, “Lord, what do You want me to do?” Then the Lord said to him, “Arise and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And the men who journeyed with him stood speechless, hearing a voice but seeing no one.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then Saul arose from the ground, and when his eyes were opened he saw no one. But they led him by the hand and brought him into Damascus.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And he was three days without sight, and neither ate nor drank.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Now there was a certain disciple at Damascus named Ananias; and to him the Lord said in a vision, “Ananias.” And he said, “Here I am, Lord.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So the Lord said to him, “Arise and go to the street called Straight, and inquire at the house of Judas for one called Saul of Tarsus, for behold, he is praying.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And in a vision he has seen a man named Ananias coming in and putting his hand on him, so that he might receive his sight.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Ananias answered, “Lord, I have heard from many about this man, how much harm he has done to Your saints in Jerusalem.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And here he has authority from the chief priests to bind all who call on Your name.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But the Lord said to him, “Go, for he is a chosen vessel of Mine to bear My name before Gentiles, kings, and the children of Israel.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For I will show him how many things he must suffer for My name’s sake.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And Ananias went his way and entered the house; and laying his hands on him he said, “Brother Saul, the Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you came, has sent me that you may receive your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Immediately there fell from his eyes something like scales, and he received his sight at once; and he arose and was baptized.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So when he had received food, he was strengthened. Then Saul spent some days with the disciples at Damascus.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 6:48-54  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>48</dt><dd>I am the bread of life.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Your fathers ate the manna in the wilderness, and are dead.</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>This is the bread which comes down from heaven, that one may eat of it and not die.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>I am the living bread which came down from heaven. If anyone eats of this bread, he will live forever; and the bread that I shall give is My flesh, which I shall give for the life of the world.”</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>The Jews therefore quarreled among themselves, saying, “How can this Man give us His flesh to eat?”</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “Most assuredly, I say to you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink His blood, you have no life in you.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>Whoever eats My flesh and drinks My blood has eternal life, and I will raise him up at the last day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 9:20-31  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>Immediately he preached the Christ in the synagogues, that He is the Son of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then all who heard were amazed, and said, “Is this not he who destroyed those who called on this name in Jerusalem, and has come here for that purpose, so that he might bring them bound to the chief priests?”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But Saul increased all the more in strength, and confounded the Jews who dwelt in Damascus, proving that this Jesus is the Christ.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Now after many days were past, the Jews plotted to kill him.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>But their plot became known to Saul. And they watched the gates day and night, to kill him.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then the disciples took him by night and let him down through the wall in a large basket.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And when Saul had come to Jerusalem, he tried to join the disciples; but they were all afraid of him, and did not believe that he was a disciple.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But Barnabas took him and brought him to the apostles. And he declared to them how he had seen the Lord on the road, and that He had spoken to him, and how he had preached boldly at Damascus in the name of Jesus.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So he was with them at Jerusalem, coming in and going out.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And he spoke boldly in the name of the Lord Jesus and disputed against the Hellenists, but they attempted to kill him.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>When the brethren found out, they brought him down to Caesarea and sent him out to Tarsus.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then the churches throughout all Judea, Galilee, and Samaria had peace and were edified. And walking in the fear of the Lord and in the comfort of the Holy Spirit, they were multiplied.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 15:17-16:2  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>These things I command you, that you love one another.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>If the world hates you, you know that it hated Me before it hated you.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>If you were of the world, the world would love its own. Yet because you are not of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Remember the word that I said to you, ‘A servant is not greater than his master.’ If they persecuted Me, they will also persecute you. If they kept My word, they will keep yours also.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But all these things they will do to you for My name’s sake, because they do not know Him who sent Me.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>If I had not come and spoken to them, they would have no sin, but now they have no excuse for their sin.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>He who hates Me hates My Father also.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>If I had not done among them the works which no one else did, they would have no sin; but now they have seen and also hated both Me and My Father.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But this happened that the word might be fulfilled which is written in their law, ‘They hated Me without a cause.’ </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But when the Helper comes, whom I shall send to you from the Father, the Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father, He will testify of Me.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And you also will bear witness, because you have been with Me from the beginning.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>These things I have spoken to you, that you should not be made to stumble.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>They will put you out of the synagogues; yes, the time is coming that whoever kills you will think that he offers God service.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 2 - Proverbs 10 3 8  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The memory of the righteous is with praise and the blessing of the Lord is upon his head. Blessed is the man who has found wisdom and the mortal who has understanding. For it is better to purchase her than treasuries of gold and silver. She is more precious than precious stones and all that is precious is unworthy of her. For length of days and years of life are in her right hand; and in her left hand are riches and glory. Out of her mouth proceeds righteousness and she bears law and mercy upon her tongue.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Hear me, O child, for I will speak noble things. Blessed is the man who keeps my ways, for my ways are the ways of life, and in them is prepared favor from the Lord. Therefore, I pray thee, and utter my voice to the sons of men: For I, wisdom, have dwelt with counsel and knowledge and I have called upon understanding. Counsel and safety are mine, understanding and strength are mine. I love those who love me and those seeking me shall find grace.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Understand craftiness, O you who are simple, and imbibe knowledge, you who are untaught. Hear me again, for I will speak noble things: I will open my mouth and from my lips shall come what is right. For my throat shall meditate truth; false lips are an abomination before me. All the words of my mouth are righteous; there is nothing in them that is twisted or perverse. They are all straight to him who understands and right to those who find knowledge.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I shall instruct you in truth, so that your hope will be in the Lord and you shall be filled with the Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 4 - Proverbs 10 Wisdom of Solomon 6 7 8 9  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous bringeth forth wisdom; the lips of the wise man know grace. The mouth of the wise speaketh wisdom, and the truth delivereth them from death. If a righteous man dies, hope doth not, for the son of the righteous is born to life, and in his own good things he acquireth the fruit of righteousness. There is always light for the righteous and they obtain grace and glory from the Lord. The tongue of the wise is a good sister-in-law, and in their hearts resteth wisdom. The Lord loveth the hearts of the holy, and acceptable to Him are all the undefiled in the way.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The wisdom of the Lord illumineth the faces of the wise. For she takes hold of those desiring her by making herself first known to them. She is easily seen by those who love her. He who rises early to seek her shall have no difficulty, and those keeping vigil for the sake of her shall quickly be without sorrows. For she goeth about seeking those worthy of her, and graciously revealeth herself in the pathways. Against wisdom evil doth not prevail.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore I was a lover of her beauty; I loved her and sought her out from my youth. I desired to make her my bride, and even the Master of All loved her. For she is an initiate in the knowledge of God, and a discoverer of His works. Her labors are virtues, for she teaches temperance and prudence, justice and courage; nothing in life is more necessary for men than these. And if anyone desireth much knowledge, she knoweth the things of old, and beholdeth things to come; she understandeth turns of speech and the solution of riddles; she has foreknowledge of signs and wonders and the outcome of times and seasons. She is a mediator of good things for all, for immortality is in her, and glory in the company of her words.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Therefore I appealed to the Lord and prayed to Him, and said to Him with all my heart: “O God of my fathers and Lord of mercy, Who hast made all things by Thy word, and by Thy wisdom hast fashioned man that he should have dominion over the creatures made by Thee, that he should rule the world in holiness and righteousness: Give me wisdom that sits by Thy throne, and cast me not away from among Thy children, for I am Thy servant and the son of Thy handmaid. Send her forth from the heavens, from Thy holy abode, and from the throne of Thy glory, that she may be with me, and instruct me in what is pleasing to Thee. And she shall guide me in understanding, and preserve me in her glory. For the thoughts of mortals are miserable, and their intentions likely to fail.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 5 - Wisdom of Solomon 4 6 7 2  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>When the righteous is praised, the people rejoice: For his memory is immortality, since it is known both by the Lord and by men, for his soul was pleasing to the Lord. Therefore love wisdom, O men, and live. Desire her and be instructed: For her beginning is love and the keeping of her laws. Honor wisdom that you may reign forever.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>I will tell you and not hide the mysteries of God from you. For He is the Guide of wisdom, the Corrector of the wise and the Artisan of all thoughts and deeds. Wisdom will teach with all understanding: For in her is a Spirit, intelligent and holy, the Radiance of the Everlasting Light and the Image of the Grace of God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>She fashions friends of God and prophets. For she is more beautiful than the sun and above all the order of the stars. Compared with the light she is found to be first. She delivered from infirmities those pleasing her and guided them on the paths of righteousness. She gave to them understanding to be holy and to preserve them from those who would ensnare them, and she granted them strength in struggles, so that all might understand that the most powerful of all is piety, and that evil might not prevail against wisdom, nor judgment pass away without convicting the wicked.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Having reasoned unrighteously, they said to themselves, “Let us oppress the righteous man and not spare his venerableness, nor let us be ashamed of the gray hairs of the old man of many years. But let our might be our law and let us seize the righteous, because he is inconvenient to us and is opposed to our deeds; he reproaches us for apostasy against the law and divulges the sins of our training.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“He declares to us to have knowledge of God and calls himself a child of the Lord. He became to us a reproof of our thoughts; the very sight of him is a burden to us, because his life is unlike that of others, and his ways are very different. We are considered by him to be an insult, and he avoids our ways as unclean; he calls the end of the righteous blessed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“Let us see if his words are true; let us test him to see what will happen to him. Let us torment him with revilement and tortures, that we may understand his meekness and test his guilelessness. Let us condemn him to a shameful death, for, according to his own words, he shall be respected.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Thus they reasoned, but were deceived, for their wickedness blinded them. They did not know the mysteries of God, nor did they discern that Thou alone art God, having the power of life and death: Who savest in times of affliction and deliverest from every evil; Who art compassionate and merciful, granting Grace to His venerable ones, and opposing the proud with His arm.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:1-12  (4th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they, and certain other women with them, came to the tomb bringing the spices which they had prepared.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But they found the stone rolled away from the tomb.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they went in and did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And it happened, as they were greatly perplexed about this, that behold, two men stood by them in shining garments.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then, as they were afraid and bowed their faces to the earth, they said to them, “Why do you seek the living among the dead?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>He is not here, but is risen! Remember how He spoke to you when He was still in Galilee,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>saying, ‘The Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and the third day rise again.’”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they remembered His words.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then they returned from the tomb and told all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and the other women with them, who told these things to the apostles.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And their words seemed to them like idle tales, and they did not believe them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Peter arose and ran to the tomb; and stooping down, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves; and he departed, marveling to himself at what had happened.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 1:11-19  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But I make known to you, brethren, that the gospel which was preached by me is not according to man.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it, but it came through the revelation of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For you have heard of my former conduct in Judaism, how I persecuted the church of God beyond measure and tried to destroy it.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And I advanced in Judaism beyond many of my contemporaries in my own nation, being more exceedingly zealous for the traditions of my fathers.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when it pleased God, who separated me from my mother’s womb and called me through His grace,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to reveal His Son in me, that I might preach Him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately confer with flesh and blood,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; but I went to Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to see Peter, and remained with him fifteen days.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I saw none of the other apostles except James, the Lord’s brother.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:1-9  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 9:32-42  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, as Peter went through all parts of the country, that he also came down to the saints who dwelt in Lydda.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>There he found a certain man named Aeneas, who had been bedridden eight years and was paralyzed.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>And Peter said to him, “Aeneas, Jesus the Christ heals you. Arise and make your bed.” Then he arose immediately.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>So all who dwelt at Lydda and Sharon saw him and turned to the Lord.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>At Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha, which is translated Dorcas. This woman was full of good works and charitable deeds which she did.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But it happened in those days that she became sick and died. When they had washed her, they laid her in an upper room.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And since Lydda was near Joppa, and the disciples had heard that Peter was there, they sent two men to him, imploring him not to delay in coming to them.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Then Peter arose and went with them. When he had come, they brought him to the upper room. And all the widows stood by him weeping, showing the tunics and garments which Dorcas had made while she was with them.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But Peter put them all out, and knelt down and prayed. And turning to the body he said, “Tabitha, arise.” And she opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter she sat up.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Then he gave her his hand and lifted her up; and when he had called the saints and widows, he presented her alive.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And it became known throughout all Joppa, and many believed on the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:1-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>After this there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Now there is in Jerusalem by the Sheep Gate a pool, which is called in Hebrew, Bethesda, having five porches.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>In these lay a great multitude of sick people, blind, lame, paralyzed, waiting for the moving of the water.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For an angel went down at a certain time into the pool and stirred up the water; then whoever stepped in first, after the stirring of the water, was made well of whatever disease he had. </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now a certain man was there who had an infirmity thirty-eight years.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>When Jesus saw him lying there, and knew that he already had been in that condition a long time, He said to him, “Do you want to be made well?”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>The sick man answered Him, “Sir, I have no man to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up; but while I am coming, another steps down before me.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “Rise, take up your bed and walk.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And immediately the man was made well, took up his bed, and walked.
