Whom are you seeking?” She, supposing Him to be the gardener, said to Him, “Sir, if You have carried Him away, tell me where You have laid Him, and I will take Him away.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Mary!” She turned and said to Him, “Rabboni!” (which is to say, Teacher).</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Do not cling to Me, for I have not yet ascended to My Father; but go to My brethren and say to them, ‘I am ascending to My Father and your Father, and to My God and your God.’”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Mary Magdalene came and told the disciples that she had seen the Lord, and that He had spoken these things to her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 26:1-5 12-20  (Epistle Saints)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You are permitted to speak for yourself.” So Paul stretched out his hand and answered for himself:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“I think myself happy, King Agrippa, because today I shall answer for myself before you concerning all the things of which I am accused by the Jews,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>especially because you are expert in all customs and questions which have to do with the Jews. Therefore I beg you to hear me patiently.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>My manner of life from my youth, which was spent from the beginning among my own nation at Jerusalem, all the Jews know.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>They knew me from the first, if they were willing to testify, that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>While thus occupied, as I journeyed to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>at midday, O king, along the road I saw a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those who journeyed with me.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And when we all had fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me and saying in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So I said, ‘Who are You, Lord?’ And He said, ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But rise and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose, to make you a minister and a witness both of the things which you have seen and of the things which I will yet reveal to you.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>I will deliver you from the Jewish people, as well as from the Gentiles, to whom I now send you,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>to open their eyes, in order to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in Me.’</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>but declared first to those in Damascus and in Jerusalem, and throughout all the region of Judea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent, turn to God, and do works befitting repentance.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:1-9  (Gospel Saints)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 16:16-34  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Now it happened, as we went to prayer, that a certain slave girl possessed with a spirit of divination met us, who brought her masters much profit by fortune-telling.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>This girl followed Paul and us, and cried out, saying, “These men are the servants of the Most High God, who proclaim to us the way of salvation.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And this she did for many days. But Paul, greatly annoyed, turned and said to the spirit, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her.” And he came out that very hour.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But when her masters saw that their hope of profit was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace to the authorities.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And they brought them to the magistrates, and said, “These men, being Jews, exceedingly trouble our city;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>and they teach customs which are not lawful for us, being Romans, to receive or observe.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then the multitude rose up together against them; and the magistrates tore off their clothes and commanded them to be beaten with rods.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And when they had laid many stripes on them, they threw them into prison, commanding the jailer to keep them securely.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Having received such a charge, he put them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But at midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken; and immediately all the doors were opened and everyone’s chains were loosed.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And the keeper of the prison, awaking from sleep and seeing the prison doors open, supposing the prisoners had fled, drew his sword and was about to kill himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But Paul called with a loud voice, saying, “Do yourself no harm, for we are all here.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then he called for a light, ran in, and fell down trembling before Paul and Silas.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And he brought them out and said, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>So they said, “Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and you will be saved, you and your household.”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all who were in his house.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And he took them the same hour of the night and washed their stripes. And immediately he and all his family were baptized.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Now when he had brought them into his house, he set food before them; and he rejoiced, having believed in God with all his household.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 9:1-38  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now as Jesus passed by, He saw a man who was blind from birth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And His disciples asked Him, saying, “Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Jesus answered, “Neither this man nor his parents sinned, but that the works of God should be revealed in him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I must work the works of Him who sent Me while it is day; the night is coming when no one can work.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>When He had said these things, He spat on the ground and made clay with the saliva; and He anointed the eyes of the blind man with the clay.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And He said to him, “Go, wash in the pool of Siloam” (which is translated, Sent). So he went and washed, and came back seeing.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore the neighbors and those who previously had seen that he was blind said, “Is not this he who sat and begged?”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Some said, “This is he.” Others said, “He is like him.” He said, “I am he.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore they said to him, “How were your eyes opened?”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He answered and said, “A Man called Jesus made clay and anointed my eyes and said to me, ‘Go to the pool of Siloam and wash.’ So I went and washed, and I received sight.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then they said to him, “Where is He?” He said, “I do not know.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>They brought him who formerly was blind to the Pharisees.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now it was a Sabbath when Jesus made the clay and opened his eyes.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees also asked him again how he had received his sight. He said to them, “He put clay on my eyes, and I washed, and I see.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore some of the Pharisees said, “This Man is not from God, because He does not keep the Sabbath.” Others said, “How can a man who is a sinner do such signs?” And there was a division among them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>They said to the blind man again, “What do you say about Him because He opened your eyes?” He said, “He is a prophet.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But the Jews did not believe concerning him, that he had been blind and received his sight, until they called the parents of him who had received his sight.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And they asked them, saying, “Is this your son, who you say was born blind? How then does he now see?”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>His parents answered them and said, “We know that this is our son, and that he was born blind;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>but by what means he now sees we do not know, or who opened his eyes we do not know. He is of age; ask him. He will speak for himself.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>His parents said these things because they feared the Jews, for the Jews had agreed already that if anyone confessed that He was Christ, he would be put out of the synagogue.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Therefore his parents said, “He is of age; ask him.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So they again called the man who was blind, and said to him, “Give God the glory! We know that this Man is a sinner.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>He answered and said, “Whether He is a sinner or not I do not know. One thing I know: that though I was blind, now I see.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then they said to him again, “What did He do to you? How did He open your eyes?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>He answered them, “I told you already, and you did not listen. Why do you want to hear it again? Do you also want to become His disciples?”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then they reviled him and said, “You are His disciple, but we are Moses’ disciples.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>We know that God spoke to Moses; as for this fellow, we do not know where He is from.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>The man answered and said to them, “Why, this is a marvelous thing, that you do not know where He is from; yet He has opened my eyes!</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Now we know that God does not hear sinners; but if anyone is a worshiper of God and does His will, He hears him.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Since the world began it has been unheard of that anyone opened the eyes of one who was born blind.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>If this Man were not from God, He could do nothing.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>They answered and said to him, “You were completely born in sins, and are you teaching us?” And they cast him out.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Jesus heard that they had cast him out; and when He had found him, He said to him, “Do you believe in the Son of God?” </dd><dt>36</dt><dd>He answered and said, “Who is He, Lord, that I may believe in Him?”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And Jesus said to him, “You have both seen Him and it is He who is talking with you.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then he said, “Lord, I believe!” And he worshiped Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 17:1-15  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when they had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then Paul, as his custom was, went in to them, and for three Sabbaths reasoned with them from the Scriptures,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>explaining and demonstrating that the Christ had to suffer and rise again from the dead, and saying, “This Jesus whom I preach to you is the Christ.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And some of them were persuaded; and a great multitude of the devout Greeks, and not a few of the leading women, joined Paul and Silas.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But the Jews who were not persuaded, becoming envious, took some of the evil men from the marketplace, and gathering a mob, set all the city in an uproar and attacked the house of Jason, and sought to bring them out to the people.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But when they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some brethren to the rulers of the city, crying out, “These who have turned the world upside down have come here too.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Jason has harbored them, and these are all acting contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying there is another king – Jesus.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they troubled the crowd and the rulers of the city when they heard these things.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So when they had taken security from Jason and the rest, they let them go.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the brethren immediately sent Paul and Silas away by night to Berea. When they arrived, they went into the synagogue of the Jews.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>These were more fair-minded than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness, and searched the Scriptures daily to find out whether these things were so.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore many of them believed, and also not a few of the Greeks, prominent women as well as men.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that the word of God was preached by Paul at Berea, they came there also and stirred up the crowds.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then immediately the brethren sent Paul away, to go to the sea; but both Silas and Timothy remained there.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So those who conducted Paul brought him to Athens; and receiving a command for Silas and Timothy to come to him with all speed, they departed.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 11:47-57  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>47</dt><dd>Then the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered a council and said, “What shall we do? For this Man works many signs.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>If we let Him alone like this, everyone will believe in Him, and the Romans will come and take away both our place and nation.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>And one of them, Caiaphas, being high priest that year, said to them, “You know nothing at all,</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>nor do you consider that it is expedient for us that one man should die for the people, and not that the whole nation should perish.”</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Now this he did not say on his own authority; but being high priest that year he prophesied that Jesus would die for the nation,</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>and not for that nation only, but also that He would gather together in one the children of God who were scattered abroad.</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>Then, from that day on, they plotted to put Him to death.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>Therefore Jesus no longer walked openly among the Jews, but went from there into the country near the wilderness, to a city called Ephraim, and there remained with His disciples.</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>And the Passover of the Jews was near, and many went from the country up to Jerusalem before the Passover, to purify themselves.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>Then they sought Jesus, and spoke among themselves as they stood in the temple, “What do you think – that He will not come to the feast?”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>Now both the chief priests and the Pharisees had given a command, that if anyone knew where He was, he should report it, that they might seize Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 17:19-28  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>And they took him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, “May we know what this new doctrine is of which you speak?</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For you are bringing some strange things to our ears. Therefore we want to know what these things mean.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For all the Athenians and the foreigners who were there spent their time in nothing else but either to tell or to hear some new thing.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then Paul stood in the midst of the Areopagus and said, “Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things you are very religious;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>for as I was passing through and considering the objects of your worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: TO THE UNKNOWN GOD. Therefore, the One whom you worship without knowing, Him I proclaim to you:</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>God, who made the world and everything in it, since He is Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in temples made with hands.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Nor is He worshiped with men’s hands, as though He needed anything, since He gives to all life, breath, and all things.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And He has made from one blood every nation of men to dwell on all the face of the earth, and has determined their preappointed times and the boundaries of their dwellings,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>so that they should seek the Lord, in the hope that they might grope for Him and find Him, though He is not far from each one of us;</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>for in Him we live and move and have our being, as also some of your own poets have said, ‘For we are also His offspring.’</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 12:19-36  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>The Pharisees therefore said among themselves, “You see that you are accomplishing nothing. Look, the world has gone after Him!”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now there were certain Greeks among those who came up to worship at the feast.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then they came to Philip, who was from Bethsaida of Galilee, and asked him, saying, “Sir, we wish to see Jesus.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Philip came and told Andrew, and in turn Andrew and Philip told Jesus.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But Jesus answered them, saying, “The hour has come that the Son of Man should be glorified.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, unless a grain of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it produces much grain.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>He who loves his life will lose it, and he who hates his life in this world will keep it for eternal life.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>If anyone serves Me, let him follow Me; and where I am, there My servant will be also. If anyone serves Me, him My Father will honor.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Now My soul is troubled, and what shall I say? ‘Father, save Me from this hour’? But for this purpose I came to this hour.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Father, glorify Your name.” Then a voice came from heaven, saying, “I have both glorified it and will glorify it again.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Therefore the people who stood by and heard it said that it had thundered. Others said, “An angel has spoken to Him.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said, “This voice did not come because of Me, but for your sake.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Now is the judgment of this world; now the ruler of this world will be cast out.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And I, if I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all peoples to Myself.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>This He said, signifying by what death He would die.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>The people answered Him, “We have heard from the law that the Christ remains forever; and how can You say, ‘The Son of Man must be lifted up’? Who is this Son of Man?”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “A little while longer the light is with you. Walk while you have the light, lest darkness overtake you; he who walks in darkness does not know where he is going.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>While you have the light, believe in the light, that you may become sons of light.” These things Jesus spoke, and departed, and was hidden from them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 18:22-28  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>And when he had landed at Caesarea, and gone up and greeted the church, he went down to Antioch.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>After he had spent some time there, he departed and went over the region of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening all the disciples.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now a certain Jew named Apollos, born at Alexandria, an eloquent man and mighty in the Scriptures, came to Ephesus.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>This man had been instructed in the way of the Lord; and being fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the things of the Lord, though he knew only the baptism of John.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>So he began to speak boldly in the synagogue. When Aquila and Priscilla heard him, they took him aside and explained to him the way of God more accurately.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And when he desired to cross to Achaia, the brethren wrote, exhorting the disciples to receive him; and when he arrived, he greatly helped those who had believed through grace;</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>for he vigorously refuted the Jews publicly, showing from the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 12:36-47  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>While you have the light, believe in the light, that you may become sons of light.” These things Jesus spoke, and departed, and was hidden from them.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But although He had done so many signs before them, they did not believe in Him,</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>that the word of Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled, which he spoke: “Lord, who has believed our report? And to whom has the arm of the LORD been revealed?” </dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Therefore they could not believe, because Isaiah said again:</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>“He has blinded their eyes and hardened their hearts, lest they should see with their eyes, lest they should understand with their hearts and turn, so that I should heal them.” </dd><dt>41</dt><dd>These things Isaiah said when he saw His glory and spoke of Him.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Nevertheless even among the rulers many believed in Him, but because of the Pharisees they did not confess Him, lest they should be put out of the synagogue;</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>for they loved the praise of men more than the praise of God.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then Jesus cried out and said, “He who believes in Me, believes not in Me but in Him who sent Me.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>And he who sees Me sees Him who sent Me.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>I have come as a light into the world, that whoever believes in Me should not abide in darkness.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>And if anyone hears My words and does not believe, I do not judge him; for I did not come to judge the world but to save the world.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 8 - Isaiah 40 41 45 48 54  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord: “Comfort, comfort My people,” says God. “Speak to the heart of Jerusalem, you Priests, comfort her, for her humiliation is increased, her iniquity is pardoned; for she has received from the Lord’s hand double for her sins. The voice of one crying in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the Lord; make straight the paths of our God.’</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“Go up to a high mountain, you who are proclaiming glad tidings to Zion, lift up your voice with strength, O herald of good tidings to Jerusalem. Lift it up, fear not! I the Lord God, I have heard the poor of Israel and will not forsake them. I will open rivers on the mountains, and fountains in the midst of the valleys; I will make the deserts pools of water, and the thirsty land springs of water. Let the heavens rejoice from above, and let the clouds rain down righteousness; let the earth bring forth, and let it sprout forth mercy and cause righteousness to shine forth also.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Declare this with a shout of joy, and let this be known, proclaim it to the end of the earth. Say, ‘The Lord hath redeemed His servant Jacob!’ And if they thirst, he shall lead them through the desert, He shall bring forth water for them out of the rock. Rejoice, O barren one who did not bear; break forth into singing and cry loud, you who have not been in travail! For more are the children of the desolate one than of her who has a husband.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 9 - Malachi 3 4  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord Almighty: “Behold, I send My messenger before Thy face, who shall prepare Thy way before Thee, and the Lord whom ye seek, shall come into His temple. But who can endure the day of His coming? For He is coming like the fire of a furnace and like the fuller’s herb; and He shall cleanse, refining and purifying, as it were, silver and gold. And He comes to you with judgment, and will be a swift witness against the evil ones and against adulterers, and against those who swear falsely by My name, against those who withhold the hireling’s wages, against those who oppress widows and beat orphans, against those who avoid judgment in favor of strangers, and against those who do not fear him,” saith the Lord Almighty.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“For I am the Lord your God, and I change not; and you, the sons of Jacob, have turned aside from the law and have not kept it. Return to Me, therefore, and I will return to you,” saith the Lord Almighty. “And all nations shall call you blessed, and they shall understand that I am the Lord, who distinguishes between the righteous and between the transgressors on that day, in which I shall act to spare those who love Me.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Know, therefore, and remember the Law of Moses, My servant, as I commanded you at Horeb, the statutes and ordinances for all Israel. And behold, I will send to you Elijah the Tishbite before the great and glorious day of the Lord comes, who shall turn the heart of a father to his son, and the heart of a man to his neighbor, lest I come quickly and smite the earth,” saith the Lord Almighty, God, the Holy One of Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 3 - Wisdom 4 5  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest. The righteous man who has died will judge the ungodly who are living. For they will see the end of the righteous, and will not understand what was said about him; for the Lord will cast down the ungodly speechless to the ground and shake them from the foundations; they shall become desolate to the end; they will be in sorrows, and their memory will perish. For they will come with fear at the thought of their sins, and their iniquities shall stand against them to convict them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then the righteous man will stand with great boldness before those who have afflicted him, and those who have made of no account his labors. Having seen it, they shall be troubled with much fear and they will be amazed at his most-glorious salvation. They will say within themselves in repentance, in anguish of spirit they will groan and say: “This was he whom we had sometimes in derision and a proverb of reproach – we fools! We accounted his life as madness, and his end to be without honor. How is he numbered among the sons of God? And why is his lot among the Saints?</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Therefore, we have erred from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness did not illumine us, nor did the sun shine on us. We took our fill of the paths of lawlessness and destruction, and we walked impassable pathways, but the way of the Lord we have not known.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:17-30  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And this report about Him went throughout all Judea and all the surrounding region.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then the disciples of John reported to him concerning all these things.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And John, calling two of his disciples to him, sent them to Jesus, saying, “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>When the men had come to Him, they said, “John the Baptist has sent us to You, saying, ‘Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?’”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And that very hour He cured many of infirmities, afflictions, and evil spirits; and to many blind He gave sight.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “Go and tell John the things you have seen and heard: that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, the poor have the gospel preached to them.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>When the messengers of John had departed, He began to speak to the multitudes concerning John: “What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A man clothed in soft garments? Indeed those who are gorgeously appareled and live in luxury are in kings’ courts.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I say to you, and more than a prophet.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>This is he of whom it is written: ‘Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, Who will prepare Your way before You.’ </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For I say to you, among those born of women there is not a greater prophet than John the Baptist; but he who is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And when all the people heard Him, even the tax collectors justified God, having been baptized with the baptism of John.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But the Pharisees and lawyers rejected the will of God for themselves, not having been baptized by him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 4:6-15  (Epistle Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>For it is the God who commanded light to shine out of darkness, who has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellence of the power may be of God and not of us.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>We are hard-pressed on every side, yet not crushed; we are perplexed, but not in despair;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>persecuted, but not forsaken; struck down, but not destroyed – </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>always carrying about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus, that the life of Jesus also may be manifested in our body.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For we who live are always delivered to death for Jesus’ sake, that the life of Jesus also may be manifested in our mortal flesh.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So then death is working in us, but life in you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And since we have the same spirit of faith, according to what is written, “I believed and therefore I spoke,” we also believe and therefore speak,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>knowing that He who raised up the Lord Jesus will also raise us up with Jesus, and will present us with you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For all things are for your sakes, that grace, having spread through the many, may cause thanksgiving to abound to the glory of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:2-15  (Gospel Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>And when John had heard in prison about the works of Christ, he sent two of his disciples</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said to Him, “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “Go and tell John the things which you hear and see:</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The blind see and the lame walk; the lepers are cleansed and the deaf hear; the dead are raised up and the poor have the gospel preached to them.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>As they departed, Jesus began to say to the multitudes concerning John: “What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A man clothed in soft garments? Indeed, those who wear soft clothing are in kings’ houses.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I say to you, and more than a prophet.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For this is he of whom it is written: ‘Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, who will prepare Your way before You.’ </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, among those born of women there has not risen one greater than John the Baptist; but he who is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And from the days of John the Baptist until now the kingdom of heaven suffers violence, and the violent take it by force.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And if you are willing to receive it, he is Elijah who is to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He who has ears to hear, let him hear!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 1:1-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The former account I made, O Theophilus, of all that Jesus began both to do and teach,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>until the day in which He was taken up, after He through the Holy Spirit had given commandments to the apostles whom He had chosen,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>to whom He also presented Himself alive after His suffering by many infallible proofs, being seen by them during forty days and speaking of the things pertaining to the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And being assembled together with them, He commanded them not to depart from Jerusalem, but to wait for the Promise of the Father, “which,” He said, “you have heard from Me;</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>for John truly baptized with water, but you shall be baptized with the Holy Spirit not many days from now.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Therefore, when they had come together, they asked Him, saying, “Lord, will You at this time restore the kingdom to Israel?”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And He said to them, “It is not for you to know times or seasons which the Father has put in His own authority.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But you shall receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you; and you shall be witnesses to Me in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the end of the earth.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when He had spoken these things, while they watched, He was taken up, and a cloud received Him out of their sight.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And while they looked steadfastly toward heaven as He went up, behold, two men stood by them in white apparel,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>who also said, “Men of Galilee, why do you stand gazing up into heaven? This same Jesus, who was taken up from you into heaven, will so come in like manner as you saw Him go into heaven.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then they returned to Jerusalem from the mount called Olivet, which is near Jerusalem, a Sabbath day’s journey.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:36-53  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>Now as they said these things, Jesus Himself stood in the midst of them, and said to them, “Peace to you.”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But they were terrified and frightened, and supposed they had seen a spirit.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Why are you troubled? And why do doubts arise in your hearts?</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Behold My hands and My feet, that it is I Myself. Handle Me and see, for a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see I have.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His feet. </dd><dt>41</dt><dd>But while they still did not believe for joy, and marveled, He said to them, “Have you any food here?”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>So they gave Him a piece of a broiled fish and some honeycomb. </dd><dt>43</dt><dd>And He took it and ate in their presence.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “These are the words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that all things must be fulfilled which were written in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms concerning Me.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>And He opened their understanding, that they might comprehend the Scriptures.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Thus it is written, and thus it was necessary for the Christ to suffer and to rise from the dead the third day,</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>and that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in His name to all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>And you are witnesses of these things.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Behold, I send the Promise of My Father upon you; but tarry in the city of Jerusalem until you are endued with power from on high.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>And He led them out as far as Bethany, and He lifted up His hands and blessed them.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, while He blessed them, that He was parted from them and carried up into heaven.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>And they worshiped Him, and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>and were continually in the temple praising and blessing God. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 19:1-8  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And it happened, while Apollos was at Corinth, that Paul, having passed through the upper regions, came to Ephesus. And finding some disciples</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>he said to them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” So they said to him, “We have not so much as heard whether there is a Holy Spirit.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And he said to them, “Into what then were you baptized?” So they said, “Into John’s baptism.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then Paul said, “John indeed baptized with a baptism of repentance, saying to the people that they should believe on Him who would come after him, that is, on Christ Jesus.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And when Paul had laid hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they spoke with tongues and prophesied.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Now the men were about twelve in all.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And he went into the synagogue and spoke boldly for three months, reasoning and persuading concerning the things of the kingdom of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 14:1-11  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Let not your heart be troubled; you believe in God, believe also in Me.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In My Father’s house are many mansions; if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you. </dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again and receive you to Myself; that where I am, there you may be also.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And where I go you know, and the way you know.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Thomas said to Him, “Lord, we do not know where You are going, and how can we know the way?”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>If you had known Me, you would have known My Father also; and from now on you know Him and have seen Him.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Philip said to Him, “Lord, show us the Father, and it is sufficient for us.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “Have I been with you so long, and yet you have not known Me, Philip? He who has seen Me has seen the Father; so how can you say, ‘Show us the Father’?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Do you not believe that I am in the Father, and the Father in Me? The words that I speak to you I do not speak on My own authority; but the Father who dwells in Me does the works.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Believe Me that I am in the Father and the Father in Me, or else believe Me for the sake of the works themselves.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 20:7-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week, when the disciples came together to break bread, Paul, ready to depart the next day, spoke to them and continued his message until midnight.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>There were many lamps in the upper room where they were gathered together.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And in a window sat a certain young man named Eutychus, who was sinking into a deep sleep. He was overcome by sleep; and as Paul continued speaking, he fell down from the third story and was taken up dead.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But Paul went down, fell on him, and embracing him said, “Do not trouble yourselves, for his life is in him.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now when he had come up, had broken bread and eaten, and talked a long while, even till daybreak, he departed.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And they brought the young man in alive, and they were not a little comforted.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 14:10-21  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Do you not believe that I am in the Father, and the Father in Me? The words that I speak to you I do not speak on My own authority; but the Father who dwells in Me does the works.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Believe Me that I am in the Father and the Father in Me, or else believe Me for the sake of the works themselves.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who believes in Me, the works that I do he will do also; and greater works than these he will do, because I go to My Father.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And whatever you ask in My name, that I will do, that the Father may be glorified in the Son.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>If you ask anything in My name, I will do it.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>If you love Me, keep My commandments.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And I will pray the Father, and He will give you another Helper, that He may abide with you forever – </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees Him nor knows Him; but you know Him, for He dwells with you and will be in you.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>I will not leave you orphans; I will come to you.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>A little while longer and the world will see Me no more, but you will see Me. Because I live, you will live also.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>At that day you will know that I am in My Father, and you in Me, and I in you.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He who has My commandments and keeps them, it is he who loves Me. And he who loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I will love him and manifest Myself to him.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 14:14-20  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when Abram heard that his brother was taken captive, he armed his three hundred and eighteen trained servants who were born in his own house, and went in pursuit as far as Dan.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He divided his forces against them by night, and he and his servants attacked them and pursued them as far as Hobah, which is north of Damascus.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So he brought back all the goods, and also brought back his brother Lot and his goods, as well as the women and the people.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And the king of Sodom went out to meet him at the Valley of Shaveh (that is, the King’s Valley), after his return from the defeat of Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine; he was the priest of God Most High.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And he blessed him and said: “Blessed be Abram of God Most High, Possessor of heaven and earth;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And blessed be God Most High, Who has delivered your enemies into your hand.” And he gave him a tithe of all.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Deuteronomy 1:8-11 15-17  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>See, I have set the land before you; go in and possess the land which the Lord swore to your fathers – to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob – to give to them and their descendants after them.’ </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And I spoke to you at that time, saying: ‘I alone am not able to bear you.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The Lord your God has multiplied you, and here you are today, as the stars of heaven in multitude. </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>May the Lord God of your fathers make you a thousand times more numerous than you are, and bless you as He has promised you! </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So I took the heads of your tribes, wise and knowledgeable men, and made them heads over you, leaders of thousands, leaders of hundreds, leaders of fifties, leaders of tens, and officers for your tribes. </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then I commanded your judges at that time, saying, ‘Hear the cases between your brethren, and judge righteously between a man and his brother or the stranger who is with him. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>You shall not show partiality in judgment; you shall hear the small as well as the great; you shall not be afraid in any man’s presence, for the judgment is God’s. The case that is too hard for you, bring to me, and I will hear it.’ </dd></dl>

readings.title: Deuteronomy 10:14-21  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Indeed heaven and the highest heavens belong to the Lord your God, also the earth with all that is in it. </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The Lord delighted only in your fathers, to love them; and He chose their descendants after them, you above all peoples, as it is this day. </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore circumcise the foreskin of your heart, and be stiff-necked no longer. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For the Lord your God is God of gods and Lord of lords, the great God, mighty and awesome, who shows no partiality nor takes a bribe. </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>He administers justice for the fatherless and the widow, and loves the stranger, giving him food and clothing. </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Therefore love the stranger, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt. </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>You shall fear the Lord your God; you shall serve Him, and to Him you shall hold fast, and take oaths in His name. </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He is your praise, and He is your God, who has done for you these great and awesome things which your eyes have seen. </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:1-14  (10th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>After these things Jesus showed Himself again to the disciples at the Sea of Tiberias, and in this way He showed Himself:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Simon Peter, Thomas called the Twin, Nathanael of Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two others of His disciples were together.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Simon Peter said to them, “I am going fishing.” They said to him, “We are going with you also.” They went out and immediately got into the boat, and that night they caught nothing.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But when the morning had now come, Jesus stood on the shore; yet the disciples did not know that it was Jesus.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “Children, have you any food?” They answered Him, “No.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Cast the net on the right side of the boat, and you will find some.” So they cast, and now they were not able to draw it in because of the multitude of fish.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore that disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, “It is the Lord!” Now when Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he put on his outer garment (for he had removed it), and plunged into the sea.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But the other disciples came in the little boat (for they were not far from land, but about two hundred cubits), dragging the net with fish.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then, as soon as they had come to land, they saw a fire of coals there, and fish laid on it, and bread.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Bring some of the fish which you have just caught.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Simon Peter went up and dragged the net to land, full of large fish, one hundred and fifty-three; and although there were so many, the net was not broken.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Come and eat breakfast.” Yet none of the disciples dared ask Him, “Who are You?” – knowing that it was the Lord.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Jesus then came and took the bread and gave it to them, and likewise the fish.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>This is now the third time Jesus showed Himself to His disciples after He was raised from the dead.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 20:16-18 28-36  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he would not have to spend time in Asia; for he was hurrying to be at Jerusalem, if possible, on the Day of Pentecost.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>From Miletus he sent to Ephesus and called for the elders of the church.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And when they had come to him, he said to them: “You know, from the first day that I came to Asia, in what manner I always lived among you,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore take heed to yourselves and to all the flock, among which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to shepherd the church of God which He purchased with His own blood.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For I know this, that after my departure savage wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Also from among yourselves men will rise up, speaking perverse things, to draw away the disciples after themselves.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore watch, and remember that for three years I did not cease to warn everyone night and day with tears.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>So now, brethren, I commend you to God and to the word of His grace, which is able to build you up and give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>I have coveted no one’s silver or gold or apparel.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Yes, you yourselves know that these hands have provided for my necessities, and for those who were with me.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>I have shown you in every way, by laboring like this, that you must support the weak. And remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that He said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And when he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 17:1-13  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Jesus spoke these words, lifted up His eyes to heaven, and said: “Father, the hour has come. Glorify Your Son, that Your Son also may glorify You,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>as You have given Him authority over all flesh, that He should give eternal life to as many as You have given Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And this is eternal life, that they may know You, the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom You have sent.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I have glorified You on the earth. I have finished the work which You have given Me to do.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And now, O Father, glorify Me together with Yourself, with the glory which I had with You before the world was.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>I have manifested Your name to the men whom You have given Me out of the world. They were Yours, You gave them to Me, and they have kept Your word.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Now they have known that all things which You have given Me are from You.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For I have given to them the words which You have given Me; and they have received them, and have known surely that I came forth from You; and they have believed that You sent Me.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I pray for them. I do not pray for the world but for those whom You have given Me, for they are Yours.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And all Mine are Yours, and Yours are Mine, and I am glorified in them.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now I am no longer in the world, but these are in the world, and I come to You. Holy Father, keep through Your name those whom You have given Me, that they may be one as We are.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>While I was with them in the world, I kept them in Your name. Those whom You gave Me I have kept; and none of them is lost except the son of perdition, that the Scripture might be fulfilled.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But now I come to You, and these things I speak in the world, that they may have My joy fulfilled in themselves.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 21:8-14  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>On the next day we who were Paul’s companions departed and came to Caesarea, and entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now this man had four virgin daughters who prophesied.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And as we stayed many days, a certain prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>When he had come to us, he took Paul’s belt, bound his own hands and feet, and said, “Thus says the Holy Spirit, ‘So shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man who owns this belt, and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Now when we heard these things, both we and those from that place pleaded with him not to go up to Jerusalem.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Paul answered, “What do you mean by weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So when he would not be persuaded, we ceased, saying, “The will of the Lord be done.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 14:27-15:7  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>Peace I leave with you, My peace I give to you; not as the world gives do I give to you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>You have heard Me say to you, ‘I am going away and coming back to you.’ If you loved Me, you would rejoice because I said, ‘I am going to the Father,’ for My Father is greater than I.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And now I have told you before it comes, that when it does come to pass, you may believe.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I will no longer talk much with you, for the ruler of this world is coming, and he has nothing in Me.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>But that the world may know that I love the Father, and as the Father gave Me commandment, so I do. Arise, let us go from here.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>I am the true vine, and My Father is the vinedresser.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Every branch in Me that does not bear fruit He takes away; and every branch that bears fruit He prunes, that it may bear more fruit.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>You are already clean because of the word which I have spoken to you.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Abide in Me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit of itself, unless it abides in the vine, neither can you, unless you abide in Me.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>I am the vine, you are the branches. He who abides in Me, and I in him, bears much fruit; for without Me you can do nothing.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>If anyone does not abide in Me, he is cast out as a branch and is withered; and they gather them and throw them into the fire, and they are burned.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>If you abide in Me, and My words abide in you, you will ask what you desire, and it shall be done for you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 21:26-32  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>Then Paul took the men, and the next day, having been purified with them, entered the temple to announce the expiration of the days of purification, at which time an offering should be made for each one of them.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Now when the seven days were almost ended, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd and laid hands on him,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>crying out, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches all men everywhere against the people, the law, and this place; and furthermore he also brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>(For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, whom they supposed that Paul had brought into the temple.)</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And all the city was disturbed; and the people ran together, seized Paul, and dragged him out of the temple; and immediately the doors were shut.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Now as they were seeking to kill him, news came to the commander of the garrison that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>He immediately took soldiers and centurions, and ran down to them. And when they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 16:2-13  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>They will put you out of the synagogues; yes, the time is coming that whoever kills you will think that he offers God service.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And these things they will do to you because they have not known the Father nor Me.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But these things I have told you, that when the time comes, you may remember that I told you of them. And these things I did not say to you at the beginning, because I was with you.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But now I go away to Him who sent Me, and none of you asks Me, ‘Where are You going?’</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But because I have said these things to you, sorrow has filled your heart.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Nevertheless I tell you the truth. It is to your advantage that I go away; for if I do not go away, the Helper will not come to you; but if I depart, I will send Him to you.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And when He has come, He will convict the world of sin, and of righteousness, and of judgment:</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>of sin, because they do not believe in Me;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>of righteousness, because I go to My Father and you see Me no more;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>of judgment, because the ruler of this world is judged.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I still have many things to say to you, but you cannot bear them now.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>However, when He, the Spirit of truth, has come, He will guide you into all truth; for He will not speak on His own authority, but whatever He hears He will speak; and He will tell you things to come.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 23:1-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then Paul, looking earnestly at the council, said, “Men and brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the high priest Ananias commanded those who stood by him to strike him on the mouth.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Paul said to him, “God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! For you sit to judge me according to the law, and do you command me to be struck contrary to the law?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And those who stood by said, “Do you revile God’s high priest?”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Paul said, “I did not know, brethren, that he was the high priest; for it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil of a ruler of your people.’”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But when Paul perceived that one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, “Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee; concerning the hope and resurrection of the dead I am being judged!”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And when he had said this, a dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees; and the assembly was divided.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For Sadducees say that there is no resurrection – and no angel or spirit; but the Pharisees confess both.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then there arose a loud outcry. And the scribes of the Pharisees’ party arose and protested, saying, “We find no evil in this man; but if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him, let us not fight against God.” </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Now when there arose a great dissension, the commander, fearing lest Paul might be pulled to pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him by force from among them, and bring him into the barracks.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But the following night the Lord stood by him and said, “Be of good cheer, Paul; for as you have testified for Me in Jerusalem, so you must also bear witness at Rome.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 16:15-23  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>All things that the Father has are Mine. Therefore I said that He will take of Mine and declare it to you. </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>A little while, and you will not see Me; and again a little while, and you will see Me, because I go to the Father.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then some of His disciples said among themselves, “What is this that He says to us, ‘A little while, and you will not see Me; and again a little while, and you will see Me’; and, ‘because I go to the Father’?”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>They said therefore, “What is this that He says, ‘A little while’? We do not know what He is saying.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Now Jesus knew that they desired to ask Him, and He said to them, “Are you inquiring among yourselves about what I said, ‘A little while, and you will not see Me; and again a little while, and you will see Me’?</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you that you will weep and lament, but the world will rejoice; and you will be sorrowful, but your sorrow will be turned into joy.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>A woman, when she is in labor, has sorrow because her hour has come; but as soon as she has given birth to the child, she no longer remembers the anguish, for joy that a human being has been born into the world.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Therefore you now have sorrow; but I will see you again and your heart will rejoice, and your joy no one will take from you.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And in that day you will ask Me nothing. Most assuredly, I say to you, whatever you ask the Father in My name He will give you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 25:13-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>And after some days King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to greet Festus.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>When they had been there many days, Festus laid Paul’s case before the king, saying: “There is a certain man left a prisoner by Felix,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>about whom the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me, when I was in Jerusalem, asking for a judgment against him.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>To them I answered, ‘It is not the custom of the Romans to deliver any man to destruction before the accused meets the accusers face to face, and has opportunity to answer for himself concerning the charge against him.’</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore when they had come together, without any delay, the next day I sat on the judgment seat and commanded the man to be brought in.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>When the accusers stood up, they brought no accusation against him of such things as I supposed,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>but had some questions against him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus, who had died, whom Paul affirmed to be alive.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 16:23-33  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>And in that day you will ask Me nothing. Most assuredly, I say to you, whatever you ask the Father in My name He will give you.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Until now you have asked nothing in My name. Ask, and you will receive, that your joy may be full.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>These things I have spoken to you in figurative language; but the time is coming when I will no longer speak to you in figurative language, but I will tell you plainly about the Father.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>In that day you will ask in My name, and I do not say to you that I shall pray the Father for you;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>for the Father Himself loves you, because you have loved Me, and have believed that I came forth from God.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>I came forth from the Father and have come into the world. Again, I leave the world and go to the Father.” </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>His disciples said to Him, “See, now You are speaking plainly, and using no figure of speech!</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now we are sure that You know all things, and have no need that anyone should question You. By this we believe that You came forth from God.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Jesus answered them, “Do you now believe?</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Indeed the hour is coming, yes, has now come, that you will be scattered, each to his own, and will leave Me alone. And yet I am not alone, because the Father is with Me.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>These things I have spoken to you, that in Me you may have peace. In the world you will have tribulation; but be of good cheer, I have overcome the world.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 27:1-44  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And when it was decided that we should sail to Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to one named Julius, a centurion of the Augustan Regiment.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>So, entering a ship of Adramyttium, we put to sea, meaning to sail along the coasts of Asia. Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, was with us.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And the next day we landed at Sidon. And Julius treated Paul kindly and gave him liberty to go to his friends and receive care.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>When we had put to sea from there, we sailed under the shelter of Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And when we had sailed over the sea which is off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing to Italy, and he put us on board.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When we had sailed slowly many days, and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, the wind not permitting us to proceed, we sailed under the shelter of Crete off Salmone.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Passing it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when much time had been spent, and sailing was now dangerous because the Fast was already over, Paul advised them,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>saying, “Men, I perceive that this voyage will end with disaster and much loss, not only of the cargo and ship, but also our lives.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Nevertheless the centurion was more persuaded by the helmsman and the owner of the ship than by the things spoken by Paul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And because the harbor was not suitable to winter in, the majority advised to set sail from there also, if by any means they could reach Phoenix, a harbor of Crete opening toward the southwest and northwest, and winter there.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>When the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained their desire, putting out to sea, they sailed close by Crete.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But not long after, a tempestuous head wind arose, called Euroclydon.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So when the ship was caught, and could not head into the wind, we let her drive.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And running under the shelter of an island called Clauda, we secured the skiff with difficulty.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>When they had taken it on board, they used cables to undergird the ship; and fearing lest they should run aground on the Syrtis Sands, they struck sail and so were driven.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And because we were exceedingly tempest-tossed, the next day they lightened the ship.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>On the third day we threw the ship’s tackle overboard with our own hands.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now when neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small tempest beat on us, all hope that we would be saved was finally given up.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But after long abstinence from food, then Paul stood in the midst of them and said, “Men, you should have listened to me, and not have sailed from Crete and incurred this disaster and loss.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And now I urge you to take heart, for there will be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For there stood by me this night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>saying, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul; you must be brought before Caesar; and indeed God has granted you all those who sail with you.’</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Therefore take heart, men, for I believe God that it will be just as it was told me.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>However, we must run aground on a certain island.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Now when the fourteenth night had come, as we were driven up and down in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors sensed that they were drawing near some land.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And they took soundings and found it to be twenty fathoms; and when they had gone a little farther, they took soundings again and found it to be fifteen fathoms.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then, fearing lest we should run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern, and prayed for day to come.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And as the sailors were seeking to escape from the ship, when they had let down the skiff into the sea, under pretense of putting out anchors from the prow,</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men stay in the ship, you cannot be saved.”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the skiff and let it fall off.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And as day was about to dawn, Paul implored them all to take food, saying, “Today is the fourteenth day you have waited and continued without food, and eaten nothing.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Therefore I urge you to take nourishment, for this is for your survival, since not a hair will fall from the head of any of you.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And when he had said these things, he took bread and gave thanks to God in the presence of them all; and when he had broken it he began to eat.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then they were all encouraged, and also took food themselves.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And in all we were two hundred and seventy-six persons on the ship.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>So when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and threw out the wheat into the sea.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>When it was day, they did not recognize the land; but they observed a bay with a beach, onto which they planned to run the ship if possible.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>And they let go the anchors and left them in the sea, meanwhile loosing the rudder ropes; and they hoisted the mainsail to the wind and made for shore.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>But striking a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the prow stuck fast and remained immovable, but the stern was being broken up by the violence of the waves.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And the soldiers’ plan was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim away and escape.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, kept them from their purpose, and commanded that those who could swim should jump overboard first and get to land,</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>and the rest, some on boards and some on parts of the ship. And so it was that they all escaped safely to land.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 17:18-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>As You sent Me into the world, I also have sent them into the world.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And for their sakes I sanctify Myself, that they also may be sanctified by the truth.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>I do not pray for these alone, but also for those who will believe in Me through their word;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>that they all may be one, as You, Father, are in Me, and I in You; that they also may be one in Us, that the world may believe that You sent Me.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And the glory which You gave Me I have given them, that they may be one just as We are one:</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>I in them, and You in Me; that they may be made perfect in one, and that the world may know that You have sent Me, and have loved them as You have loved Me.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Father, I desire that they also whom You gave Me may be with Me where I am, that they may behold My glory which You have given Me; for You loved Me before the foundation of the world.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>O righteous Father! The world has not known You, but I have known You; and these have known that You sent Me.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And I have declared to them Your name, and will declare it, that the love with which You loved Me may be in them, and I in them.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17  (Epistle Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning those who have fallen asleep, lest you sorrow as others who have no hope.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who sleep in Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and remain until the coming of the Lord will by no means precede those who are asleep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of an archangel, and with the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then we who are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And thus we shall always be with the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 15:47-57  (Epistle Departed variant)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>47</dt><dd>The first man was of the earth, made of dust; the second Man is the Lord from heaven.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>As was the man of dust, so also are those who are made of dust; and as is the heavenly Man, so also are those who are heavenly.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>And as we have borne the image of the man of dust, we shall also bear the image of the heavenly Man.</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God; nor does corruption inherit incorruption.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Behold, I tell you a mystery: We shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed – </dd><dt>52</dt><dd>in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed.</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>So when this corruptible has put on incorruption, and this mortal has put on immortality, then shall be brought to pass the saying that is written: “Death is swallowed up in victory.”</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>O Death, where is your sting? O Hell, where is your victory?</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>The sting of death is sin, and the strength of sin is the law.</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:24-30  (Gospel Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have life in Himself,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and has given Him authority to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of Man.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will hear His voice</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and come forth – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 6:35-39  (Gospel Departed variant)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>And Jesus said to them, “I am the bread of life. He who comes to Me shall never hunger, and he who believes in Me shall never thirst.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>But I said to you that you have seen Me and yet do not believe.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>All that the Father gives Me will come to Me, and the one who comes to Me I will by no means cast out.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>For I have come down from heaven, not to do My own will, but the will of Him who sent Me.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>This is the will of the Father who sent Me, that of all He has given Me I should lose nothing, but should raise it up at the last day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 28:1-31  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when they had escaped, they then found out that the island was called Malta.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the natives showed us unusual kindness; for they kindled a fire and made us all welcome, because of the rain that was falling and because of the cold.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and laid them on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat, and fastened on his hand.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So when the natives saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he has escaped the sea, yet justice does not allow to live.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But he shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>However, they were expecting that he would swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But after they had looked for a long time and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In that region there was an estate of the leading citizen of the island, whose name was Publius, who received us and entertained us courteously for three days.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And it happened that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and dysentery. Paul went in to him and prayed, and he laid his hands on him and healed him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So when this was done, the rest of those on the island who had diseases also came and were healed.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>They also honored us in many ways; and when we departed, they provided such things as were necessary.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>After three months we sailed in an Alexandrian ship whose figurehead was the Twin Brothers, which had wintered at the island.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And landing at Syracuse, we stayed three days.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>From there we circled round and reached Rhegium. And after one day the south wind blew; and the next day we came to Puteoli,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>where we found brethren, and were invited to stay with them seven days. And so we went toward Rome.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And from there, when the brethren heard about us, they came to meet us as far as Appii Forum and Three Inns. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Now when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard; but Paul was permitted to dwell by himself with the soldier who guarded him.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And it came to pass after three days that Paul called the leaders of the Jews together. So when they had come together, he said to them: “Men and brethren, though I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>who, when they had examined me, wanted to let me go, because there was no cause for putting me to death.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But when the Jews spoke against it, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, not that I had anything of which to accuse my nation.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For this reason therefore I have called for you, to see you and speak with you, because for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then they said to him, “We neither received letters from Judea concerning you, nor have any of the brethren who came reported or spoken any evil of you.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But we desire to hear from you what you think; for concerning this sect, we know that it is spoken against everywhere.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So when they had appointed him a day, many came to him at his lodging, to whom he explained and solemnly testified of the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus from both the Law of Moses and the Prophets, from morning till evening.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And some were persuaded by the things which were spoken, and some disbelieved.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>So when they did not agree among themselves, they departed after Paul had said one word: “The Holy Spirit spoke rightly through Isaiah the prophet to our fathers,</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>saying, ‘Go to this people and say: Hearing you will hear, and shall not understand; and seeing you will see, and not perceive;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>for the hearts of this people have grown dull.
