Their ears are hard of hearing, and their eyes they have closed, lest they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears, lest they should understand with their hearts and turn, so that I should heal them.’</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore let it be known to you that the salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will hear it!”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And when he had said these words, the Jews departed and had a great dispute among themselves.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then Paul dwelt two whole years in his own rented house, and received all who came to him,</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>preaching the kingdom of God and teaching the things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ with all confidence, no one forbidding him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:15-25  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>So when they had eaten breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me more than these?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Feed My lambs.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He said to him again a second time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Tend My sheep.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He said to him the third time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” Peter was grieved because He said to him the third time, “Do you love Me?” And he said to Him, “Lord, You know all things; You know that I love You.” Jesus said to him, “Feed My sheep.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, when you were younger, you girded yourself and walked where you wished; but when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will gird you and carry you where you do not wish.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>This He spoke, signifying by what death he would glorify God. And when He had spoken this, He said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Peter, turning around, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following, who also had leaned on His breast at the supper, and said, “Lord, who is the one who betrays You?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Peter, seeing him, said to Jesus, “But Lord, what about this man?”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you? You follow Me.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then this saying went out among the brethren that this disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>This is the disciple who testifies of these things, and wrote these things; and we know that his testimony is true.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And there are also many other things that Jesus did, which if they were written one by one, I suppose that even the world itself could not contain the books that would be written. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Numbers 11:16-17 24-29  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>So the LORD said to Moses: “Gather to Me seventy men of the elders of Israel, whom you know to be the elders of the people and officers over them; bring them to the tabernacle of meeting, that they may stand there with you.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then I will come down and talk with you there. I will take of the Spirit that is upon you and will put the same upon them; and they shall bear the burden of the people with you, that you may not bear it yourself alone.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So Moses went out and told the people the words of the LORD, and he gathered the seventy men of the elders of the people and placed them around the tabernacle.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then the LORD came down in the cloud, and spoke to him, and took of the Spirit that was upon him, and placed the same upon the seventy elders; and it happened, when the Spirit rested upon them, that they prophesied, although they never did so again.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But two men had remained in the camp: the name of one was Eldad, and the name of the other Medad. And the Spirit rested upon them. Now they were among those listed, but who had not gone out to the tabernacle; yet they prophesied in the camp.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And a young man ran and told Moses, and said, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So Joshua the son of Nun, Moses’ assistant, one of his choice men, answered and said, “Moses my lord, forbid them!”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then Moses said to him, “Are you zealous for my sake? Oh, that all the LORD’s people were prophets and that the LORD would put His Spirit upon them!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Joel 2:23-32  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Be glad then, you children of Zion, and rejoice in the Lord your God; for He has given you the former rain faithfully, and He will cause the rain to come down for you – the former rain, and the latter rain in the first month.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>The threshing floors shall be full of wheat, and the vats shall overflow with new wine and oil. </dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“So I will restore to you the years that the swarming locust has eaten, the crawling locust, the consuming locust, and the chewing locust, My great army which I sent among you.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>You shall eat in plenty and be satisfied, and praise the name of the Lord your God, Who has dealt wondrously with you; and My people shall never be put to shame.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then you shall know that I am in the midst of Israel: I am the Lord your God and there is no other. My people shall never be put to shame.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And it shall come to pass afterward that I will pour out My Spirit on all flesh; your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and also on My menservants and on My maidservants I will pour out My Spirit in those days.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And I will show wonders in the heavens and in the earth: blood and fire and pillars of smoke.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the coming of the great and awesome day of the Lord.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And it shall come to pass that whoever calls on the Name of the Lord shall be saved. For in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem there shall be deliverance, as the Lord has said, among the remnant whom the Lord calls.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 36:24-28  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>“For I will take you from among the nations, gather you out of all countries, and bring you into your own land.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“Then I will sprinkle clean water on you, and you shall be clean; I will cleanse you from all your filthiness and from all your idols.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>“I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit within you; I will take the heart of stone out of your flesh and give you a heart of flesh.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>“I will put My Spirit within you and cause you to walk in My statutes, and you will keep My judgments and do them.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>“Then you shall dwell in the land that I gave to your fathers; you shall be My people, and I will be your God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:19-23  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Then, the same day at evening, being the first day of the week, when the doors were shut where the disciples were assembled, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood in the midst, and said to them, “Peace be with you.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His side. Then the disciples were glad when they saw the Lord.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So Jesus said to them again, “Peace to you! As the Father has sent Me, I also send you.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And when He had said this, He breathed on them, and said to them, “Receive the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven them; if you retain the sins of any, they are retained.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 2:1-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>When the Day of Pentecost had fully come, they were all with one accord in one place.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And suddenly there came a sound from heaven, as of a rushing mighty wind, and it filled the whole house where they were sitting.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then there appeared to them divided tongues, as of fire, and one sat upon each of them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak with other tongues, as the Spirit gave them utterance.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And there were dwelling in Jerusalem Jews, devout men, from every nation under heaven.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And when this sound occurred, the multitude came together, and were confused, because everyone heard them speak in his own language.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then they were all amazed and marveled, saying to one another, “Look, are not all these who speak Galileans?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And how is it that we hear, each in our own language in which we were born?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Parthians and Medes and Elamites, those dwelling in Mesopotamia, Judea and Cappadocia, Pontus and Asia,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and the parts of Libya adjoining Cyrene, visitors from Rome, both Jews and proselytes,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Cretans and Arabs – we hear them speaking in our own tongues the wonderful works of God.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 7:37-52 8:12  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>37</dt><dd>On the last day, that great day of the feast, Jesus stood and cried out, saying, “If anyone thirsts, let him come to Me and drink.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>He who believes in Me, as the Scripture has said, out of his heart will flow rivers of living water.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But this He spoke concerning the Spirit, whom those believing in Him would receive; for the Holy Spirit was not yet given, because Jesus was not yet glorified.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Therefore many from the crowd, when they heard this saying, said, “Truly this is the Prophet.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>Others said, “This is the Christ.” But some said, “Will the Christ come out of Galilee?</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Has not the Scripture said that the Christ comes from the seed of David and from the town of Bethlehem, where David was?”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>So there was a division among the people because of Him.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Now some of them wanted to take Him, but no one laid hands on Him.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then the officers came to the chief priests and Pharisees, who said to them, “Why have you not brought Him?”</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>The officers answered, “No man ever spoke like this Man!”</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees answered them, “Are you also deceived?</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Have any of the rulers or the Pharisees believed in Him?</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>But this crowd that does not know the law is accursed.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Nikodemos (he who came to Jesus by night, being one of them) said to them,</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>“Does our law judge a man before it hears him and knows what he is doing?”</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>They answered and said to him, “Are you also from Galilee? Search and look, for no prophet has arisen out of Galilee.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then Jesus spoke to them again, saying, “I am the light of the world. He who follows Me shall not walk in darkness, but have the light of life.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 5:9-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>(for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, righteousness, and truth),</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>finding out what is acceptable to the Lord.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather expose them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For it is shameful even to speak of those things which are done by them in secret.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But all things that are exposed are made manifest by the light, for whatever makes manifest is light.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore He says: “Awake, you who sleep, arise from the dead, and Christ will give you light.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>See then that you walk circumspectly, not as fools but as wise,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>redeeming the time, because the days are evil.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore do not be unwise, but understand what the will of the Lord is.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And do not be drunk with wine, in which is dissipation; but be filled with the Spirit,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>speaking to one another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 18:10-20  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Take heed that you do not despise one of these little ones, for I say to you that in heaven their angels always see the face of My Father who is in heaven.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For the Son of Man has come to save that which was lost. </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>What do you think? If a man has a hundred sheep, and one of them goes astray, does he not leave the ninety-nine and go to the mountains to seek the one that is straying?</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And if he should find it, assuredly, I say to you, he rejoices more over that sheep than over the ninety-nine that did not go astray.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Even so it is not the will of your Father who is in heaven that one of these little ones should perish.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Moreover if your brother sins against you, go and tell him his fault between you and him alone. If he hears you, you have gained your brother.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But if he will not hear, take with you one or two more, that ‘by the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established.’ </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And if he refuses to hear them, tell it to the church. But if he refuses even to hear the church, let him be to you like a heathen and a tax collector.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Again I say to you that if two of you agree on earth concerning anything that they ask, it will be done for them by My Father in heaven.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For where two or three are gathered together in My name, I am there in the midst of them.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 1:1-7 13-17  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Paul, a bondservant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, separated to the gospel of God</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>which He promised before through His prophets in the Holy Scriptures,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>concerning His Son Jesus Christ our Lord, who was born of the seed of David according to the flesh,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>and declared to be the Son of God with power according to the Spirit of holiness, by the resurrection from the dead.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Through Him we have received grace and apostleship for obedience to the faith among all nations for His name,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>among whom you also are the called of Jesus Christ;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>To all who are in Rome, beloved of God, called to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Now I do not want you to be unaware, brethren, that I often planned to come to you (but was hindered until now), that I might have some fruit among you also, just as among the other Gentiles.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am a debtor both to Greeks and to barbarians, both to wise and to unwise.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So, as much as is in me, I am ready to preach the gospel to you who are in Rome also.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ, for it is the power of God to salvation for everyone who believes, for the Jew first and also for the Greek.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith; as it is written, “The just shall live by faith.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 4:25-5:13  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>25</dt><dd>Great multitudes followed Him – from Galilee, and from Decapolis, Jerusalem, Judea, and beyond the Jordan.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And seeing the multitudes, He went up on a mountain, and when He was seated His disciples came to Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He opened His mouth and taught them, saying:</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be filled.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Blessed are the merciful, for they shall obtain mercy.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Blessed are you when they revile and persecute you, and say all kinds of evil against you falsely for My sake.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Rejoice and be exceedingly glad, for great is your reward in heaven, for so they persecuted the prophets who were before you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>You are the salt of the earth; but if the salt loses its flavor, how shall it be seasoned? It is then good for nothing but to be thrown out and trampled underfoot by men.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 1:18-27  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who suppress the truth in unrighteousness,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>because what may be known of God is manifest in them, for God has shown it to them.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For since the creation of the world His invisible attributes are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead, so that they are without excuse,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>because, although they knew God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor were thankful, but became futile in their thoughts, and their foolish hearts were darkened.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Professing to be wise, they became fools,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>and changed the glory of the incorruptible God into an image made like corruptible man – and birds and four-footed animals and creeping things.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore God also gave them up to uncleanness, in the lusts of their hearts, to dishonor their bodies among themselves,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>who exchanged the truth of God for the lie, and worshiped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed forever. Amen.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For this reason God gave them up to vile passions. For even their women exchanged the natural use for what is against nature.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Likewise also the men, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust for one another, men with men committing what is shameful, and receiving in themselves the penalty of their error which was due.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 5:20-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>For I say to you, that unless your righteousness exceeds the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, you will by no means enter the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>You have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not murder, and whoever murders will be in danger of the judgment.’</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But I say to you that whoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment. And whoever says to his brother, ‘Raca!’ shall be in danger of the council. But whoever says, ‘You fool!’ shall be in danger of hell fire.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Therefore if you bring your gift to the altar, and there remember that your brother has something against you,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>leave your gift there before the altar, and go your way. First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Agree with your adversary quickly, while you are on the way with him, lest your adversary deliver you to the judge, the judge hand you over to the officer, and you be thrown into prison.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, you will by no means get out of there till you have paid the last penny.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 1:28-2:9  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a debased mind, to do those things which are not fitting;</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>being filled with all unrighteousness, sexual immorality, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness; full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, evil-mindedness; they are whisperers,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>backbiters, haters of God, violent, proud, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents,</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>undiscerning, untrustworthy, unloving, unforgiving, unmerciful;</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>who, knowing the righteous judgment of God, that those who practice such things are deserving of death, not only do the same but also approve of those who practice them.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore you are inexcusable, O man, whoever you are who judge, for in whatever you judge another you condemn yourself; for you who judge practice the same things.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But we know that the judgment of God is according to truth against those who practice such things.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And do you think this, O man, you who judge those practicing such things, and doing the same, that you will escape the judgment of God?</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Or do you despise the riches of His goodness, forbearance, and longsuffering, not knowing that the goodness of God leads you to repentance?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But in accordance with your hardness and your impenitent heart you are treasuring up for yourself wrath in the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>who “will render to each one according to his deeds”: </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>eternal life to those who by patient continuance in doing good seek for glory, honor, and immortality;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>but to those who are self-seeking and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness – indignation and wrath,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>tribulation and anguish, on every soul of man who does evil, of the Jew first and also of the Greek;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 5:27-32  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>You have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not commit adultery.’ </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But I say to you that whoever looks at a woman to lust for her has already committed adultery with her in his heart.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>If your right eye causes you to sin, pluck it out and cast it from you; for it is more profitable for you that one of your members perish, than for your whole body to be cast into hell.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and cast it from you; for it is more profitable for you that one of your members perish, than for your whole body to be cast into hell.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Furthermore it has been said, ‘Whoever divorces his wife, let him give her a certificate of divorce.’</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>But I say to you that whoever divorces his wife for any reason except sexual immorality causes her to commit adultery; and whoever marries a woman who is divorced commits adultery.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 2:14-29  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>for when Gentiles, who do not have the law, by nature do the things in the law, these, although not having the law, are a law to themselves,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>who show the work of the law written in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witness, and between themselves their thoughts accusing or else excusing them)</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>in the day when God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my gospel.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Indeed you are called a Jew, and rest on the law, and make your boast in God,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>and know His will, and approve the things that are excellent, being instructed out of the law,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and are confident that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>an instructor of the foolish, a teacher of babes, having the form of knowledge and truth in the law.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>You, therefore, who teach another, do you not teach yourself? You who preach that a man should not steal, do you steal?</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>You who say, “Do not commit adultery,” do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>You who make your boast in the law, do you dishonor God through breaking the law?</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For “the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you,” as it is written.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>For circumcision is indeed profitable if you keep the law; but if you are a breaker of the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Therefore, if an uncircumcised man keeps the righteous requirements of the law, will not his uncircumcision be counted as circumcision?</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And will not the physically uncircumcised, if he fulfills the law, judge you who, even with your written code and circumcision, are a transgressor of the law?</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For he is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is circumcision that which is outward in the flesh;</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>but he is a Jew who is one inwardly; and circumcision is that of the heart, in the Spirit, not in the letter; whose praise is not from men but from God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 5:33-41  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>Again you have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not swear falsely, but shall perform your oaths to the Lord.’</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But I say to you, do not swear at all: neither by heaven, for it is God’s throne;</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>nor by the earth, for it is His footstool; nor by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Nor shall you swear by your head, because you cannot make one hair white or black.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But let your ‘Yes’ be ‘Yes,’ and your ‘No,’ ‘No’. For whatever is more than these is from the evil one.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>You have heard that it was said, ‘An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.’ </dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But I tell you not to resist an evil person. But whoever slaps you on your right cheek, turn the other to him also.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>If anyone wants to sue you and take away your tunic, let him have your cloak also.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And whoever compels you to go one mile, go with him two.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 1:7-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>To all who are in Rome, beloved of God, called to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of His Son, that without ceasing I make mention of you always in my prayers,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>making request if, by some means, now at last I may find a way in the will of God to come to you.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For I long to see you, that I may impart to you some spiritual gift, so that you may be established – </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>that is, that I may be encouraged together with you by the mutual faith both of you and me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 5:42-48  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>42</dt><dd>Give to him who asks you, and from him who wants to borrow from you do not turn away.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>You have heard that it was said, ‘You shall love your neighbor and hate your enemy.’</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>But I say to you, love your enemies, bless those who curse you, do good to those who hate you, and pray for those who spitefully use you and persecute you, </dd><dt>45</dt><dd>that you may be sons of your Father in heaven; for He makes His sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>For if you love those who love you, what reward have you? Do not even the tax collectors do the same?</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>And if you greet your brethren only, what do you do more than others? Do not even the tax collectors do so?</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Therefore you shall be perfect, just as your Father in heaven is perfect.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 1:3-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who according to His abundant mercy has begotten us again to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>to an inheritance incorruptible and undefiled and that does not fade away, reserved in heaven for you,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>who are kept by the power of God through faith for salvation ready to be revealed in the last time.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>In this you greatly rejoice, though now for a little while, if need be, you have been grieved by various trials,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>that the genuineness of your faith, being much more precious than gold that perishes, though it is tested by fire, may be found to praise, honor, and glory at the revelation of Jesus Christ,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>whom having not seen you love. Though now you do not see Him, yet believing, you rejoice with joy inexpressible and full of glory,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>receiving the end of your faith – the salvation of your souls.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 1:13-19  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore gird up the loins of your mind, be sober, and rest your hope fully upon the grace that is to be brought to you at the revelation of Jesus Christ;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>as obedient children, not conforming yourselves to the former lusts, as in your ignorance;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>but as He who called you is holy, you also be holy in all your conduct,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>because it is written, “Be holy, for I am holy.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And if you call on the Father, who without partiality judges according to each one’s work, conduct yourselves throughout the time of your stay here in fear;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>knowing that you were not redeemed with corruptible things, like silver or gold, from your aimless conduct received by tradition from your fathers,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>but with the precious blood of Christ, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 2:11-24  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Beloved, I beg you as sojourners and pilgrims, abstain from fleshly lusts which war against the soul,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>having your conduct honorable among the Gentiles, that when they speak against you as evildoers, they may, by your good works which they observe, glorify God in the day of visitation.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore submit yourselves to every ordinance of man for the Lord’s sake, whether to the king as supreme,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>or to governors, as to those who are sent by him for the punishment of evildoers and for the praise of those who do good.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this is the will of God, that by doing good you may put to silence the ignorance of foolish men – </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>as free, yet not using liberty as a cloak for vice, but as bondservants of God.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Honor all people. Love the brotherhood. Fear God. Honor the king.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Servants, be submissive to your masters with all fear, not only to the good and gentle, but also to the harsh.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For this is commendable, if because of conscience toward God one endures grief, suffering wrongfully.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For what credit is it if, when you are beaten for your faults, you take it patiently? But when you do good and suffer, if you take it patiently, this is commendable before God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For to this you were called, because Christ also suffered for us, leaving us an example, that you should follow His steps:</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>“Who committed no sin, nor was deceit found in His mouth”;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>who, when He was reviled, did not revile in return; when He suffered, He did not threaten, but committed Himself to Him who judges righteously;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>who Himself bore our sins in His own body on the tree, that we, having died to sins, might live for righteousness – by whose stripes you were healed.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 28:16-20  (1st  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Then the eleven disciples went away into Galilee, to the mountain which Jesus had appointed for them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>When they saw Him, they worshiped Him; but some doubted.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And Jesus came and spoke to them, saying, “All authority has been given to Me in heaven and on earth.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Go therefore and make disciples of all the nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>teaching them to observe all things that I have commanded you; and lo, I am with you always, even to the end of the age. Amen.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 11:19-26 29-30  (Epistle Apostles)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Now those who were scattered after the persecution that arose over Stephen traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, preaching the word to no one but the Jews only.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But some of them were men from Cyprus and Cyrene, who, when they had come to Antioch, spoke to the Hellenists, preaching the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And the hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number believed and turned to the Lord.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then news of these things came to the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they sent out Barnabas to go as far as Antioch.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>When he came and had seen the grace of God, he was glad, and encouraged them all that with purpose of heart they should continue with the Lord.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For he was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and of faith. And a great many people were added to the Lord.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then Barnabas departed for Tarsus to seek Saul.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And when he had found him, he brought him to Antioch. So it was that for a whole year they assembled with the church and taught a great many people. And the disciples were first called Christians in Antioch.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then the disciples, each according to his ability, determined to send relief to the brethren dwelling in Judea.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>This they also did, and sent it to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:16-21  (Gospel Apostles)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>He who hears you hears Me, he who rejects you rejects Me, and he who rejects Me rejects Him who sent Me.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then the seventy returned with joy, saying, “Lord, even the demons are subject to us in Your name.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And He said to them, “I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Behold, I give you the authority to trample on serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy, and nothing shall by any means hurt you.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Nevertheless do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you, but rather rejoice because your names are written in heaven.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>In that hour Jesus rejoiced in the Spirit and said, “I thank You, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that You have hidden these things from the wise and prudent and revealed them to babes. Even so, Father, for so it seemed good in Your sight.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 11:33-12:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>who through faith subdued kingdoms, worked righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakness were made strong, became valiant in battle, turned to flight the armies of the aliens.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Women received their dead raised to life again. Others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Still others had trial of mockings and scourgings, yes, and of chains and imprisonment.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>They were stoned, they were sawn in two, were tempted, were slain with the sword. They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented – </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>of whom the world was not worthy. They wandered in deserts and mountains, in dens and caves of the earth.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And all these, having obtained a good testimony through faith, did not receive the promise,</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>God having provided something better for us, that they should not be made perfect apart from us.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore we also, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which so easily ensnares us, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 10:32-33 37-38 19:27-30  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Therefore whoever confesses Me before men, him I will also confess before My Father who is in heaven.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But whoever denies Me before men, him I will also deny before My Father who is in heaven.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>He who loves father or mother more than Me is not worthy of Me. And he who loves son or daughter more than Me is not worthy of Me.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And he who does not take his cross and follow after Me is not worthy of Me.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then Peter answered and said to Him, “See, we have left all and followed You. Therefore what shall we have?”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So Jesus said to them, “Assuredly I say to you, that in the regeneration, when the Son of Man sits on the throne of His glory, you who have followed Me will also sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or wife or children or lands, for My name’s sake, shall receive a hundredfold, and inherit eternal life.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But many who are first will be last, and the last first.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 2:28-3:18  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>For he is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is circumcision that which is outward in the flesh;</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>but he is a Jew who is one inwardly; and circumcision is that of the heart, in the Spirit, not in the letter; whose praise is not from men but from God.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>What advantage then has the Jew, or what is the profit of circumcision?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Much in every way! Chiefly because to them were committed the oracles of God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For what if some did not believe? Will their unbelief make the faithfulness of God without effect?</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Certainly not! Indeed, let God be true but every man a liar. As it is written: “That You may be justified in Your words, and may overcome when You are judged.” </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But if our unrighteousness demonstrates the righteousness of God, what shall we say? Is God unjust who inflicts wrath? (I speak as a man.)</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Certainly not! For then how will God judge the world?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For if the truth of God has increased through my lie to His glory, why am I also still judged as a sinner?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And why not say, “Let us do evil that good may come”? – as we are slanderously reported and as some affirm that we say. Their condemnation is just.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>What then? Are we better than they? Not at all. For we have previously charged both Jews and Greeks that they are all under sin.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>As it is written: “There is none righteous, no, not one;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>there is none who understands; there is none who seeks after God.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>They have all turned aside; they have together become unprofitable; there is none who does good, no, not one.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>“Their throat is an open tomb; with their tongues they have practiced deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Their feet are swift to shed blood;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>destruction and misery are in their ways;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>and the way of peace they have not known.” </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>There is no fear of God before their eyes. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 6:31-34 7:9-11  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore do not worry, saying, ‘What shall we eat?’ or ‘What shall we drink?’ or ‘What shall we wear?’</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>For after all these things the Gentiles seek. For your heavenly Father knows that you need all these things.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things shall be added to you.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about its own things. Sufficient for the day is its own trouble.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Or what man is there among you who, if his son asks for bread, will give him a stone?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Or if he asks for a fish, will he give him a serpent?</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in heaven give good things to those who ask Him!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 4:4-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>Now to him who works, the wages are not counted as grace but as debt.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But to him who does not work but believes on Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is accounted for righteousness,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>just as David also describes the blessedness of the man to whom God imputes righteousness apart from works:</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>“Blessed are those whose lawless deeds are forgiven, and whose sins are covered;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>blessed is the man to whom the LORD shall not impute sin.” </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Does this blessedness then come upon the circumcised only, or upon the uncircumcised also? For we say that faith was accounted to Abraham for righteousness.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>How then was it accounted? While he was circumcised, or uncircumcised? Not while circumcised, but while uncircumcised.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had while still uncircumcised, that he might be the father of all those who believe, though they are uncircumcised, that righteousness might be imputed to them also,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>and the father of circumcision to those who not only are of the circumcision, but who also walk in the steps of the faith which our father Abraham had while still uncircumcised.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 7:15-21  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing, but inwardly they are ravenous wolves.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>You will know them by their fruits. Do men gather grapes from thornbushes or figs from thistles?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Even so, every good tree bears good fruit, but a bad tree bears bad fruit.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>A good tree cannot bear bad fruit, nor can a bad tree bear good fruit.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Therefore by their fruits you will know them.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Not everyone who says to Me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ shall enter the kingdom of heaven, but he who does the will of My Father in heaven.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 4:13-25  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>For the promise that he would be the heir of the world was not to Abraham or to his seed through the law, but through the righteousness of faith.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if those who are of the law are heirs, faith is made void and the promise made of no effect,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>because the law brings about wrath; for where there is no law there is no transgression.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore it is of faith that it might be according to grace, so that the promise might be sure to all the seed, not only to those who are of the law, but also to those who are of the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>(as it is written, “I have made you a father of many nations” ) in the presence of Him whom he believed – God, who gives life to the dead and calls those things which do not exist as though they did;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>who, contrary to hope, in hope believed, so that he became the father of many nations, according to what was spoken, “So shall your descendants be.” </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And not being weak in faith, he did not consider his own body, already dead (since he was about a hundred years old), and the deadness of Sarah’s womb.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>He did not waver at the promise of God through unbelief, but was strengthened in faith, giving glory to God,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>and being fully convinced that what He had promised He was also able to perform.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And therefore “it was accounted to him for righteousness.” </dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Now it was not written for his sake alone that it was imputed to him,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>but also for us. It shall be imputed to us who believe in Him who raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>who was delivered up because of our offenses, and was raised because of our justification.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 7:21-23  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>Not everyone who says to Me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ shall enter the kingdom of heaven, but he who does the will of My Father in heaven.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Many will say to Me in that day, ‘Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in Your name, cast out demons in Your name, and done many wonders in Your name?’</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And then I will declare to them, ‘I never knew you; depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness!’</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 5:10-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>For if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, having been reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And not only that, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received the reconciliation.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore, just as through one man sin entered the world, and death through sin, and thus death spread to all men, because all sinned:</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For until the law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed when there is no law.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned according to the likeness of the transgression of Adam, who is a type of Him who was to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But the free gift is not like the offense. For if by the one man’s offense many died, much more the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one Man, Jesus Christ, abounded to many.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And the gift is not like that which came through the one who sinned. For the judgment which came from one offense resulted in condemnation, but the free gift which came from many offenses resulted in justification.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 8:23-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Now when He got into a boat, His disciples followed Him.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And suddenly a great tempest arose on the sea, so that the boat was covered with the waves. But He was asleep.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then His disciples came to Him and awoke Him, saying, “Lord, save us! We are perishing!”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But He said to them, “Why are you fearful, O you of little faith?” Then He arose and rebuked the winds and the sea, and there was a great calm.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>So the men marveled, saying, “Who can this be, that even the winds and the sea obey Him?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 5:17-6:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>For if by the one man’s offense death reigned through the one, much more those who receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness will reign in life through the One, Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Therefore, as through one man’s offense judgment came to all men, resulting in condemnation, even so through one Man’s righteous act the free gift came to all men, resulting in justification of life.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For as by one man’s disobedience many were made sinners, so also by one Man’s obedience many will be made righteous.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Moreover the law entered that the offense might abound. But where sin abounded, grace abounded much more,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>so that as sin reigned in death, even so grace might reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>What shall we say then? Shall we continue in sin that grace may abound?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Certainly not! How shall we who died to sin live any longer in it?</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 9:14-17  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Then the disciples of John came to Him, saying, “Why do we and the Pharisees fast often, but Your disciples do not fast?”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And Jesus said to them, “Can the friends of the bridegroom mourn as long as the bridegroom is with them? But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>No one puts a piece of unshrunk cloth on an old garment; for the patch pulls away from the garment, and the tear is made worse.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Nor do they put new wine into old wineskins, or else the wineskins break, the wine is spilled, and the wineskins are ruined. But they put new wine into new wineskins, and both are preserved.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 3:19-26  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law, that every mouth may be stopped, and all the world may become guilty before God.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Therefore by the deeds of the law no flesh will be justified in His sight, for by the law is the knowledge of sin.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But now the righteousness of God apart from the law is revealed, being witnessed by the Law and the Prophets,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>even the righteousness of God, through faith in Jesus Christ, to all and on all who believe. For there is no difference;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>being justified freely by His grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>whom God set forth as a propitiation by His blood, through faith, to demonstrate His righteousness, because in His forbearance God had passed over the sins that were previously committed,</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>to demonstrate at the present time His righteousness, that He might be just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 7:1-8  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Judge not, that you be not judged.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For with what judgment you judge, you will be judged; and with the measure you use, it will be measured back to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And why do you look at the speck in your brother’s eye, but do not consider the plank in your own eye?</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Or how can you say to your brother, ‘Let me remove the speck from your eye’; and look, a plank is in your own eye?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Hypocrite! First remove the plank from your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Do not give what is holy to the dogs; nor cast your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under their feet, and turn and tear you in pieces.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For everyone who asks receives, and he who seeks finds, and to him who knocks it will be opened.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 43:9-14  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Let all the nations be gathered together, and let the people be assembled. Who among them can declare this, and show us former things? Let them bring out their witnesses, that they may be justified; or let them hear and say, “It is truth.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“You are My witnesses,” says the Lord, “And My servant whom I have chosen, that you may know and believe Me, and understand that I am He. Before Me there was no God formed, nor shall there be after Me.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I, even I, am the Lord, and besides Me there is no savior. </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I have declared and saved, I have proclaimed, and there was no foreign god among you; therefore you are My witnesses,” says the Lord, “that I am God.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Indeed before the day was, I am He; and there is no one who can deliver out of My hand; I work, and who will reverse it?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: “For your sake I will send to Babylon, and bring them all down as fugitives – the Chaldeans, who rejoice in their ships.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 16:1-8  (2nd  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when the Sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices, that they might come and anoint Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Very early in the morning, on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb when the sun had risen.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And they said among themselves, “Who will roll away the stone from the door of the tomb for us?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But when they looked up, they saw that the stone had been rolled away – for it was very large.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And entering the tomb, they saw a young man clothed in a long white robe sitting on the right side; and they were alarmed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But he said to them, “Do not be alarmed. You seek Jesus of Nazareth, who was crucified. He is risen! He is not here. See the place where they laid Him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But go, tell His disciples – and Peter – that He is going before you into Galilee; there you will see Him, as He said to you.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So they went out quickly and fled from the tomb, for they trembled and were amazed. And they said nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 11:33-12:2  (Epistle Saints)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>who through faith subdued kingdoms, worked righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakness were made strong, became valiant in battle, turned to flight the armies of the aliens.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Women received their dead raised to life again. Others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Still others had trial of mockings and scourgings, yes, and of chains and imprisonment.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>They were stoned, they were sawn in two, were tempted, were slain with the sword. They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented – </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>of whom the world was not worthy. They wandered in deserts and mountains, in dens and caves of the earth.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And all these, having obtained a good testimony through faith, did not receive the promise,</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>God having provided something better for us, that they should not be made perfect apart from us.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore we also, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which so easily ensnares us, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 4:25-5:12  (Gospel Saints)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>25</dt><dd>Great multitudes followed Him – from Galilee, and from Decapolis, Jerusalem, Judea, and beyond the Jordan.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And seeing the multitudes, He went up on a mountain, and when He was seated His disciples came to Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He opened His mouth and taught them, saying:</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be filled.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Blessed are the merciful, for they shall obtain mercy.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Blessed are you when they revile and persecute you, and say all kinds of evil against you falsely for My sake.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Rejoice and be exceedingly glad, for great is your reward in heaven, for so they persecuted the prophets who were before you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 2:10-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>but glory, honor, and peace to everyone who works what is good, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For there is no partiality with God.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For as many as have sinned without law will also perish without law, and as many as have sinned in the law will be judged by the law</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>(for not the hearers of the law are just in the sight of God, but the doers of the law will be justified;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for when Gentiles, who do not have the law, by nature do the things in the law, these, although not having the law, are a law to themselves,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>who show the work of the law written in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witness, and between themselves their thoughts accusing or else excusing them)</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>in the day when God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my gospel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 4:18-23  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>And Jesus, walking by the Sea of Galilee, saw two brothers, Simon called Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea; for they were fishermen.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Follow Me, and I will make you fishers of men.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>They immediately left their nets and followed Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Going on from there, He saw two other brothers, James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. He called them,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and immediately they left the boat and their father, and followed Him.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And Jesus went about all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all kinds of sickness and all kinds of disease among the people.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 1-10  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Jude, a bondservant of Jesus Christ, and brother of James, to those who are called, sanctified by God the Father, and preserved in Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Beloved, while I was very diligent to write to you concerning our common salvation, I found it necessary to write to you exhorting you to contend earnestly for the faith which was once for all delivered to the saints.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For certain men have crept in unnoticed, who long ago were marked out for this condemnation, ungodly men, who turn the grace of our God into lewdness and deny the only Lord God and our Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But I want to remind you, though you once knew this, that the Lord, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed those who did not believe.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the angels who did not keep their proper domain, but left their own abode, He has reserved in everlasting chains under darkness for the judgment of the great day;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>as Sodom and Gomorrah, and the cities around them in a similar manner to these, having given themselves over to sexual immorality and gone after strange flesh, are set forth as an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Likewise also these dreamers defile the flesh, reject authority, and speak evil of dignitaries.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Yet Michael the archangel, in contending with the devil, when he disputed about the body of Moses, dared not bring against him a reviling accusation, but said, “The Lord rebuke you!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But these speak evil of whatever they do not know; and whatever they know naturally, like brute beasts, in these things they corrupt themselves.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 11-16  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Woe to them! For they have gone in the way of Cain, have run greedily in the error of Balaam for profit, and perished in the rebellion of Korah.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>These are spots in your love feasts, while they feast with you without fear, serving only themselves. They are clouds without water, carried about by the winds; late autumn trees without fruit, twice dead, pulled up by the roots;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>raging waves of the sea, foaming up their own shame; wandering stars for whom is reserved the blackness of darkness forever.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now Enoch, the seventh from Adam, prophesied about these men also, saying, “Behold, the Lord comes with ten thousands of His saints,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>to execute judgment on all, to convict all who are ungodly among them of all their ungodly deeds which they have committed in an ungodly way, and of all the harsh things which ungodly sinners have spoken against Him.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>These are grumblers, complainers, walking according to their own lusts; and they mouth great swelling words, flattering people to gain advantage.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 17-25  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>But you, beloved, remember the words which were spoken before by the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>how they told you that there would be mockers in the last time who would walk according to their own ungodly lusts.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>These are sensual persons, who cause divisions, not having the Spirit.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But you, beloved, building yourselves up on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Spirit,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>keep yourselves in the love of God, looking for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And on some have compassion, making a distinction;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>but others save with fear, pulling them out of the fire, hating even the garment defiled by the flesh.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now to Him who is able to keep you from stumbling, and to present you faultless before the presence of His glory with exceeding joy,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>To God our Savior, Who alone is wise, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and forever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:15-25  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>So when they had eaten breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me more than these?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Feed My lambs.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He said to him again a second time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Tend My sheep.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He said to him the third time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” Peter was grieved because He said to him the third time, “Do you love Me?” And he said to Him, “Lord, You know all things; You know that I love You.” Jesus said to him, “Feed My sheep.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, when you were younger, you girded yourself and walked where you wished; but when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will gird you and carry you where you do not wish.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>This He spoke, signifying by what death he would glorify God. And when He had spoken this, He said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Peter, turning around, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following, who also had leaned on His breast at the supper, and said, “Lord, who is the one who betrays You?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Peter, seeing him, said to Jesus, “But Lord, what about this man?”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you? You follow Me.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then this saying went out among the brethren that this disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>This is the disciple who testifies of these things, and wrote these things; and we know that his testimony is true.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And there are also many other things that Jesus did, which if they were written one by one, I suppose that even the world itself could not contain the books that would be written. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 1-10  (Epistle Apostle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Jude, a bondservant of Jesus Christ, and brother of James, to those who are called, sanctified by God the Father, and preserved in Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Beloved, while I was very diligent to write to you concerning our common salvation, I found it necessary to write to you exhorting you to contend earnestly for the faith which was once for all delivered to the saints.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For certain men have crept in unnoticed, who long ago were marked out for this condemnation, ungodly men, who turn the grace of our God into lewdness and deny the only Lord God and our Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But I want to remind you, though you once knew this, that the Lord, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed those who did not believe.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the angels who did not keep their proper domain, but left their own abode, He has reserved in everlasting chains under darkness for the judgment of the great day;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>as Sodom and Gomorrah, and the cities around them in a similar manner to these, having given themselves over to sexual immorality and gone after strange flesh, are set forth as an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Likewise also these dreamers defile the flesh, reject authority, and speak evil of dignitaries.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Yet Michael the archangel, in contending with the devil, when he disputed about the body of Moses, dared not bring against him a reviling accusation, but said, “The Lord rebuke you!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But these speak evil of whatever they do not know; and whatever they know naturally, like brute beasts, in these things they corrupt themselves.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 14:21-24  (Gospel Apostle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>He who has My commandments and keeps them, it is he who loves Me. And he who loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I will love him and manifest Myself to him.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Judas (not Iscariot) said to Him, “Lord, how is it that You will manifest Yourself to us, and not to the world?”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to him, “If anyone loves Me, he will keep My word; and My Father will love him, and We will come to him and make Our home with him.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>He who does not love Me does not keep My words; and the word which you hear is not Mine but the Father’s who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 7:1-13  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Or do you not know, brethren (for I speak to those who know the law), that the law has dominion over a man as long as he lives?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For the woman who has a husband is bound by the law to her husband as long as he lives. But if the husband dies, she is released from the law of her husband.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So then if, while her husband lives, she marries another man, she will be called an adulteress; but if her husband dies, she is free from that law, so that she is no adulteress, though she has married another man.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Therefore, my brethren, you also have become dead to the law through the body of Christ, that you may be married to another – to Him who was raised from the dead, that we should bear fruit to God.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For when we were in the flesh, the sinful passions which were aroused by the law were at work in our members to bear fruit to death.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But now we have been delivered from the law, having died to what we were held by, so that we should serve in the newness of the Spirit and not in the oldness of the letter.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>What shall we say then? Is the law sin? Certainly not! On the contrary, I would not have known sin except through the law. For I would not have known covetousness unless the law had said, “You shall not covet.” </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But sin, taking opportunity by the commandment, produced in me all manner of evil desire. For apart from the law sin was dead.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I was alive once without the law, but when the commandment came, sin revived and I died.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the commandment, which was to bring life, I found to bring death.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For sin, taking occasion by the commandment, deceived me, and by it killed me.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore the law is holy, and the commandment holy and just and good.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Has then what is good become death to me? Certainly not! But sin, that it might appear sin, was producing death in me through what is good, so that sin through the commandment might become exceedingly sinful.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 9:36-10:8  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>But when He saw the multitudes, He was moved with compassion for them, because they were weary and scattered, like sheep having no shepherd.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then He said to His disciples, “The harvest truly is plentiful, but the laborers are few.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Therefore pray the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into His harvest.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>And when He had called His twelve disciples to Him, He gave them power over unclean spirits, to cast them out, and to heal all kinds of sickness and all kinds of disease.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Now the names of the twelve apostles are these: first, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Philip and Bartholomew; Thomas and Matthew the tax collector; James the son of Alphaeus, and Lebbaeus, whose surname was Thaddaeus;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Simon the Cananite, and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed Him.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>These twelve Jesus sent out and commanded them, saying: “Do not go into the way of the Gentiles, and do not enter a city of the Samaritans.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But go rather to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And as you go, preach, saying, ‘The kingdom of heaven is at hand.’</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out demons. Freely you have received, freely give.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 7:14-8:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>For we know that the law is spiritual, but I am carnal, sold under sin.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For what I am doing, I do not understand. For what I will to do, that I do not practice; but what I hate, that I do.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>If, then, I do what I will not to do, I agree with the law that it is good.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But now, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells in me.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For I know that in me (that is, in my flesh) nothing good dwells; for to will is present with me, but how to perform what is good I do not find.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For the good that I will to do, I do not do; but the evil I will not to do, that I practice.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now if I do what I will not to do, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells in me.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>I find then a law, that evil is present with me, the one who wills to do good.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For I delight in the law of God according to the inward man.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But I see another law in my members, warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>O wretched man that I am! Who will deliver me from this body of death?</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>I thank God – through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, with the mind I myself serve the law of God, but with the flesh the law of sin.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus, who do not walk according to the flesh, but according to the Spirit.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has made me free from the law of sin and death.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 10:9-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Provide neither gold nor silver nor copper in your money belts,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>nor bag for your journey, nor two tunics, nor sandals, nor staffs; for a worker is worthy of his food.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now whatever city or town you enter, inquire who in it is worthy, and stay there till you go out.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And when you go into a household, greet it.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>If the household is worthy, let your peace come upon it. But if it is not worthy, let your peace return to you.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And whoever will not receive you nor hear your words, when you depart from that house or city, shake off the dust from your feet.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, it will be more tolerable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrah in the day of judgment than for that city!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 8:2-13  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has made me free from the law of sin and death.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For what the law could not do in that it was weak through the flesh, God did by sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, on account of sin: He condemned sin in the flesh,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>that the righteous requirement of the law might be fulfilled in us who do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For those who live according to the flesh set their minds on the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit, the things of the Spirit.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For to be carnally minded is death, but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Because the carnal mind is enmity against God; for it is not subject to the law of God, nor indeed can be.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So then, those who are in the flesh cannot please God.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But you are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God dwells in you.
