Now if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, he is not His.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And if Christ is in you, the body is dead because of sin, but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But if the Spirit of Him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you, He who raised Christ from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through His Spirit who dwells in you.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore, brethren, we are debtors – not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For if you live according to the flesh you will die; but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body, you will live.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 10:16-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Behold, I send you out as sheep in the midst of wolves. Therefore be wise as serpents and harmless as doves.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But beware of men, for they will deliver you up to councils and scourge you in their synagogues.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>You will be brought before governors and kings for My sake, as a testimony to them and to the Gentiles.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But when they deliver you up, do not worry about how or what you should speak. For it will be given to you in that hour what you should speak;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>for it is not you who speak, but the Spirit of your Father who speaks in you.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Now brother will deliver up brother to death, and a father his child; and children will rise up against parents and cause them to be put to death.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And you will be hated by all for My name’s sake. But he who endures to the end will be saved.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 8:22-27  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>For we know that the whole creation groans and labors with birth pangs together until now.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Not only that, but we also who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, eagerly waiting for the adoption, the redemption of our body.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For we were saved in this hope, but hope that is seen is not hope; for why does one still hope for what he sees?</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But if we hope for what we do not see, we eagerly wait for it with perseverance.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Likewise the Spirit also helps in our weaknesses. For we do not know what we should pray for as we ought, but the Spirit Himself makes intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Now He who searches the hearts knows what the mind of the Spirit is, because He makes intercession for the saints according to the will of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 10:23-31  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>When they persecute you in this city, flee to another. For assuredly, I say to you, you will not have gone through the cities of Israel before the Son of Man comes.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>A disciple is not above his teacher, nor a servant above his master.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>It is enough for a disciple that he be like his teacher, and a servant like his master. If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more will they call those of his household!</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Therefore do not fear them. For there is nothing covered that will not be revealed, and hidden that will not be known.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Whatever I tell you in the dark, speak in the light; and what you hear in the ear, preach on the housetops.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And do not fear those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul. But rather fear Him who is able to destroy both soul and body in hell.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Are not two sparrows sold for a copper coin? And not one of them falls to the ground apart from your Father’s will.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But the very hairs of your head are all numbered.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Do not fear therefore; you are of more value than many sparrows.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 9:6-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>But it is not that the word of God has taken no effect. For they are not all Israel who are of Israel,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>nor are they all children because they are the seed of Abraham; but, “In Isaac your seed shall be called.” </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>That is, those who are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God; but the children of the promise are counted as the seed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For this is the word of promise: “At this time I will come and Sarah shall have a son.” </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And not only this, but when Rebecca also had conceived by one man, even by our father Isaac</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>(for the children not yet being born, nor having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works but of Him who calls),</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>it was said to her, “The older shall serve the younger.” </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>As it is written, “Jacob I have loved, but Esau I have hated.” </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>What shall we say then? Is there unrighteousness with God? Certainly not!</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For He says to Moses, “I will have mercy on whomever I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whomever I will have compassion.” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So then it is not of him who wills, nor of him who runs, but of God who shows mercy.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For the Scripture says to the Pharaoh, “For this very purpose I have raised you up, that I may show My power in you, and that My name may be declared in all the earth.” </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Therefore He has mercy on whom He wills, and whom He wills He hardens.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>You will say to me then, “Why does He still find fault? For who has resisted His will?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 10:32-36 11:1  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Therefore whoever confesses Me before men, him I will also confess before My Father who is in heaven.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But whoever denies Me before men, him I will also deny before My Father who is in heaven.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Do not think that I came to bring peace on earth. I did not come to bring peace but a sword.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>For I have come to ‘set a man against his father, a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law’;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>and ‘a man’s enemies will be those of his own household.’ </dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, when Jesus finished commanding His twelve disciples, that He departed from there to teach and to preach in their cities.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 10 - Genesis 17:15-17 19 18:11-14 21:1-8  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>God said to Abraham, “As for Sarai thy wife, her name shall not be called Sarai, but Sarah shall be her name. And I will bless her, and give thee a child by her; and I will bless him, and he shall become nations, and kings of nations shall come from him.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And Abraham fell on his face and said to himself, “Shall there be born a son to one who is a hundred years old? And shall Sarah, who is ninety years old, give birth?” And God said to Abraham, “Yes. Behold, Sarah thy wife shall bear you a son, and thou shalt call his name Isaac. I will establish My covenant with him, for an everlasting covenant.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Now Abraham and Sarah were old, advanced in days. Sarah laughed to herself saying, “This has not as yet happened to me, even until now, and my lord is old.” And the Lord God said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh to herself, saying, ‘Shall I then indeed bear? but I am old’? Shall anything be impossible that is spoken by God?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And the Lord visited Sarah as He had said. And she conceived, and bore Abraham a son in old age as the Lord God had spoken to him. And Abraham circumcised him on the eighth day, as the Lord God had commanded him.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And Abraham was a hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him. And Sarah said, “The Lord God has made laughter for me; for every one who hears shall rejoice with me.” And she said, “Who shall say to Abraham that Sarah suckles a child? Yet I have borne him a child in my old age.” And the child grew, and was weaned; and Abraham made a feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 11 - Judges 13:2-8 13-14 17-18 21  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In those days, there was a certain man of the tribe of Dan, whose name was Manoah; and his wife was barren and bore not. And the angel of the Lord appeared to the woman and said to her, “Behold, you are barren. But you shall conceive and bear a son. And now beware and drink no wine or strong drink, and eat nothing unclean, for lo, you shall conceive and bear a son. And no razor shall come upon his head, for the child shall be consecrated to God from the womb.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the woman went and spoke to her husband, saying, “A man of God came to me, and his countenance was like the countenance of an angel of God, very bright. And he said to me, ‘Behold, you shall conceive and bear a son; and now, drink no wine or strong drink, and eat nothing unclean, for the boy shall be consecrated to God from the womb, even until the day of his death.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Manoah prayed to God and said, “O Lord, let the man of God whom Thou didst send come again to us, and teach us what we are to do with the child that will be born.” And the angel of the Lord came to Manoah, and said, “Of all things that I said to your wife, let her keep. Let her eat nothing that comes from the vine, neither let her drink wine or strong drink.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “What is your name, that, when your words come to pass, we may glorify you?” And the angel of the Lord said to him, “Why do you ask concerning my name, whereas it is wonderful?” And the angel of the Lord appeared no more to Manoah and his wife.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 8 - Isaiah 40 41 45 48 54  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord: “Comfort, comfort My people,” says God. “Speak to the heart of Jerusalem, you Priests, comfort her, for her humiliation is increased, her iniquity is pardoned; for she has received from the Lord’s hand double for her sins. The voice of one crying in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the Lord; make straight the paths of our God.’</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“Go up to a high mountain, you who are proclaiming glad tidings to Zion, lift up your voice with strength, O herald of good tidings to Jerusalem. Lift it up, fear not! I the Lord God, I have heard the poor of Israel and will not forsake them. I will open rivers on the mountains, and fountains in the midst of the valleys; I will make the deserts pools of water, and the thirsty land springs of water. Let the heavens rejoice from above, and let the clouds rain down righteousness; let the earth bring forth, and let it sprout forth mercy and cause righteousness to shine forth also.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Declare this with a shout of joy, and let this be known, proclaim it to the end of the earth. Say, ‘The Lord hath redeemed His servant Jacob!’ And if they thirst, he shall lead them through the desert, He shall bring forth water for them out of the rock. Rejoice, O barren one who did not bear; break forth into singing and cry loud, you who have not been in travail! For more are the children of the desolate one than of her who has a husband.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 1:24-25 57-68 76 80  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Now after those days his wife Elizabeth conceived; and she hid herself five months, saying,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“Thus the Lord has dealt with me, in the days when He looked on me, to take away my reproach among people.”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>Now Elizabeth’s full time came for her to be delivered, and she brought forth a son.</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>When her neighbors and relatives heard how the Lord had shown great mercy to her, they rejoiced with her.</dd><dt>59</dt><dd>So it was, on the eighth day, that they came to circumcise the child; and they would have called him by the name of his father, Zacharias.</dd><dt>60</dt><dd>His mother answered and said, “No; he shall be called John.”</dd><dt>61</dt><dd>But they said to her, “There is no one among your relatives who is called by this name.”</dd><dt>62</dt><dd>So they made signs to his father – what he would have him called.</dd><dt>63</dt><dd>And he asked for a writing tablet, and wrote, saying, “His name is John.” So they all marveled.</dd><dt>64</dt><dd>Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue loosed, and he spoke, praising God.</dd><dt>65</dt><dd>Then fear came on all who dwelt around them; and all these sayings were discussed throughout all the hill country of Judea.</dd><dt>66</dt><dd>And all those who heard them kept them in their hearts, saying, “What kind of child will this be?” And the hand of the Lord was with him.</dd><dt>67</dt><dd>Now his father Zacharias was filled with the Holy Spirit, and prophesied, saying:</dd><dt>68</dt><dd>“Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, for He has visited and redeemed His people,</dd><dt>76</dt><dd>and you, child, will be called the prophet of the Highest; for you will go before the face of the Lord to prepare His ways.”</dd><dt>80</dt><dd>So the child grew and became strong in spirit, and was in the deserts till the day of his manifestation to Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 13:11-14:4  (Epistle Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>And do this, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep; for now our salvation is nearer than when we first believed.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>The night is far spent, the day is at hand. Therefore let us cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armor of light.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Let us walk properly, as in the day, not in revelry and drunkenness, not in lewdness and lust, not in strife and envy.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh, to fulfill its lusts.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Receive one who is weak in the faith, but not to disputes over doubtful things.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For one believes he may eat all things, but he who is weak eats only vegetables.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Let not him who eats despise him who does not eat, and let not him who does not eat judge him who eats; for God has received him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Who are you to judge another’s servant? To his own master he stands or falls. Indeed, he will be made to stand, for God is able to make him stand.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 1:1-25 57-68 76 80  (Gospel Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Inasmuch as many have taken in hand to set in order a narrative of those things which have been fulfilled among us,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>just as those who from the beginning were eyewitnesses and ministers of the word delivered them to us,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>it seemed good to me also, having had perfect understanding of all things from the very first, to write to you an orderly account, most excellent Theophilus,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>that you may know the certainty of those things in which you were instructed.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>There was in the days of Herod, the king of Judea, a certain priest named Zacharias, of the division of Abijah. His wife was of the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And they were both righteous before God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But they had no child, because Elizabeth was barren, and they were both well advanced in years.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So it was, that while he was serving as priest before God in the order of his division,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>according to the custom of the priesthood, his lot fell to burn incense when he went into the temple of the Lord.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the whole multitude of the people was praying outside at the hour of incense.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing on the right side of the altar of incense.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And when Zacharias saw him, he was troubled, and fear fell upon him.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But the angel said to him, “Do not be afraid, Zacharias, for your prayer is heard; and your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you shall call his name John.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And you will have joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For he will be great in the sight of the Lord, and shall drink neither wine nor strong drink. He will also be filled with the Holy Spirit, even from his mother’s womb.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And he will turn many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He will also go before Him in the spirit and power of Elijah, ‘to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children,’ and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just, to make ready a people prepared for the Lord.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And Zacharias said to the angel, “How shall I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is well advanced in years.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the angel answered and said to him, “I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and was sent to speak to you and bring you these glad tidings.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But behold, you will be mute and not able to speak until the day these things take place, because you did not believe my words which will be fulfilled in their own time.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And the people waited for Zacharias, and marveled that he lingered so long in the temple.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But when he came out, he could not speak to them; and they perceived that he had seen a vision in the temple, for he beckoned to them and remained speechless.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So it was, as soon as the days of his service were completed, that he departed to his own house.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now after those days his wife Elizabeth conceived; and she hid herself five months, saying,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>“Thus the Lord has dealt with me, in the days when He looked on me, to take away my reproach among people.”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>Now Elizabeth’s full time came for her to be delivered, and she brought forth a son.</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>When her neighbors and relatives heard how the Lord had shown great mercy to her, they rejoiced with her.</dd><dt>59</dt><dd>So it was, on the eighth day, that they came to circumcise the child; and they would have called him by the name of his father, Zacharias.</dd><dt>60</dt><dd>His mother answered and said, “No; he shall be called John.”</dd><dt>61</dt><dd>But they said to her, “There is no one among your relatives who is called by this name.”</dd><dt>62</dt><dd>So they made signs to his father – what he would have him called.</dd><dt>63</dt><dd>And he asked for a writing tablet, and wrote, saying, “His name is John.” So they all marveled.</dd><dt>64</dt><dd>Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue loosed, and he spoke, praising God.</dd><dt>65</dt><dd>Then fear came on all who dwelt around them; and all these sayings were discussed throughout all the hill country of Judea.</dd><dt>66</dt><dd>And all those who heard them kept them in their hearts, saying, “What kind of child will this be?” And the hand of the Lord was with him.</dd><dt>67</dt><dd>Now his father Zacharias was filled with the Holy Spirit, and prophesied, saying:</dd><dt>68</dt><dd>“Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, for He has visited and redeemed His people,</dd><dt>76</dt><dd>and you, child, will be called the prophet of the Highest; for you will go before the face of the Lord to prepare His ways.”</dd><dt>80</dt><dd>So the child grew and became strong in spirit, and was in the deserts till the day of his manifestation to Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 3:28-4:3  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith apart from the deeds of the law.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Or is He the God of the Jews only? Is He not also the God of the Gentiles? Yes, of the Gentiles also,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>since there is one God who will justify the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised through faith.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Do we then make void the law through faith? Certainly not! On the contrary, we establish the law.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>What then shall we say that Abraham our father has found according to the flesh? </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For if Abraham was justified by works, he has something to boast about, but not before God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For what does the Scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 7:24-8:4  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore whoever hears these sayings of Mine, and does them, I will liken him to a wise man who built his house on the rock:</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>and the rain descended, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house; and it did not fall, for it was founded on the rock.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But everyone who hears these sayings of Mine, and does not do them, will be like a foolish man who built his house on the sand:</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and the rain descended, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house; and it fell. And great was its fall.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And so it was, when Jesus had ended these sayings, that the people were astonished at His teaching,</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>for He taught them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>When He had come down from the mountain, great multitudes followed Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And behold, a leper came and worshiped Him, saying, “Lord, if You are willing, You can make me clean.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Jesus put out His hand and touched him, saying, “I am willing; be cleansed.” Immediately his leprosy was cleansed.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And Jesus said to him, “See that you tell no one; but go your way, show yourself to the priest, and offer the gift that Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 16:9-20  (3rd  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when He rose early on the first day of the week, He appeared first to Mary Magdalene, out of whom He had cast seven demons.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>She went and told those who had been with Him, as they mourned and wept.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when they heard that He was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>After that, He appeared in another form to two of them as they walked and went into the country.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And they went and told it to the rest, but they did not believe them either.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Later He appeared to the eleven as they sat at the table; and He rebuked their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they did not believe those who had seen Him after He had risen.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He who believes and is baptized will be saved; but he who does not believe will be condemned.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And these signs will follow those who believe: In My name they will cast out demons; they will speak with new tongues;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>they will take up serpents; and if they drink anything deadly, it will by no means hurt them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So then, after the Lord had spoken to them, He was received up into heaven, and sat down at the right hand of God.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And they went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming the word through the accompanying signs. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 5:1-10  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore, having been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>through whom also we have access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And not only that, but we also glory in tribulations, knowing that tribulation produces perseverance;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>and perseverance, character; and character, hope.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now hope does not disappoint, because the love of God has been poured out in our hearts by the Holy Spirit who was given to us.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For when we were still without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For scarcely for a righteous man will one die; yet perhaps for a good man someone would even dare to die.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But God demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Much more then, having now been justified by His blood, we shall be saved from wrath through Him.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, having been reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 6:22-33  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>The lamp of the body is the eye. If therefore your eye is good, your whole body will be full of light.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But if your eye is bad, your whole body will be full of darkness. If therefore the light that is in you is darkness, how great is that darkness!</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>No one can serve two masters; for either he will hate the one and love the other, or else he will be loyal to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Therefore I say to you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or what you will drink; nor about your body, what you will put on. Is not life more than food and the body more than clothing?</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Look at the birds of the air, for they neither sow nor reap nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not of more value than they?</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Which of you by worrying can add one cubit to his stature?</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So why do you worry about clothing? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow: they neither toil nor spin;</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and yet I say to you that even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now if God so clothes the grass of the field, which today is, and tomorrow is thrown into the oven, will He not much more clothe you, O you of little faith?</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore do not worry, saying, ‘What shall we eat?’ or ‘What shall we drink?’ or ‘What shall we wear?’</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>For after all these things the Gentiles seek. For your heavenly Father knows that you need all these things.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things shall be added to you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 9:18-33  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Therefore He has mercy on whom He wills, and whom He wills He hardens.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>You will say to me then, “Why does He still find fault? For who has resisted His will?”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But indeed, O man, who are you to reply against God? Will the thing formed say to him who formed it, “Why have you made me like this?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Does not the potter have power over the clay, from the same lump to make one vessel for honor and another for dishonor?</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>What if God, wanting to show His wrath and to make His power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath prepared for destruction,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>and that He might make known the riches of His glory on the vessels of mercy, which He had prepared beforehand for glory,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>even us whom He called, not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles?</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>As He says also in Hosea: “I will call them My people, who were not My people, and her beloved, who was not beloved.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And it shall come to pass in the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not My people,’ there they shall be called sons of the living God.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Isaiah also cries out concerning Israel: “Though the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, the remnant will be saved.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For He will finish the work and cut it short in righteousness, because the LORD will make a short work upon the earth.” </dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And as Isaiah said before: “Unless the LORD of Sabaoth had left us a seed, we would have become like Sodom, and we would have been made like Gomorrah.” </dd><dt>30</dt><dd>What shall we say then? That Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, have attained to righteousness, even the righteousness of faith;</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>but Israel, pursuing the law of righteousness, has not attained to the law of righteousness. </dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Why? Because they did not seek it by faith, but as it were, by the works of the law. For they stumbled at that stumbling stone.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>As it is written: “Behold, I lay in Zion a stumbling stone and rock of offense, and whoever believes on Him will not be put to shame.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:2-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>And when John had heard in prison about the works of Christ, he sent two of his disciples</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said to Him, “Are You the Coming One, or do we look for another?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “Go and tell John the things which you hear and see:</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The blind see and the lame walk; the lepers are cleansed and the deaf hear; the dead are raised up and the poor have the gospel preached to them.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And blessed is he who is not offended because of Me.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>As they departed, Jesus began to say to the multitudes concerning John: “What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A man clothed in soft garments? Indeed, those who wear soft clothing are in kings’ houses.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I say to you, and more than a prophet.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For this is he of whom it is written: ‘Behold, I send My messenger before Your face, who will prepare Your way before You.’ </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, among those born of women there has not risen one greater than John the Baptist; but he who is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And from the days of John the Baptist until now the kingdom of heaven suffers violence, and the violent take it by force.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And if you are willing to receive it, he is Elijah who is to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He who has ears to hear, let him hear!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 10:11-11:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>For the Scripture says, “Whoever believes on Him will not be put to shame.” </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For there is no distinction between Jew and Greek, for the same Lord over all is rich to all who call upon Him.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For “whoever calls on the Name of the LORD shall be saved.” </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>How then shall they call on Him in whom they have not believed? And how shall they believe in Him of whom they have not heard? And how shall they hear without a preacher?</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And how shall they preach unless they are sent? As it is written: “How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the gospel of peace, who bring glad tidings of good things!” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But they have not all obeyed the gospel. For Isaiah says, “LORD, who has believed our report?” </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So then faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But I say, have they not heard? Yes indeed: “Their sound has gone out to all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.” </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I say, did Israel not know? First Moses says: “I will provoke you to jealousy by those who are not a nation, I will move you to anger by a foolish nation.” </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But Isaiah is very bold and says: “I was found by those who did not seek Me; I was made manifest to those who did not ask for Me.” </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But to Israel he says: “All day long I have stretched out My hands to a disobedient and contrary people.” </dd><dt>1</dt><dd>I say then, has God cast away His people? Certainly not! For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>God has not cast away His people whom He foreknew. Or do you not know what the Scripture says of Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel, saying,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:16-20  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>But to what shall I liken this generation? It is like children sitting in the marketplaces and calling to their companions,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>and saying: ‘We played the flute for you, and you did not dance; we mourned to you, and you did not lament.’</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For John came neither eating nor drinking, and they say, ‘He has a demon.’</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and they say, ‘Look, a glutton and a winebibber, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!’ But wisdom is justified by her children.” </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He began to rebuke the cities in which most of His mighty works had been done, because they did not repent:</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 11:2-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>God has not cast away His people whom He foreknew. Or do you not know what the Scripture says of Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel, saying,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>LORD, they have killed Your prophets and torn down Your altars, and I alone am left, and they seek my life? </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But what does the divine response say to him? “I have reserved for Myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to Baal.” </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Even so then, at this present time there is a remnant according to the election of grace.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And if by grace, then it is no longer of works; otherwise grace is no longer grace. But if it is of works, it is no longer grace; otherwise work is no longer work.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>What then? Israel has not obtained what it seeks; but the elect have obtained it, and the rest were blinded.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Just as it is written: “God has given them a spirit of stupor, eyes that they should not see and ears that they should not hear, to this very day.” </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And David says: “Let their table become a snare and a trap, a stumbling block and a recompense to them.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Let their eyes be darkened, so that they do not see, and bow down their back always.” </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I say then, have they stumbled that they should fall? Certainly not! But through their fall, to provoke them to jealousy, salvation has come to the Gentiles.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Now if their fall is riches for the world, and their failure riches for the Gentiles, how much more their fullness!</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:20-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He began to rebuke the cities in which most of His mighty works had been done, because they did not repent:</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>“Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth and ashes.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But I say to you, it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon in the day of judgment than for you.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And you, Capernaum, who are exalted to heaven, will be brought down to Hades; for if the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Sodom, it would have remained until this day.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>But I say to you that it shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom in the day of judgment than for you.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>At that time Jesus answered and said, “I thank You, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that You have hidden these things from the wise and prudent and have revealed them to babes.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Even so, Father, for so it seemed good in Your sight.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 1:3-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who according to His abundant mercy has begotten us again to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>to an inheritance incorruptible and undefiled and that does not fade away, reserved in heaven for you,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>who are kept by the power of God through faith for salvation ready to be revealed in the last time.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>In this you greatly rejoice, though now for a little while, if need be, you have been grieved by various trials,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>that the genuineness of your faith, being much more precious than gold that perishes, though it is tested by fire, may be found to praise, honor, and glory at the revelation of Jesus Christ,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>whom having not seen you love. Though now you do not see Him, yet believing, you rejoice with joy inexpressible and full of glory,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>receiving the end of your faith – the salvation of your souls.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 1:13-19  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore gird up the loins of your mind, be sober, and rest your hope fully upon the grace that is to be brought to you at the revelation of Jesus Christ;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>as obedient children, not conforming yourselves to the former lusts, as in your ignorance;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>but as He who called you is holy, you also be holy in all your conduct,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>because it is written, “Be holy, for I am holy.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And if you call on the Father, who without partiality judges according to each one’s work, conduct yourselves throughout the time of your stay here in fear;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>knowing that you were not redeemed with corruptible things, like silver or gold, from your aimless conduct received by tradition from your fathers,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>but with the precious blood of Christ, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 2:11-24  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Beloved, I beg you as sojourners and pilgrims, abstain from fleshly lusts which war against the soul,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>having your conduct honorable among the Gentiles, that when they speak against you as evildoers, they may, by your good works which they observe, glorify God in the day of visitation.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore submit yourselves to every ordinance of man for the Lord’s sake, whether to the king as supreme,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>or to governors, as to those who are sent by him for the punishment of evildoers and for the praise of those who do good.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this is the will of God, that by doing good you may put to silence the ignorance of foolish men – </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>as free, yet not using liberty as a cloak for vice, but as bondservants of God.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Honor all people. Love the brotherhood. Fear God. Honor the king.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Servants, be submissive to your masters with all fear, not only to the good and gentle, but also to the harsh.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For this is commendable, if because of conscience toward God one endures grief, suffering wrongfully.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For what credit is it if, when you are beaten for your faults, you take it patiently? But when you do good and suffer, if you take it patiently, this is commendable before God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For to this you were called, because Christ also suffered for us, leaving us an example, that you should follow His steps:</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>“Who committed no sin, nor was deceit found in His mouth”;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>who, when He was reviled, did not revile in return; when He suffered, He did not threaten, but committed Himself to Him who judges righteously;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>who Himself bore our sins in His own body on the tree, that we, having died to sins, might live for righteousness – by whose stripes you were healed.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:15-25  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>So when they had eaten breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me more than these?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Feed My lambs.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He said to him again a second time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Tend My sheep.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He said to him the third time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” Peter was grieved because He said to him the third time, “Do you love Me?” And he said to Him, “Lord, You know all things; You know that I love You.” Jesus said to him, “Feed My sheep.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, when you were younger, you girded yourself and walked where you wished; but when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will gird you and carry you where you do not wish.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>This He spoke, signifying by what death he would glorify God. And when He had spoken this, He said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Peter, turning around, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following, who also had leaned on His breast at the supper, and said, “Lord, who is the one who betrays You?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Peter, seeing him, said to Jesus, “But Lord, what about this man?”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you? You follow Me.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then this saying went out among the brethren that this disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>This is the disciple who testifies of these things, and wrote these things; and we know that his testimony is true.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And there are also many other things that Jesus did, which if they were written one by one, I suppose that even the world itself could not contain the books that would be written. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 11:21-12:9  (Epistle Apostles)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>21</dt><dd>To our shame I say that we were too weak for that! But in whatever anyone is bold – I speak foolishly – I am bold also.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they the seed of Abraham? So am I.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Are they ministers of Christ? – I speak as a fool – I am more: in labors more abundant, in stripes above measure, in prisons more frequently, in deaths often.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>From the Jews five times I received forty stripes minus one.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Three times I was beaten with rods; once I was stoned; three times I was shipwrecked; a night and a day I have been in the deep;</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>in journeys often, in perils of waters, in perils of robbers, in perils of my own countrymen, in perils of the Gentiles, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderness, in perils in the sea, in perils among false brethren;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>in weariness and toil, in sleeplessness often, in hunger and thirst, in fastings often, in cold and nakedness – </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>besides the other things, what comes upon me daily: my deep concern for all the churches.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is made to stumble, and I do not burn with indignation?</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>If I must boast, I will boast in the things which concern my infirmity.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is blessed forever, knows that I am not lying.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>In Damascus the governor, under Aretas the king, was guarding the city of the Damascenes with a garrison, desiring to arrest me;</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>but I was let down in a basket through a window in the wall, and escaped from his hands.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>It is doubtless not profitable for me to boast. I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago – whether in the body I do not know, or whether out of the body I do not know, God knows – such a one was caught up to the third heaven.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And I know such a man – whether in the body or out of the body I do not know, God knows – </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>how he was caught up into Paradise and heard inexpressible words, which it is not lawful for a man to utter.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Of such a one I will boast; yet of myself I will not boast, except in my infirmities.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For though I might desire to boast, I will not be a fool; for I will speak the truth. But I refrain, lest anyone should think of me above what he sees me to be or hears from me.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And lest I should be exalted above measure by the abundance of the revelations, a thorn in the flesh was given to me, a messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I be exalted above measure.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Concerning this thing I pleaded with the Lord three times that it might depart from me.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And He said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for My strength is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore most gladly I will rather boast in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 16:13-19  (Gospel Apostles)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>When Jesus came into the region of Caesarea Philippi, He asked His disciples, saying, “Who do men say that I, the Son of Man, am?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So they said, “Some say John the Baptist, some Elijah, and others Jeremiah or one of the prophets.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He said to them, “But who do you say that I am?”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Simon Peter answered and said, “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to him, “Blessed are you, Simon Bar-Jonah, for flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but My Father who is in heaven.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And I also say to you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My church, and the gates of Hades shall not prevail against it.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 11:13-24  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>For I speak to you Gentiles; inasmuch as I am an apostle to the Gentiles, I magnify my ministry,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>if by any means I may provoke to jealousy those who are my flesh and save some of them.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For if their being cast away is the reconciling of the world, what will their acceptance be but life from the dead?</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For if the firstfruit is holy, the lump is also holy; and if the root is holy, so are the branches.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And if some of the branches were broken off, and you, being a wild olive tree, were grafted in among them, and with them became a partaker of the root and fatness of the olive tree,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>do not boast against the branches. But if you do boast, remember that you do not support the root, but the root supports you.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>You will say then, “Branches were broken off that I might be grafted in.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Well said. Because of unbelief they were broken off, and you stand by faith. Do not be haughty, but fear.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For if God did not spare the natural branches, He may not spare you either.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Therefore consider the goodness and severity of God: on those who fell, severity; but toward you, goodness, if you continue in His goodness. Otherwise you also will be cut off.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And they also, if they do not continue in unbelief, will be grafted in, for God is able to graft them in again.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For if you were cut out of the olive tree which is wild by nature, and were grafted contrary to nature into a cultivated olive tree, how much more will these, who are natural branches, be grafted into their own olive tree?</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 43:9-14  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Let all the nations be gathered together, and let the people be assembled. Who among them can declare this, and show us former things? Let them bring out their witnesses, that they may be justified; or let them hear and say, “It is truth.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“You are My witnesses,” says the Lord, “And My servant whom I have chosen, that you may know and believe Me, and understand that I am He. Before Me there was no God formed, nor shall there be after Me.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I, even I, am the Lord, and besides Me there is no savior. </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I have declared and saved, I have proclaimed, and there was no foreign god among you; therefore you are My witnesses,” says the Lord, “that I am God.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Indeed before the day was, I am He; and there is no one who can deliver out of My hand; I work, and who will reverse it?”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: “For your sake I will send to Babylon, and bring them all down as fugitives – the Chaldeans, who rejoice in their ships.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 4:9-16  (Epistle Apostles)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>For I think that God has displayed us, the apostles, last, as men condemned to death; for we have been made a spectacle to the world, both to angels and to men.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are wise in Christ! We are weak, but you are strong! You are distinguished, but we are dishonored!</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>To the present hour we both hunger and thirst, and we are poorly clothed, and beaten, and homeless.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And we labor, working with our own hands. Being reviled, we bless; being persecuted, we endure;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>being defamed, we entreat. We have been made as the filth of the world, the offscouring of all things until now.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I do not write these things to shame you, but as my beloved children I warn you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For though you might have ten thousand instructors in Christ, yet you do not have many fathers; for in Christ Jesus I have begotten you through the gospel.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore I urge you, imitate me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 3:13-19  (Gospel Apostles)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>And He went up on the mountain and called to Him those He Himself wanted. And they came to Him.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then He appointed twelve, that they might be with Him and that He might send them out to preach,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and to have power to heal sicknesses and to cast out demons:</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Simon, to whom He gave the name Peter;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>James the son of Zebedee and John the brother of James, to whom He gave the name Boanerges, that is, “Sons of Thunder”;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Cananite;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed Him. And they went into a house.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 11:25-36  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>25</dt><dd>For I do not desire, brethren, that you should be ignorant of this mystery, lest you should be wise in your own opinion, that blindness in part has happened to Israel until the fullness of the Gentiles has come in.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And so all Israel will be saved, as it is written: “The Deliverer will come out of Zion, and He will turn away ungodliness from Jacob;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>for this is My covenant with them, when I take away their sins.” </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Concerning the gospel they are enemies for your sake, but concerning the election they are beloved for the sake of the fathers.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For as you were once disobedient to God, yet have now obtained mercy through their disobedience,</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>even so these also have now been disobedient, that through the mercy shown you they also may obtain mercy.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>For God has committed them all to disobedience, that He might have mercy on all.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Oh, the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments and His ways past finding out!</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>“For who has known the mind of the LORD? Or who has become His counselor?” </dd><dt>35</dt><dd>“Or who has first given to Him and it shall be repaid to him?” </dd><dt>36</dt><dd>For of Him and through Him and to Him are all things, to whom be glory forever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 12:1-8  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>At that time Jesus went through the grainfields on the Sabbath. And His disciples were hungry, and began to pluck heads of grain and to eat.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And when the Pharisees saw it, they said to Him, “Look, Your disciples are doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath!”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But He said to them, “Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with him:</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>how he entered the house of God and ate the showbread which was not lawful for him to eat, nor for those who were with him, but only for the priests?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Or have you not read in the law that on the Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath, and are blameless?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Yet I say to you that in this place there is One greater than the temple.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But if you had known what this means, ‘I desire mercy and not sacrifice,’ you would not have condemned the guiltless.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For the Son of Man is Lord even of the Sabbath.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 6:11-17  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Likewise you also, reckon yourselves to be dead indeed to sin, but alive to God in Christ Jesus our Lord.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body, that you should obey it in its lusts.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And do not present your members as instruments of unrighteousness to sin, but present yourselves to God as being alive from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousness to God.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For sin shall not have dominion over you, for you are not under law but under grace.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>What then? Shall we sin because we are not under law but under grace? Certainly not!</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Do you not know that to whom you present yourselves slaves to obey, you are that one’s slaves whom you obey, whether of sin leading to death, or of obedience leading to righteousness?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But God be thanked that though you were slaves of sin, yet you obeyed from the heart that form of doctrine to which you were delivered.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 8:14-23  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when Jesus had come into Peter’s house, He saw his wife’s mother lying sick with a fever.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So He touched her hand, and the fever left her. And she arose and served them. </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>When evening had come, they brought to Him many who were demon-possessed. And He cast out the spirits with a word, and healed all who were sick,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Isaiah the prophet, saying: “He Himself took our infirmities and bore our sicknesses.” </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And when Jesus saw great multitudes about Him, He gave a command to depart to the other side.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then a certain scribe came and said to Him, “Teacher, I will follow You wherever You go.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And Jesus said to him, “Foxes have holes and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay His head.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then another of His disciples said to Him, “Lord, let me first go and bury my father.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But Jesus said to him, “Follow Me, and let the dead bury their own dead.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Now when He got into a boat, His disciples followed Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:1-12  (4th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they, and certain other women with them, came to the tomb bringing the spices which they had prepared.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But they found the stone rolled away from the tomb.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they went in and did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And it happened, as they were greatly perplexed about this, that behold, two men stood by them in shining garments.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then, as they were afraid and bowed their faces to the earth, they said to them, “Why do you seek the living among the dead?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>He is not here, but is risen! Remember how He spoke to you when He was still in Galilee,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>saying, ‘The Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and the third day rise again.’”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they remembered His words.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then they returned from the tomb and told all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and the other women with them, who told these things to the apostles.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And their words seemed to them like idle tales, and they did not believe them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Peter arose and ran to the tomb; and stooping down, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves; and he departed, marveling to himself at what had happened.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 6:18-23  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>And having been set free from sin, you became slaves of righteousness.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>I speak in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh. For just as you presented your members as slaves of uncleanness, and of lawlessness leading to more lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves of righteousness for holiness.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For when you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>What fruit did you have then in the things of which you are now ashamed? For the end of those things is death.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But now having been set free from sin, and having become slaves of God, you have your fruit to holiness, and the end, everlasting life.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 8:5-13  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Now when Jesus had entered Capernaum, a centurion came to Him, pleading with Him,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>saying, “Lord, my servant is lying at home paralyzed, dreadfully tormented.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And Jesus said to him, “I will come and heal him.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The centurion answered and said, “Lord, I am not worthy that You should come under my roof. But only speak a word, and my servant will be healed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For I also am a man under authority, having soldiers under me. And I say to this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and to another, ‘Come,’ and he comes; and to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When Jesus heard it, He marveled, and said to those who followed, “Assuredly, I say to you, I have not found such great faith, not even in Israel!</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And I say to you that many will come from east and west, and sit down with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But the sons of the kingdom will be cast out into outer darkness. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to the centurion, “Go your way; and as you have believed, so let it be done for you.” And his servant was healed that same hour.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 12:4-5 15-21  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>For as we have many members in one body, but all the members do not have the same function,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>so we, being many, are one body in Christ, and individually members of one another.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Rejoice with those who rejoice, and weep with those who weep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Be of the same mind toward one another. Do not set your mind on high things, but associate with the humble. Do not be wise in your own opinion.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Repay no one evil for evil. Have regard for good things in the sight of all men.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>If it is possible, as much as depends on you, live peaceably with all men.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Beloved, do not avenge yourselves, but rather give place to wrath; for it is written, “Vengeance is Mine, I will repay,” says the Lord.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Therefore “If your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him a drink; for in so doing you will heap coals of fire on his head.” </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 12:9-13  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Now when He had departed from there, He went into their synagogue.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And behold, there was a man who had a withered hand. And they asked Him, saying, “Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?” – that they might accuse Him.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “What man is there among you who has one sheep, and if it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, will not lay hold of it and lift it out?</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Of how much more value then is a man than a sheep? Therefore it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then He said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” And he stretched it out, and it was restored as whole as the other.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 14:9-18  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>For to this end Christ died and rose and lived again, that He might be Lord of both the dead and the living.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But why do you judge your brother? Or why do you show contempt for your brother? For we shall all stand before the judgment seat of Christ. </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For it is written: “As I live, says the LORD, every knee shall bow to Me, and every tongue shall confess to God.” </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So then each of us shall give account of himself to God.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore let us not judge one another anymore, but rather resolve this, not to put a stumbling block or a cause to fall in our brother’s way.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I know and am convinced by the Lord Jesus that there is nothing unclean of itself; but to him who considers anything to be unclean, to him it is unclean.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet if your brother is grieved because of your food, you are no longer walking in love. Do not destroy with your food the one for whom Christ died.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore do not let your good be spoken of as evil;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>for the kingdom of God is not eating and drinking, but righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For he who serves Christ in these things is acceptable to God and approved by men.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 12:14-16 22-30  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees went out and plotted against Him, how they might destroy Him.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when Jesus knew it, He withdrew from there. And great multitudes followed Him, and He healed them all.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Yet He warned them not to make Him known,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Then one was brought to Him who was demon-possessed, blind and mute; and He healed him, so that the blind and mute man both spoke and saw.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And all the multitudes were amazed and said, “Could this be the Son of David?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now when the Pharisees heard it they said, “This fellow does not cast out demons except by Beelzebub, the ruler of the demons.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But Jesus knew their thoughts, and said to them: “Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation, and every city or house divided against itself will not stand.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>If Satan casts out Satan, he is divided against himself. How then will his kingdom stand?</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And if I cast out demons by Beelzebub, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore they shall be your judges.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But if I cast out demons by the Spirit of God, surely the kingdom of God has come upon you.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Or how can one enter a strong man’s house and plunder his goods, unless he first binds the strong man? And then he will plunder his house.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>He who is not with Me is against Me, and he who does not gather with Me scatters abroad.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading Athanasius)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading Athanasius)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading Athanasius)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Matins Gospel either Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle either Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Gospel either Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 15:7-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore receive one another, just as Christ also received us, to the glory of God.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Now I say that Jesus Christ has become a servant to the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made to the fathers,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>and that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy, as it is written: “For this reason I will confess to You among the Gentiles, and sing to Your name.” </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And again he says: “Rejoice, O Gentiles, with His people!” </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And again: “Praise the LORD, all you Gentiles! Laud Him, all you peoples!” </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And again, Isaiah says: “There shall be a root of Jesse; and He who shall rise to reign over the Gentiles, in Him the Gentiles shall hope.” </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now I myself am confident concerning you, my brethren, that you also are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, able also to admonish one another. </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Nevertheless, brethren, I have written more boldly to you on some points, as reminding you, because of the grace given to me by God,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>that I might be a minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, ministering the gospel of God, that the offering of the Gentiles might be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 12:38-45  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>38</dt><dd>Then some of the scribes and Pharisees answered, saying, “Teacher, we want to see a sign from You.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But He answered and said to them, “An evil and adulterous generation seeks after a sign, and no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>For as Jonah was three days and three nights in the belly of the great fish, so will the Son of Man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>The men of Nineveh will rise up in the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because they repented at the preaching of Jonah; and indeed a greater than Jonah is here.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>The queen of the South will rise up in the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and indeed a greater than Solomon is here.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>When an unclean spirit goes out of a man, he goes through dry places, seeking rest, and finds none.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then he says, ‘I will return to my house from which I came.’ And when he comes, he finds it empty, swept, and put in order.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Then he goes and takes with him seven other spirits more wicked than himself, and they enter and dwell there; and the last state of that man is worse than the first. So shall it also be with this wicked generation.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 15:17-29  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore I have reason to glory in Christ Jesus in the things which pertain to God.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For I will not dare to speak of any of those things which Christ has not accomplished through me, in word and deed, to make the Gentiles obedient – </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>in mighty signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God, so that from Jerusalem and round about to Illyricum I have fully preached the gospel of Christ.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And so I have made it my aim to preach the gospel, not where Christ was named, lest I should build on another man’s foundation,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>but as it is written: “To whom He was not announced, they shall see; and those who have not heard shall understand.” </dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For this reason I also have been much hindered from coming to you.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But now no longer having a place in these parts, and having a great desire these many years to come to you,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>whenever I journey to Spain, I shall come to you.
