readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>But now, brethren, if I come to you speaking with tongues, what shall I profit you unless I speak to you either by revelation, by knowledge, by prophesying, or by teaching?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Even things without life, whether flute or harp, when they make a sound, unless they make a distinction in the sounds, how will it be known what is piped or played?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For if the trumpet makes an uncertain sound, who will prepare for battle?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So likewise you, unless you utter by the tongue words easy to understand, how will it be known what is spoken? For you will be speaking into the air.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There are, it may be, so many kinds of languages in the world, and none of them is without significance.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore, if I do not know the meaning of the language, I shall be a foreigner to him who speaks, and he who speaks will be a foreigner to me.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Even so you, since you are zealous for spiritual gifts, let it be for the edification of the church that you seek to excel.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore let him who speaks in a tongue pray that he may interpret.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays, but my understanding is unfruitful.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>What is the conclusion then? I will pray with the spirit, and I will also pray with the understanding. I will sing with the spirit, and I will also sing with the understanding.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Otherwise, if you bless with the spirit, how will he who occupies the place of the uninformed say “Amen” at your giving of thanks, since he does not understand what you say?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For you indeed give thanks well, but the other is not edified.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>I thank my God I speak with tongues more than you all;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>yet in the church I would rather speak five words with my understanding, that I may teach others also, than ten thousand words in a tongue.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 20:17-28  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Now Jesus, going up to Jerusalem, took the twelve disciples aside on the road and said to them,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be betrayed to the chief priests and to the scribes; and they will condemn Him to death,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and deliver Him to the Gentiles to mock and to scourge and to crucify. And the third day He will rise again.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then the mother of Zebedee’s sons came to Him with her sons, kneeling down and asking something from Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And He said to her, “What do you wish?” She said to Him, “Grant that these two sons of mine may sit, one on Your right hand and the other on the left, in Your kingdom.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But Jesus answered and said, “You do not know what you ask. Are you able to drink the cup that I am about to drink, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?” They said to Him, “We are able.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So He said to them, “You will indeed drink My cup, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with; but to sit on My right hand and on My left is not Mine to give, but it is for those for whom it is prepared by My Father.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And when the ten heard it, they were greatly displeased with the two brothers.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But Jesus called them to Himself and said, “You know that the rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and those who are great exercise authority over them.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Yet it shall not be so among you; but whoever desires to become great among you, let him be your servant.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And whoever desires to be first among you, let him be your slave – </dd><dt>28</dt><dd>just as the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give His life a ransom for many.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 14:26-40  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>How is it then, brethren? Whenever you come together, each of you has a psalm, has a teaching, has a tongue, has a revelation, has an interpretation. Let all things be done for edification.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>If anyone speaks in a tongue, let there be two or at the most three, each in turn, and let one interpret.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But if there is no interpreter, let him keep silent in church, and let him speak to himself and to God.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Let two or three prophets speak, and let the others judge.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But if anything is revealed to another who sits by, let the first keep silent.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>For you can all prophesy one by one, that all may learn and all may be encouraged.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>For God is not the author of confusion but of peace, as in all the churches of the saints.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Let your women keep silent in the churches, for they are not permitted to speak; but they are to be submissive, as the law also says.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And if they want to learn something, let them ask their own husbands at home; for it is shameful for women to speak in church.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Or did the word of God come originally from you? Or was it you only that it reached?</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>If anyone thinks himself to be a prophet or spiritual, let him acknowledge that the things which I write to you are the commandments of the Lord.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But if anyone is ignorant, let him be ignorant.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Therefore, brethren, desire earnestly to prophesy, and do not forbid to speak with tongues.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Let all things be done decently and in order.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:12-14 17-20  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Then Jesus went into the temple of God and drove out all those who bought and sold in the temple, and overturned the tables of the money changers and the seats of those who sold doves.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And He said to them, “It is written, ‘My house shall be called a house of prayer,’ but you have made it a ‘den of thieves.’” </dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then the blind and the lame came to Him in the temple, and He healed them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then He left them and went out of the city to Bethany, and He lodged there.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Now in the morning, as He returned to the city, He was hungry.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And seeing a fig tree by the road, He came to it and found nothing on it but leaves, and said to it, “Let no fruit grow on you ever again.” Immediately the fig tree withered away.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And when the disciples saw it, they marveled, saying, “How did the fig tree wither away so soon?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 14:6-9  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>He who observes the day, observes it to the Lord; and he who does not observe the day, to the Lord he does not observe it. He who eats, eats to the Lord, for he gives God thanks; and he who does not eat, to the Lord he does not eat, and gives God thanks.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For none of us lives to himself, and no one dies to himself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For if we live, we live to the Lord; and if we die, we die to the Lord. Therefore, whether we live or die, we are the Lord’s.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For to this end Christ died and rose and lived again, that He might be Lord of both the dead and the living.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 15:32-39  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Now Jesus called His disciples to Himself and said, “I have compassion on the multitude, because they have now continued with Me three days and have nothing to eat. And I do not want to send them away hungry, lest they faint on the way.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Then His disciples said to Him, “Where could we get enough bread in the wilderness to fill such a great multitude?”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “How many loaves do you have?” And they said, “Seven, and a few little fish.”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>So He commanded the multitude to sit down on the ground.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And He took the seven loaves and the fish and gave thanks, broke them and gave them to His disciples; and the disciples gave to the multitude.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>So they all ate and were filled, and they took up seven large baskets full of the fragments that were left.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Now those who ate were four thousand men, besides women and children.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And He sent away the multitude, got into the boat, and came to the region of Magdala. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Exodus 24:12-18  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Then the Lord said to Moses, “Come up to Me on the mountain and be there; and I will give you tablets of stone, and the law and commandments which I have written, that you may teach them.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So Moses arose with his assistant Joshua, and Moses went up to the mountain of God.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And he said to the elders, “Wait here for us until we come back to you. Indeed, Aaron and Hur are with you. If any man has a difficulty, let him go to them.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then Moses went up into the mountain, and a cloud covered the mountain.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Now the glory of the Lord rested on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days. And on the seventh day He called to Moses out of the midst of the cloud.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The sight of the glory of the Lord was like a consuming fire on the top of the mountain in the eyes of the children of Israel.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>So Moses went into the midst of the cloud and went up into the mountain. And Moses was on the mountain forty days and forty nights.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 15 - Exodus 33:11-23 34:4-6 8  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The Lord spoke to Moses, as if one should speak to his friend; and he returned to the camp, but his servant Joshua the son of Nun, a young man, departed not from the Tabernacle. And Moses said to the Lord, “Behold, Thou didst command me to lead forth this people, but Thou hast not showed me whom Thou wilt send with me; but Thou hast said to me, ‘I know you above all, and you have found favor with me.’ If, then, I have found grace in Thy sight, reveal Thyself to me, that I may see Thee clearly, that I may find grace in Thy sight, and that I may know that this great nation is Thy people.” And the Lord said unto him, “I Myself will go before you, and I will give you rest.” And Moses said to Him, “If Thou Thyself dost not go with us, bring me not up from here.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“And how shall it be surely known that both I and Thy people have found grace with Thee, except Thou go with us? So both I and Thy people shall be glorified beyond all the nations, as many as are upon the earth.” And the Lord said to Moses, “This word also, which you have spoken, I will do; for you have found grace before Me, and I know you above all.” And Moses said, “Show me Thy glory.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And the Lord said to Moses, I will go before you with My glory, and I will call out My name, ‘the Lord’ before you; and I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.” And again He said, “You shall not be able to see My face, for man shall not see My face and live.” And again the Lord said, “Behold there is a place by Me; you shall stand upon the rock. And when My glory shall pass by, then I will put you in a cleft on the rock; and I will cover you with My hand, until I pass by. And I will take away My hand, and then you shall see My backside; but My face shall not appear to you.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And having risen early in the morning, Moses went up Mount Sinai, as the Lord had told him. And the Lord descended in a cloud, and Moses stood there before Him and called out in the name of the Lord. And the Lord passed by before his face, and called out, “The Lord God, compassionate and merciful, longsuffering, greatly-merciful, and true.” And Moses, making haste, stooped down to the earth and worshipped the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 23 - 3 [1] Kings 19:3-9 11-13 15 16  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In those days, Elijah went to Beersheba, in the land of Judah. And he left his servant there and went a days journey into the wilderness, and came and sat down under a juniper tree. And he lay down and slept under the tree. And behold, someone touched him and said to him, “Arise, eat and drink.” And Elijah looked, and behold, at his head there was a cake of barley and a cruse of water. And he arose, and ate and drank, and lay down again and slept.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the angel of the Lord returned a second time, and touched him, and said to him, “Arise, eat and drink, for the journey will be too much for you.” And he arose, and ate and drank. And he went in the strength of that food forty days and forty nights to Mount Horeb.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And he entered there into a cave, and lodged there. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him, and the Lord said to him, “You shall go forth and stand on the mountain before the Lord.” And behold, the Lord passed by, and a great and strong wind rent the mountain, and broke in pieces the rock before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind; and after the wind an earthquake; but the Lord was not in the earthquake; and after the earthquake a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire; and after the fire a voice of a gentle breeze, and the Lord was there. And it came to pass when Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his mantle and went out and stood before the cave.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And the Lord said to him, “Go, return on your way, and you shall come on the way of the widerness of Damascus; and you shall anoint Elisha the son of Shaphat to be prophet in your place.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:28-36  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, about eight days after these sayings, that He took Peter, John, and James and went up on the mountain to pray.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>As He prayed, the appearance of His face was altered, and His robe became white and glistening.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And behold, two men talked with Him, who were Moses and Elijah,</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>who appeared in glory and spoke of His decease which He was about to accomplish at Jerusalem.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>But Peter and those with him were heavy with sleep; and when they were fully awake, they saw His glory and the two men who stood with Him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Then it happened, as they were parting from Him, that Peter said to Jesus, “Master, it is good for us to be here; and let us make three tabernacles: one for You, one for Moses, and one for Elijah” – not knowing what he said.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>While he was saying this, a cloud came and overshadowed them; and they were fearful as they entered the cloud.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And a voice came out of the cloud, saying, “This is My beloved Son. Hear Him!”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>When the voice had ceased, Jesus was found alone. But they kept quiet, and told no one in those days any of the things they had seen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 3:9-17  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>For we are God’s fellow workers; you are God’s field, you are God’s building.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>According to the grace of God which was given to me, as a wise master builder I have laid the foundation, and another builds on it. But let each one take heed how he builds on it.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For no other foundation can anyone lay than that which is laid, which is Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Now if anyone builds on this foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, straw,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>each one’s work will become clear; for the Day will declare it, because it will be revealed by fire; and the fire will test each one’s work, of what sort it is.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>If anyone’s work which he has built on it endures, he will receive a reward.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>If anyone’s work is burned, he will suffer loss; but he himself will be saved, yet so as through fire.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Do you not know that you are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God dwells in you?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>If anyone defiles the temple of God, God will destroy him. For the temple of God is holy, which temple you are.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 14:22-34  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>Immediately Jesus made His disciples get into the boat and go before Him to the other side, while He sent the multitudes away.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And when He had sent the multitudes away, He went up on the mountain by Himself to pray. Now when evening came, He was alone there.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>But the boat was now in the middle of the sea, tossed by the waves, for the wind was contrary.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Now in the fourth watch of the night Jesus went to them, walking on the sea.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And when the disciples saw Him walking on the sea, they were troubled, saying, “It is a ghost!” And they cried out for fear.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But immediately Jesus spoke to them, saying, “Be of good cheer! It is I; do not be afraid.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And Peter answered Him and said, “Lord, if it is You, command me to come to You on the water.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>So He said, “Come.” And when Peter had come down out of the boat, he walked on the water to go to Jesus.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But when he saw that the wind was boisterous, he was afraid; and beginning to sink he cried out, saying, “Lord, save me!”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And immediately Jesus stretched out His hand and caught him, and said to him, “O you of little faith, why did you doubt?”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And when they got into the boat, the wind ceased.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Then those who were in the boat came and worshiped Him, saying, “Truly You are the Son of God.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>When they had crossed over, they came to the land of Gennesaret.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Peter 1:10-19  (Epistle Transfiguration)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore, brethren, be even more diligent to make your call and election sure, for if you do these things you will never stumble;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>for so an entrance will be supplied to you abundantly into the everlasting kingdom of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For this reason I will not be negligent to remind you always of these things, though you know and are established in the present truth.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Yes, I think it is right, as long as I am in this tent, to stir you up by reminding you,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>knowing that shortly I must put off my tent, just as our Lord Jesus Christ showed me.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Moreover I will be careful to ensure that you always have a reminder of these things after my decease.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For we did not follow cunningly devised fables when we made known to you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, but were eyewitnesses of His majesty.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For He received from God the Father honor and glory when such a voice came to Him from the Excellent Glory: “This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And we heard this voice which came from heaven when we were with Him on the holy mountain.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And so we have the prophetic word confirmed, which you do well to heed as a light that shines in a dark place, until the day dawns and the morning star rises in your hearts;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 17:1-9  (Gospel Transfiguration)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now after six days Jesus took Peter, James, and John his brother, led them up on a high mountain by themselves;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and He was transfigured before them. His face shone like the sun, and His clothes became as white as the light.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And behold, Moses and Elijah appeared to them, talking with Him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then Peter answered and said to Jesus, “Lord, it is good for us to be here; if You wish, let us make here three tabernacles: one for You, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>While he was still speaking, behold, a bright cloud overshadowed them; and suddenly a voice came out of the cloud, saying, “This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased. Hear Him!”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And when the disciples heard it, they fell on their faces and were greatly afraid.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But Jesus came and touched them and said, “Arise, and do not be afraid.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>When they had lifted up their eyes, they saw no one but Jesus only.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now as they came down from the mountain, Jesus commanded them, saying, “Tell the vision to no one until the Son of Man is risen from the dead.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 15:12-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Now if Christ is preached that He has been raised from the dead, how do some among you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ is not risen.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And if Christ is not risen, then our preaching is empty and your faith is also empty.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yes, and we are found false witnesses of God, because we have testified of God that He raised up Christ, whom He did not raise up – if in fact the dead do not rise.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For if the dead do not rise, then Christ is not risen.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And if Christ is not risen, your faith is futile; you are still in your sins!</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then also those who have fallen asleep in Christ have perished.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>If in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men the most pitiable.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:18-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Now in the morning, as He returned to the city, He was hungry.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And seeing a fig tree by the road, He came to it and found nothing on it but leaves, and said to it, “Let no fruit grow on you ever again.” Immediately the fig tree withered away.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And when the disciples saw it, they marveled, saying, “How did the fig tree wither away so soon?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So Jesus answered and said to them, “Assuredly, I say to you, if you have faith and do not doubt, you will not only do what was done to the fig tree, but also if you say to this mountain, ‘Be removed and be cast into the sea,’ it will be done.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And whatever things you ask in prayer, believing, you will receive.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 15:29-38  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>29</dt><dd>Otherwise, what will they do who are baptized for the dead, if the dead do not rise at all? Why then are they baptized for the dead?</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And why do we stand in jeopardy every hour?</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>I affirm, by the boasting in you which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die daily.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>If, in the manner of men, I have fought with beasts at Ephesus, what advantage is it to me? If the dead do not rise, “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die!”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Do not be deceived: “Evil company corrupts good habits.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Awake to righteousness, and do not sin; for some do not have the knowledge of God. I speak this to your shame.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>But someone will say, “How are the dead raised up? And with what body do they come?”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Foolish one, what you sow is not made alive unless it dies.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And what you sow, you do not sow that body that shall be, but mere grain – perhaps wheat or some other grain.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But God gives it a body as He pleases, and to each seed its own body.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:23-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Now when He came into the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people confronted Him as He was teaching, and said, “By what authority are You doing these things? And who gave You this authority?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>But Jesus answered and said to them, “I also will ask you one thing, which if you tell Me, I likewise will tell you by what authority I do these things:</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The baptism of John – where was it from? From heaven or from men?” And they reasoned among themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ He will say to us, ‘Why then did you not believe him?’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But if we say, ‘From men,’ we fear the multitude, for all count John as a prophet.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>So they answered Jesus and said, “We do not know.” And He said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 16:4-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>But if it is fitting that I go also, they will go with me.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now I will come to you when I pass through Macedonia (for I am passing through Macedonia).</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And it may be that I will remain, or even spend the winter with you, that you may send me on my journey, wherever I go.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For I do not wish to see you now on the way; but I hope to stay a while with you, if the Lord permits.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But I will tarry in Ephesus until Pentecost.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For a great and effective door has opened to me, and there are many adversaries.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And if Timothy comes, see that he may be with you without fear; for he does the work of the Lord, as I also do.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore let no one despise him. But send him on his journey in peace, that he may come to me; for I am waiting for him with the brethren.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Now concerning our brother Apollos, I strongly urged him to come to you with the brethren, but he was quite unwilling to come at this time; however, he will come when he has a convenient time.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:28-32  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>But what do you think? A man had two sons, and he came to the first and said, ‘Son, go, work today in my vineyard.’</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>He answered and said, ‘I will not,’ but afterward he regretted it and went.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then he came to the second and said likewise. And he answered and said, ‘I go, sir,’ but he did not go.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Which of the two did the will of his father?” They said to Him, “The first.” Jesus said to them, “Assuredly, I say to you that tax collectors and harlots enter the kingdom of God before you.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>For John came to you in the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him; but tax collectors and harlots believed him; and when you saw it, you did not afterward relent and believe him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 1:1-7  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Timothy our brother, to the church of God which is at Corinth, with all the saints who are in all Achaia:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all comfort,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>who comforts us in all our tribulation, that we may be able to comfort those who are in any trouble, with the comfort with which we ourselves are comforted by God.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For as the sufferings of Christ abound in us, so our consolation also abounds through Christ.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Now if we are afflicted, it is for your consolation and salvation, which is effective for enduring the same sufferings which we also suffer. Or if we are comforted, it is for your consolation and salvation.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And our hope for you is steadfast, because we know that as you are partakers of the sufferings, so also you will partake of the consolation.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:43-46  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>43</dt><dd>Therefore I say to you, the kingdom of God will be taken from you and given to a nation bearing the fruits of it.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>And whoever falls on this stone will be broken; but on whomever it falls, it will grind him to powder.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Now when the chief priests and Pharisees heard His parables, they perceived that He was speaking of them.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>But when they sought to lay hands on Him, they feared the multitudes, because they took Him for a prophet.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 1:12-20  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>For our boasting is this: the testimony of our conscience that we conducted ourselves in the world in simplicity and godly sincerity, not with fleshly wisdom but by the grace of God, and more abundantly toward you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For we are not writing any other things to you than what you read or understand. Now I trust you will understand, even to the end</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>(as also you have understood us in part), that we are your boast as you also are ours, in the day of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And in this confidence I intended to come to you before, that you might have a second benefit – </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to pass by way of you to Macedonia, to come again from Macedonia to you, and be helped by you on my way to Judea.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, when I was planning this, did I do it lightly? Or the things I plan, do I plan according to the flesh, that with me there should be Yes, Yes, and No, No?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But as God is faithful, our word to you was not Yes and No.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, who was preached among you by us – by me, Silvanus, and Timothy – was not Yes and No, but in Him was Yes.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For all the promises of God in Him are Yes, and in Him Amen, to the glory of God through us.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 22:23-33  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>The same day the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to Him and asked Him,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>saying: “Teacher, Moses said that if a man dies, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife and raise up offspring for his brother.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Now there were with us seven brothers. The first died after he had married, and having no offspring, left his wife to his brother.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Likewise the second also, and the third, even to the seventh.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Last of all the woman died also.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore, in the resurrection, whose wife of the seven will she be? For they all had her.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “You are mistaken, not knowing the Scriptures nor the power of God.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels of God in heaven.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what was spoken to you by God, saying,</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>’I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And when the multitudes heard this, they were astonished at His teaching.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Romans 15:30-33  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>30</dt><dd>Now I beg you, brethren, through the Lord Jesus Christ, and through the love of the Spirit, that you strive together with me in prayers to God for me,</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>that I may be delivered from those in Judea who do not believe, and that my service for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>that I may come to you with joy by the will of God, and may be refreshed together with you.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Now the God of peace be with you all. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 17:24-18:4  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>When they had come to Capernaum, those who received the temple tax came to Peter and said, “Does your Teacher not pay the temple tax?”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>He said, “Yes.” And when he had come into the house, Jesus anticipated him, saying, “What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth take customs or taxes, from their sons or from strangers?”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Peter said to Him, “From strangers.” Jesus said to him, “Then the sons are free.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Nevertheless, lest we offend them, go to the sea, cast in a hook, and take the fish that comes up first. And when you have opened its mouth, you will find a piece of money; take that and give it to them for Me and you.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>At that time the disciples came to Jesus, saying, “Who then is greatest in the kingdom of heaven?”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then Jesus called a little child to Him, set him in the midst of them,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said, “Assuredly, I say to you, unless you are converted and become as little children, you will by no means enter the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Therefore whoever humbles himself as this little child is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 2 - Proverbs 10 3 8  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The memory of the righteous is with praise and the blessing of the Lord is upon his head. Blessed is the man who has found wisdom and the mortal who has understanding. For it is better to purchase her than treasuries of gold and silver. She is more precious than precious stones and all that is precious is unworthy of her. For length of days and years of life are in her right hand; and in her left hand are riches and glory. Out of her mouth proceeds righteousness and she bears law and mercy upon her tongue.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Hear me, O child, for I will speak noble things. Blessed is the man who keeps my ways, for my ways are the ways of life, and in them is prepared favor from the Lord. Therefore, I pray thee, and utter my voice to the sons of men: For I, wisdom, have dwelt with counsel and knowledge and I have called upon understanding. Counsel and safety are mine, understanding and strength are mine. I love those who love me and those seeking me shall find grace.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Understand craftiness, O you who are simple, and imbibe knowledge, you who are untaught. Hear me again, for I will speak noble things: I will open my mouth and from my lips shall come what is right. For my throat shall meditate truth; false lips are an abomination before me. All the words of my mouth are righteous; there is nothing in them that is twisted or perverse. They are all straight to him who understands and right to those who find knowledge.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I shall instruct you in truth, so that your hope will be in the Lord and you shall be filled with the Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 10:31-11:12  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut out.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked what is perverse.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Dishonest scales are an abomination to the Lord, but a just weight is His delight.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>When pride comes, then comes shame; but with the humble is wisdom.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The integrity of the upright will guide them, but the perversity of the unfaithful will destroy them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The righteousness of the blameless will direct his way aright, but the wicked will fall by his own wickedness.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The righteousness of the upright will deliver them, but the unfaithful will be caught by their lust.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When a wicked man dies, his expectation will perish, and the hope of the unjust perishes.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The righteous is delivered from trouble, and it comes to the wicked instead.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The hypocrite with his mouth destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge the righteous will be delivered.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices; and when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted, but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>He who is devoid of wisdom despises his neighbor, but a man of understanding holds his peace.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:1-14  (10th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>After these things Jesus showed Himself again to the disciples at the Sea of Tiberias, and in this way He showed Himself:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Simon Peter, Thomas called the Twin, Nathanael of Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two others of His disciples were together.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Simon Peter said to them, “I am going fishing.” They said to him, “We are going with you also.” They went out and immediately got into the boat, and that night they caught nothing.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But when the morning had now come, Jesus stood on the shore; yet the disciples did not know that it was Jesus.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “Children, have you any food?” They answered Him, “No.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Cast the net on the right side of the boat, and you will find some.” So they cast, and now they were not able to draw it in because of the multitude of fish.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore that disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, “It is the Lord!” Now when Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he put on his outer garment (for he had removed it), and plunged into the sea.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But the other disciples came in the little boat (for they were not far from land, but about two hundred cubits), dragging the net with fish.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then, as soon as they had come to land, they saw a fire of coals there, and fish laid on it, and bread.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Bring some of the fish which you have just caught.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Simon Peter went up and dragged the net to land, full of large fish, one hundred and fifty-three; and although there were so many, the net was not broken.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Come and eat breakfast.” Yet none of the disciples dared ask Him, “Who are You?” – knowing that it was the Lord.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Jesus then came and took the bread and gave it to them, and likewise the fish.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>This is now the third time Jesus showed Himself to His disciples after He was raised from the dead.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:26-8:2  (Epistle St Tikhon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For such a High Priest was fitting for us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and has become higher than the heavens;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>who does not need daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for his own sins and then for the people’s, for this He did once for all when He offered up Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the law appoints as high priests men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints the Son who has been perfected forever.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the main point of the things we are saying: We have such a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>a Minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord erected, and not man.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 5:14-19  (Gospel St Tikhon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>You are the light of the world. A city that is set on a hill cannot be hidden.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Nor do they light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a lampstand, and it gives light to all who are in the house.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works and glorify your Father in heaven.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Do not think that I came to destroy the Law or the Prophets. I did not come to destroy but to fulfill.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For assuredly, I say to you, till heaven and earth pass away, one jot or one tittle will by no means pass from the law till all is fulfilled.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Whoever therefore breaks one of the least of these commandments, and teaches men so, shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven; but whoever does and teaches them, he shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 4:9-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>For I think that God has displayed us, the apostles, last, as men condemned to death; for we have been made a spectacle to the world, both to angels and to men.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are wise in Christ! We are weak, but you are strong! You are distinguished, but we are dishonored!</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>To the present hour we both hunger and thirst, and we are poorly clothed, and beaten, and homeless.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And we labor, working with our own hands. Being reviled, we bless; being persecuted, we endure;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>being defamed, we entreat. We have been made as the filth of the world, the offscouring of all things until now.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I do not write these things to shame you, but as my beloved children I warn you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For though you might have ten thousand instructors in Christ, yet you do not have many fathers; for in Christ Jesus I have begotten you through the gospel.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore I urge you, imitate me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 17:14-23  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>And when they had come to the multitude, a man came to Him, kneeling down to Him and saying,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Lord, have mercy on my son, for he is an epileptic and suffers severely; for he often falls into the fire and often into the water.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So I brought him to Your disciples, but they could not cure him.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then Jesus answered and said, “O faithless and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you? Bring him here to Me.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And Jesus rebuked the demon, and it came out of him; and the child was cured from that very hour.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then the disciples came to Jesus privately and said, “Why could we not cast it out?”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>So Jesus said to them, “Because of your unbelief; for assuredly, I say to you, if you have faith as a mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move; and nothing will be impossible for you.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>However, this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Now while they were staying in Galilee, Jesus said to them, “The Son of Man is about to be betrayed into the hands of men,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>and they will kill Him, and the third day He will be raised up.” And they were exceedingly sorrowful.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 2:4-15  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>For out of much affliction and anguish of heart I wrote to you, with many tears, not that you should be grieved, but that you might know the love which I have so abundantly for you.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But if anyone has caused grief, he has not grieved me, but all of you to some extent – not to be too severe.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>This punishment which was inflicted by the majority is sufficient for such a man,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>so that, on the contrary, you ought rather to forgive and comfort him, lest perhaps such a one be swallowed up with too much sorrow.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore I urge you to reaffirm your love to him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For to this end I also wrote, that I might put you to the test, whether you are obedient in all things.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Now whom you forgive anything, I also forgive. For if indeed I have forgiven anything, I have forgiven that one for your sakes in the presence of Christ,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>lest Satan should take advantage of us; for we are not ignorant of his devices.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Furthermore, when I came to Troas to preach Christ’s gospel, and a door was opened to me by the Lord,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I had no rest in my spirit, because I did not find Titus my brother; but taking my leave of them, I departed for Macedonia.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now thanks be to God who always leads us in triumph in Christ, and through us diffuses the fragrance of His knowledge in every place.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For we are to God the fragrance of Christ among those who are being saved and among those who are perishing.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 23:13-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you shut up the kingdom of heaven against men; for you neither go in yourselves, nor do you allow those who are entering to go in.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you devour widows’ houses, and for a pretense make long prayers. Therefore you will receive greater condemnation. </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you travel land and sea to win one proselyte, and when he is won, you make him twice as much a son of hell as yourselves.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Woe to you, blind guides, who say, ‘Whoever swears by the temple, it is nothing; but whoever swears by the gold of the temple, he is obliged to perform it.’</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Fools and blind! For which is greater, the gold or the temple that sanctifies the gold?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And, ‘Whoever swears by the altar, it is nothing; but whoever swears by the gift that is on it, he is obliged to perform it.’</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Fools and blind! For which is greater, the gift or the altar that sanctifies the gift?</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Therefore he who swears by the altar, swears by it and by all things on it.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He who swears by the temple, swears by it and by Him who dwells in it.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And he who swears by heaven, swears by the throne of God and by Him who sits on it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 28:10-17  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Now Jacob went out from Beersheba and went toward Haran.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So he came to a certain place and stayed there all night, because the sun had set. And he took one of the stones of that place and put it at his head, and he lay down in that place to sleep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then he dreamed, and behold, a ladder was set up on the earth, and its top reached to heaven; and there the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And behold, the Lord stood above it and said: “I am the Lord God of Abraham your father and the God of Isaac; the land on which you lie I will give to you and your descendants.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Also your descendants shall be as the dust of the earth; you shall spread abroad to the west and the east, to the north and the south; and in you and in your seed all the families of the earth shall be blessed.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Behold, I am with you and will keep you wherever you go, and will bring you back to this land; for I will not leave you until I have done what I have spoken to you.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Jacob awoke from his sleep and said, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I did not know it.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And he was afraid and said, “How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ezekiel 43:27-44:4  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>‘When these days are over it shall be, on the eighth day and thereafter, that the priests shall offer your burnt offerings and your peace offerings on the altar; and I will accept you,’ says the Lord God.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then He brought me back to the outer gate of the sanctuary which faces toward the east, but it was shut.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the Lord said to me, “This gate shall be shut; it shall not be opened, and no man shall enter by it, because the Lord God of Israel has entered by it; therefore it shall be shut.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“As for the prince, because he is the prince, he may sit in it to eat bread before the Lord; he shall enter by way of the vestibule of the gateway, and go out the same way.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Also He brought me by way of the north gate to the front of the temple; so I looked, and behold, the glory of the Lord filled the house of the Lord; and I fell on my face.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 9:1-11  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Wisdom has built her house, she has hewn out her seven pillars;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>she has slaughtered her meat, she has mixed her wine, she has also furnished her table.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>She has sent out her maidens, she cries out from the highest places of the city,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!” as for him who lacks understanding, she says to him,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“Come, eat of my bread and drink of the wine I have mixed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Forsake foolishness and live, and go in the way of understanding.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>He who corrects a scoffer gets shame for himself, and he who rebukes a wicked man only harms himself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Do not correct a scoffer, lest he hate you; </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>give instruction to a wise man, and he will be still wiser; teach a just man, and he will increase in learning.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For by me your days will be multiplied, and years of life will be added to you.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 1:39-49 56  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>39</dt><dd>Now Mary arose in those days and went into the hill country with haste, to a city of Judah,</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>and entered the house of Zacharias and greeted Elizabeth.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And it happened, when Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, that the babe leaped in her womb; and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Then she spoke out with a loud voice and said, “Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your womb!</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>But why is this granted to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>For indeed, as soon as the voice of your greeting sounded in my ears, the babe leaped in my womb for joy.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Blessed is she who believed, for there will be a fulfillment of those things which were told her from the Lord.”</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And Mary said: “My soul magnifies the Lord,</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>and my spirit has rejoiced in God my Savior.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>For He has regarded the lowly state of His maidservant; for behold, henceforth all generations will call me blessed.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>For He who is mighty has done great things for me, and holy is His name.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>And Mary remained with her about three months, and returned to her house.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 2:14-3:3  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Now thanks be to God who always leads us in triumph in Christ, and through us diffuses the fragrance of His knowledge in every place.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For we are to God the fragrance of Christ among those who are being saved and among those who are perishing.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>To the one we are the aroma of death leading to death, and to the other the aroma of life leading to life. And who is sufficient for these things?</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For we are not, as so many, peddling the word of God; but as of sincerity, but as from God, we speak in the sight of God in Christ.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Do we begin again to commend ourselves? Or do we need, as some others, epistles of commendation to you or letters of commendation from you?</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>You are our epistle written in our hearts, known and read by all men;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>clearly you are an epistle of Christ, ministered by us, written not with ink but by the Spirit of the living God, not on tablets of stone but on tablets of flesh, that is, of the heart.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 23:23-28  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you pay tithe of mint and anise and cummin, and have neglected the weightier matters of the law: justice and mercy and faith. These you ought to have done, without leaving the others undone.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Blind guides, who strain out a gnat and swallow a camel!</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you cleanse the outside of the cup and dish, but inside they are full of extortion and self-indulgence. </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Blind Pharisee, first cleanse the inside of the cup and dish, that the outside of them may be clean also.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs which indeed appear beautiful outwardly, but inside are full of dead men’s bones and all uncleanness.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Even so you also outwardly appear righteous to men, but inside you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 2:5-11  (Epistle Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Let this mind be in you which was also in Christ Jesus,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>who, being in the form of God, did not consider it robbery to be equal with God,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>but made Himself of no reputation, taking the form of a bondservant, and coming in the likeness of men.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And being found in appearance as a man, He humbled Himself and became obedient to the point of death, even the death of the cross.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Therefore God also has highly exalted Him and given Him the name which is above every name,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those in heaven, and of those on earth, and of those under the earth,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>and that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:38-42 11:27-28  (Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>38</dt><dd>Now it happened as they went that He entered a certain village; and a certain woman named Martha welcomed Him into her house.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And she had a sister called Mary, who also sat at Jesus’ feet and heard His word.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But Martha was distracted with much serving, and she approached Him and said, “Lord, do You not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Therefore tell her to help me.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to her, “Martha, Martha, you are worried and troubled about many things.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>But one thing is needed, and Mary has chosen that good part, which will not be taken away from her.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And it happened, as He spoke these things, that a certain woman from the crowd raised her voice and said to Him, “Blessed is the womb that bore You, and the breasts which nursed You!”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But He said, “More than that, blessed are those who hear the word of God and keep it!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Colossians 1:12-18  (Epistle Image)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>giving thanks to the Father who has qualified us to be partakers of the inheritance of the saints in the light.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>He has delivered us from the power of darkness and conveyed us into the kingdom of the Son of His love,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>in whom we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of sins.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For by Him all things were created that are in heaven and that are on earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or dominions or principalities or powers. All things were created through Him and for Him.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And He is before all things, and in Him all things consist.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And He is the head of the body, the church, who is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead, that in all things He may have the preeminence.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:51-56 10:22-24  (Gospel Image)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>51</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, when the time had come for Him to be received up, that He steadfastly set His face to go to Jerusalem,</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>and sent messengers before His face. And as they went, they entered a village of the Samaritans, to prepare for Him.</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>But they did not receive Him, because His face was set for the journey to Jerusalem.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>And when His disciples James and John saw this, they said, “Lord, do You want us to command fire to come down from heaven and consume them, just as Elijah did?” </dd><dt>55</dt><dd>But He turned and rebuked them, and said, “You do not know what manner of spirit you are of.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>For the Son of Man did not come to destroy men’s lives but to save them.” And they went to another village.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows who the Son is except the Father, and who the Father is except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then He turned to His disciples and said privately, “Blessed are the eyes which see the things you see;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>for I tell you that many prophets and kings have desired to see what you see, and have not seen it, and to hear what you hear, and have not heard it.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 3:4-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>And we have such trust through Christ toward God.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Not that we are sufficient of ourselves to think of anything as being from ourselves, but our sufficiency is from God,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>who also made us sufficient as ministers of the new covenant, not of the letter but of the Spirit; for the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But if the ministry of death, written and engraved on stones, was glorious, so that the children of Israel could not look steadily at the face of Moses because of the glory of his countenance, which glory was passing away,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>how will the ministry of the Spirit not be more glorious?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For if the ministry of condemnation had glory, the ministry of righteousness exceeds much more in glory.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For even what was made glorious had no glory in this respect, because of the glory that excels.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For if what is passing away was glorious, what remains is much more glorious.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 23:29-39  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>29</dt><dd>Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because you build the tombs of the prophets and adorn the monuments of the righteous,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>and say, ‘If we had lived in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets.’</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Therefore you are witnesses against yourselves that you are sons of those who murdered the prophets.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Fill up, then, the measure of your fathers’ guilt.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Serpents, brood of vipers! How can you escape the condemnation of hell?</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Therefore, indeed, I send you prophets, wise men, and scribes: some of them you will kill and crucify, and some of them you will scourge in your synagogues and persecute from city to city,</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>that on you may come all the righteous blood shed on the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah, son of Berechiah, whom you murdered between the temple and the altar.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, all these things will come upon this generation.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the one who kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to her! How often I wanted to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing!</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>See! Your house is left to you desolate;</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>for I say to you, you shall see Me no more till you say, ‘Blessed is He who comes in the name of the LORD!’” </dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 4:1-6  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore, since we have this ministry, as we have received mercy, we do not lose heart.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But we have renounced the hidden things of shame, not walking in craftiness nor handling the word of God deceitfully, but by manifestation of the truth commending ourselves to every man’s conscience in the sight of God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But even if our gospel is veiled, it is veiled to those who are perishing,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>whose minds the god of this age has blinded, who do not believe, lest the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God, should shine on them.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For we do not preach ourselves, but Christ Jesus the Lord, and ourselves your bondservants for Jesus’ sake.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For it is the God who commanded light to shine out of darkness, who has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 24:13-28  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But he who endures to the end shall be saved.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And this gospel of the kingdom will be preached in all the world as a witness to all the nations, and then the end will come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore when you see the ‘abomination of desolation,’ spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place (whoever reads, let him understand),</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Let him who is on the housetop not go down to take anything out of his house.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And let him who is in the field not go back to get his clothes.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing babies in those days!</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And pray that your flight may not be in winter or on the Sabbath.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been since the beginning of the world until this time, no, nor ever shall be.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And unless those days were shortened, no flesh would be saved; but for the elect’s sake those days will be shortened.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then if anyone says to you, ‘Look, here is the Christ!’ or ‘There!’ do not believe it.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For false christs and false prophets will rise and show great signs and wonders to deceive, if possible, even the elect.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>See, I have told you beforehand.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Therefore if they say to you, ‘Look, He is in the desert!’ do not go out; or ‘Look, He is in the inner rooms!’ do not believe it.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For as the lightning comes from the east and flashes to the west, so also will the coming of the Son of Man be.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For wherever the carcass is, there the eagles will be gathered together.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 4:13-18  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>And since we have the same spirit of faith, according to what is written, “I believed and therefore I spoke,” we also believe and therefore speak,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>knowing that He who raised up the Lord Jesus will also raise us up with Jesus, and will present us with you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For all things are for your sakes, that grace, having spread through the many, may cause thanksgiving to abound to the glory of God.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore we do not lose heart. Even though our outward man is perishing, yet the inward man is being renewed day by day.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For our light affliction, which is but for a moment, is working for us a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>while we do not look at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen. For the things which are seen are temporary, but the things which are not seen are eternal.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 24:27-33 42-51  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>For as the lightning comes from the east and flashes to the west, so also will the coming of the Son of Man be.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For wherever the carcass is, there the eagles will be gathered together.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Immediately after the tribulation of those days the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light; the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven, and then all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And He will send His angels with a great sound of a trumpet, and they will gather together His elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Now learn this parable from the fig tree: When its branch has already become tender and puts forth leaves, you know that summer is near.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>So you also, when you see all these things, know that it is near – at the doors!</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Watch therefore, for you do not know what hour your Lord is coming.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>But know this, that if the master of the house had known what hour the thief would come, he would have watched and not allowed his house to be broken into.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Therefore you also be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Who then is a faithful and wise servant, whom his master made ruler over his household, to give them food in due season?</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Blessed is that servant whom his master, when he comes, will find so doing.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you that he will make him ruler over all his goods.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>But if that evil servant says in his heart, ‘My master is delaying his coming,’ </dd><dt>49</dt><dd>and begins to beat his fellow servants, and to eat and drink with the drunkards,</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>the master of that servant will come on a day when he is not looking for him and at an hour that he is not aware of,</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>and will cut him in two and appoint him his portion with the hypocrites. There shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 1:3-9  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I thank my God always concerning you for the grace of God which was given to you by Christ Jesus,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>that you were enriched in everything by Him in all utterance and all knowledge,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>even as the testimony of Christ was confirmed in you,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>so that you come short in no gift, eagerly waiting for the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>who will also confirm you to the end, that you may be blameless in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>God is faithful, by whom you were called into the fellowship of His Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 19:3-12  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>The Pharisees also came to Him, testing Him, and saying to Him, “Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for just any reason?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And He answered and said to them, “Have you not read that He who made them at the beginning ‘made them male and female,’ </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>and said, ‘For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and the two shall become one flesh’? </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So then, they are no longer two but one flesh. Therefore what God has joined together, let not man separate.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>They said to Him, “Why then did Moses command to give a certificate of divorce, and to put her away?”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>He said to them, “Moses, because of the hardness of your hearts, permitted you to divorce your wives, but from the beginning it was not so.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And I say to you, whoever divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and marries another, commits adultery; and whoever marries her who is divorced commits adultery.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>His disciples said to Him, “If such is the case of the man with his wife, it is better not to marry.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But He said to them, “All cannot accept this saying, but only those to whom it has been given:</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For there are eunuchs who were born thus from their mother’s womb, and there are eunuchs who were made eunuchs by men, and there are eunuchs who have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven’s sake. He who is able to accept it, let him accept it.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:15-25  (11th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>So when they had eaten breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me more than these?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Feed My lambs.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He said to him again a second time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Tend My sheep.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He said to him the third time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” Peter was grieved because He said to him the third time, “Do you love Me?” And he said to Him, “Lord, You know all things; You know that I love You.” Jesus said to him, “Feed My sheep.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, when you were younger, you girded yourself and walked where you wished; but when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will gird you and carry you where you do not wish.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>This He spoke, signifying by what death he would glorify God. And when He had spoken this, He said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Peter, turning around, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following, who also had leaned on His breast at the supper, and said, “Lord, who is the one who betrays You?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Peter, seeing him, said to Jesus, “But Lord, what about this man?”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you? You follow Me.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then this saying went out among the brethren that this disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>This is the disciple who testifies of these things, and wrote these things; and we know that his testimony is true.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And there are also many other things that Jesus did, which if they were written one by one, I suppose that even the world itself could not contain the books that would be written. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 9:2-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>If I am not an apostle to others, yet doubtless I am to you.
