For you are the seal of my apostleship in the Lord.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>My defense to those who examine me is this:</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Do we have no right to eat and drink?</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Do we have no right to take along a believing wife, as do also the other apostles, the brothers of the Lord, and Cephas?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Or is it only Barnabas and I who have no right to refrain from working?</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Who ever goes to war at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat of its fruit? Or who tends a flock and does not drink of the milk of the flock?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Do I say these things as a mere man? Or does not the law say the same also?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For it is written in the law of Moses, “You shall not muzzle an ox while it treads out the grain.” Is it oxen God is concerned about?</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Or does He say it altogether for our sakes? For our sakes, no doubt, this is written, that he who plows should plow in hope, and he who threshes in hope should be partaker of his hope.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>If we have sown spiritual things for you, is it a great thing if we reap your material things?</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>If others are partakers of this right over you, are we not even more? Nevertheless we have not used this right, but endure all things lest we hinder the gospel of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 18:23-35  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Therefore the kingdom of heaven is like a certain king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And when he had begun to settle accounts, one was brought to him who owed him ten thousand talents.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But as he was not able to pay, his master commanded that he be sold, with his wife and children and all that he had, and that payment be made.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>The servant therefore fell down before him, saying, ‘Master, have patience with me, and I will pay you all.’</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then the master of that servant was moved with compassion, released him, and forgave him the debt.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But that servant went out and found one of his fellow servants who owed him a hundred denarii; and he laid hands on him and took him by the throat, saying, ‘Pay me what you owe!’</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>So his fellow servant fell down at his feet and begged him, saying, ‘Have patience with me, and I will pay you all.’ </dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And he would not, but went and threw him into prison till he should pay the debt.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>So when his fellow servants saw what had been done, they were very grieved, and came and told their master all that had been done.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Then his master, after he had called him, said to him, ‘You wicked servant! I forgave you all that debt because you begged me.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Should you not also have had compassion on your fellow servant, just as I had pity on you?’</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>And his master was angry, and delivered him to the torturers until he should pay all that was due to him.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>So My heavenly Father also will do to you if each of you, from his heart, does not forgive his brother his trespasses.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 5:10-15  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that each one may receive the things done in the body, according to what he has done, whether good or bad.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Knowing, therefore, the terror of the Lord, we persuade men; but we are well known to God, and I also trust are well known in your consciences.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For we do not commend ourselves again to you, but give you opportunity to boast on our behalf, that you may have an answer for those who boast in appearance and not in heart.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For if we are beside ourselves, it is for God; or if we are of sound mind, it is for you.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For the love of Christ compels us, because we judge thus: that if One died for all, then all died;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and He died for all, that those who live should live no longer for themselves, but for Him who died for them and rose again.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 1:9-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>It came to pass in those days that Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee, and was baptized by John in the Jordan.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And immediately, coming up from the water, He saw the heavens parting and the Spirit descending upon Him like a dove.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then a voice came from heaven, “You are My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Immediately the Spirit drove Him into the wilderness.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And He was there in the wilderness forty days, tempted by Satan, and was with the wild beasts; and the angels ministered to Him.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now after John was put in prison, Jesus came to Galilee, preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and saying, “The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand. Repent, and believe in the gospel.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 5:15-21  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>and He died for all, that those who live should live no longer for themselves, but for Him who died for them and rose again.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore, from now on, we regard no one according to the flesh. Even though we have known Christ according to the flesh, yet now we know Him thus no longer.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; old things have passed away; behold, all things have become new.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Now all things are of God, who has reconciled us to Himself through Jesus Christ, and has given us the ministry of reconciliation,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>that is, that God was in Christ reconciling the world to Himself, not imputing their trespasses to them, and has committed to us the word of reconciliation.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now then, we are ambassadors for Christ, as though God were pleading through us: we implore you on Christ’s behalf, be reconciled to God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For He made Him who knew no sin to be sin for us, that we might become the righteousness of God in Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 1:16-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>And as He walked by the Sea of Galilee, He saw Simon and Andrew his brother casting a net into the sea; for they were fishermen.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “Follow Me, and I will make you become fishers of men.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>They immediately left their nets and followed Him.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>When He had gone a little farther from there, He saw James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, who also were in the boat mending their nets.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And immediately He called them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired servants, and went after Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then they went into Capernaum, and immediately on the Sabbath He entered the synagogue and taught.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And they were astonished at His teaching, for He taught them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 2:5-11  (Epistle Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Let this mind be in you which was also in Christ Jesus,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>who, being in the form of God, did not consider it robbery to be equal with God,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>but made Himself of no reputation, taking the form of a bondservant, and coming in the likeness of men.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And being found in appearance as a man, He humbled Himself and became obedient to the point of death, even the death of the cross.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Therefore God also has highly exalted Him and given Him the name which is above every name,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those in heaven, and of those on earth, and of those under the earth,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>and that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:38-42 11:27-28  (Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>38</dt><dd>Now it happened as they went that He entered a certain village; and a certain woman named Martha welcomed Him into her house.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And she had a sister called Mary, who also sat at Jesus’ feet and heard His word.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But Martha was distracted with much serving, and she approached Him and said, “Lord, do You not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Therefore tell her to help me.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to her, “Martha, Martha, you are worried and troubled about many things.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>But one thing is needed, and Mary has chosen that good part, which will not be taken away from her.”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And it happened, as He spoke these things, that a certain woman from the crowd raised her voice and said to Him, “Blessed is the womb that bore You, and the breasts which nursed You!”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>But He said, “More than that, blessed are those who hear the word of God and keep it!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 6:11-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>O Corinthians! We have spoken openly to you, our heart is wide open.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>You are not restricted by us, but you are restricted by your own affections.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Now in return for the same (I speak as to children), you also be open.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Do not be unequally yoked together with unbelievers. For what fellowship has righteousness with lawlessness? And what communion has light with darkness?</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And what accord has Christ with Belial? Or what part has a believer with an unbeliever?</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And what agreement has the temple of God with idols? For you are the temple of the living God. As God has said: “I will dwell in them and walk among them. I will be their God, and they shall be My people.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 1:23-28  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Now there was a man in their synagogue with an unclean spirit. And he cried out,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>saying, “Let us alone! What have we to do with You, Jesus of Nazareth? Did You come to destroy us? I know who You are – the Holy One of God!”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But Jesus rebuked him, saying, “Be quiet, and come out of him!”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And when the unclean spirit had convulsed him and cried out with a loud voice, he came out of him.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then they were all amazed, so that they questioned among themselves, saying, “What is this? What new doctrine is this? For with authority He commands even the unclean spirits, and they obey Him.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And immediately His fame spread throughout all the region around Galilee.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 7:1-10  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore, having these promises, beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Open your hearts to us. We have wronged no one, we have corrupted no one, we have cheated no one.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>I do not say this to condemn; for I have said before that you are in our hearts, to die together and to live together.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Great is my boldness of speech toward you, great is my boasting on your behalf. I am filled with comfort. I am exceedingly joyful in all our tribulation.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For indeed, when we came to Macedonia, our bodies had no rest, but we were troubled on every side. Outside were conflicts, inside were fears.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Nevertheless God, who comforts the downcast, comforted us by the coming of Titus,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>and not only by his coming, but also by the consolation with which he was comforted in you, when he told us of your earnest desire, your mourning, your zeal for me, so that I rejoiced even more.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For even if I made you sorry with my letter, I do not regret it; though I did regret it. For I perceive that the same epistle made you sorry, though only for a while.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Now I rejoice, not that you were made sorry, but that your sorrow led to repentance. For you were made sorry in a godly manner, that you might suffer loss from us in nothing.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For godly sorrow produces repentance leading to salvation, not to be regretted; but the sorrow of the world produces death.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 1:29-35  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>29</dt><dd>Now as soon as they had come out of the synagogue, they entered the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But Simon’s wife’s mother lay sick with a fever, and they told Him about her at once.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>So He came and took her by the hand and lifted her up, and immediately the fever left her. And she served them.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>At evening, when the sun had set, they brought to Him all who were sick and those who were demon-possessed.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And the whole city was gathered together at the door.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Then He healed many who were sick with various diseases, and cast out many demons; and He did not allow the demons to speak, because they knew Him.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Now in the morning, having risen a long while before daylight, He went out and departed to a solitary place; and there He prayed.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 7:10-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>For godly sorrow produces repentance leading to salvation, not to be regretted; but the sorrow of the world produces death.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For observe this very thing, that you sorrowed in a godly manner: What diligence it produced in you, what clearing of yourselves, what indignation, what fear, what vehement desire, what zeal, what vindication! In all things you proved yourselves to be clear in this matter.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore, although I wrote to you, I did not do it for the sake of him who had done the wrong, nor for the sake of him who suffered wrong, but that our care for you in the sight of God might appear to you.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore we have been comforted in your comfort. And we rejoiced exceedingly more for the joy of Titus, because his spirit has been refreshed by you all.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if in anything I have boasted to him about you, I am not ashamed. But as we spoke all things to you in truth, even so our boasting to Titus was found true.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And his affections are greater for you as he remembers the obedience of you all, how with fear and trembling you received him.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore I rejoice that I have confidence in you in everything.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 2:18-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>The disciples of John and of the Pharisees were fasting. Then they came and said to Him, “Why do the disciples of John and of the Pharisees fast, but Your disciples do not fast?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And Jesus said to them, “Can the friends of the bridegroom fast while the bridegroom is with them? As long as they have the bridegroom with them they cannot fast.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast in those days.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>No one sews a piece of unshrunk cloth on an old garment; or else the new piece pulls away from the old, and the tear is made worse.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And no one puts new wine into old wineskins; or else the new wine bursts the wineskins, the wine is spilled, and the wineskins are ruined. But new wine must be put into new wineskins.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 1:26-29  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For you see your calling, brethren, that not many wise according to the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are called.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But God has chosen the foolish things of the world to put to shame the wise, and God has chosen the weak things of the world to put to shame the things which are mighty;</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>and the base things of the world and the things which are despised God has chosen, and the things which are not, to bring to nothing the things that are,</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>that no flesh should glory in His presence.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 20:29-34  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>29</dt><dd>Now as they went out of Jericho, a great multitude followed Him.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And behold, two blind men sitting by the road, when they heard that Jesus was passing by, cried out, saying, “Have mercy on us, O Lord, Son of David!”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then the multitude warned them that they should be quiet; but they cried out all the more, saying, “Have mercy on us, O Lord, Son of David!”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>So Jesus stood still and called them, and said, “What do you want Me to do for you?”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>They said to Him, “Lord, that our eyes may be opened.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>So Jesus had compassion and touched their eyes. And immediately their eyes received sight, and they followed Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 28:16-20  (1st  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Then the eleven disciples went away into Galilee, to the mountain which Jesus had appointed for them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>When they saw Him, they worshiped Him; but some doubted.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And Jesus came and spoke to them, saying, “All authority has been given to Me in heaven and on earth.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Go therefore and make disciples of all the nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>teaching them to observe all things that I have commanded you; and lo, I am with you always, even to the end of the age. Amen.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 15:1-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Moreover, brethren, I declare to you the gospel which I preached to you, which also you received and in which you stand,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>by which also you are saved, if you hold fast that word which I preached to you – unless you believed in vain.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For I delivered to you first of all that which I also received: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>and that He was buried, and that He rose again the third day according to the Scriptures,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>and that He was seen by Cephas, then by the twelve.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>After that He was seen by over five hundred brethren at once, of whom the greater part remain to the present, but some have fallen asleep.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>After that He was seen by James, then by all the apostles.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then last of all He was seen by me also, as by one born out of due time.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For I am the least of the apostles, who am not worthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But by the grace of God I am what I am, and His grace toward me was not in vain; but I labored more abundantly than they all, yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore, whether it was I or they, so we preach and so you believed.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 19:16-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Now behold, one came and said to Him, “Good Teacher, what good thing shall I do that I may have eternal life?”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So He said to him, “Why do you call Me good? No one is good but One, that is, God. But if you want to enter into life, keep the commandments.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>He said to Him, “Which ones?” Jesus said, “’You shall not murder,’ ‘You shall not commit adultery,’ ‘You shall not steal,’ ‘You shall not bear false witness,’</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>’Honor your father and your mother,’ and, ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’ “ </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>The young man said to Him, “All these things I have kept from my youth. What do I still lack?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If you want to be perfect, go, sell what you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow Me.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But when the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful, for he had great possessions.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to His disciples, “Assuredly, I say to you that it is hard for a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And again I say to you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>When His disciples heard it, they were greatly astonished, saying, “Who then can be saved?”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But Jesus looked at them and said to them, “With men this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 8:7-15  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But as you abound in everything – in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in all diligence, and in your love for us – see that you abound in this grace also.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>I speak not by commandment, but I am testing the sincerity of your love by the diligence of others.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though He was rich, yet for your sakes He became poor, that you through His poverty might become rich.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And in this I give advice: It is to your advantage not only to be doing what you began and were desiring to do a year ago;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>but now you also must complete the doing of it; that as there was a readiness to desire it, so there also may be a completion out of what you have.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For if there is first a willing mind, it is accepted according to what one has, and not according to what he does not have.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For I do not mean that others should be eased and you burdened;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>but by an equality, that now at this time your abundance may supply their lack, that their abundance also may supply your lack – that there may be equality.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As it is written, “He who gathered much had nothing left over, and he who gathered little had no lack.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 3:6-12  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees went out and immediately plotted with the Herodians against Him, how they might destroy Him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But Jesus withdrew with His disciples to the sea. And a great multitude from Galilee followed Him, and from Judea</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>and Jerusalem and Idumea and beyond the Jordan; and those from Tyre and Sidon, a great multitude, when they heard how many things He was doing, came to Him.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So He told His disciples that a small boat should be kept ready for Him because of the multitude, lest they should crush Him.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For He healed many, so that as many as had afflictions pressed about Him to touch Him.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And the unclean spirits, whenever they saw Him, fell down before Him and cried out, saying, “You are the Son of God.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But He sternly warned them that they should not make Him known.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 8 - Isaiah 40 41 45 48 54  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord: “Comfort, comfort My people,” says God. “Speak to the heart of Jerusalem, you Priests, comfort her, for her humiliation is increased, her iniquity is pardoned; for she has received from the Lord’s hand double for her sins. The voice of one crying in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the Lord; make straight the paths of our God.’</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“Go up to a high mountain, you who are proclaiming glad tidings to Zion, lift up your voice with strength, O herald of good tidings to Jerusalem. Lift it up, fear not! I the Lord God, I have heard the poor of Israel and will not forsake them. I will open rivers on the mountains, and fountains in the midst of the valleys; I will make the deserts pools of water, and the thirsty land springs of water. Let the heavens rejoice from above, and let the clouds rain down righteousness; let the earth bring forth, and let it sprout forth mercy and cause righteousness to shine forth also.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Declare this with a shout of joy, and let this be known, proclaim it to the end of the earth. Say, ‘The Lord hath redeemed His servant Jacob!’ And if they thirst, he shall lead them through the desert, He shall bring forth water for them out of the rock. Rejoice, O barren one who did not bear; break forth into singing and cry loud, you who have not been in travail! For more are the children of the desolate one than of her who has a husband.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 9 - Malachi 3 4  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Thus saith the Lord Almighty: “Behold, I send My messenger before Thy face, who shall prepare Thy way before Thee, and the Lord whom ye seek, shall come into His temple. But who can endure the day of His coming? For He is coming like the fire of a furnace and like the fuller’s herb; and He shall cleanse, refining and purifying, as it were, silver and gold. And He comes to you with judgment, and will be a swift witness against the evil ones and against adulterers, and against those who swear falsely by My name, against those who withhold the hireling’s wages, against those who oppress widows and beat orphans, against those who avoid judgment in favor of strangers, and against those who do not fear him,” saith the Lord Almighty.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“For I am the Lord your God, and I change not; and you, the sons of Jacob, have turned aside from the law and have not kept it. Return to Me, therefore, and I will return to you,” saith the Lord Almighty. “And all nations shall call you blessed, and they shall understand that I am the Lord, who distinguishes between the righteous and between the transgressors on that day, in which I shall act to spare those who love Me.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Know, therefore, and remember the Law of Moses, My servant, as I commanded you at Horeb, the statutes and ordinances for all Israel. And behold, I will send to you Elijah the Tishbite before the great and glorious day of the Lord comes, who shall turn the heart of a father to his son, and the heart of a man to his neighbor, lest I come quickly and smite the earth,” saith the Lord Almighty, God, the Holy One of Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 3 - Wisdom of Solomon 4 5  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest. The righteous man who has died will judge the ungodly who are living. For they will see the end of the righteous, and will not understand what was said about him; for the Lord will cast down the ungodly speechless to the ground and shake them from the foundations; they shall become desolate to the end; they will be in sorrows, and their memory will perish. For they will come with fear at the thought of their sins, and their iniquities shall stand against them to convict them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then the righteous man will stand with great boldness before those who have afflicted him, and those who have made of no account his labors. Having seen it, they shall be troubled with much fear and they will be amazed at his most-glorious salvation. They will say within themselves in repentance, in anguish of spirit they will groan and say: “This was he whom we had sometimes in derision and a proverb of reproach – we fools! We accounted his life as madness, and his end to be without honor. How is he numbered among the sons of God? And why is his lot among the Saints?</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Therefore, we have erred from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness did not illumine us, nor did the sun shine on us. We took our fill of the paths of lawlessness and destruction, and we walked impassable pathways, but the way of the Lord we have not known.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 14:1-13  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>At that time Herod the tetrarch heard the report about Jesus</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and said to his servants, “This is John the Baptist; he is risen from the dead, and therefore these powers are at work in him.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For Herod had laid hold of John and bound him, and put him in prison for the sake of Herodias, his brother Philip’s wife.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Because John had said to him, “It is not lawful for you to have her.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And although he wanted to put him to death, he feared the multitude, because they counted him as a prophet.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But when Herod’s birthday was celebrated, the daughter of Herodias danced before them and pleased Herod.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore he promised with an oath to give her whatever she might ask.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So she, having been prompted by her mother, said, “Give me John the Baptist’s head here on a platter.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And the king was sorry; nevertheless, because of the oaths and because of those who sat with him, he commanded it to be given to her.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>So he sent and had John beheaded in prison.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And his head was brought on a platter and given to the girl, and she brought it to her mother.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then his disciples came and took away the body and buried it, and went and told Jesus.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>When Jesus heard it, He departed from there by boat to a deserted place by Himself. But when the multitudes heard it, they followed Him on foot from the cities.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 13:25-33  (Epistle Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>25</dt><dd>And as John was finishing his course, he said, ‘Who do you think I am? I am not He. But behold, there comes One after me, the sandals of whose feet I am not worthy to loose.’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Men and brethren, sons of the family of Abraham, and those among you who fear God, to you the word of this salvation has been sent.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For those who dwell in Jerusalem, and their rulers, because they did not know Him, nor even the voices of the Prophets which are read every Sabbath, have fulfilled them in condemning Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And though they found no cause for death in Him, they asked Pilate that He should be put to death.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Now when they had fulfilled all that was written concerning Him, they took Him down from the tree and laid Him in a tomb.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>But God raised Him from the dead.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>He was seen for many days by those who came up with Him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are His witnesses to the people.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And we declare to you glad tidings – that promise which was made to the fathers.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>God has fulfilled this for us their children, in that He has raised up Jesus. As it is also written in the second Psalm: ‘You are My Son, today I have begotten You.’ </dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 6:14-30  (Gospel Forerunner)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Now King Herod heard of Him, for His name had become well known. And he said, “John the Baptist is risen from the dead, and therefore these powers are at work in him.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Others said, “It is Elijah.” And others said, “It is the Prophet, or like one of the prophets.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But when Herod heard, he said, “This is John, whom I beheaded; he has been raised from the dead!”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For Herod himself had sent and laid hold of John, and bound him in prison for the sake of Herodias, his brother Philip’s wife; for he had married her.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Because John had said to Herod, “It is not lawful for you to have your brother’s wife.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Therefore Herodias held it against him and wanted to kill him, but she could not;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>for Herod feared John, knowing that he was a just and holy man, and he protected him. And when he heard him, he did many things, and heard him gladly.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then an opportune day came when Herod on his birthday gave a feast for his nobles, the high officers, and the chief men of Galilee.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And when Herodias’ daughter herself came in and danced, and pleased Herod and those who sat with him, the king said to the girl, “Ask me whatever you want, and I will give it to you.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>He also swore to her, “Whatever you ask me, I will give you, up to half my kingdom.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>So she went out and said to her mother, “What shall I ask?” And she said, “The head of John the Baptist!”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Immediately she came in with haste to the king and asked, saying, “I want you to give me at once the head of John the Baptist on a platter.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And the king was exceedingly sorry; yet, because of the oaths and because of those who sat with him, he did not want to refuse her.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Immediately the king sent an executioner and commanded his head to be brought. And he went and beheaded him in prison,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>brought his head on a platter, and gave it to the girl; and the girl gave it to her mother.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>When his disciples heard of it, they came and took away his corpse and laid it in a tomb.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then the apostles gathered to Jesus and told Him all things, both what they had done and what they had taught.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 8:16-9:5  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>But thanks be to God who puts the same earnest care for you into the heart of Titus.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For he not only accepted the exhortation, but being more diligent, he went to you of his own accord.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And we have sent with him the brother whose praise is in the gospel throughout all the churches,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and not only that, but who was also chosen by the churches to travel with us with this gift, which is administered by us to the glory of the Lord Himself and to show your ready mind,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>avoiding this: that anyone should blame us in this lavish gift which is administered by us – </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>providing honorable things, not only in the sight of the Lord, but also in the sight of men.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And we have sent with them our brother whom we have often proved diligent in many things, but now much more diligent, because of the great confidence which we have in you.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>If anyone inquires about Titus, he is my partner and fellow worker concerning you. Or if our brethren are inquired about, they are messengers of the churches, the glory of Christ.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore show to them, and before the churches, the proof of your love and of our boasting on your behalf.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now concerning the ministering to the saints, it is superfluous for me to write to you;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>for I know your willingness, about which I boast of you to the Macedonians, that Achaia was ready a year ago; and your zeal has stirred up the majority.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Yet I have sent the brethren, lest our boasting of you should be in vain in this respect, that, as I said, you may be ready;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>lest if some Macedonians come with me and find you unprepared, we (not to mention you!) should be ashamed of this confident boasting.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Therefore I thought it necessary to exhort the brethren to go to you ahead of time, and prepare your generous gift beforehand, which you had previously promised, that it may be ready as a matter of generosity and not as a grudging obligation.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 3:13-19  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>And He went up on the mountain and called to Him those He Himself wanted. And they came to Him.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then He appointed twelve, that they might be with Him and that He might send them out to preach,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and to have power to heal sicknesses and to cast out demons:</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Simon, to whom He gave the name Peter;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>James the son of Zebedee and John the brother of James, to whom He gave the name Boanerges, that is, “Sons of Thunder”;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Cananite;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed Him. And they went into a house.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 9:12-10:7  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>For the administration of this service not only supplies the needs of the saints, but also is abounding through many thanksgivings to God,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>while, through the proof of this ministry, they glorify God for the obedience of your confession to the gospel of Christ, and for your liberal sharing with them and all men,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>and by their prayer for you, who long for you because of the exceeding grace of God in you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Thanks be to God for His indescribable gift!</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now I, Paul, myself am pleading with you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ – who in presence am lowly among you, but being absent am bold toward you.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But I beg you that when I am present I may not be bold with that confidence by which I intend to be bold against some, who think of us as if we walked according to the flesh.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war according to the flesh.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal but mighty in God for pulling down strongholds,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>casting down arguments and every high thing that exalts itself against the knowledge of God, bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of Christ,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>and being ready to punish all disobedience when your obedience is fulfilled.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Do you look at things according to the outward appearance? If anyone is convinced in himself that he is Christ’s, let him again consider this in himself, that just as he is Christ’s, even so we are Christ’s.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 3:20-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>Then the multitude came together again, so that they could not so much as eat bread.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But when His own people heard about this, they went out to lay hold of Him, for they said, “He is out of His mind.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And the scribes who came down from Jerusalem said, “He has Beelzebub,” and, “By the ruler of the demons He casts out demons.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So He called them to Himself and said to them in parables: “How can Satan cast out Satan?</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And if a house is divided against itself, that house cannot stand.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And if Satan has risen up against himself, and is divided, he cannot stand, but has an end.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>No one can enter a strong man’s house and plunder his goods, unless he first binds the strong man. And then he will plunder his house.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 10:7-18  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>Do you look at things according to the outward appearance? If anyone is convinced in himself that he is Christ’s, let him again consider this in himself, that just as he is Christ’s, even so we are Christ’s.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For even if I should boast somewhat more about our authority, which the Lord gave us for edification and not for your destruction, I shall not be ashamed – </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>lest I seem to terrify you by letters.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For his letters, they say, “are weighty and powerful, but his bodily presence is weak, and his speech contemptible.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Let such a person consider this, that what we are in word by letters when we are absent, such we will also be in deed when we are present.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For we dare not class ourselves or compare ourselves with those who commend themselves. But they, measuring themselves by themselves, and comparing themselves among themselves, are not wise.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>We, however, will not boast beyond measure, but within the limits of the sphere which God appointed us – a sphere which especially includes you.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For we are not overextending ourselves (as though our authority did not extend to you), for it was to you that we came with the gospel of Christ;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>not boasting of things beyond measure, that is, in other men’s labors, but having hope, that as your faith is increased, we shall be greatly enlarged by you in our sphere,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to preach the gospel in the regions beyond you, and not to boast in another man’s sphere of accomplishment.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But “he who glories, let him glory in the LORD.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For not he who commends himself is approved, but whom the Lord commends.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 3:28-35  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, all sins will be forgiven the sons of men, and whatever blasphemies they may utter;</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>but he who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit never has forgiveness, but is subject to eternal condemnation” – </dd><dt>30</dt><dd>because they said, “He has an unclean spirit.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then His brothers and His mother came, and standing outside they sent to Him, calling Him.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And a multitude was sitting around Him; and they said to Him, “Look, Your mother and Your brothers are outside seeking You.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But He answered them, saying, “Who is My mother, or My brothers?”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>And He looked around in a circle at those who sat about Him, and said, “Here are My mother and My brothers!</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>For whoever does the will of God is My brother and My sister and mother.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 61:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>“The Spirit of the Lord God is upon Me, because the Lord has anointed Me to preach good tidings to the poor; He has sent Me to heal the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to those who are bound;</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>to proclaim the acceptable year of the Lord, and the day of vengeance of our God; to comfort all who mourn, </dd><dt>3</dt><dd>to console those who mourn in Zion, to give them beauty for ashes, the oil of joy for mourning, the garment of praise for the spirit of heaviness; that they may be called trees of righteousness, the planting of the Lord, that He may be glorified.”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And they shall rebuild the old ruins, they shall raise up the former desolations, and they shall repair the ruined cities, the desolations of many generations.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Strangers shall stand and feed your flocks, and the sons of the foreigner shall be your plowmen and your vinedressers. </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But you shall be named the priests of the Lord, they shall call you the servants of our God. You shall eat the riches of the Gentiles, and in their glory you shall boast.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Instead of your shame you shall have double honor, and instead of confusion they shall rejoice in their portion. Therefore in their land they shall possess double; everlasting joy shall be theirs.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“For I, the Lord, love justice; I hate robbery for burnt offering; I will direct their work in truth, and will make with them an everlasting covenant.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Their descendants shall be known among the Gentiles, and their offspring among the people. All who see them shall acknowledge them, that they are the posterity whom the Lord has blessed.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 24 - Leviticus 26  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The Lord spoke to the sons of Israel, saying: “If you will walk in My statutes, and keep My commandments, and do them, then will I give you the rain in its season, and the land shall yield its produce, and the trees of the field shall yield their fruit. And the time of your threshing shall reach unto the gathering of the vine, and the gathering of the vine shall reach unto the sowing; you shall eat your bread to the full, and you shall dwell securely in your land. And I will give peace in your land, and you shall sleep, and none shall make you afraid; and I will destroy the cruel beasts out of your land, and war shall not go through your land. And you shall pursue your enemies, and they shall fall before you with slaughter. And five of you shall pursue a hundred, and a hundred of you shall pursue ten thousand; and your enemies shall fall before you by the sword. And I will look upon you and bless you; I will increase you and multiply you, and establish My covenant with you. You shall eat the old stores, and the oldest of the old; and you shall carry off the old to make way for the new. And I will establish My covenant with you, and My soul shall not be disturbed with you. And I will walk among you and be your God, and you shall be My people.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“But if you will not hearken unto Me, nor do these My commandments, nor submit yourselves to them, and your soul should abhor My judgments, so that you should not keep all My commandments, so as to break My covenant, then will I do thus to you: I will bring want upon you; you shall sow your seed vainly, and your enemies shall eat up the fruit of your labors. And I will set My face against you, and you shall fall before your enemies and be made subject to them that hate you; you shall flee when no one pursues you. And I will break down the haughtiness of your pride; I will make your heaven like iron and your earth like brass. And your strength shall be in vain, for your land shall not yield its seed, nor shall the tree of your field yield its fruit. And I will send upon you the wild beasts of the land, and they shall devour you and lay waste to your cattle; and I will make you few in number, and the sword falling upon you shall destroy you. And your land shall be desolate and your gates deserted, for you walked perversely before Me; and I will walk contrary to you in fury,“ saith the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 2:1-7  (Epistle New Year)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore I exhort first of all that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and giving of thanks be made for all men,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>for kings and all who are in authority, that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in all godliness and reverence.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Savior,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>who desires all men to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For there is one God and one Mediator between God and men, the Man Christ Jesus,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>who gave Himself a ransom for all, to be testified in due time,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>for which I was appointed a preacher and an apostle – I am speaking the truth in Christ and not lying – a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and truth.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 4:16-22  (Gospel New Year)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>So He came to Nazareth, where He had been brought up. And as His custom was, He went into the synagogue on the Sabbath day, and stood up to read.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And He was handed the book of the prophet Isaiah. And when He had opened the book, He found the place where it was written:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“The Spirit of the LORD is upon Me, because He has anointed Me to preach the gospel to the poor; He has sent Me to heal the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives and recovery of sight to the blind, to set at liberty those who are oppressed;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>to proclaim the acceptable year of the LORD.” </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He closed the book, and gave it back to the attendant and sat down. And the eyes of all who were in the synagogue were fixed on Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And He began to say to them, “Today this Scripture is fulfilled in your hearing.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So all bore witness to Him, and marveled at the gracious words which proceeded out of His mouth. And they said, “Is this not Joseph’s son?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Colossians 3:12-16  (Epistle St Simeon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, put on tender mercies, kindness, humility, meekness, longsuffering;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>bearing with one another, and forgiving one another, if anyone has a complaint against another; even as Christ forgave you, so you also must do.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But above all these things put on love, which is the bond of perfection.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And let the peace of God rule in your hearts, to which also you were called in one body; and be thankful.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Let the word of Christ dwell in you richly in all wisdom, teaching and admonishing one another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing with grace in your hearts to the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Gospel St Simeon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 11:5-21  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>For I consider that I am not at all inferior to the most eminent apostles.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Even though I am untrained in speech, yet I am not in knowledge. But we have been thoroughly manifested among you in all things.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Did I commit sin in humbling myself that you might be exalted, because I preached the gospel of God to you free of charge?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>I robbed other churches, taking wages from them to minister to you.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And when I was present with you, and in need, I was a burden to no one, for what I lacked the brethren who came from Macedonia supplied. And in everything I kept myself from being burdensome to you, and so I will keep myself.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>As the truth of Christ is in me, no one shall stop me from this boasting in the regions of Achaia.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Why? Because I do not love you? God knows!</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But what I do, I will also continue to do, that I may cut off the opportunity from those who desire an opportunity to be regarded just as we are in the things of which they boast.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For such are false apostles, deceitful workers, transforming themselves into apostles of Christ.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And no wonder! For Satan himself transforms himself into an angel of light.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore it is no great thing if his ministers also transform themselves into ministers of righteousness, whose end will be according to their works.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>I say again, let no one think me a fool. If otherwise, at least receive me as a fool, that I also may boast a little.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>What I speak, I speak not according to the Lord, but as it were, foolishly, in this confidence of boasting.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Seeing that many boast according to the flesh, I also will boast.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For you put up with fools gladly, since you yourselves are wise!</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For you put up with it if one brings you into bondage, if one devours you, if one takes from you, if one exalts himself, if one strikes you on the face.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>To our shame I say that we were too weak for that! But in whatever anyone is bold – I speak foolishly – I am bold also.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 4:1-9  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And again He began to teach by the sea. And a great multitude was gathered to Him, so that He got into a boat and sat in it on the sea; and the whole multitude was on the land facing the sea.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He taught them many things by parables, and said to them in His teaching:</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>“Listen! Behold, a sower went out to sow.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And it happened, as he sowed, that some seed fell by the wayside; and the birds of the air came and devoured it.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Some fell on stony ground, where it did not have much earth; and immediately it sprang up because it had no depth of earth.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But when the sun was up it was scorched, and because it had no root it withered away.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And some seed fell among thorns; and the thorns grew up and choked it, and it yielded no crop.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But other seed fell on good ground and yielded a crop that sprang up, increased and produced: some thirtyfold, some sixty, and some a hundred.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And He said to them, “He who has ears to hear, let him hear!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 2:6-9  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>However, we speak wisdom among those who are mature, yet not the wisdom of this age, nor of the rulers of this age, who are coming to nothing.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But we speak the wisdom of God in a mystery, the hidden wisdom which God ordained before the ages for our glory,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>which none of the rulers of this age knew; for had they known, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But, as it is written: “What no eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor the heart of man conceived, what God has prepared for those who love Him,”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 22:15-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees went and plotted how they might entangle Him in His talk.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And they sent to Him their disciples with the Herodians, saying, “Teacher, we know that You are true, and teach the way of God in truth; nor do You care about anyone, for You do not regard the person of men.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Tell us, therefore, what do You think? Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But Jesus perceived their wickedness, and said, “Why do you test Me, you hypocrites?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Show Me the tax money.” So they brought Him a denarius.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Whose image and inscription is this?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>They said to Him, “Caesar’s.” And He said to them, “Render therefore to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>When they had heard these words, they marveled, and left Him and went their way.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 16:1-8  (2nd  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when the Sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices, that they might come and anoint Him.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Very early in the morning, on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb when the sun had risen.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And they said among themselves, “Who will roll away the stone from the door of the tomb for us?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But when they looked up, they saw that the stone had been rolled away – for it was very large.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And entering the tomb, they saw a young man clothed in a long white robe sitting on the right side; and they were alarmed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But he said to them, “Do not be alarmed. You seek Jesus of Nazareth, who was crucified. He is risen! He is not here. See the place where they laid Him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But go, tell His disciples – and Peter – that He is going before you into Galilee; there you will see Him, as He said to you.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So they went out quickly and fled from the tomb, for they trembled and were amazed. And they said nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 16:13-24  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Watch, stand fast in the faith, be brave, be strong.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Let all that you do be done with love.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>I urge you, brethren – you know the household of Stephanas, that it is the firstfruits of Achaia, and that they have devoted themselves to the ministry of the saints – </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>that you also submit to such, and to everyone who works and labors with us.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>I am glad about the coming of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus, for what was lacking on your part they supplied.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For they refreshed my spirit and yours. Therefore acknowledge such men.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>The churches of Asia greet you. Aquila and Priscilla greet you heartily in the Lord, with the church that is in their house.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>All the brethren greet you. Greet one another with a holy kiss.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>The salutation with my own hand – Paul’s.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>If anyone does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be accursed. O Lord, come!</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>My love be with you all in Christ Jesus. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:33-42  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>Hear another parable: There was a certain landowner who planted a vineyard and set a hedge around it, dug a winepress in it and built a tower. And he leased it to vinedressers and went into a far country.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Now when vintage-time drew near, he sent his servants to the vinedressers, that they might receive its fruit.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And the vinedressers took his servants, beat one, killed one, and stoned another.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Again he sent other servants, more than the first, and they did likewise to them.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then last of all he sent his son to them, saying, ‘They will respect my son.’</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But when the vinedressers saw the son, they said among themselves, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance.’</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>So they took him and cast him out of the vineyard and killed him.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Therefore, when the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those vinedressers?”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>They said to Him, “He will destroy those wicked men miserably, and lease his vineyard to other vinedressers who will render to him the fruits in their seasons.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Have you never read in the Scriptures: ‘The stone which the builders rejected Has become the chief cornerstone. This was the LORD’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes’? </dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 12:10-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in needs, in persecutions, in distresses, for Christ’s sake. For when I am weak, then I am strong.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I have become a fool in boasting; you have compelled me. For I ought to have been commended by you; for in nothing was I behind the most eminent apostles, though I am nothing.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Truly the signs of an apostle were accomplished among you with all perseverance, in signs and wonders and mighty deeds.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For what is it in which you were inferior to other churches, except that I myself was not burdensome to you? Forgive me this wrong!</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now for the third time I am ready to come to you. And I will not be burdensome to you; for I do not seek yours, but you. For the children ought not to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And I will very gladly spend and be spent for your souls; though the more abundantly I love you, the less I am loved.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But be that as it may, I did not burden you. Nevertheless, being crafty, I caught you by cunning!</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Did I take advantage of you by any of those whom I sent to you?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>I urged Titus, and sent our brother with him. Did Titus take advantage of you? Did we not walk in the same spirit? Did we not walk in the same steps?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Again, do you think that we excuse ourselves to you? We speak before God in Christ. But we do all things, beloved, for your edification.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 4:10-23  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>But when He was alone, those around Him with the twelve asked Him about the parable.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And He said to them, “To you it has been given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God; but to those who are outside, all things come in parables,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>so that ‘Seeing they may see and not perceive, and hearing they may hear and not understand; lest they should turn, and their sins be forgiven them.’” </dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Do you not understand this parable? How then will you understand all the parables?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>The sower sows the word.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And these are the ones by the wayside where the word is sown. When they hear, Satan comes immediately and takes away the word that was sown in their hearts.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>These likewise are the ones sown on stony ground who, when they hear the word, immediately receive it with gladness;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>and they have no root in themselves, and so endure only for a time. Afterward, when tribulation or persecution arises for the word’s sake, immediately they stumble.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Now these are the ones sown among thorns; they are the ones who hear the word,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and the cares of this world, the deceitfulness of riches, and the desires for other things entering in choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But these are the ones sown on good ground, those who hear the word, accept it, and bear fruit: some thirtyfold, some sixty, and some a hundred.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Also He said to them, “Is a lamp brought to be put under a basket or under a bed? Is it not to be set on a lampstand?</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For there is nothing hidden which will not be revealed, nor has anything been kept secret but that it should come to light.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 12:20-13:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>For I fear lest, when I come, I shall not find you such as I wish, and that I shall be found by you such as you do not wish; lest there be contentions, jealousies, outbursts of wrath, selfish ambitions, backbitings, whisperings, conceits, tumults;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>lest, when I come again, my God will humble me among you, and I shall mourn for many who have sinned before and have not repented of the uncleanness, fornication, and lewdness which they have practiced.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>This will be the third time I am coming to you. “By the mouth of two or three witnesses every word shall be established.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>I have told you before, and foretell as if I were present the second time, and now being absent I write to those who have sinned before, and to all the rest, that if I come again I will not spare – </dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 4:24-34  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Take heed what you hear. With the same measure you use, it will be measured to you; and to you who hear, more will be given.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>For whoever has, to him more will be given; but whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And He said, “The kingdom of God is as if a man should scatter seed on the ground,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and should sleep by night and rise by day, and the seed should sprout and grow, he himself does not know how.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the earth yields crops by itself: first the blade, then the head, after that the full grain in the head.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But when the grain ripens, immediately he puts in the sickle, because the harvest has come.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Then He said, “To what shall we liken the kingdom of God? Or with what parable shall we picture it?</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>It is like a mustard seed which, when it is sown on the ground, is smaller than all the seeds on earth;</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>but when it is sown, it grows up and becomes greater than all herbs, and shoots out large branches, so that the birds of the air may nest under its shade.”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>And with many such parables He spoke the word to them as they were able to hear it.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But without a parable He did not speak to them. And when they were alone, He explained all things to His disciples.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 13:3-14  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>since you seek a proof of Christ speaking in me, who is not weak toward you, but mighty in you.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though He was crucified in weakness, yet He lives by the power of God. For we also are weak in Him, but we shall live with Him by the power of God toward you.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Examine yourselves as to whether you are in the faith. Test yourselves. Do you not know yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you? – unless indeed you are disqualified.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But I trust that you will know that we are not disqualified.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Now I pray to God that you do no evil, not that we should appear approved, but that you should do what is honorable, though we may seem disqualified.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For we can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For we are glad when we are weak and you are strong. And this also we pray, that you may be made complete.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore I write these things being absent, lest being present I should use sharpness, according to the authority which the Lord has given me for edification and not for destruction.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Finally, brethren, farewell. Become complete. Be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Greet one another with a holy kiss.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>All the saints greet you.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Spirit be with you all. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 4:35-41  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>On the same day, when evening had come, He said to them, “Let us cross over to the other side.”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Now when they had left the multitude, they took Him along in the boat as He was. And other little boats were also with Him.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And a great windstorm arose, and the waves beat into the boat, so that it was already filling.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But He was in the stern, asleep on a pillow. And they awoke Him and said to Him, “Teacher, do You not care that we are perishing?”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Then He arose and rebuked the wind, and said to the sea, “Peace, be still!” And the wind ceased and there was a great calm.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But He said to them, “Why are you so fearful? How is it that you have no faith?” </dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And they feared exceedingly, and said to one another, “Who can this be, that even the wind and the sea obey Him!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 1:1-10 20-2:5  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Paul, an apostle (not from men nor through man, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father who raised Him from the dead),</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and all the brethren who are with me, to the churches of Galatia:</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Grace to you and peace from God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>who gave Himself for our sins, that He might deliver us from this present evil age, according to the will of our God and Father,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>I marvel that you are turning away so soon from Him who called you in the grace of Christ, to a different gospel,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>which is not another; but there are some who trouble you and want to pervert the gospel of Christ.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But even if we, or an angel from heaven, preach any other gospel to you than what we have preached to you, let him be accursed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>As we have said before, so now I say again, if anyone preaches any other gospel to you than what you have received, let him be accursed.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For do I now persuade men, or God? Or do I seek to please men? For if I still pleased men, I would not be a bondservant of Christ.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>(Now concerning the things which I write to you, indeed, before God, I do not lie.)</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Afterward I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And I was unknown by face to the churches of Judea which were in Christ.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But they were hearing only, “He who formerly persecuted us now preaches the faith which he once tried to destroy.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And they glorified God in me.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then after fourteen years I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, and also took Titus with me.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And I went up by revelation, and communicated to them that gospel which I preach among the Gentiles, but privately to those who were of reputation, lest by any means I might run, or had run, in vain.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Yet not even Titus who was with me, being a Greek, was compelled to be circumcised.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And this occurred because of false brethren secretly brought in (who came in by stealth to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ Jesus, that they might bring us into bondage),</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>to whom we did not yield submission even for an hour, that the truth of the gospel might continue with you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 5:1-20  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then they came to the other side of the sea, to the country of the Gadarenes. </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And when He had come out of the boat, immediately there met Him out of the tombs a man with an unclean spirit,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>who had his dwelling among the tombs; and no one could bind him, not even with chains,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>because he had often been bound with shackles and chains. And the chains had been pulled apart by him, and the shackles broken in pieces; neither could anyone tame him.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And always, night and day, he was in the mountains and in the tombs, crying out and cutting himself with stones.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>When he saw Jesus from afar, he ran and worshiped Him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And he cried out with a loud voice and said, “What have I to do with You, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I implore You by God that You do not torment me.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For He said to him, “Come out of the man, unclean spirit!”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then He asked him, “What is your name?” And he answered, saying, “My name is Legion; for we are many.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Also he begged Him earnestly that He would not send them out of the country.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now a large herd of swine was feeding there near the mountains.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>So all the demons begged Him, saying, “Send us to the swine, that we may enter them.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And at once Jesus gave them permission. Then the unclean spirits went out and entered the swine (there were about two thousand); and the herd ran violently down the steep place into the sea, and drowned in the sea.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So those who fed the swine fled, and they told it in the city and in the country.
