readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:26-8:2  (Epistle St Innocent)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For such a High Priest was fitting for us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and has become higher than the heavens;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>who does not need daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for his own sins and then for the people’s, for this He did once for all when He offered up Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the law appoints as high priests men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints the Son who has been perfected forever.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the main point of the things we are saying: We have such a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>a Minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord erected, and not man.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Gospel St Innocent)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 6:18-24  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>praying always with all prayer and supplication in the Spirit, being watchful to this end with all perseverance and supplication for all the saints – </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and for me, that utterance may be given to me, that I may open my mouth boldly to make known the mystery of the gospel,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>for which I am an ambassador in chains; that in it I may speak boldly, as I ought to speak.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But that you also may know my affairs and how I am doing, Tychicus, a beloved brother and faithful minister in the Lord, will make all things known to you;</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>whom I have sent to you for this very purpose, that you may know our affairs, and that he may comfort your hearts.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Peace to the brethren, and love with faith, from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Grace be with all those who love our Lord Jesus Christ in sincerity. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:31-35  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>And the Lord said, “To what then shall I liken the men of this generation, and what are they like?</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>They are like children sitting in the marketplace and calling to one another, saying: ‘We played the flute for you, and you did not dance; we mourned to you, and you did not weep.’</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>For John the Baptist came neither eating bread nor drinking wine, and you say, ‘He has a demon.’</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>The Son of Man has come eating and drinking, and you say, ‘Look, a glutton and a winebibber, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!’</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>But wisdom is justified by all her children.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 15:39-45  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>39</dt><dd>All flesh is not the same flesh, but there is one kind of flesh of men, another flesh of animals, another of fish, and another of birds.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>There are also celestial bodies and terrestrial bodies; but the glory of the celestial is one, and the glory of the terrestrial is another.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>There is one glory of the sun, another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for one star differs from another star in glory.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>So also is the resurrection of the dead. The body is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness, it is raised in power.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body. There is a natural body, and there is a spiritual body.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>And so it is written, “The first man Adam became a living being.” The last Adam became a life-giving spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 5:27-32  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>After these things He went out and saw a tax collector named Levi, sitting at the tax office. And He said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>So he left all, rose up, and followed Him.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then Levi gave Him a great feast in his own house. And there were a great number of tax collectors and others who sat down with them.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And their scribes and the Pharisees complained against His disciples, saying, “Why do You eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners, to repentance.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 14:14-20  (Vespers 1st  reading Fathers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when Abram heard that his brother was taken captive, he armed his three hundred and eighteen trained servants who were born in his own house, and went in pursuit as far as Dan.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>He divided his forces against them by night, and he and his servants attacked them and pursued them as far as Hobah, which is north of Damascus.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>So he brought back all the goods, and also brought back his brother Lot and his goods, as well as the women and the people.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And the king of Sodom went out to meet him at the Valley of Shaveh (that is, the King’s Valley), after his return from the defeat of Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine; he was the priest of God Most High.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And he blessed him and said: “Blessed be Abram of God Most High, Possessor of heaven and earth;</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And blessed be God Most High, Who has delivered your enemies into your hand.” And he gave him a tithe of all.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Deuteronomy 1:8-11 15-17  (Vespers 2nd  reading Fathers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>See, I have set the land before you; go in and possess the land which the Lord swore to your fathers – to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob – to give to them and their descendants after them.’ </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And I spoke to you at that time, saying: ‘I alone am not able to bear you.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The Lord your God has multiplied you, and here you are today, as the stars of heaven in multitude. </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>May the Lord God of your fathers make you a thousand times more numerous than you are, and bless you as He has promised you! </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So I took the heads of your tribes, wise and knowledgeable men, and made them heads over you, leaders of thousands, leaders of hundreds, leaders of fifties, leaders of tens, and officers for your tribes. </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then I commanded your judges at that time, saying, ‘Hear the cases between your brethren, and judge righteously between a man and his brother or the stranger who is with him. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>You shall not show partiality in judgment; you shall hear the small as well as the great; you shall not be afraid in any man’s presence, for the judgment is God’s. The case that is too hard for you, bring to me, and I will hear it.’ </dd></dl>

readings.title: Deuteronomy 10:14-21  (Vespers 3rd  reading Fathers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>Indeed heaven and the highest heavens belong to the Lord your God, also the earth with all that is in it. </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>The Lord delighted only in your fathers, to love them; and He chose their descendants after them, you above all peoples, as it is this day. </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore circumcise the foreskin of your heart, and be stiff-necked no longer. </dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For the Lord your God is God of gods and Lord of lords, the great God, mighty and awesome, who shows no partiality nor takes a bribe. </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>He administers justice for the fatherless and the widow, and loves the stranger, giving him food and clothing. </dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Therefore love the stranger, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt. </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>You shall fear the Lord your God; you shall serve Him, and to Him you shall hold fast, and take oaths in His name. </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>He is your praise, and He is your God, who has done for you these great and awesome things which your eyes have seen. </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:1-10  (7th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week Mary Magdalene went to the tomb early, while it was still dark, and saw that the stone had been taken away from the tomb.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then she ran and came to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple, whom Jesus loved, and said to them, “They have taken away the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid Him.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Peter therefore went out, and the other disciple, and were going to the tomb.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So they both ran together, and the other disciple outran Peter and came to the tomb first.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And he, stooping down and looking in, saw the linen cloths lying there; yet he did not go in.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then Simon Peter came, following him, and went into the tomb; and he saw the linen cloths lying there,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>and the handkerchief that had been around His head, not lying with the linen cloths, but folded together in a place by itself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then the other disciple, who came to the tomb first, went in also; and he saw and believed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For as yet they did not know the Scripture, that He must rise again from the dead.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the disciples went away again to their own homes.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 13:7-16  (Epistle Fathers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd> Remember those who rule over you, who have spoken the word of God to you, whose faith follow, considering the outcome of their conduct.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Do not be carried about with various and strange doctrines. For it is good that the heart be established by grace, not with foods which have not profited those who have been occupied with them.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>We have an altar from which those who serve the tabernacle have no right to eat.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For the bodies of those animals, whose blood is brought into the sanctuary by the high priest for sin, are burned outside the camp.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore Jesus also, that He might sanctify the people with His own blood, suffered outside the gate.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore let us go forth to Him, outside the camp, bearing His reproach.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For here we have no continuing city, but we seek the one to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore by Him let us continually offer the sacrifice of praise to God, that is, the fruit of our lips, giving thanks to His name.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But do not forget to do good and to share, for with such sacrifices God is well pleased.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 17:1-13  (Gospel Fathers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Jesus spoke these words, lifted up His eyes to heaven, and said: “Father, the hour has come. Glorify Your Son, that Your Son also may glorify You,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>as You have given Him authority over all flesh, that He should give eternal life to as many as You have given Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And this is eternal life, that they may know You, the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom You have sent.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I have glorified You on the earth. I have finished the work which You have given Me to do.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And now, O Father, glorify Me together with Yourself, with the glory which I had with You before the world was.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>I have manifested Your name to the men whom You have given Me out of the world. They were Yours, You gave them to Me, and they have kept Your word.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Now they have known that all things which You have given Me are from You.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For I have given to them the words which You have given Me; and they have received them, and have known surely that I came forth from You; and they have believed that You sent Me.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I pray for them. I do not pray for the world but for those whom You have given Me, for they are Yours.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And all Mine are Yours, and Yours are Mine, and I am glorified in them.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now I am no longer in the world, but these are in the world, and I come to You. Holy Father, keep through Your name those whom You have given Me, that they may be one as We are.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>While I was with them in the world, I kept them in Your name. Those whom You gave Me I have kept; and none of them is lost except the son of perdition, that the Scripture might be fulfilled.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But now I come to You, and these things I speak in the world, that they may have My joy fulfilled in themselves.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 9:6-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>But this I say: “He who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and he who sows bountifully will also reap bountifully.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So let each one give as he purposes in his heart, not grudgingly or of necessity; for God loves a cheerful giver.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And God is able to make all grace abound toward you, that you, always having all sufficiency in all things, may have an abundance for every good work.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>As it is written: “He has dispersed abroad, He has given to the poor; His righteousness endures forever.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Now may He who supplies seed to the sower, and bread for food, supply and multiply the seed you have sown and increase the fruits of your righteousness,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>while you are enriched in everything for all liberality, which causes thanksgiving through us to God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:11-16  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Now it happened, the day after, that He went into a city called Nain; and many of His disciples went with Him, and a large crowd.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And when He came near the gate of the city, behold, a dead man was being carried out, the only son of his mother; and she was a widow. And a large crowd from the city was with her.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>When the Lord saw her, He had compassion on her and said to her, “Do not weep.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Then He came and touched the open coffin, and those who carried him stood still. And He said, “Young man, I say to you, arise.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So he who was dead sat up and began to speak. And He presented him to his mother.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then fear came upon all, and they glorified God, saying, “A great prophet has risen up among us”; and, “God has visited His people.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:1-9  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but climbs up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But he who enters by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>To him the doorkeeper opens, and the sheep hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he brings out his own sheep, he goes before them; and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Yet they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Jesus used this illustration, but they did not understand the things which He spoke to them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them again, “Most assuredly, I say to you, I am the door of the sheep.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>All who ever came before Me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:26-8:2  (Epistle St Tikhon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>26</dt><dd>For such a High Priest was fitting for us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and has become higher than the heavens;</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>who does not need daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for his own sins and then for the people’s, for this He did once for all when He offered up Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>For the law appoints as high priests men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints the Son who has been perfected forever.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now this is the main point of the things we are saying: We have such a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>a Minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord erected, and not man.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Gospel St Tikhon)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 1:1-7  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Paul and Timothy, bondservants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus who are in Philippi, with the bishops and deacons:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>I thank my God upon every remembrance of you,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>always in every prayer of mine making request for you all with joy,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>for your fellowship in the gospel from the first day until now,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>being confident of this very thing, that He who has begun a good work in you will complete it until the day of Jesus Christ;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>just as it is right for me to think this of you all, because I have you in my heart, inasmuch as both in my chains and in the defense and confirmation of the gospel, you all are partakers with me of grace.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:36-50  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>Then one of the Pharisees asked Him to eat with him. And He went to the Pharisee’s house, and sat down to eat.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>And behold, a woman in the city who was a sinner, when she knew that Jesus sat at the table in the Pharisee’s house, brought an alabaster flask of fragrant oil,</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>and stood at His feet behind Him weeping; and she began to wash His feet with her tears, and wiped them with the hair of her head; and she kissed His feet and anointed them with the fragrant oil.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Now when the Pharisee who had invited Him saw this, he spoke to himself, saying, “This Man, if He were a prophet, would know who and what manner of woman this is who is touching Him, for she is a sinner.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to him, “Simon, I have something to say to you.” So he said, “Teacher, say it.”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>“There was a certain creditor who had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And when they had nothing with which to repay, he freely forgave them both. Tell Me, therefore, which of them will love him more?”</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>Simon answered and said, “I suppose the one whom he forgave more.” And He said to him, “You have rightly judged.”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then He turned to the woman and said to Simon, “Do you see this woman? I entered your house; you gave Me no water for My feet, but she has washed My feet with her tears and wiped them with the hair of her head.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>You gave Me no kiss, but this woman has not ceased to kiss My feet since the time I came in.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>You did not anoint My head with oil, but this woman has anointed My feet with fragrant oil.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Therefore I say to you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven, for she loved much. But to whom little is forgiven, the same loves little.”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Then He said to her, “Your sins are forgiven.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>And those who sat at the table with Him began to say to themselves, “Who is this who even forgives sins?”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Then He said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you. Go in peace.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 1:8-14  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>For God is my witness, how greatly I long for you all with the affection of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And this I pray, that your love may abound still more and more in knowledge and all discernment,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>that you may approve the things that are excellent, that you may be sincere and without offense till the day of Christ,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>being filled with the fruits of righteousness which are by Jesus Christ, to the glory and praise of God.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But I want you to know, brethren, that the things which happened to me have actually turned out for the furtherance of the gospel,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>so that it has become evident to the whole palace guard, and to all the rest, that my chains are in Christ;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>and most of the brethren in the Lord, having become confident by my chains, are much more bold to speak the word without fear.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 8:1-3  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, afterward, that He went through every city and village, preaching and bringing the glad tidings of the kingdom of God. And the twelve were with Him,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and certain women who had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities – Mary called Magdalene, out of whom had come seven demons,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and Joanna the wife of Chuza, Herod’s steward, and Susanna, and many others who provided for Him from their substance.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 1:12-20  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>But I want you to know, brethren, that the things which happened to me have actually turned out for the furtherance of the gospel,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>so that it has become evident to the whole palace guard, and to all the rest, that my chains are in Christ;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>and most of the brethren in the Lord, having become confident by my chains, are much more bold to speak the word without fear.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Some indeed preach Christ even from envy and strife, and some also from goodwill:</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>The former preach Christ from selfish ambition, not sincerely, supposing to add affliction to my chains;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>but the latter out of love, knowing that I am appointed for the defense of the gospel.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>What then? Only that in every way, whether in pretense or in truth, Christ is preached; and in this I rejoice, yes, and will rejoice.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>For I know that this will turn out for my deliverance through your prayer and the supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>according to my earnest expectation and hope that in nothing I shall be ashamed, but with all boldness, as always, so now also Christ will be magnified in my body, whether by life or by death.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 8:22-25  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>Now it happened, on a certain day, that He got into a boat with His disciples. And He said to them, “Let us cross over to the other side of the lake.” And they launched out.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But as they sailed He fell asleep. And a windstorm came down on the lake, and they were filling with water, and were in jeopardy.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And they came to Him and awoke Him, saying, “Master, Master, we are perishing!” Then He arose and rebuked the wind and the raging of the water. And they ceased, and there was a calm.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But He said to them, “Where is your faith?” And they were afraid, and marveled, saying to one another, “Who can this be? For He commands even the winds and water, and they obey Him!”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 1:20-27  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>according to my earnest expectation and hope that in nothing I shall be ashamed, but with all boldness, as always, so now also Christ will be magnified in my body, whether by life or by death.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For to me, to live is Christ, and to die is gain.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But if I live on in the flesh, this will mean fruit from my labor; yet what I shall choose I cannot tell.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For I am hard-pressed between the two, having a desire to depart and be with Christ, which is far better.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Nevertheless to remain in the flesh is more needful for you.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And being confident of this, I know that I shall remain and continue with you all for your progress and joy of faith,</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>that your rejoicing for me may be more abundant in Jesus Christ by my coming to you again.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Only let your conduct be worthy of the gospel of Christ, so that whether I come and see you or am absent, I may hear of your affairs, that you stand fast in one spirit, with one mind striving together for the faith of the gospel,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:7-11  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>Now Herod the tetrarch heard of all that was done by Him; and he was perplexed, because it was said by some that John had risen from the dead,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>and by some that Elijah had appeared, and by others that one of the old prophets had risen again.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Herod said, “John I have beheaded, but who is this of whom I hear such things?” So he sought to see Him.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And the apostles, when they had returned, told Him all that they had done. Then He took them and went aside privately into a deserted place belonging to the city called Bethsaida.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But when the multitudes knew it, they followed Him; and He received them and spoke to them about the kingdom of God, and healed those who had need of healing.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 1:27-2:4  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>Only let your conduct be worthy of the gospel of Christ, so that whether I come and see you or am absent, I may hear of your affairs, that you stand fast in one spirit, with one mind striving together for the faith of the gospel,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>and not in any way terrified by your adversaries, which is to them a proof of perdition, but to you of salvation, and that from God.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>For to you it has been granted on behalf of Christ, not only to believe in Him, but also to suffer for His sake,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>having the same conflict which you saw in me and now hear is in me.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore if there is any consolation in Christ, if any comfort of love, if any fellowship of the Spirit, if any affection and mercy,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>fulfill my joy by being like-minded, having the same love, being of one accord, of one mind.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Let nothing be done through selfish ambition or conceit, but in lowliness of mind let each esteem others better than himself.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Let each of you look out not only for his own interests, but also for the interests of others.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:12-18  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>When the day began to wear away, the twelve came and said to Him, “Send the multitude away, that they may go into the surrounding towns and country, and lodge and get provisions; for we are in a deserted place here.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But He said to them, “You give them something to eat.” And they said, “We have no more than five loaves and two fish, unless we go and buy food for all these people.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For there were about five thousand men. Then He said to His disciples, “Make them sit down in groups of fifty.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And they did so, and made them all sit down.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then He took the five loaves and the two fish, and looking up to heaven, He blessed and broke them, and gave them to the disciples to set before the multitude.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So they all ate and were filled, and twelve baskets of the leftover fragments were taken up by them.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And it happened, as He was alone praying, that His disciples joined Him, and He asked them, saying, “Who do the crowds say that I am?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 15:58-16:3  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>58</dt><dd>Therefore, my beloved brethren, be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that your labor is not in vain in the Lord.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now concerning the collection for the saints, as I have given orders to the churches of Galatia, so you must do also:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>On the first day of the week let each one of you lay something aside, storing up as he may prosper, that there be no collections when I come.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And when I come, whomever you approve by your letters I will send to bear your gift to Jerusalem.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:1-10  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it happened on the second Sabbath after the first that He went through the grainfields. And His disciples plucked the heads of grain and ate them, rubbing them in their hands.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And some of the Pharisees said to them, “Why are you doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath?”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But Jesus answering them said, “Have you not even read this, what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with him:</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>how he went into the house of God, took and ate the showbread, and also gave some to those with him, which is not lawful for any but the priests to eat?”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And He said to them, “The Son of Man is also Lord of the Sabbath.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Now it happened on another Sabbath, also, that He entered the synagogue and taught. And a man was there whose right hand was withered.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So the scribes and Pharisees watched Him closely, whether He would heal on the Sabbath, that they might find an accusation against Him.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But He knew their thoughts, and said to the man who had the withered hand, “Arise and stand here.” And he arose and stood.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then Jesus said to them, “I will ask you one thing: Is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil, to save life or to destroy?” </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And when He had looked around at them all, He said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” And he did so, and his hand was restored as whole as the other. </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:11-18  (8th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But Mary stood outside by the tomb weeping, and as she wept she stooped down and looked into the tomb.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And she saw two angels in white sitting, one at the head and the other at the feet, where the body of Jesus had lain.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then they said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping?” She said to them, “Because they have taken away my Lord, and I do not know where they have laid Him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing there, and did not know that it was Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?” She, supposing Him to be the gardener, said to Him, “Sir, if You have carried Him away, tell me where You have laid Him, and I will take Him away.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Mary!” She turned and said to Him, “Rabboni!” (which is to say, Teacher).</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Do not cling to Me, for I have not yet ascended to My Father; but go to My brethren and say to them, ‘I am ascending to My Father and your Father, and to My God and your God.’”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Mary Magdalene came and told the disciples that she had seen the Lord, and that He had spoken these things to her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 11:31-12:9  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is blessed forever, knows that I am not lying.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>In Damascus the governor, under Aretas the king, was guarding the city of the Damascenes with a garrison, desiring to arrest me;</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>but I was let down in a basket through a window in the wall, and escaped from his hands.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>It is doubtless not profitable for me to boast. I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago – whether in the body I do not know, or whether out of the body I do not know, God knows – such a one was caught up to the third heaven.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And I know such a man – whether in the body or out of the body I do not know, God knows – </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>how he was caught up into Paradise and heard inexpressible words, which it is not lawful for a man to utter.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Of such a one I will boast; yet of myself I will not boast, except in my infirmities.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For though I might desire to boast, I will not be a fool; for I will speak the truth. But I refrain, lest anyone should think of me above what he sees me to be or hears from me.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And lest I should be exalted above measure by the abundance of the revelations, a thorn in the flesh was given to me, a messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I be exalted above measure.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Concerning this thing I pleaded with the Lord three times that it might depart from me.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And He said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for My strength is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore most gladly I will rather boast in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 8:5-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>“A sower went out to sow his seed. And as he sowed, some fell by the wayside; and it was trampled down, and the birds of the air devoured it.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Some fell on rock; and as soon as it sprang up, it withered away because it lacked moisture.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And some fell among thorns, and the thorns sprang up with it and choked it.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But others fell on good ground, sprang up, and yielded a crop a hundredfold.” When He had said these things He cried, “He who has ears to hear, let him hear!”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then His disciples asked Him, saying, “What does this parable mean?”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And He said, “To you it has been given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God, but to the rest it is given in parables, that ‘Seeing they may not see, And hearing they may not understand.’ </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Now the parable is this: The seed is the word of God.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Those by the wayside are the ones who hear; then the devil comes and takes away the word out of their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But the ones on the rock are those who, when they hear, receive the word with joy; and these have no root, who believe for a while and in time of temptation fall away.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now the ones that fell among thorns are those who, when they have heard, go out and are choked with cares, riches, and pleasures of life, and bring no fruit to maturity.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But the ones that fell on the good ground are those who, having heard the word with a noble and good heart, keep it and bear fruit with patience.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 2:12-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore, my beloved, as you have always obeyed, not as in my presence only, but now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>for it is God who works in you both to will and to do for His good pleasure.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Do all things without complaining and disputing,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>that you may become blameless and harmless, children of God without fault in the midst of a crooked and perverse generation, among whom you shine as lights in the world,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>holding fast the word of life, so that I may rejoice in the day of Christ that I have not run in vain or labored in vain.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:18-22  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>And it happened, as He was alone praying, that His disciples joined Him, and He asked them, saying, “Who do the crowds say that I am?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So they answered and said, “John the Baptist, but some say Elijah; and others say that one of the old prophets has risen again.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>He said to them, “But who do you say that I am?” Peter answered and said, “The Christ of God.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And He strictly warned and commanded them to tell this to no one,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>saying, “The Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and be raised the third day.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 2:17-23  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Yes, and if I am being poured out as a drink offering on the sacrifice and service of your faith, I am glad and rejoice with you all.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For the same reason you also be glad and rejoice with me.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I trust in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you shortly, that I also may be encouraged when I know your state.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>For I have no one like-minded, who will sincerely care for your state.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>For all seek their own, not the things which are of Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But you know his proven character, that as a son with his father he served with me in the gospel.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Therefore I hope to send him at once, as soon as I see how it goes with me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:23-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Then He said to them all, “If anyone desires to come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow Me.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>For whoever desires to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for My sake will save it.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>For what profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and is himself destroyed or lost?</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For whoever is ashamed of Me and My words, of him the Son of Man will be ashamed when He comes in His own glory, and in His Father’s, and of the holy angels.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But I tell you truly, there are some standing here who shall not taste death till they see the kingdom of God.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 John 1:1-7  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes, which we have looked upon, and our hands have handled, concerning the Word of life – </dd><dt>2</dt><dd>the life was manifested, and we have seen, and bear witness, and declare to you that eternal life which was with the Father and was manifested to us – </dd><dt>3</dt><dd>that which we have seen and heard we declare to you, that you also may have fellowship with us; and truly our fellowship is with the Father and with His Son Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And these things we write to you that your joy may be full.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>This is the message which we have heard from Him and declare to you, that God is light and in Him is no darkness at all.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>If we say that we have fellowship with Him, and walk in darkness, we lie and do not practice the truth.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But if we walk in the light as He is in the light, we have fellowship with one another, and the blood of Jesus Christ His Son cleanses us from all sin.</dd></dl>

readings.title: James 1:1-12  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>James, a bondservant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scattered abroad: Greetings.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>My brethren, count it all joy when you fall into various trials,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>knowing that the testing of your faith produces patience.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But let patience have its perfect work, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all liberally and without reproach, and it will be given to him.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But let him ask in faith, with no doubting, for he who doubts is like a wave of the sea driven and tossed by the wind.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For let not that man suppose that he will receive anything from the Lord;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>he is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Let the lowly brother glory in his exaltation,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>but the rich in his humiliation, because as a flower of the field he will pass away.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For no sooner has the sun risen with a burning heat than it withers the grass; its flower falls, and its beautiful appearance perishes. So the rich man also will fade away in his pursuits.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Blessed is the man who endures temptation; for when he has been approved, he will receive the crown of life which the Lord has promised to those who love Him.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jude 1:1-7 17-25  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Jude, a bondservant of Jesus Christ, and brother of James, to those who are called, sanctified by God the Father, and preserved in Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Beloved, while I was very diligent to write to you concerning our common salvation, I found it necessary to write to you exhorting you to contend earnestly for the faith which was once for all delivered to the saints.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For certain men have crept in unnoticed, who long ago were marked out for this condemnation, ungodly men, who turn the grace of our God into lewdness and deny the only Lord God and our Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But I want to remind you, though you once knew this, that the Lord, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed those who did not believe.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And the angels who did not keep their proper domain, but left their own abode, He has reserved in everlasting chains under darkness for the judgment of the great day;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>as Sodom and Gomorrah, and the cities around them in a similar manner to these, having given themselves over to sexual immorality and gone after strange flesh, are set forth as an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But you, beloved, remember the words which were spoken before by the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>how they told you that there would be mockers in the last time who would walk according to their own ungodly lusts.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>These are sensual persons, who cause divisions, not having the Spirit.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But you, beloved, building yourselves up on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Spirit,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>keep yourselves in the love of God, looking for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And on some have compassion, making a distinction;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>but others save with fear, pulling them out of the fire, hating even the garment defiled by the flesh.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now to Him who is able to keep you from stumbling, and to present you faultless before the presence of His glory with exceeding joy,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>To God our Savior, Who alone is wise, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and forever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 21:15-25  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>So when they had eaten breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me more than these?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Feed My lambs.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He said to him again a second time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” He said to Him, “Yes, Lord; You know that I love You.” He said to him, “Tend My sheep.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>He said to him the third time, “Simon, son of Jonah, do you love Me?” Peter was grieved because He said to him the third time, “Do you love Me?” And he said to Him, “Lord, You know all things; You know that I love You.” Jesus said to him, “Feed My sheep.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, when you were younger, you girded yourself and walked where you wished; but when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will gird you and carry you where you do not wish.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>This He spoke, signifying by what death he would glorify God. And when He had spoken this, He said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then Peter, turning around, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following, who also had leaned on His breast at the supper, and said, “Lord, who is the one who betrays You?”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Peter, seeing him, said to Jesus, “But Lord, what about this man?”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you? You follow Me.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then this saying went out among the brethren that this disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but, “If I will that he remain till I come, what is that to you?”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>This is the disciple who testifies of these things, and wrote these things; and we know that his testimony is true.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And there are also many other things that Jesus did, which if they were written one by one, I suppose that even the world itself could not contain the books that would be written. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Colossians 4:5-9 14 18  (Epistle St Luke)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Walk in wisdom toward those who are outside, redeeming the time.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Let your speech always be with grace, seasoned with salt, that you may know how you ought to answer each one.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Tychicus, a beloved brother, faithful minister, and fellow servant in the Lord, will tell you all the news about me.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>I am sending him to you for this very purpose, that he may know your circumstances and comfort your hearts,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>with Onesimus, a faithful and beloved brother, who is one of you. They will make known to you all things which are happening here.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Luke the beloved physician and Demas greet you.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>This salutation by my own hand – Paul. Remember my chains. Grace be with you. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:16-21  (Gospel St Luke)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>He who hears you hears Me, he who rejects you rejects Me, and he who rejects Me rejects Him who sent Me.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then the seventy returned with joy, saying, “Lord, even the demons are subject to us in Your name.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And He said to them, “I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Behold, I give you the authority to trample on serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy, and nothing shall by any means hurt you.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Nevertheless do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you, but rather rejoice because your names are written in heaven.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>In that hour Jesus rejoiced in the Spirit and said, “I thank You, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that You have hidden these things from the wise and prudent and revealed them to babes. Even so, Father, for so it seemed good in Your sight.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 2:24-30  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>But I trust in the Lord that I myself shall also come shortly.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Yet I considered it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother, fellow worker, and fellow soldier, but your messenger and the one who ministered to my need;</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>since he was longing for you all, and was distressed because you had heard that he was sick.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For indeed he was sick almost unto death; but God had mercy on him, and not only on him but on me also, lest I should have sorrow upon sorrow.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Therefore I sent him the more eagerly, that when you see him again you may rejoice, and I may be less sorrowful.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Receive him therefore in the Lord with all gladness, and hold such men in esteem;</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>because for the work of Christ he came close to death, not regarding his life, to supply what was lacking in your service toward me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:44-50  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>44</dt><dd>“Let these words sink down into your ears, for the Son of Man is about to be betrayed into the hands of men.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>But they did not understand this saying, and it was hidden from them so that they did not perceive it; and they were afraid to ask Him about this saying.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Then a dispute arose among them as to which of them would be greatest.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>And Jesus, perceiving the thought of their heart, took a little child and set him by Him,</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>and said to them, “Whoever receives this little child in My name receives Me; and whoever receives Me receives Him who sent Me. For he who is least among you all will be great.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Now John answered and said, “Master, we saw someone casting out demons in Your name, and we forbade him because he does not follow with us.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>But Jesus said to him, “Do not forbid him, for he who is not against us is on our side.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 3:1-8  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Finally, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord. For me to write the same things to you is not tedious, but for you it is safe.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Beware of dogs, beware of evil workers, beware of the mutilation!</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For we are the circumcision, who worship God in the Spirit, rejoice in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>though I also might have confidence in the flesh. If anyone else thinks he may have confidence in the flesh, I more so:</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of the Hebrews; concerning the law, a Pharisee;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>concerning zeal, persecuting the church; concerning the righteousness which is in the law, blameless.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But what things were gain to me, these I have counted loss for Christ.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Yet indeed I also count all things loss for the excellence of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and count them as rubbish, that I may gain Christ</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 9:49-56  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>49</dt><dd>Now John answered and said, “Master, we saw someone casting out demons in Your name, and we forbade him because he does not follow with us.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>But Jesus said to him, “Do not forbid him, for he who is not against us is on our side.” </dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, when the time had come for Him to be received up, that He steadfastly set His face to go to Jerusalem,</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>and sent messengers before His face. And as they went, they entered a village of the Samaritans, to prepare for Him.</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>But they did not receive Him, because His face was set for the journey to Jerusalem.</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>And when His disciples James and John saw this, they said, “Lord, do You want us to command fire to come down from heaven and consume them, just as Elijah did?” </dd><dt>55</dt><dd>But He turned and rebuked them, and said, “You do not know what manner of spirit you are of.</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>For the Son of Man did not come to destroy men’s lives but to save them.” And they went to another village.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 3:8-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>Yet indeed I also count all things loss for the excellence of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and count them as rubbish, that I may gain Christ</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>and be found in Him, not having my own righteousness, which is from the law, but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness which is from God by faith;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>that I may know Him and the power of His resurrection, and the fellowship of His sufferings, being conformed to His death,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>if, by any means, I may attain to the resurrection from the dead.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Not that I have already attained, or am already perfected; but I press on, that I may lay hold of that for which Christ Jesus has also laid hold of me.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Brethren, I do not count myself to have apprehended; but one thing I do, forgetting those things which are behind and reaching forward to those things which are ahead,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I press toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore let us, as many as are mature, have this mind; and if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Nevertheless, to the degree that we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule, let us be of the same mind.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Brethren, join in following my example, and note those who so walk, as you have us for a pattern.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For many walk, of whom I have told you often, and now tell you even weeping, that they are the enemies of the cross of Christ:</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>whose end is destruction, whose god is their belly, and whose glory is in their shame – who set their mind on earthly things.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:1-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>After these things the Lord appointed seventy others also, and sent them two by two before His face into every city and place where He Himself was about to go.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “The harvest truly is great, but the laborers are few; therefore pray the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into His harvest.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Go your way; behold, I send you out as lambs among wolves.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Carry neither money bag, knapsack, nor sandals; and greet no one along the road.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>But whatever house you enter, first say, ‘Peace to this house.’</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And if a son of peace is there, your peace will rest on it; if not, it will return to you.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And remain in the same house, eating and drinking such things as they give, for the laborer is worthy of his wages. Do not go from house to house.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Whatever city you enter, and they receive you, eat such things as are set before you.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And heal the sick there, and say to them, ‘The kingdom of God has come near to you.’</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But whatever city you enter, and they do not receive you, go out into its streets and say,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>‘The very dust of your city which clings to us we wipe off against you. Nevertheless know this, that the kingdom of God has come near you.’</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But I say to you that it will be more tolerable in that Day for Sodom than for that city.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And you, Capernaum, who are exalted to heaven, will be brought down to Hades. </dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17  (Epistle Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>But I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning those who have fallen asleep, lest you sorrow as others who have no hope.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who sleep in Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and remain until the coming of the Lord will by no means precede those who are asleep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of an archangel, and with the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then we who are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And thus we shall always be with the Lord.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 5:24-30  (Gospel Departed)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>24</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, he who hears My word and believes in Him who sent Me has everlasting life, and shall not come into judgment, but has passed from death into life.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Most assuredly, I say to you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear will live.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For as the Father has life in Himself, so He has granted the Son to have life in Himself,</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>and has given Him authority to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of Man.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Do not marvel at this; for the hour is coming in which all who are in the graves will hear His voice</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>and come forth – those who have done good, to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil, to the resurrection of condemnation.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>I can of Myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge; and My judgment is righteous, because I do not seek My own will but the will of the Father who sent Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Corinthians 1:8-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>For we do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, of our trouble which came to us in Asia: that we were burdened beyond measure, above strength, so that we despaired even of life.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Yes, we had the sentence of death in ourselves, that we should not trust in ourselves but in God who raises the dead,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>who delivered us from so great a death, and does deliver us; in whom we trust that He will still deliver us,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>you also helping together in prayer for us, that thanks may be given by many persons on our behalf for the gift granted to us through many.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 7:1-10  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now when He concluded all His sayings in the hearing of the people, He entered Capernaum.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And a certain centurion’s servant, who was dear to him, was sick and ready to die.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So when he heard about Jesus, he sent elders of the Jews to Him, pleading with Him to come and heal his servant.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when they came to Jesus, they begged Him earnestly, saying that the one for whom He should do this was deserving,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>for he loves our nation, and has built us a synagogue.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then Jesus went with them. And when He was already not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to Him, saying to Him, “Lord, do not trouble Yourself, for I am not worthy that You should enter under my roof.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore I did not even think myself worthy to come to You. But say the word, and my servant will be healed.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For I also am a man placed under authority, having soldiers under me. And I say to one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and to another, ‘Come,’ and he comes; and to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>When Jesus heard these things, He marveled at him, and turned around and said to the crowd that followed Him, “I say to you, I have not found such great faith, not even in Israel!”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And those who were sent, returning to the house, found the servant well who had been sick. </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:19-31  (9th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>Then, the same day at evening, being the first day of the week, when the doors were shut where the disciples were assembled, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood in the midst, and said to them, “Peace be with you.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His side. Then the disciples were glad when they saw the Lord.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So Jesus said to them again, “Peace to you! As the Father has sent Me, I also send you.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And when He had said this, He breathed on them, and said to them, “Receive the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven them; if you retain the sins of any, they are retained.”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Now Thomas, called the Twin, one of the twelve, was not with them when Jesus came.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>The other disciples therefore said to him, “We have seen the Lord.” So he said to them, “Unless I see in His hands the print of the nails, and put my finger into the print of the nails, and put my hand into His side, I will not believe.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And after eight days His disciples were again inside, and Thomas with them. Jesus came, the doors being shut, and stood in the midst, and said, “Peace to you!”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then He said to Thomas, “Reach your finger here, and look at My hands; and reach your hand here, and put it into My side. Do not be unbelieving, but believing.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And Thomas answered and said to Him, “My Lord and my God!”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Jesus said to him, “Thomas, because you have seen Me, you have believed. Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.”</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And truly Jesus did many other signs in the presence of His disciples, which are not written in this book;</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>but these are written that you may believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and that believing you may have life in His name.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 1:11-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But I make known to you, brethren, that the gospel which was preached by me is not according to man.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it, but it came through the revelation of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For you have heard of my former conduct in Judaism, how I persecuted the church of God beyond measure and tried to destroy it.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And I advanced in Judaism beyond many of my contemporaries in my own nation, being more exceedingly zealous for the traditions of my fathers.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when it pleased God, who separated me from my mother’s womb and called me through His grace,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to reveal His Son in me, that I might preach Him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately confer with flesh and blood,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; but I went to Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to see Peter, and remained with him fifteen days.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I saw none of the other apostles except James, the Lord’s brother.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 16:19-31  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>There was a certain rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen and fared sumptuously every day.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But there was a certain beggar named Lazarus, full of sores, who was laid at his gate,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>desiring to be fed with the crumbs which fell from the rich man’s table. Moreover the dogs came and licked his sores.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So it was that the beggar died, and was carried by the angels to Abraham’s bosom. The rich man also died and was buried.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And being in torments in Hades, he lifted up his eyes and saw Abraham afar off, and Lazarus in his bosom.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then he cried and said, ‘Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus that he may dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue; for I am tormented in this flame.’</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But Abraham said, ‘Son, remember that in your lifetime you received your good things, and likewise Lazarus evil things; but now he is comforted and you are tormented.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And besides all this, between us and you there is a great gulf fixed, so that those who want to pass from here to you cannot, nor can those from there pass to us.’</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>Then he said, ‘I beg you therefore, father, that you would send him to my father’s house,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>for I have five brothers, that he may testify to them, lest they also come to this place of torment.’</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Abraham said to him, ‘They have Moses and the prophets; let them hear them.’</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And he said, ‘No, father Abraham; but if one goes to them from the dead, they will repent.’</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>But he said to him, ‘If they do not hear Moses and the prophets, neither will they be persuaded though one rise from the dead.’”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Gal 1:11-19  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But I make known to you, brethren, that the gospel which was preached by me is not according to man.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it, but it came through the revelation of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For you have heard of my former conduct in Judaism, how I persecuted the church of God beyond measure and tried to destroy it.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And I advanced in Judaism beyond many of my contemporaries in my own nation, being more exceedingly zealous for the traditions of my fathers.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when it pleased God, who separated me from my mother’s womb and called me through His grace,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to reveal His Son in me, that I might preach Him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately confer with flesh and blood,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; but I went to Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to see Peter, and remained with him fifteen days.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I saw none of the other apostles except James, the Lord’s brother.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 13:54-58  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>54</dt><dd>When He had come to His own country, He taught them in their synagogue, so that they were astonished and said, “Where did this Man get this wisdom and these mighty works?</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>Is this not the carpenter’s son? Is not His mother called Mary? And His brothers James, Joses, Simon, and Judas?</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>And His sisters, are they not all with us? Where then did this Man get all these things?”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>So they were offended at Him. But Jesus said to them, “A prophet is not without honor except in his own country and in his own house.”</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>Now He did not do many mighty works there because of their unbelief.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Philippians 4:10-23  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>But I rejoiced in the Lord greatly that now at last your care for me has flourished again; though you surely did care, but you lacked opportunity.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Not that I speak in regard to need, for I have learned in whatever state I am, to be content:</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>I know how to be abased, and I know how to abound. Everywhere and in all things I have learned both to be full and to be hungry, both to abound and to suffer need.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Nevertheless you have done well that you shared in my distress.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Now you Philippians know also that in the beginning of the gospel, when I departed from Macedonia, no church shared with me concerning giving and receiving but you only.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For even in Thessalonica you sent aid once and again for my necessities.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Not that I seek the gift, but I seek the fruit that abounds to your account.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Indeed I have all and abound. I am full, having received from Epaphroditus the things sent from you, a sweet-smelling aroma, an acceptable sacrifice, well pleasing to God.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And my God shall supply all your need according to His riches in glory by Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now to our God and Father be glory forever and ever. Amen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Greet every saint in Christ Jesus. The brethren who are with me greet you.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>All the saints greet you, but especially those who are of Caesar’s household.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 10:22-24  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows who the Son is except the Father, and who the Father is except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then He turned to His disciples and said privately, “Blessed are the eyes which see the things you see;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>for I tell you that many prophets and kings have desired to see what you see, and have not seen it, and to hear what you hear, and have not heard it.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Colossians 1:1-2 7-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Timothy our brother,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>to the saints and faithful brethren in Christ who are in Colosse: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>as you also learned from Epaphras, our dear fellow servant, who is a faithful minister of Christ on your behalf,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>who also declared to us your love in the Spirit.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For this reason we also, since the day we heard it, do not cease to pray for you, and to ask that you may be filled with the knowledge of His will in all wisdom and spiritual understanding;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>that you may walk worthy of the Lord, fully pleasing Him, being fruitful in every good work and increasing in the knowledge of God;</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>strengthened with all might, according to His glorious power, for all patience and longsuffering with joy;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 11:1-10  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, as He was praying in a certain place, when He ceased, that one of His disciples said to Him, “Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples.”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>So He said to them, “When you pray, say: Our Father in heaven, hallowed be Your name. Your kingdom come. Your will be done on earth as it is in heaven.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Give us day by day our daily bread.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And forgive us our sins, for we also forgive everyone who is indebted to us. And do not lead us into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one.” </dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Which of you shall have a friend, and go to him at midnight and say to him, ‘Friend, lend me three loaves;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>for a friend of mine has come to me on his journey, and I have nothing to set before him’;</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>and he will answer from within and say, ‘Do not trouble me; the door is now shut, and my children are with me in bed; I cannot rise and give to you’?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>I say to you, though he will not rise and give to him because he is his friend, yet because of his persistence he will rise and give him as many as he needs.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So I say to you, ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For everyone who asks receives, and he who seeks finds, and to him who knocks it will be opened.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Colossians 1:18-23  (Epistle)
