when He suffered, He did not threaten, but committed Himself to Him who judges righteously;</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>who Himself bore our sins in His own body on the tree, that we, having died to sins, might live for righteousness – by whose stripes you were healed.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>For you were like sheep going astray, but have now returned to the Shepherd and Overseer of your souls.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Wives, likewise, be submissive to your own husbands, that even if some do not obey the word, they, without a word, may be won by the conduct of their wives,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>when they observe your chaste conduct accompanied by fear.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Do not let your adornment be merely outward – arranging the hair, wearing gold, or putting on fine apparel – </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>rather let it be the hidden person of the heart, with the incorruptible beauty of a gentle and quiet spirit, which is very precious in the sight of God.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For in this manner, in former times, the holy women who trusted in God also adorned themselves, being submissive to their own husbands,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>as Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, whose daughters you are if you do good and are not afraid with any terror.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Husbands, likewise, dwell with them with understanding, giving honor to the wife, as to the weaker vessel, and as being heirs together of the grace of life, that your prayers may not be hindered.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Finally, all of you be of one mind, having compassion for one another; love as brothers, be tenderhearted, be courteous;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>not returning evil for evil or reviling for reviling, but on the contrary blessing, knowing that you were called to this, that you may inherit a blessing.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Peter 4:1-11  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore, since Christ suffered for us in the flesh, arm yourselves also with the same mind, for he who has suffered in the flesh has ceased from sin,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>that he no longer should live the rest of his time in the flesh for the lusts of men, but for the will of God.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For we have spent enough of our past lifetime in doing the will of the Gentiles – when we walked in lewdness, lusts, drunkenness, revelries, drinking parties, and abominable idolatries.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>In regard to these, they think it strange that you do not run with them in the same flood of dissipation, speaking evil of you.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>They will give an account to Him who is ready to judge the living and the dead.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>For this reason the gospel was preached also to those who are dead, that they might be judged according to men in the flesh, but live according to God in the spirit.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But the end of all things is at hand; therefore be serious and watchful in your prayers.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And above all things have fervent love for one another, for “love will cover a multitude of sins.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Be hospitable to one another without grumbling.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>As each one has received a gift, minister it to one another, as good stewards of the manifold grace of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 4:18-23  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>And Jesus, walking by the Sea of Galilee, saw two brothers, Simon called Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea; for they were fishermen.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Follow Me, and I will make you fishers of men.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>They immediately left their nets and followed Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Going on from there, He saw two other brothers, James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. He called them,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and immediately they left the boat and their father, and followed Him.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And Jesus went about all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all kinds of sickness and all kinds of disease among the people.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Corinthians 4:9-16  (Epistle Apostle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>For I think that God has displayed us, the apostles, last, as men condemned to death; for we have been made a spectacle to the world, both to angels and to men.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>We are fools for Christ’s sake, but you are wise in Christ! We are weak, but you are strong! You are distinguished, but we are dishonored!</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>To the present hour we both hunger and thirst, and we are poorly clothed, and beaten, and homeless.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And we labor, working with our own hands. Being reviled, we bless; being persecuted, we endure;</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>being defamed, we entreat. We have been made as the filth of the world, the offscouring of all things until now.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I do not write these things to shame you, but as my beloved children I warn you.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For though you might have ten thousand instructors in Christ, yet you do not have many fathers; for in Christ Jesus I have begotten you through the gospel.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore I urge you, imitate me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 1:35-51  (Gospel Apostle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>Again, the next day, John stood with two of his disciples.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>And looking at Jesus as He walked, he said, “Behold the Lamb of God!”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>The two disciples heard him speak, and they followed Jesus.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then Jesus turned, and seeing them following, said to them, “What do you seek?” They said to Him, “Rabbi,” (which is to say, when translated, Teacher) “where are You staying?”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>He said to them, “Come and see.” They came and saw where He was staying, and remained with Him that day (now it was about the tenth hour).</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>One of the two who heard John speak, and followed Him, was Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>He first found his own brother Simon, and said to him, “We have found the Messiah” (which is translated, the Christ).</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>And he brought him to Jesus. Now when Jesus looked at him, He said, “You are Simon the son of Jonah. You shall be called Cephas” (which is translated, A Stone).</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>The following day Jesus wanted to go to Galilee, and He found Philip and said to him, “Follow Me.”</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Now Philip was from Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Philip found Nathanael and said to him, “We have found Him of whom Moses in the law, and also the prophets, wrote – Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.”</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>And Nathanael said to him, “Can anything good come out of Nazareth?” Philip said to him, “Come and see.”</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward Him, and said of him, “Behold, an Israelite indeed, in whom is no deceit!”</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>Nathanael said to Him, “How do You know me?” Jesus answered and said to him, “Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you.”</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Nathanael answered and said to Him, “Rabbi, You are the Son of God! You are the King of Israel!”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to him, “Because I said to you, ‘I saw you under the fig tree,’ do you believe? You will see greater things than these.”</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>And He said to him, “Most assuredly, I say to you, hereafter you shall see heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of Man.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 3:1-13  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>This is a faithful saying: If a man desires the position of a bishop, he desires a good work.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>A bishop then must be blameless, the husband of one wife, temperate, sober-minded, of good behavior, hospitable, able to teach;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>not given to wine, not violent, not greedy for money, but gentle, not quarrelsome, not covetous;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>one who rules his own house well, having his children in submission with all reverence</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>(for if a man does not know how to rule his own house, how will he take care of the church of God?);</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>not a novice, lest being puffed up with pride he fall into the same condemnation as the devil.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Moreover he must have a good testimony among those who are outside, lest he fall into reproach and the snare of the devil.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Likewise deacons must be reverent, not double-tongued, not given to much wine, not greedy for money,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>holding the mystery of the faith with a pure conscience.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But let these also first be tested; then let them serve as deacons, being found blameless.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Likewise, their wives must be reverent, not slanderers, temperate, faithful in all things.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Let deacons be the husbands of one wife, ruling their children and their own houses well.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For those who have served well as deacons obtain for themselves a good standing and great boldness in the faith which is in Christ Jesus.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 20:9-18  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Then He began to tell the people this parable: “A certain man planted a vineyard, leased it to vinedressers, and went into a far country for a long time.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Now at vintage-time he sent a servant to the vinedressers, that they might give him some of the fruit of the vineyard. But the vinedressers beat him and sent him away empty-handed.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Again he sent another servant; and they beat him also, treated him shamefully, and sent him away empty-handed.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And again he sent a third; and they wounded him also and cast him out.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then the owner of the vineyard said, ‘What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Probably they will respect him when they see him.’</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But when the vinedressers saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, that the inheritance may be ours.’</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So they cast him out of the vineyard and killed him. Therefore what will the owner of the vineyard do to them?</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>He will come and destroy those vinedressers and give the vineyard to others.” And when they heard it they said, “Certainly not!”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then He looked at them and said, “What then is this that is written: ‘The stone which the builders rejected Has become the chief cornerstone’? </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Whoever falls on that stone will be broken; but on whomever it falls, it will grind him to powder.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 4:4-8 16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>For every creature of God is good, and nothing is to be refused if it is received with thanksgiving;</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>for it is sanctified by the word of God and prayer.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>If you instruct the brethren in these things, you will be a good minister of Jesus Christ, nourished in the words of faith and of the good doctrine which you have carefully followed.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But reject profane and old wives’ fables, and exercise yourself toward godliness.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For bodily exercise profits a little, but godliness is profitable for all things, having promise of the life that now is and of that which is to come.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Take heed to yourself and to the doctrine. Continue in them, for in doing this you will save both yourself and those who hear you.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 20:19-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>19</dt><dd>And the chief priests and the scribes that very hour sought to lay hands on Him, but they feared the people – for they knew He had spoken this parable against them.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>So they watched Him, and sent spies who pretended to be righteous, that they might seize on His words, in order to deliver Him to the power and the authority of the governor.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then they asked Him, saying, “Teacher, we know that You say and teach rightly, and You do not show personal favoritism, but teach the way of God in truth:</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Is it lawful for us to pay taxes to Caesar or not?”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But He perceived their craftiness, and said to them, “Why do you test Me? </dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Show Me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?” They answered and said, “Caesar’s.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Render therefore to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But they could not catch Him in His words in the presence of the people. And they marveled at His answer and kept silent.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 3:8-12  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>And the Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached the gospel to Abraham beforehand, saying, “In you all the nations shall be blessed.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So then those who are of faith are blessed with believing Abraham.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For as many as are of the works of the law are under the curse; for it is written, “Cursed is everyone who does not continue in all things which are written in the book of the law, to do them.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But that no one is justified by the law in the sight of God is evident, for “the just shall live by faith.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Yet the law is not of faith, but “the man who does them shall live by them.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 12:32-40  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Do not fear, little flock, for it is your Father’s good pleasure to give you the kingdom.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Sell what you have and give alms; provide yourselves money bags which do not grow old, a treasure in the heavens that does not fail, where no thief approaches nor moth destroys.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Let your waist be girded and your lamps burning;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>and you yourselves be like men who wait for their master, when he will return from the wedding, that when he comes and knocks they may open to him immediately.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Blessed are those servants whom the master, when he comes, will find watching. Assuredly, I say to you that he will gird himself and have them sit down to eat, and will come and serve them.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And if he should come in the second watch, or come in the third watch, and find them so, blessed are those servants.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But know this, that if the master of the house had known what hour the thief would come, he would have watched and not allowed his house to be broken into.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Therefore you also be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:1-12  (4th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they, and certain other women with them, came to the tomb bringing the spices which they had prepared.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>But they found the stone rolled away from the tomb.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then they went in and did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And it happened, as they were greatly perplexed about this, that behold, two men stood by them in shining garments.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then, as they were afraid and bowed their faces to the earth, they said to them, “Why do you seek the living among the dead?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>He is not here, but is risen! Remember how He spoke to you when He was still in Galilee,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>saying, ‘The Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and the third day rise again.’”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And they remembered His words.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then they returned from the tomb and told all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and the other women with them, who told these things to the apostles.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And their words seemed to them like idle tales, and they did not believe them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Peter arose and ran to the tomb; and stooping down, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves; and he departed, marveling to himself at what had happened.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 5:9-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>(for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, righteousness, and truth),</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>finding out what is acceptable to the Lord.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather expose them.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For it is shameful even to speak of those things which are done by them in secret.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But all things that are exposed are made manifest by the light, for whatever makes manifest is light.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore He says: “Awake, you who sleep, arise from the dead, and Christ will give you light.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>See then that you walk circumspectly, not as fools but as wise,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>redeeming the time, because the days are evil.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore do not be unwise, but understand what the will of the Lord is.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And do not be drunk with wine, in which is dissipation; but be filled with the Spirit,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>speaking to one another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 18:18-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Now a certain ruler asked Him, saying, “Good Teacher, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So Jesus said to him, “Why do you call Me good? No one is good but One, that is, God.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>You know the commandments: ‘Do not commit adultery,’ ‘Do not murder,’ ‘Do not steal,’ ‘Do not bear false witness,’ ‘Honor your father and your mother.’”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And he said, “All these things I have kept from my youth.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So when Jesus heard these things, He said to him, “You still lack one thing. Sell all that you have and distribute to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow Me.”</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But when he heard this, he became very sorrowful, for he was very rich.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And when Jesus saw that he became very sorrowful, He said, “How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>For it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And those who heard it said, “Who then can be saved?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But He said, “The things which are impossible with men are possible with God.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 13:7-16  (Epistle St Alexander)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd> Remember those who rule over you, who have spoken the word of God to you, whose faith follow, considering the outcome of their conduct.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Do not be carried about with various and strange doctrines. For it is good that the heart be established by grace, not with foods which have not profited those who have been occupied with them.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>We have an altar from which those who serve the tabernacle have no right to eat.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For the bodies of those animals, whose blood is brought into the sanctuary by the high priest for sin, are burned outside the camp.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore Jesus also, that He might sanctify the people with His own blood, suffered outside the gate.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore let us go forth to Him, outside the camp, bearing His reproach.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For here we have no continuing city, but we seek the one to come.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Therefore by Him let us continually offer the sacrifice of praise to God, that is, the fruit of our lips, giving thanks to His name.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But do not forget to do good and to share, for with such sacrifices God is well pleased.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 12:32-40  (Gospel St Alexander)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>32</dt><dd>Do not fear, little flock, for it is your Father’s good pleasure to give you the kingdom.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Sell what you have and give alms; provide yourselves money bags which do not grow old, a treasure in the heavens that does not fail, where no thief approaches nor moth destroys.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Let your waist be girded and your lamps burning;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>and you yourselves be like men who wait for their master, when he will return from the wedding, that when he comes and knocks they may open to him immediately.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Blessed are those servants whom the master, when he comes, will find watching. Assuredly, I say to you that he will gird himself and have them sit down to eat, and will come and serve them.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And if he should come in the second watch, or come in the third watch, and find them so, blessed are those servants.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But know this, that if the master of the house had known what hour the thief would come, he would have watched and not allowed his house to be broken into.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Therefore you also be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 5:1-10  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Do not rebuke an older man, but exhort him as a father, younger men as brothers,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>older women as mothers, younger women as sisters, with all purity.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Honor widows who are really widows.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But if any widow has children or grandchildren, let them first learn to show piety at home and to repay their parents; for this is good and acceptable before God.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Now she who is really a widow, and left alone, trusts in God and continues in supplications and prayers night and day.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But she who lives in pleasure is dead while she lives.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And these things command, that they may be blameless.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But if anyone does not provide for his own, and especially for those of his household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Do not let a widow under sixty years old be taken into the number, and not unless she has been the wife of one man,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>well reported for good works: if she has brought up children, if she has lodged strangers, if she has washed the saints’ feet, if she has relieved the afflicted, if she has diligently followed every good work.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 20:27-44  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>Then some of the Sadducees, who deny that there is a resurrection, came to Him and asked Him,</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>saying: “Teacher, Moses wrote to us that if a man’s brother dies, having a wife, and he dies without children, his brother should take his wife and raise up offspring for his brother.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Now there were seven brothers. And the first took a wife, and died without children.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>And the second took her as wife, and he died childless.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then the third took her, and in like manner the seven also; and they left no children, and died.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Last of all the woman died also.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Therefore, in the resurrection, whose wife does she become? For all seven had her as wife.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Jesus answered and said to them, “The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>But those who are counted worthy to attain that age, and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry nor are given in marriage;</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>nor can they die anymore, for they are equal to the angels and are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But even Moses showed in the burning bush passage that the dead are raised, when he called the Lord ‘the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’ </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>For He is not the God of the dead but of the living, for all live to Him.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Then some of the scribes answered and said, “Teacher, You have spoken well.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>But after that they dared not question Him anymore.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>And He said to them, “How can they say that the Christ is the Son of David?</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Now David himself said in the Book of Psalms: ‘The LORD said to my Lord, sit at My right hand,</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>till I make Your enemies Your footstool.’ </dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Therefore David calls Him ‘Lord’; how is He then his Son?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 5:11-21  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But refuse the younger widows; for when they have begun to grow wanton against Christ, they desire to marry,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>having condemnation because they have cast off their first faith.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And besides they learn to be idle, wandering about from house to house, and not only idle but also gossips and busybodies, saying things which they ought not.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore I desire that the younger widows marry, bear children, manage the house, give no opportunity to the adversary to speak reproachfully.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>For some have already turned aside after Satan.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>If any believing man or woman has widows, let them relieve them, and do not let the church be burdened, that it may relieve those who are really widows.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Let the elders who rule well be counted worthy of double honor, especially those who labor in the word and doctrine.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For the Scripture says, “You shall not muzzle an ox while it treads out the grain,” and, “The laborer is worthy of his wages.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Do not receive an accusation against an elder except from two or three witnesses.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Those who are sinning rebuke in the presence of all, that the rest also may fear.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>I charge you before God and the Lord Jesus Christ and the elect angels that you observe these things without prejudice, doing nothing with partiality.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 21:12-19  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>But before all these things, they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues and prisons. You will be brought before kings and rulers for My name’s sake.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But it will turn out for you as an occasion for testimony.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Therefore settle it in your hearts not to meditate beforehand on what you will answer;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>for I will give you a mouth and wisdom which all your adversaries will not be able to contradict or resist.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>You will be betrayed even by parents and brothers, relatives and friends; and they will put some of you to death.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And you will be hated by all for My name’s sake.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But not a hair of your head shall be lost.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>By your patience possess your souls.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Composite 2 - Proverbs 10 3 8  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The memory of the righteous is with praise and the blessing of the Lord is upon his head. Blessed is the man who has found wisdom and the mortal who has understanding. For it is better to purchase her than treasuries of gold and silver. She is more precious than precious stones and all that is precious is unworthy of her. For length of days and years of life are in her right hand; and in her left hand are riches and glory. Out of her mouth proceeds righteousness and she bears law and mercy upon her tongue.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Hear me, O child, for I will speak noble things. Blessed is the man who keeps my ways, for my ways are the ways of life, and in them is prepared favor from the Lord. Therefore, I pray thee, and utter my voice to the sons of men: For I, wisdom, have dwelt with counsel and knowledge and I have called upon understanding. Counsel and safety are mine, understanding and strength are mine. I love those who love me and those seeking me shall find grace.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Understand craftiness, O you who are simple, and imbibe knowledge, you who are untaught. Hear me again, for I will speak noble things: I will open my mouth and from my lips shall come what is right. For my throat shall meditate truth; false lips are an abomination before me. All the words of my mouth are righteous; there is nothing in them that is twisted or perverse. They are all straight to him who understands and right to those who find knowledge.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>I shall instruct you in truth, so that your hope will be in the Lord and you shall be filled with the Spirit.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Proverbs 10:31-11:12  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut out.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked what is perverse.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Dishonest scales are an abomination to the Lord, but a just weight is His delight.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>When pride comes, then comes shame; but with the humble is wisdom.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>The integrity of the upright will guide them, but the perversity of the unfaithful will destroy them.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>The righteousness of the blameless will direct his way aright, but the wicked will fall by his own wickedness.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>The righteousness of the upright will deliver them, but the unfaithful will be caught by their lust.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>When a wicked man dies, his expectation will perish, and the hope of the unjust perishes.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The righteous is delivered from trouble, and it comes to the wicked instead.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>The hypocrite with his mouth destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge the righteous will be delivered.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices; and when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted, but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>He who is devoid of wisdom despises his neighbor, but a man of understanding holds his peace.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: John 10:9-16  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>I am the door. If anyone enters by Me, he will be saved, and will go in and out and find pasture.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>The thief does not come except to steal, and to kill, and to destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it more abundantly.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd gives His life for the sheep.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But a hireling, he who is not the shepherd, one who does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf catches the sheep and scatters them.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>The hireling flees because he is a hireling and does not care about the sheep.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>I am the good shepherd; and I know My sheep, and am known by My own.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>As the Father knows Me, even so I know the Father; and I lay down My life for the sheep.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And other sheep I have which are not of this fold; them also I must bring, and they will hear My voice; and there will be one flock and one shepherd.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 13:17-21  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Obey those who rule over you, and be submissive, for they watch out for your souls, as those who must give account. Let them do so with joy and not with grief, for that would be unprofitable for you.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Pray for us; for we are confident that we have a good conscience, in all things desiring to live honorably.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I especially urge you to do this, that I may be restored to you the sooner.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now may the God of peace who brought up our Lord Jesus from the dead, that great Shepherd of the sheep, through the blood of the everlasting covenant,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>make you complete in every good work to do His will, working in you what is well pleasing in His sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 5:22-6:11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>Do not lay hands on anyone hastily, nor share in other people’s sins; keep yourself pure.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>No longer drink only water, but use a little wine for your stomach’s sake and your frequent infirmities.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Some men’s sins are clearly evident, preceding them to judgment, but those of some men follow later.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Likewise, the good works of some are clearly evident, and those that are otherwise cannot be hidden.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Let as many bondservants as are under the yoke count their own masters worthy of all honor, so that the name of God and His doctrine may not be blasphemed.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And those who have believing masters, let them not despise them because they are brethren, but rather serve them because those who are benefited are believers and beloved. Teach and exhort these things.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>If anyone teaches otherwise and does not consent to wholesome words, even the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which accords with godliness,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>he is proud, knowing nothing, but is obsessed with disputes and arguments over words, from which come envy, strife, reviling, evil suspicions,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>useless wranglings of men of corrupt minds and destitute of the truth, who suppose that godliness is a means of gain. From such withdraw yourself.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Now godliness with contentment is great gain.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For we brought nothing into this world, and it is certain we can carry nothing out.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And having food and clothing, with these we shall be content.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>But those who desire to be rich fall into temptation and a snare, and into many foolish and harmful lusts which drown men in destruction and perdition.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil, for which some have strayed from the faith in their greediness, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But you, O man of God, flee these things and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, gentleness.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 21:5-7 10-11 20-24  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>Then, as some spoke of the temple, how it was adorned with beautiful stones and donations, He said,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“These things which you see – the days will come in which not one stone shall be left upon another that shall not be thrown down.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So they asked Him, saying, “Teacher, but when will these things be? And what sign will there be when these things are about to take place?”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And there will be great earthquakes in various places, and famines and pestilences; and there will be fearful sights and great signs from heaven.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then know that its desolation is near.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, let those who are in the midst of her depart, and let not those who are in the country enter her.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>For these are the days of vengeance, that all things which are written may be fulfilled.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing babies in those days! For there will be great distress in the land and wrath upon this people.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And they will fall by the edge of the sword, and be led away captive into all nations. And Jerusalem will be trampled by Gentiles until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 6:17-21  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Command those who are rich in this present age not to be haughty, nor to trust in uncertain riches but in the living God, who gives us richly all things to enjoy.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Let them do good, that they be rich in good works, ready to give, willing to share,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>storing up for themselves a good foundation for the time to come, that they may lay hold on eternal life.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>O Timothy! Guard what was committed to your trust, avoiding the profane and idle babblings and contradictions of what is falsely called knowledge – </dd><dt>21</dt><dd>by professing it some have strayed concerning the faith. Grace be with you. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 21:28-33  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>28</dt><dd>Now when these things begin to happen, look up and lift up your heads, because your redemption draws near.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Then He spoke to them a parable: “Look at the fig tree, and all the trees.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>When they are already budding, you see and know for yourselves that summer is now near.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>So you also, when you see these things happening, know that the kingdom of God is near.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, this generation will by no means pass away till all things take place.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>Heaven and earth will pass away, but My words will by no means pass away.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Timothy 1:1-2 8-18  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, according to the promise of life which is in Christ Jesus,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>to Timothy, a beloved son: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me His prisoner, but share with me in the sufferings for the gospel according to the power of God,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>who has saved us and called us with a holy calling, not according to our works, but according to His own purpose and grace which was given to us in Christ Jesus before time began,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>but has now been revealed by the appearing of our Savior Jesus Christ, who has abolished death and brought life and immortality to light through the gospel,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>to which I was appointed a preacher, an apostle, and a teacher of the Gentiles.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For this reason I also suffer these things; nevertheless I am not ashamed, for I know whom I have believed and am persuaded that He is able to keep what I have committed to Him until that Day.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Hold fast the pattern of sound words which you have heard from me, in faith and love which are in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>That good thing which was committed to you, keep by the Holy Spirit who dwells in us.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>This you know, that all those in Asia have turned away from me, among whom are Phygellus and Hermogenes.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>The Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me, and was not ashamed of my chain;</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>but when he arrived in Rome, he sought me out very zealously and found me.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>The Lord grant to him that he may find mercy from the Lord in that Day – and you know very well how many ways he ministered to me at Ephesus.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 21:37-22:8  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>37</dt><dd>And in the daytime He was teaching in the temple, but at night He went out and stayed on the mountain called Olivet.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Then early in the morning all the people came to Him in the temple to hear Him.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the Feast of Unleavened Bread drew near, which is called Passover.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And the chief priests and the scribes sought how they might kill Him, for they feared the people.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then Satan entered Judas, surnamed Iscariot, who was numbered among the twelve.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So he went his way and conferred with the chief priests and captains, how he might betray Him to them.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And they were glad, and agreed to give him money.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So he promised and sought opportunity to betray Him to them in the absence of the multitude.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then came the Day of Unleavened Bread, when the Passover lamb must be killed.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And He sent Peter and John, saying, “Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 4:22-31  (Epistle St Anna)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>For it is written that Abraham had two sons: the one by a bondwoman, the other by a freewoman.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But he who was of the bondwoman was born according to the flesh, and he of the freewoman through promise,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>which things are symbolic. For these are the two covenants: the one from Mount Sinai which gives birth to bondage, which is Hagar – </dd><dt>25</dt><dd>for this Hagar is Mount Sinai in Arabia, and corresponds to Jerusalem which now is, and is in bondage with her children – </dd><dt>26</dt><dd>but the Jerusalem above is free, which is the mother of us all.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For it is written: “Rejoice, O barren, You who do not bear! Break forth and shout, You who are not in labor! For the desolate has many more children Than she who has a husband.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Now we, brethren, as Isaac was, are children of promise.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But, as he who was born according to the flesh then persecuted him who was born according to the Spirit, even so it is now.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Nevertheless what does the Scripture say? “Cast out the bondwoman and her son, for the son of the bondwoman shall not be heir with the son of the freewoman.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>So then, brethren, we are not children of the bondwoman but of the free.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 8:16-21  (Gospel St Anna)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>No one, when he has lit a lamp, covers it with a vessel or puts it under a bed, but sets it on a lampstand, that those who enter may see the light.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>For nothing is secret that will not be revealed, nor anything hidden that will not be known and come to light.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Therefore take heed how you hear. For whoever has, to him more will be given; and whoever does not have, even what he seems to have will be taken from him.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then His mother and brothers came to Him, and could not approach Him because of the crowd.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And it was told Him by some, who said, “Your mother and Your brothers are standing outside, desiring to see You.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But He answered and said to them, “My mother and My brothers are these who hear the word of God and do it.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 13:18-29  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Then He said, “What is the kingdom of God like? And to what shall I compare it?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>It is like a mustard seed, which a man took and put in his garden; and it grew and became a large tree, and the birds of the air nested in its branches.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And again He said, “To what shall I liken the kingdom of God?</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>It is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal till it was all leavened.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And He went through the cities and villages, teaching, and journeying toward Jerusalem.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then one said to Him, “Lord, are there few who are saved?” And He said to them,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>“Strive to enter through the narrow gate, for many, I say to you, will seek to enter and will not be able.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>When once the Master of the house has risen up and shut the door, and you begin to stand outside and knock at the door, saying, ‘Lord, Lord, open for us,’ and He will answer and say to you, ‘I do not know you, where you are from,’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>then you will begin to say, ‘We ate and drank in Your presence, and You taught in our streets.’</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But He will say, ‘I tell you I do not know you, where you are from. Depart from Me, all you workers of iniquity.’</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and yourselves thrust out.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>They will come from the east and the west, from the north and the south, and sit down in the kingdom of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:12-35  (5th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>But Peter arose and ran to the tomb; and stooping down, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves; and he departed, marveling to himself at what had happened.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Now behold, two of them were traveling that same day to a village called Emmaus, which was seven miles from Jerusalem.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And they talked together of all these things which had happened.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So it was, while they conversed and reasoned, that Jesus Himself drew near and went with them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But their eyes were restrained, so that they did not know Him.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And He said to them, “What kind of conversation is this that you have with one another as you walk and are sad?” </dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then the one whose name was Cleopas answered and said to Him, “Are You the only stranger in Jerusalem, and have You not known the things which happened there in these days?”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And He said to them, “What things?” So they said to Him, “The things concerning Jesus of Nazareth, who was a Prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and how the chief priests and our rulers delivered Him to be condemned to death, and crucified Him.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>But we were hoping that it was He who was going to redeem Israel. Indeed, besides all this, today is the third day since these things happened.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Yes, and certain women of our company, who arrived at the tomb early, astonished us.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>When they did not find His body, they came saying that they had also seen a vision of angels who said He was alive.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And certain of those who were with us went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said; but Him they did not see.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “O foolish ones, and slow of heart to believe in all that the prophets have spoken!</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Ought not the Christ to have suffered these things and to enter into His glory?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>And beginning at Moses and all the Prophets, He expounded to them in all the Scriptures the things concerning Himself.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then they drew near to the village where they were going, and He indicated that He would have gone farther.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But they constrained Him, saying, “Abide with us, for it is toward evening, and the day is far spent.” And He went in to stay with them.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, as He sat at the table with them, that He took bread, blessed and broke it, and gave it to them.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>Then their eyes were opened and they knew Him; and He vanished from their sight.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And they said to one another, “Did not our heart burn within us while He talked with us on the road, and while He opened the Scriptures to us?”</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>So they rose up that very hour and returned to Jerusalem, and found the eleven and those who were with them gathered together,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>saying, “The Lord is risen indeed, and has appeared to Simon!”</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And they told about the things that had happened on the road, and how He was known to them in the breaking of bread.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 6:10-17  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Finally, my brethren, be strong in the Lord and in the power of His might.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Put on the whole armor of God, that you may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For we do not wrestle against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this age, against spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Therefore take up the whole armor of God, that you may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Stand therefore, having girded your waist with truth, having put on the breastplate of righteousness,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and having shod your feet with the preparation of the gospel of peace;</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>above all, taking the shield of faith with which you will be able to quench all the fiery darts of the wicked one.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And take the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God;</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 17:12-19  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>12</dt><dd>Then as He entered a certain village, there met Him ten men who were lepers, who stood afar off.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And they lifted up their voices and said, “Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>So when He saw them, He said to them, “Go, show yourselves to the priests.” And so it was that as they went, they were cleansed.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And one of them, when he saw that he was healed, returned, and with a loud voice glorified God,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>and fell down on his face at His feet, giving Him thanks. And he was a Samaritan.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So Jesus answered and said, “Were there not ten cleansed? But where are the nine?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Were there not any found who returned to give glory to God except this foreigner?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And He said to him, “Arise, go your way. Your faith has made you well.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Timothy 2:20-26  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>20</dt><dd>But in a great house there are not only vessels of gold and silver, but also of wood and clay, some for honor and some for dishonor.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Therefore if anyone cleanses himself from the latter, he will be a vessel for honor, sanctified and useful for the Master, prepared for every good work.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Flee also youthful lusts; but pursue righteousness, faith, love, peace with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>But avoid foolish and ignorant disputes, knowing that they generate strife.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And a servant of the Lord must not quarrel but be gentle to all, able to teach, patient,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>in humility correcting those who are in opposition, if God perhaps will grant them repentance, so that they may know the truth,</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>and that they may come to their senses and escape the snare of the devil, having been taken captive by him to do his will.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 8:11-21  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Then the Pharisees came out and began to dispute with Him, seeking from Him a sign from heaven, testing Him.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But He sighed deeply in His spirit, and said, “Why does this generation seek a sign? Assuredly, I say to you, no sign shall be given to this generation.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And He left them, and getting into the boat again, departed to the other side.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now the disciples had forgotten to take bread, and they did not have more than one loaf with them in the boat.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Then He charged them, saying, “Take heed, beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the leaven of Herod.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And they reasoned among themselves, saying, “It is because we have no bread.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But Jesus, being aware of it, said to them, “Why do you reason because you have no bread? Do you not yet perceive nor understand? Is your heart still hardened?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Having eyes, do you not see? And having ears, do you not hear? And do you not remember?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did you take up?” They said to Him, “Twelve.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>“Also, when I broke the seven for the four thousand, how many large baskets full of fragments did you take up?” And they said, “Seven.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So He said to them, “How is it you do not understand?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Timothy 3:16-4:4  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>All Scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>that the man of God may be complete, thoroughly equipped for every good work.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>I charge you therefore before God and the Lord Jesus Christ, who will judge the living and the dead at His appearing and His kingdom:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Preach the word! Be ready in season and out of season. Convince, rebuke, exhort, with all longsuffering and teaching.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For the time will come when they will not endure sound doctrine, but according to their own desires, because they have itching ears, they will heap up for themselves teachers;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>and they will turn their ears away from the truth, and be turned aside to fables.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 8:22-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>Then He came to Bethsaida; and they brought a blind man to Him, and begged Him to touch him.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>So He took the blind man by the hand and led him out of the town. And when He had spit on his eyes and put His hands on him, He asked him if he saw anything.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And he looked up and said, “I see men like trees, walking.”</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Then He put His hands on his eyes again and made him look up. And he was restored and saw everyone clearly.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Then He sent him away to his house, saying, “Neither go into the town, nor tell anyone in the town.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 3:1-9  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and no torment will ever touch them.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died, and their departure was thought to be affliction,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and their going from us to be their destruction; but they are at peace.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope is full of immortality.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Having been disciplined a little, they will receive great good, because God tested them and found them worthy of himself;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>like gold in the furnace he tried them, and like a sacrificial burnt offering he accepted them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>In the time of their visitation they will shine forth, and will run like sparks through the stubble.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>They will govern nations and rule over peoples, and the Lord will reign over them for ever.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Those who trust in him will understand truth, and the faithful will abide with him in love, because grace and mercy are upon his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 5:15-6:3  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But the righteous live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord; the Most High takes care of them.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Therefore they will receive a glorious crown and a beautiful diadem from the hand of the Lord, because with his right hand he will cover them, and with his arm he will shield them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>The Lord will take his zeal as his whole armor, and will arm all creation to repel his enemies;</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>he will put on righteousness as a breastplate, and wear impartial justice as a helmet;</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>he will take holiness as a invincible shield,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>and sharpen stern wrath for a sword, and creation will join with him to fight against the madmen.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim, and will leap to the target as from a well-drawn bow of clouds,</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>and hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult; the water of the sea will rage against them, and rivers will relentlessly overwhelm them;</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>a mighty wind will rise against them, and like a tempest it will winnow them away. Lawlessness will lay waste the whole earth, and evil-doing will overturn the thrones of rulers.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O judges of the ends of the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Give ear, you that rule over multitudes, and boast of many nations.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For your dominion was given you from the Lord, and your sovereignty from the Most High, who will search out your works and inquire into your plans.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Wisdom of Solomon 4:7-15  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>7</dt><dd>But the righteous man, though he die early, will be at rest.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For old age is not honored for length of time, nor measured by number of years;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>There was one who pleased God and was loved by him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>He was caught up lest evil change his understanding or guile deceive his soul.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and roving desire perverts the innocent mind.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for his soul was pleasing to the Lord, therefore he took him quickly from the midst of wickedness.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Yet the peoples saw and did not understand, nor take such a thing to heart, that God’s grace and mercy are with his elect, and he watches over his holy ones.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 11:27-30  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>All things have been delivered to Me by My Father, and no one knows the Son except the Father. Nor does anyone know the Father except the Son, and the one to whom the Son wills to reveal Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Come to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 5:22-6:2  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no law.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And those who are Christ’s have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Brethren, if a man is overtaken in any trespass, you who are spiritual restore such a one in a spirit of gentleness, considering yourself lest you also be tempted.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 6:17-23  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>And He came down with them and stood on a level place with a crowd of His disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear Him and be healed of their diseases,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>as well as those who were tormented with unclean spirits. And they were healed.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And the whole multitude sought to touch Him, for power went out from Him and healed them all.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then He lifted up His eyes toward His disciples, and said: “Blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you, and revile you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of Man’s sake.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Rejoice in that day and leap for joy! For indeed your reward is great in heaven, for in like manner their fathers did to the prophets.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 2 Timothy 4:9-22  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>Be diligent to come to me quickly;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>for Demas has forsaken me, having loved this present world, and has departed for Thessalonica – Crescens for Galatia, Titus for Dalmatia.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Only Luke is with me. Get Mark and bring him with you, for he is useful to me for ministry.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And Tychicus I have sent to Ephesus.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Bring the cloak that I left with Carpus at Troas when you come – and the books, especially the parchments.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Alexander the coppersmith did me much harm. May the Lord repay him according to his works.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>You also must beware of him, for he has greatly resisted our words.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>At my first defense no one stood with me, but all forsook me. May it not be charged against them.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>But the Lord stood with me and strengthened me, so that the message might be preached fully through me, and that all the Gentiles might hear. Also I was delivered out of the mouth of the lion.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And the Lord will deliver me from every evil work and preserve me for His heavenly kingdom. To Him be glory forever and ever. Amen!</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Greet Prisca and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Erastus stayed in Corinth, but Trophimus I have left in Miletus sick.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Do your utmost to come before winter. Eubulus greets you, as well as Pudens, Linus, Claudia, and all the brethren.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>The Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Grace be with you. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 8:30-34  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>30</dt><dd>Then He strictly warned them that they should tell no one about Him.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And He began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and after three days rise again.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>He spoke this word openly. Then Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>But when He had turned around and looked at His disciples, He rebuked Peter, saying, “Get behind Me, Satan! For you are not mindful of the things of God, but the things of men.”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>When He had called the people to Himself, with His disciples also, He said to them, “Whoever desires to come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow Me.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Titus 1:5-2:1  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>For this reason I left you in Crete, that you should set in order the things that are lacking, and appoint elders in every city as I commanded you – </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>if a man is blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children not accused of dissipation or insubordination.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For a bishop must be blameless, as a steward of God, not self-willed, not quick-tempered, not given to wine, not violent, not greedy for money,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>but hospitable, a lover of what is good, sober-minded, just, holy, self-controlled,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>holding fast the faithful word as he has been taught, that he may be able, by sound doctrine, both to exhort and convict those who contradict.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For there are many insubordinate, both idle talkers and deceivers, especially those of the circumcision,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>whose mouths must be stopped, who subvert whole households, teaching things which they ought not, for the sake of dishonest gain.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>One of them, a prophet of their own, said, “Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, lazy gluttons.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>This testimony is true. Therefore rebuke them sharply, that they may be sound in the faith,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>not giving heed to Jewish fables and commandments of men who turn from the truth.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>To the pure all things are pure, but to those who are defiled and unbelieving nothing is pure; but even their mind and conscience are defiled.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>They profess to know God, but in works they deny Him, being abominable, disobedient, and disqualified for every good work.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>But as for you, speak the things which are proper for sound doctrine:</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 9:10-16  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>So they kept this word to themselves, questioning what the rising from the dead meant.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And they asked Him, saying, “Why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then He answered and told them, “Indeed, Elijah is coming first and restores all things. And how is it written concerning the Son of Man, that He must suffer many things and be treated with contempt?</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But I say to you that Elijah has also come, and they did to him whatever they wished, as it is written of him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And when He came to the disciples, He saw a great multitude around them, and scribes disputing with them.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Immediately, when they saw Him, all the people were greatly amazed, and running to Him, greeted Him.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And He asked the scribes, “What are you discussing with them?”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Titus 1:15-2:10  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>To the pure all things are pure, but to those who are defiled and unbelieving nothing is pure; but even their mind and conscience are defiled.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>They profess to know God, but in works they deny Him, being abominable, disobedient, and disqualified for every good work.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>But as for you, speak the things which are proper for sound doctrine:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>that the older men be sober, reverent, temperate, sound in faith, in love, in patience;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>the older women likewise, that they be reverent in behavior, not slanderers, not given to much wine, teachers of good things – </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>that they admonish the young women to love their husbands, to love their children,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>to be discreet, chaste, homemakers, good, obedient to their own husbands, that the word of God may not be blasphemed.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Likewise, exhort the young men to be sober-minded,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>in all things showing yourself to be a pattern of good works; in doctrine showing integrity, reverence, incorruptibility, </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>sound speech that cannot be condemned, that one who is an opponent may be ashamed, having nothing evil to say of you. </dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Exhort bondservants to be obedient to their own masters, to be well pleasing in all things, not answering back,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>not pilfering, but showing all good fidelity, that they may adorn the doctrine of God our Savior in all things.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 9:33-41  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>Then He came to Capernaum. And when He was in the house He asked them, “What was it you disputed among yourselves on the road?”</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>But they kept silent, for on the road they had disputed among themselves who would be the greatest.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And He sat down, called the twelve, and said to them, “If anyone desires to be first, he shall be last of all and servant of all.”</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Then He took a little child and set him in the midst of them. And when He had taken him in His arms, He said to them,</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>“Whoever receives one of these little children in My name receives Me; and whoever receives Me, receives not Me but Him who sent Me.”</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Now John answered Him, saying, “Teacher, we saw someone who does not follow us casting out demons in Your name, and we forbade him because he does not follow us.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But Jesus said, “Do not forbid him, for no one who works a miracle in My name can soon afterward speak evil of Me.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>For he who is not against us is on our side.</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>For whoever gives you a cup of water to drink in My name, because you belong to Christ, assuredly, I say to you, he will by no means lose his reward.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 1:16-23  (Epistle)
