readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>do not cease to give thanks for you, making mention of you in my prayers:</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give to you the spirit of wisdom and revelation in the knowledge of Him,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>the eyes of your understanding being enlightened; that you may know what is the hope of His calling, what are the riches of the glory of His inheritance in the saints,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>and what is the exceeding greatness of His power toward us who believe, according to the working of His mighty power</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>which He worked in Christ when He raised Him from the dead and seated Him at His right hand in the heavenly places,</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>far above all principality and power and might and dominion, and every name that is named, not only in this age but also in that which is to come.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And He put all things under His feet, and gave Him to be head over all things to the church,</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>which is His body, the fullness of Him who fills all in all.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 14:1-11  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now it happened, as He went into the house of one of the rulers of the Pharisees to eat bread on the Sabbath, that they watched Him closely.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And behold, there was a certain man before Him who had dropsy.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And Jesus, answering, spoke to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, “Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?” </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>But they kept silent. And He took him and healed him, and let him go.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then He answered them, saying, “Which of you, having a donkey or an ox that has fallen into a pit, will not immediately pull him out on the Sabbath day?”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And they could not answer Him regarding these things.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>So He told a parable to those who were invited, when He noted how they chose the best places, saying to them:</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“When you are invited by anyone to a wedding feast, do not sit down in the best place, lest one more honorable than you be invited by him;</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>and he who invited you and him come and say to you, ‘Give place to this man,’ and then you begin with shame to take the lowest place.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>But when you are invited, go and sit down in the lowest place, so that when he who invited you comes he may say to you, ‘Friend, go up higher.’ Then you will have glory in the presence of those who sit at the table with you.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 24:36-53  (6th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>36</dt><dd>Now as they said these things, Jesus Himself stood in the midst of them, and said to them, “Peace to you.”</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>But they were terrified and frightened, and supposed they had seen a spirit.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>And He said to them, “Why are you troubled? And why do doubts arise in your hearts?</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>Behold My hands and My feet, that it is I Myself. Handle Me and see, for a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see I have.”</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His feet. </dd><dt>41</dt><dd>But while they still did not believe for joy, and marveled, He said to them, “Have you any food here?”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>So they gave Him a piece of a broiled fish and some honeycomb. </dd><dt>43</dt><dd>And He took it and ate in their presence.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “These are the words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that all things must be fulfilled which were written in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms concerning Me.”</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>And He opened their understanding, that they might comprehend the Scriptures.</dd><dt>46</dt><dd>Then He said to them, “Thus it is written, and thus it was necessary for the Christ to suffer and to rise from the dead the third day,</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>and that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in His name to all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>And you are witnesses of these things.</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>Behold, I send the Promise of My Father upon you; but tarry in the city of Jerusalem until you are endued with power from on high.”</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>And He led them out as far as Bethany, and He lifted up His hands and blessed them.</dd><dt>51</dt><dd>Now it came to pass, while He blessed them, that He was parted from them and carried up into heaven.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>And they worshiped Him, and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>and were continually in the temple praising and blessing God. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Colossians 3:4-11  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>When Christ who is our life appears, then you also will appear with Him in glory.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Therefore put to death your members which are on the earth: fornication, uncleanness, passion, evil desire, and covetousness, which is idolatry.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Because of these things the wrath of God is coming upon the sons of disobedience,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>in which you yourselves once walked when you lived in them.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But now you yourselves are to put off all these: anger, wrath, malice, blasphemy, filthy language out of your mouth.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Do not lie to one another, since you have put off the old man with his deeds,</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>and have put on the new man who is renewed in knowledge according to the image of Him who created him,</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>where there is neither Greek nor Jew, circumcised nor uncircumcised, barbarian, Scythian, slave nor free, but Christ is all and in all.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 14:16-24  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>16</dt><dd>Then He said to him, “A certain man gave a great supper and invited many,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>and sent his servant at supper time to say to those who were invited, ‘Come, for all things are now ready.’</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>But they all with one accord began to make excuses. The first said to him, ‘I have bought a piece of ground, and I must go and see it. I ask you to have me excused.’</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>And another said, ‘I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going to test them. I ask you to have me excused.’</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Still another said, ‘I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.’</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>So that servant came and reported these things to his master. Then the master of the house, being angry, said to his servant, ‘Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in here the poor and the maimed and the lame and the blind.’</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And the servant said, ‘Master, it is done as you commanded, and still there is room.’</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then the master said to the servant, ‘Go out into the highways and hedges, and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>’For I say to you that none of those men who were invited shall taste my supper.’”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 3:5-11 17-19  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>5</dt><dd>And Moses indeed was faithful in all His house as a servant, for a testimony of those things which would be spoken afterward,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>but Christ as a Son over His own house, whose house we are if we hold fast the confidence and the rejoicing of the hope firm to the end.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore, as the Holy Spirit says: “Today, if you will hear His voice,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion, in the day of trial in the wilderness,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>where your fathers tested Me, tried Me, and saw My works forty years.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Therefore I was angry with that generation, and said, ‘They always go astray in their heart, and they have not known My ways.’</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So I swore in My wrath, ‘They shall not enter My rest.’”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Now with whom was He angry forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose corpses fell in the wilderness?</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And to whom did He swear that they would not enter His rest, but to those who did not obey?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>So we see that they could not enter in because of unbelief.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 9:42-10:1  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>42</dt><dd>But whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in Me to stumble, it would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck, and he were thrown into the sea.</dd><dt>43</dt><dd>If your hand causes you to sin, cut it off. It is better for you to enter into life maimed, rather than having two hands, to go to hell, into the fire that shall never be quenched – </dd><dt>44</dt><dd>where ‘Their worm does not die, and the fire is not quenched.’ </dd><dt>45</dt><dd>And if your foot causes you to sin, cut it off. It is better for you to enter life lame, rather than having two feet, to be cast into hell, into the fire that shall never be quenched – </dd><dt>46</dt><dd>where ‘Their worm does not die, and the fire is not quenched.’ </dd><dt>47</dt><dd>And if your eye causes you to sin, pluck it out. It is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with one eye, rather than having two eyes, to be cast into hell fire – </dd><dt>48</dt><dd>where ‘Their worm does not die, and the fire is not quenched.’ </dd><dt>49</dt><dd>For everyone will be seasoned with fire, and every sacrifice will be seasoned with salt.</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Salt is good, but if the salt loses its flavor, how will you season it? Have salt in yourselves, and have peace with one another.”</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then He arose from there and came to the region of Judea by the other side of the Jordan. And multitudes gathered to Him again, and as He was accustomed, He taught them again.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 4:1-13  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore, since a promise remains of entering His rest, let us fear lest any of you seem to have come short of it.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For indeed the gospel was preached to us as well as to them; but the word which they heard did not profit them, not being mixed with faith in those who heard it.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For we who have believed do enter that rest, as He has said: “So I swore in My wrath, ‘They shall not enter My rest,’” although the works were finished from the foundation of the world.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For He has spoken in a certain place of the seventh day in this way: “And God rested on the seventh day from all His works”;</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>and again in this place: “They shall not enter My rest.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Since therefore it remains that some must enter it, and those to whom it was first preached did not enter because of disobedience,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>again He designates a certain day, saying in David, “Today,” after such a long time, as it has been said: “Today, if you will hear His voice, do not harden your hearts.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For if Joshua had given them rest, then He would not afterward have spoken of another day.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>There remains therefore a rest for the people of God.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For he who has entered His rest has himself also ceased from his works as God did from His.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Let us therefore be diligent to enter that rest, lest anyone fall according to the same example of disobedience.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For the word of God is living and powerful, and sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing even to the division of soul and spirit, and of joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And there is no creature hidden from His sight, but all things are naked and open to the eyes of Him to whom we must give account.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 10:2-12  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>The Pharisees came and asked Him, “Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?” testing Him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And He answered and said to them, “What did Moses command you?”</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>They said, “Moses permitted a man to write a certificate of divorce, and to dismiss her.”</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And Jesus answered and said to them, “Because of the hardness of your heart he wrote you this precept.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But from the beginning of the creation, God ‘made them male and female.’ </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife,</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>‘and the two shall become one flesh’; so then they are no longer two, but one flesh.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Therefore what God has joined together, let not man separate.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>In the house His disciples also asked Him again about the same matter.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>So He said to them, “Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And if a woman divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 5:11-6:8  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>We have much to say about Melchizedek, which is hard to explain, since you have become dull in hearing.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you again the first principles of the oracles of God; and you have come to need milk and not solid food.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For everyone who partakes only of milk is unskilled in the word of righteousness, for he is a babe.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But solid food belongs to those who are of full age, that is, those who by reason of use have their senses exercised to discern both good and evil.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore, leaving the discussion of the elementary principles of Christ, let us go on to perfection, not laying again the foundation of repentance from dead works and of faith toward God,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>of the doctrine of baptisms, of laying on of hands, of resurrection of the dead, and of eternal judgment.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And this we will do if God permits.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For it is impossible for those who were once enlightened, and have tasted the heavenly gift, and have become partakers of the Holy Spirit,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>and have tasted the good word of God and the powers of the age to come,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>if they fall away, to renew them again to repentance, since they crucify again for themselves the Son of God, and put Him to an open shame.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>For the earth which drinks in the rain that often comes upon it, and bears herbs useful for those by whom it is cultivated, receives a blessing from God;</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>but if it bears thorns and briers, it is rejected and near to being cursed, whose end is to be burned.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 10:11-16  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>So He said to them, “Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And if a woman divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then they brought little children to Him, that He might touch them; but the disciples rebuked those who brought them.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>But when Jesus saw it, He was greatly displeased and said to them, “Let the little children come to Me, and do not forbid them; for of such is the kingdom of God.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Assuredly, I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God as a little child will by no means enter it.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And He took them up in His arms, laid His hands on them, and blessed them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:1-6  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>to whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of all, first being translated “king of righteousness,” and then also king of Salem, meaning “king of peace,”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but made like the Son of God, remains a priest continually.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Now consider how great this man was, to whom even the patriarch Abraham gave a tenth of the spoils.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And indeed those who are of the sons of Levi, who receive the priesthood, have a commandment to receive tithes from the people according to the law, that is, from their brethren, though they have come from the loins of Abraham;</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>but he whose genealogy is not derived from them received tithes from Abraham and blessed him who had the promises.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 10:17-27  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>17</dt><dd>Now as He was going out on the road, one came running, knelt before Him, and asked Him, “Good Teacher, what shall I do that I may inherit eternal life?”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>So Jesus said to him, “Why do you call Me good? No one is good but One, that is, God.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>You know the commandments: ‘Do not commit adultery,’ ‘Do not murder,’ ‘Do not steal,’ ‘Do not bear false witness,’ ‘Do not defraud,’ ‘Honor your father and your mother.’” </dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And he answered and said to Him, “Teacher, all these things I have kept from my youth.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then Jesus, looking at him, loved him, and said to him, “One thing you lack: Go your way, sell whatever you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, take up the cross, and follow Me.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But he was sad at this word, and went away sorrowful, for he had great possessions.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then Jesus looked around and said to His disciples, “How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And the disciples were astonished at His words. But Jesus answered again and said to them, “Children, how hard it is for those who trust in riches to enter the kingdom of God!</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And they were greatly astonished, saying among themselves, “Who then can be saved?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But Jesus looked at them and said, “With men it is impossible, but not with God; for with God all things are possible.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Micah 5:2-4  (1st Hour Prophecy)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>“But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah, though you are little among the thousands of Judah, yet out of you shall come forth to Me the One to be Ruler in Israel,    Whose goings forth are from of old, from everlasting.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore He shall give them up, until the time that she who is in labor has given birth; then the remnant of His brethren shall return to the children of Israel.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And He shall stand and feed His flock in the strength of the LORD, in the majesty of the name of the LORD His God; and they shall abide, for now He shall be great to the ends of the earth.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 1:1-12  (1st Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>God, who at various times and in various ways spoke in time past to the fathers by the prophets,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>has in these last days spoken to us by His Son, whom He has appointed heir of all things, through whom also He made the worlds;</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>who being the brightness of His glory and the express image of His person, and upholding all things by the word of His power, when He had by Himself purged our sins, sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>having become so much better than the angels, as He has by inheritance obtained a more excellent name than they.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For to which of the angels did He ever say: “You are My Son, today I have begotten You”? And again: “I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to Me a Son”?</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But when He again brings the firstborn into the world, He says: “Let all the angels of God worship Him.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And of the angels He says: “Who makes His angels spirits and His ministers a flame of fire.”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But to the Son He says: “Your throne, O God, is forever and ever; a scepter of righteousness is the scepter of Your kingdom.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>You have loved righteousness and hated lawlessness; therefore God, Your God, has anointed You with the oil of gladness more than Your companions.”</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And: “You, LORD, in the beginning laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the work of Your hands.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>They will perish, but You remain; and they will all grow old like a garment;</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>like a cloak You will fold them up, and they will be changed. But You are the same, and Your years will not fail.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 1:18-25  (1st Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Now the birth of Jesus Christ was as follows: After His mother Mary was betrothed to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then Joseph her husband, being a just man, and not wanting to make her a public example, was minded to put her away secretly.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But while he thought about these things, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, “Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take to you Mary your wife, for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And she will bring forth a Son, and you shall call His name JESUS, for He will save His people from their sins.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So all this was done that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Lord through the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>“Behold, the virgin shall be with child, and bear a Son, and they shall call His name Immanuel, which is translated, ‘God with us.’”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then Joseph, being aroused from sleep, did as the angel of the Lord commanded him and took to him his wife,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>and did not know her till she had brought forth her firstborn Son. And he called His name JESUS.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jeremiah (Baruch 3:35-4:4)  (3rd Hour Prophecy)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>This is our God; no other can be compared to him!</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>He found the whole way to knowledge, and gave her to Jacob his servant and to Israel whom He loved.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Afterward she appeared on earth and lived among men.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>She is the book of the commandments of God, and the law that endures for ever. All who hold fast will live, and those who forsake her will die.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Turn, O Jacob, and take her; walk toward the shining of her light.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Do not give your glory to another, or your advantage to an alien people.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Happy we are, O Israel, for we know what is pleasing to God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 3:23-29  (3rd Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>But before faith came, we were kept under guard by the law, kept for the faith which would afterward be revealed.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore the law was our tutor to bring us to Christ, that we might be justified by faith.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>But after faith has come, we are no longer under a tutor.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>For you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>For as many of you as were baptized into Christ have put on Christ.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is neither male nor female; for you are all one in Christ Jesus.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>And if you are Christ’s, then you are Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 2:1-20  (3rd Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And it came to pass in those days that a decree went out from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be registered.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>This census first took place while Quirinius was governing Syria.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So all went to be registered, everyone to his own city.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judea, to the city of David, which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and lineage of David,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>to be registered with Mary, his betrothed wife, who was with child.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So it was, that while they were there, the days were completed for her to be delivered.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And she brought forth her firstborn Son, and wrapped Him in swaddling cloths, and laid Him in a manger, because there was no room for them in the inn.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Now there were in the same country shepherds living out in the fields, keeping watch over their flock by night.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And behold, an angel of the Lord stood before them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were greatly afraid.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid, for behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy which will be to all people.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For there is born to you this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And this will be the sign to you: You will find a Babe wrapped in swaddling cloths, lying in a manger.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God and saying:</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, goodwill toward men!” </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So it was, when the angels had gone away from them into heaven, that the shepherds said to one another, “Let us now go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has come to pass, which the Lord has made known to us.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And they came with haste and found Mary and Joseph, and the Babe lying in a manger.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Now when they had seen Him, they made widely known the saying which was told them concerning this Child.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And all those who heard it marveled at those things which were told them by the shepherds.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But Mary kept all these things and pondered them in her heart.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things that they had heard and seen, as it was told them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 7:10-16 8:1-4 9-10  (6th Hour Prophecy)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Moreover the Lord spoke again to Ahaz, saying, </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Ask a sign for yourself from the Lord your God; ask it either in the depth or in the height above.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, nor will I test the Lord!”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then he said, “Hear now, O house of David! Is it a small thing for you to weary men, but will you weary my God also?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a Son, and shall call His name Immanuel.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Curds and honey He shall eat, that He may know to refuse the evil and choose the good.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“For before the Child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land that you dread will be forsaken by both her kings.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Moreover the Lord said to me, “Take a large scroll, and write on it with a man’s pen concerning Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“And I will take for Myself faithful witnesses to record, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Call his name Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“for before the child shall have knowledge to cry ‘My father’ and ‘My mother,’ the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken away before the king of Assyria.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“Be shattered, O you peoples, and be broken in pieces! Give ear, all you from far countries. Gird yourselves, but be broken in pieces; gird yourselves, but be broken in pieces.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Take counsel together, but it will come to nothing; speak the word, but it will not stand, for God is with us.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 1:10-2:3  (6th Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>And: “You, LORD, in the beginning laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the work of Your hands.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>They will perish, but You remain; and they will all grow old like a garment;</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>like a cloak You will fold them up, and they will be changed. But You are the same, and Your years will not fail.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But to which of the angels has He ever said: “Sit at My right hand, till I make Your enemies Your footstool”?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Are they not all ministering spirits sent forth to minister for those who will inherit salvation?</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore we must give the more earnest heed to the things we have heard, lest we drift away.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For if the word spoken through angels proved steadfast, and every transgression and disobedience received a just reward,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>how shall we escape if we neglect so great a salvation, which at the first began to be spoken by the Lord, and was confirmed to us by those who heard Him,</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 2:1-12  (6th Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now after Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea in the days of Herod the king, behold, wise men from the East came to Jerusalem,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>saying, “Where is He who has been born King of the Jews? For we have seen His star in the East and have come to worship Him.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>When Herod the king heard this, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he had gathered all the chief priests and scribes of the people together, he inquired of them where the Christ was to be born.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>So they said to him, “In Bethlehem of Judea, for thus it is written by the prophet:</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>‘But you, Bethlehem, in the land of Judah, Are not the least among the rulers of Judah; For out of you shall come a Ruler Who will shepherd My people Israel.’” </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Herod, when he had secretly called the wise men, determined from them what time the star appeared.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And he sent them to Bethlehem and said, “Go and search carefully for the young Child, and when you have found Him, bring back word to me, that I may come and worship Him also.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>When they heard the king, they departed; and behold, the star which they had seen in the East went before them, till it came and stood over where the young Child was.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When they saw the star, they rejoiced with exceedingly great joy.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when they had come into the house, they saw the young Child with Mary His mother, and fell down and worshiped Him. And when they had opened their treasures, they presented gifts to Him: gold, frankincense, and myrrh.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then, being divinely warned in a dream that they should not return to Herod, they departed for their own country another way.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 9:6-7  (9th Hour Prophecy)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>For unto us a Child is born, unto us a Son is given; and the government will be upon His shoulder. And His Name will be called Wonderful, Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Of the increase of His government and peace there will be no end, upon the throne of David and over His kingdom, to order it and establish it with judgment and justice from that time forward, even forever. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will perform this.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 2:11-18  (9th Hour Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>For both He who sanctifies and those who are being sanctified are all of one, for which reason He is not ashamed to call them brethren,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>saying: “I will declare Your name to My brethren; in the midst of the assembly I will sing praise to You.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And again: “I will put My trust in Him.” And again: “Here am I and the children whom God has given Me.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Inasmuch then as the children have partaken of flesh and blood, He Himself likewise shared in the same, that through death He might destroy him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and release those who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For indeed He does not give aid to angels, but He does give aid to the seed of Abraham.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, in all things He had to be made like His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things pertaining to God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For in that He Himself has suffered, being tempted, He is able to aid those who are tempted.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 2:13-23  (9th Hour Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Now when they had departed, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream, saying, “Arise, take the young Child and His mother, flee to Egypt, and stay there until I bring you word; for Herod will seek the young Child to destroy Him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>When he arose, he took the young Child and His mother by night and departed for Egypt,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and was there until the death of Herod, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Lord through the prophet, saying, “Out of Egypt I called My Son.” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Herod, when he saw that he was deceived by the wise men, was exceedingly angry; and he sent forth and put to death all the male children who were in Bethlehem and in all its districts, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had determined from the wise men.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then was fulfilled what was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“A voice was heard in Ramah, lamentation, weeping, and great mourning, Rachel weeping for her children, refusing to be comforted, because they are no more.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Now when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>saying, “Arise, take the young Child and His mother, and go to the land of Israel, for those who sought the young Child’s life are dead.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then he arose, took the young Child and His mother, and came into the land of Israel.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But when he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea instead of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there. And being warned by God in a dream, he turned aside into the region of Galilee.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, “He shall be called a Nazarene.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 7:18-25  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>For on the one hand there is an annulling of the former commandment because of its weakness and unprofitableness,</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>for the law made nothing perfect; on the other hand, there is the bringing in of a better hope, through which we draw near to God.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And inasmuch as He was not made priest without an oath</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>(for they have become priests without an oath, but He with an oath by Him who said to Him: “The LORD has sworn and will not relent, ‘You are a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek’”),</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>by so much more Jesus has become a surety of a better covenant.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Also there were many priests, because they were prevented by death from continuing.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>But He, because He continues forever, has an unchangeable priesthood.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>Therefore He is also able to save to the uttermost those who come to God through Him, since He always lives to make intercession for them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 10:23-32  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>23</dt><dd>Then Jesus looked around and said to His disciples, “How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>And the disciples were astonished at His words. But Jesus answered again and said to them, “Children, how hard it is for those who trust in riches to enter the kingdom of God!</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.”</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>And they were greatly astonished, saying among themselves, “Who then can be saved?”</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But Jesus looked at them and said, “With men it is impossible, but not with God; for with God all things are possible.”</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>Then Peter began to say to Him, “See, we have left all and followed You.”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>So Jesus answered and said, “Assuredly, I say to you, there is no one who has left house or brothers or sisters or father or mother or wife or children or lands, for My sake and the gospel’s,</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>who shall not receive a hundredfold now in this time – houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and children and lands, with persecutions – and in the age to come, eternal life.</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>But many who are first will be last, and the last first.”</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>Now they were on the road, going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was going before them; and they were amazed. And as they followed they were afraid. Then He took the twelve aside again and began to tell them the things that would happen to Him:</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 3:8-12  (Epistle Saturday Before)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>And the Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached the gospel to Abraham beforehand, saying, “In you all the nations shall be blessed.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>So then those who are of faith are blessed with believing Abraham.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>For as many as are of the works of the law are under the curse; for it is written, “Cursed is everyone who does not continue in all things which are written in the book of the law, to do them.”</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>But that no one is justified by the law in the sight of God is evident, for “the just shall live by faith.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Yet the law is not of faith, but “the man who does them shall live by them.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 13:18-29  (Gospel Saturday Before)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Then He said, “What is the kingdom of God like? And to what shall I compare it?</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>It is like a mustard seed, which a man took and put in his garden; and it grew and became a large tree, and the birds of the air nested in its branches.”</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>And again He said, “To what shall I liken the kingdom of God?</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>It is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal till it was all leavened.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>And He went through the cities and villages, teaching, and journeying toward Jerusalem.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>Then one said to Him, “Lord, are there few who are saved?” And He said to them,</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>“Strive to enter through the narrow gate, for many, I say to you, will seek to enter and will not be able.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>When once the Master of the house has risen up and shut the door, and you begin to stand outside and knock at the door, saying, ‘Lord, Lord, open for us,’ and He will answer and say to you, ‘I do not know you, where you are from,’</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>then you will begin to say, ‘We ate and drank in Your presence, and You taught in our streets.’</dd><dt>27</dt><dd>But He will say, ‘I tell you I do not know you, where you are from. Depart from Me, all you workers of iniquity.’</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and yourselves thrust out.</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>They will come from the east and the west, from the north and the south, and sit down in the kingdom of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 2:11-13  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore remember that you, once Gentiles in the flesh – who are called Uncircumcision by what is called the Circumcision made in the flesh by hands – </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>that at that time you were without Christ, being aliens from the commonwealth of Israel and strangers from the covenants of promise, having no hope and without God in the world.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>But now in Christ Jesus you who once were far off have been brought near by the blood of Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 16:10-15  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>He who is faithful in what is least is faithful also in much; and he who is unjust in what is least is unjust also in much.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Therefore if you have not been faithful in the unrighteous mammon, who will commit to your trust the true riches?</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And if you have not been faithful in what is another man’s, who will give you what is your own?</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>No servant can serve two masters; for either he will hate the one and love the other, or else he will be loyal to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now the Pharisees, who were lovers of money, also heard all these things, and they derided Him.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And He said to them, “You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts. For what is highly esteemed among men is an abomination in the sight of God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Genesis 1:1-13  (Vespers 1st  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The earth was without form, and void; and darkness was on the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the face of the waters.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be light”; and there was light.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And God saw the light, that it was good; and God divided the light from the darkness.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>God called the light Day, and the darkness He called Night. So the evening and the morning were the first day.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Thus God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament; and it was so.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And God called the firmament Heaven. So the evening and the morning were the second day.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the waters under the heavens be gathered together into one place, and let the dry land appear”; and it was so.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And God called the dry land Earth, and the gathering together of the waters He called Seas. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then God said, “Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb that yields seed, and the fruit tree that yields fruit according to its kind, whose seed is in itself, on the earth”; and it was so.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And the earth brought forth grass, the herb that yields seed according to its kind, and the tree that yields fruit, whose seed is in itself according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>So the evening and the morning were the third day.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Numbers 24:2-3 5-9 17-18  (Vespers 2nd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>2</dt><dd>And Balaam raised his eyes, and saw Israel encamped according to their tribes; and the Spirit of God came upon him.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then he took up his oracle and said: “The utterance of Balaam the son of Beor, The utterance of the man whose eyes are opened,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>“How lovely are your tents, O Jacob! Your dwellings, O Israel!</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Like valleys that stretch out, Like gardens by the riverside, Like aloes planted by the LORD, Like cedars beside the waters.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>He shall pour water from his buckets, And his seed shall be in many waters. “His king shall be higher than Agag, And his kingdom shall be exalted.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>“God brings him out of Egypt; He has strength like a wild ox; He shall consume the nations, his enemies; He shall break their bones And pierce them with his arrows.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>‘He bows down, he lies down as a lion; And as a lion, who shall rouse him?’ “ Blessed is he who blesses you, And cursed is he who curses you.”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>“I see Him, but not now; I behold Him, but not near; A Star shall come out of Jacob; A Scepter shall rise out of Israel, And batter the brow of Moab, And destroy all the sons of tumult.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“And Edom shall be a possession; Seir also, his enemies, shall be a possession, While Israel does valiantly.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Micah 4:6-7 5:2-4  (Vespers 3rd  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>In that day, declares the LORD, I will gather the lame; I will assemble the exiles and those I have brought to grief.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>I will make the lame a remnant, those driven away a strong nation. The LORD will rule over them in Mount Zion from that day and forever.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah, though you are little among the thousands of Judah, yet out of you shall come forth to Me the One to be Ruler in Israel,    Whose goings forth are from of old, from everlasting.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Therefore He shall give them up, until the time that she who is in labor has given birth; then the remnant of His brethren shall return to the children of Israel.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And He shall stand and feed His flock in the strength of the LORD, in the majesty of the name of the LORD His God; and they shall abide, for now He shall be great to the ends of the earth.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 11:1-10  (Vespers 4th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>There shall come forth a Rod from the stem of Jesse, and a Branch shall grow out of his roots.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>The Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon Him, the Spirit of wisdom and understanding, the Spirit of counsel and might, the Spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the Lord.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>His delight is in the fear of the Lord, and He shall not judge by the sight of His eyes, nor decide by the hearing of His ears;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>but with righteousness He shall judge the poor, and decide with equity for the meek of the earth; He shall strike the earth with the rod of His mouth, and with the breath of His lips He shall slay the wicked.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Righteousness shall be the belt of His loins, and faithfulness the belt of His waist. </dd><dt>6</dt><dd>“The wolf also shall dwell with the lamb, the leopard shall lie down with the young goat, the calf and the young lion and the fatling together; and a little child shall lead them.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>The cow and the bear shall graze; their young ones shall lie down together; and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>The nursing child shall play by the cobra’s hole, and the weaned child shall put his hand in the viper’s den.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>They shall not hurt nor destroy in all My holy mountain, for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord as the waters cover the sea.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>“And in that day there shall be a Root of Jesse, who shall stand as a banner to the people; for the Gentiles shall seek Him, and His resting place shall be glorious.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Jeremiah (Baruch 3:35-4:4)  (Vespers 5th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>This is our God; no other can be compared to him!</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>He found the whole way to knowledge, and gave her to Jacob his servant and to Israel whom He loved.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Afterward she appeared on earth and lived among men.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>She is the book of the commandments of God, and the law that endures for ever. All who hold fast will live, and those who forsake her will die.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Turn, O Jacob, and take her; walk toward the shining of her light.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Do not give your glory to another, or your advantage to an alien people.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Happy we are, O Israel, for we know what is pleasing to God.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Daniel 2:31-36 44-45  (Vespers 6th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>31</dt><dd>“You, O king, were watching; and behold, a great image! This great image, whose splendor was excellent, stood before you; and its form was awesome.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>This image’s head was of fine gold, its chest and arms of silver, its belly and thighs of bronze,</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>its legs of iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of clay.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>You watched while a stone was cut out without hands, which struck the image on its feet of iron and clay, and broke them in pieces.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were crushed together, and became like chaff from the summer threshing floors; the wind carried them away so that no trace of them was found. And the stone that struck the image became a great mountain and filled the whole earth.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>“This is the dream. Now we will tell the interpretation of it before the king.</dd><dt>44</dt><dd>In the days of these kings the God of heaven will set up a kingdom which shall never be destroyed; and the kingdom shall not be left to other people; it shall break in pieces and consume all these kingdoms, and it shall stand forever.</dd><dt>45</dt><dd>Inasmuch as you saw that the stone was cut out of the mountain without hands, and that it broke in pieces the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver, and the gold – the great God has made known to the king what will come to pass after this. The dream is certain, and its interpretation is sure.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 9:6-7  (Vespers 7th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>6</dt><dd>For unto us a Child is born, unto us a Son is given; and the government will be upon His shoulder. And His Name will be called Wonderful, Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Of the increase of His government and peace there will be no end, upon the throne of David and over His kingdom, to order it and establish it with judgment and justice from that time forward, even forever. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will perform this.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Isaiah 7:10-16 8:1-4 9-10  (Vespers 8th  reading)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>10</dt><dd>Moreover the Lord spoke again to Ahaz, saying, </dd><dt>11</dt><dd>“Ask a sign for yourself from the Lord your God; ask it either in the depth or in the height above.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, nor will I test the Lord!”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then he said, “Hear now, O house of David! Is it a small thing for you to weary men, but will you weary my God also?</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a Son, and shall call His name Immanuel.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>“Curds and honey He shall eat, that He may know to refuse the evil and choose the good.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“For before the Child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land that you dread will be forsaken by both her kings.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Moreover the Lord said to me, “Take a large scroll, and write on it with a man’s pen concerning Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>“And I will take for Myself faithful witnesses to record, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Then I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Call his name Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>“for before the child shall have knowledge to cry ‘My father’ and ‘My mother,’ the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be taken away before the king of Assyria.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>“Be shattered, O you peoples, and be broken in pieces! Give ear, all you from far countries. Gird yourselves, but be broken in pieces; gird yourselves, but be broken in pieces.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Take counsel together, but it will come to nothing; speak the word, but it will not stand, for God is with us.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:1-10  (7th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now on the first day of the week Mary Magdalene went to the tomb early, while it was still dark, and saw that the stone had been taken away from the tomb.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Then she ran and came to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple, whom Jesus loved, and said to them, “They have taken away the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid Him.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Peter therefore went out, and the other disciple, and were going to the tomb.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>So they both ran together, and the other disciple outran Peter and came to the tomb first.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And he, stooping down and looking in, saw the linen cloths lying there; yet he did not go in.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Then Simon Peter came, following him, and went into the tomb; and he saw the linen cloths lying there,</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>and the handkerchief that had been around His head, not lying with the linen cloths, but folded together in a place by itself.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Then the other disciple, who came to the tomb first, went in also; and he saw and believed.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>For as yet they did not know the Scripture, that He must rise again from the dead.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the disciples went away again to their own homes.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 3:15-22  (Epistle At Vespers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>Brethren, I speak in the manner of men: Though it is only a man’s covenant, yet if it is confirmed, no one annuls or adds to it.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Now to Abraham and his Seed were the promises made. He does not say, “And to seeds,” as of many, but as of one, “And to your Seed,” who is Christ.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>And this I say, that the law, which was four hundred and thirty years later, cannot annul the covenant that was confirmed before by God in Christ, that it should make the promise of no effect.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For if the inheritance is of the law, it is no longer of promise; but God gave it to Abraham by promise.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>What purpose then does the law serve? It was added because of transgressions, till the Seed should come to whom the promise was made; and it was appointed through angels by the hand of a mediator.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Now a mediator does not mediate for one only, but God is one.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Is the law then against the promises of God? Certainly not! For if there had been a law given which could have given life, truly righteousness would have been by the law.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But the Scripture has confined all under sin, that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 2:1-20  (Gospel At Vespers)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>And it came to pass in those days that a decree went out from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be registered.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>This census first took place while Quirinius was governing Syria.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>So all went to be registered, everyone to his own city.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judea, to the city of David, which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and lineage of David,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>to be registered with Mary, his betrothed wife, who was with child.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So it was, that while they were there, the days were completed for her to be delivered.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And she brought forth her firstborn Son, and wrapped Him in swaddling cloths, and laid Him in a manger, because there was no room for them in the inn.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Now there were in the same country shepherds living out in the fields, keeping watch over their flock by night.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>And behold, an angel of the Lord stood before them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were greatly afraid.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Then the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid, for behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy which will be to all people.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>For there is born to you this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And this will be the sign to you: You will find a Babe wrapped in swaddling cloths, lying in a manger.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God and saying:</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>“Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, goodwill toward men!” </dd><dt>15</dt><dd>So it was, when the angels had gone away from them into heaven, that the shepherds said to one another, “Let us now go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has come to pass, which the Lord has made known to us.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And they came with haste and found Mary and Joseph, and the Babe lying in a manger.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Now when they had seen Him, they made widely known the saying which was told them concerning this Child.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>And all those who heard it marveled at those things which were told them by the shepherds.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But Mary kept all these things and pondered them in her heart.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>Then the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things that they had heard and seen, as it was told them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 11:9-10 17-23 32-40  (Epistle Sunday Before)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>9</dt><dd>By faith he dwelt in the land of promise as in a foreign country, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise;</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>for he waited for the city which has foundations, whose builder and maker is God.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>By faith Abraham, when he was tested, offered up Isaac, and he who had received the promises offered up his only begotten son,</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>of whom it was said, “In Isaac your seed shall be called,”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>concluding that God was able to raise him up, even from the dead, from which he also received him in a figurative sense.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>By faith Jacob, when he was dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph, and worshiped, leaning on the top of his staff.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>By faith Joseph, when he was dying, made mention of the departure of the children of Israel, and gave instructions concerning his bones.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>By faith Moses, when he was born, was hidden three months by his parents, because they saw he was a beautiful child; and they were not afraid of the king’s command.</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>And what more shall I say? For the time would fail me to tell of Gideon and Barak and Samson and Jephthah, also of David and Samuel and the prophets:</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>who through faith subdued kingdoms, worked righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakness were made strong, became valiant in battle, turned to flight the armies of the aliens.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>Women received their dead raised to life again. Others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Still others had trial of mockings and scourgings, yes, and of chains and imprisonment.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>They were stoned, they were sawn in two, were tempted, were slain with the sword. They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented – </dd><dt>38</dt><dd>of whom the world was not worthy. They wandered in deserts and mountains, in dens and caves of the earth.</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>And all these, having obtained a good testimony through faith, did not receive the promise,</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>God having provided something better for us, that they should not be made perfect apart from us.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 1:1-25  (Gospel Sunday Before)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>The book of the genealogy of Jesus Christ, the Son of David, the Son of Abraham:</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Abraham begot Isaac, Isaac begot Jacob, and Jacob begot Judah and his brothers.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>Judah begot Perez and Zerah by Tamar, Perez begot Hezron, and Hezron begot Ram.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Ram begot Amminadab, Amminadab begot Nahshon, and Nahshon begot Salmon.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Salmon begot Boaz by Rahab, Boaz begot Obed by Ruth, Obed begot Jesse,</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>and Jesse begot David the king. David the king begot Solomon by her who had been the wife of Uriah.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Solomon begot Rehoboam, Rehoboam begot Abijah, and Abijah begot Asa. </dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Asa begot Jehoshaphat, Jehoshaphat begot Joram, and Joram begot Uzziah.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Uzziah begot Jotham, Jotham begot Ahaz, and Ahaz begot Hezekiah.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Hezekiah begot Manasseh, Manasseh begot Amon, and Amon begot Josiah.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Josiah begot Jeconiah and his brothers about the time they were carried away to Babylon.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And after they were brought to Babylon, Jeconiah begot Shealtiel, and Shealtiel begot Zerubbabel.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Zerubbabel begot Abiud, Abiud begot Eliakim, and Eliakim begot Azor.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Azor begot Zadok, Zadok begot Achim, and Achim begot Eliud.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Eliud begot Eleazar, Eleazar begot Matthan, and Matthan begot Jacob.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And Jacob begot Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus who is called Christ.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>So all the generations from Abraham to David are fourteen generations, from David until the captivity in Babylon are fourteen generations, and from the captivity in Babylon until the Christ are fourteen generations.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Now the birth of Jesus Christ was as follows: After His mother Mary was betrothed to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then Joseph her husband, being a just man, and not wanting to make her a public example, was minded to put her away secretly.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But while he thought about these things, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, “Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take to you Mary your wife, for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And she will bring forth a Son, and you shall call His name JESUS, for He will save His people from their sins.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So all this was done that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Lord through the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>“Behold, the virgin shall be with child, and bear a Son, and they shall call His name Immanuel, which is translated, ‘God with us.’”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then Joseph, being aroused from sleep, did as the angel of the Lord commanded him and took to him his wife,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>and did not know her till she had brought forth her firstborn Son. And he called His name JESUS.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 1:18-25  (Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>18</dt><dd>Now the birth of Jesus Christ was as follows: After His mother Mary was betrothed to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Then Joseph her husband, being a just man, and not wanting to make her a public example, was minded to put her away secretly.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>But while he thought about these things, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, “Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take to you Mary your wife, for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Spirit.</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>And she will bring forth a Son, and you shall call His name JESUS, for He will save His people from their sins.”</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>So all this was done that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Lord through the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>“Behold, the virgin shall be with child, and bear a Son, and they shall call His name Immanuel, which is translated, ‘God with us.’”</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Then Joseph, being aroused from sleep, did as the angel of the Lord commanded him and took to him his wife,</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>and did not know her till she had brought forth her firstborn Son. And he called His name JESUS.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 4:4-7  (Epistle Nativity)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>4</dt><dd>But when the fullness of the time had come, God sent forth His Son, born of a woman, born under the law,</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>to redeem those who were under the law, that we might receive the adoption as sons.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>And because you are sons, God has sent forth the Spirit of His Son into your hearts, crying out, “Abba, Father!”</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore you are no longer a slave but a son, and if a son, then an heir of God through Christ.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 2:1-12  (Gospel Nativity)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Now after Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea in the days of Herod the king, behold, wise men from the East came to Jerusalem,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>saying, “Where is He who has been born King of the Jews? For we have seen His star in the East and have come to worship Him.”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>When Herod the king heard this, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And when he had gathered all the chief priests and scribes of the people together, he inquired of them where the Christ was to be born.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>So they said to him, “In Bethlehem of Judea, for thus it is written by the prophet:</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>‘But you, Bethlehem, in the land of Judah, Are not the least among the rulers of Judah; For out of you shall come a Ruler Who will shepherd My people Israel.’” </dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then Herod, when he had secretly called the wise men, determined from them what time the star appeared.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>And he sent them to Bethlehem and said, “Go and search carefully for the young Child, and when you have found Him, bring back word to me, that I may come and worship Him also.”</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>When they heard the king, they departed; and behold, the star which they had seen in the East went before them, till it came and stood over where the young Child was.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>When they saw the star, they rejoiced with exceedingly great joy.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And when they had come into the house, they saw the young Child with Mary His mother, and fell down and worshiped Him. And when they had opened their treasures, they presented gifts to Him: gold, frankincense, and myrrh.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Then, being divinely warned in a dream that they should not return to Herod, they departed for their own country another way.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 2:11-18  (Epistle Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>For both He who sanctifies and those who are being sanctified are all of one, for which reason He is not ashamed to call them brethren,</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>saying: “I will declare Your name to My brethren; in the midst of the assembly I will sing praise to You.”</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>And again: “I will put My trust in Him.” And again: “Here am I and the children whom God has given Me.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Inasmuch then as the children have partaken of flesh and blood, He Himself likewise shared in the same, that through death He might destroy him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and release those who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>For indeed He does not give aid to angels, but He does give aid to the seed of Abraham.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Therefore, in all things He had to be made like His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things pertaining to God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>For in that He Himself has suffered, being tempted, He is able to aid those who are tempted.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 2:13-23  (Gospel Theotokos)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Now when they had departed, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream, saying, “Arise, take the young Child and His mother, flee to Egypt, and stay there until I bring you word; for Herod will seek the young Child to destroy Him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>When he arose, he took the young Child and His mother by night and departed for Egypt,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and was there until the death of Herod, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Lord through the prophet, saying, “Out of Egypt I called My Son.” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Herod, when he saw that he was deceived by the wise men, was exceedingly angry; and he sent forth and put to death all the male children who were in Bethlehem and in all its districts, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had determined from the wise men.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then was fulfilled what was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“A voice was heard in Ramah, lamentation, weeping, and great mourning, Rachel weeping for her children, refusing to be comforted, because they are no more.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Now when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>saying, “Arise, take the young Child and His mother, and go to the land of Israel, for those who sought the young Child’s life are dead.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then he arose, took the young Child and His mother, and came into the land of Israel.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But when he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea instead of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there. And being warned by God in a dream, he turned aside into the region of Galilee.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, “He shall be called a Nazarene.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Acts 6:8-15 7:1-5 47-60  (Epistle Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd>And Stephen, full of faith and power, did great wonders and signs among the people.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Then there arose some from what is called the Synagogue of the Freedmen (Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and Asia), disputing with Stephen.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And they were not able to resist the wisdom and the Spirit by which he spoke.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>Then they secretly induced men to say, “We have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses and God.”</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And they stirred up the people, the elders, and the scribes; and they came upon him, seized him, and brought him to the council.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>They also set up false witnesses who said, “This man does not cease to speak blasphemous words against this holy place and the law;</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>for we have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs which Moses delivered to us.”</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And all who sat in the council, looking steadfastly at him, saw his face as the face of an angel.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Then the high priest said, “Are these things so?”</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And he said, “Brethren and fathers, listen: The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Haran,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>and said to him, ‘Get out of your country and from your relatives, and come to a land that I will show you.’ </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Then he came out of the land of the Chaldeans and dwelt in Haran. And from there, when his father was dead, He moved him to this land in which you now dwell.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And God gave him no inheritance in it, not even enough to set his foot on. But even when Abraham had no child, He promised to give it to him for a possession, and to his descendants after him.</dd><dt>47</dt><dd>But Solomon built Him a house.</dd><dt>48</dt><dd>However, the Most High does not dwell in temples made with hands, as the prophet says:</dd><dt>49</dt><dd>‘Heaven is My throne, and earth is My footstool. What house will you build for Me? says the LORD, or what is the place of My rest?</dd><dt>50</dt><dd>Has My hand not made all these things?’ </dd><dt>51</dt><dd>You stiff-necked and uncircumcised in heart and ears! You always resist the Holy Spirit; as your fathers did, so do you.</dd><dt>52</dt><dd>Which of the prophets did your fathers not persecute? And they killed those who foretold the coming of the Just One, of whom you now have become the betrayers and murderers,</dd><dt>53</dt><dd>who have received the law by the direction of angels and have not kept it.”</dd><dt>54</dt><dd>When they heard these things they were cut to the heart, and they gnashed at him with their teeth.</dd><dt>55</dt><dd>But he, being full of the Holy Spirit, gazed into heaven and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God,</dd><dt>56</dt><dd>and said, “Look! I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God!”</dd><dt>57</dt><dd>Then they cried out with a loud voice, stopped their ears, and ran at him with one accord;</dd><dt>58</dt><dd>and they cast him out of the city and stoned him. And the witnesses laid down their clothes at the feet of a young man named Saul.</dd><dt>59</dt><dd>And they stoned Stephen as he was calling on God and saying, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”</dd><dt>60</dt><dd>Then he knelt down and cried out with a loud voice, “Lord, do not charge them with this sin.” And when he had said this, he fell asleep.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 21:33-42  (Gospel Saint)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>33</dt><dd>Hear another parable: There was a certain landowner who planted a vineyard and set a hedge around it, dug a winepress in it and built a tower. And he leased it to vinedressers and went into a far country.</dd><dt>34</dt><dd>Now when vintage-time drew near, he sent his servants to the vinedressers, that they might receive its fruit.</dd><dt>35</dt><dd>And the vinedressers took his servants, beat one, killed one, and stoned another.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>Again he sent other servants, more than the first, and they did likewise to them.</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>Then last of all he sent his son to them, saying, ‘They will respect my son.’</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>But when the vinedressers saw the son, they said among themselves, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance.’</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>So they took him and cast him out of the vineyard and killed him.</dd><dt>40</dt><dd>Therefore, when the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those vinedressers?”</dd><dt>41</dt><dd>They said to Him, “He will destroy those wicked men miserably, and lease his vineyard to other vinedressers who will render to him the fruits in their seasons.”</dd><dt>42</dt><dd>Jesus said to them, “Have you never read in the Scriptures: ‘The stone which the builders rejected Has become the chief cornerstone. This was the LORD’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes’? </dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 10:1-18  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>For the law, having a shadow of the good things to come, and not the very image of the things, can never with these same sacrifices, which they offer continually year by year, make those who approach perfect.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For then would they not have ceased to be offered? For the worshipers, once purified, would have had no more consciousness of sins.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But in those sacrifices there is a reminder of sins every year.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For it is not possible that the blood of bulls and goats could take away sins.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Therefore, when He came into the world, He said: “Sacrifice and offering You did not desire, but a body You have prepared for Me.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>In burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin You had no pleasure.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Then I said, ‘Behold, I have come – in the volume of the book it is written of Me – to do Your will, O God.’”</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Previously saying, “Sacrifice and offering, burnt offerings, and offerings for sin You did not desire, nor had pleasure in them” (which are offered according to the law),</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>then He said, “Behold, I have come to do Your will, O God.” He takes away the first that He may establish the second.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>By that will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>And every priest stands ministering daily and offering repeatedly the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>But this Man, after He had offered one sacrifice for sins forever, sat down at the right hand of God,</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>from that time waiting till His enemies are made His footstool.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For by one offering He has perfected forever those who are being sanctified.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But the Holy Spirit also witnesses to us; for after He had said before,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>“This is the covenant that I will make with them after those days,” says the LORD: “I will put My laws into their hearts, and in their minds I will write them,”</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>then He adds, “Their sins and their lawless deeds I will remember no more.”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Now where there is remission of these, there is no longer an offering for sin.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 11:22-26  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>22</dt><dd>So Jesus answered and said to them, “Have faith in God.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>For assuredly, I say to you, whoever says to this mountain, ‘Be removed and be cast into the sea,’ and does not doubt in his heart, but believes that those things he says will be done, he will have whatever he says.</dd><dt>24</dt><dd>Therefore I say to you, whatever things you ask when you pray, believe that you receive them, and you will have them.</dd><dt>25</dt><dd>And whenever you stand praying, if you have anything against anyone, forgive him, that your Father in heaven may also forgive you your trespasses.</dd><dt>26</dt><dd>But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father in heaven forgive your trespasses.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 10:35-11:7  (Epistle)
