readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>35</dt><dd>Therefore do not cast away your confidence, which has great reward.</dd><dt>36</dt><dd>For you have need of endurance, so that after you have done the will of God, you may receive the promise:</dd><dt>37</dt><dd>“For yet a little while, and He who is coming will come and will not tarry.</dd><dt>38</dt><dd>Now the just shall live by faith; but if anyone draws back, my soul has no pleasure in him.”</dd><dt>39</dt><dd>But we are not of those who draw back to perdition, but of those who believe to the saving of the soul.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>For by it the elders obtained a good testimony.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>By faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the word of God, so that the things which are seen were not made of things which are visible.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd> By faith Abel offered to God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, through which he obtained witness that he was righteous, God testifying of his gifts; and through it he being dead still speaks.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>By faith Enoch was taken away so that he did not see death, “and was not found, because God had taken him”; for before he was taken he had this testimony, that he pleased God.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>But without faith it is impossible to please Him, for he who comes to God must believe that He is, and that He is a rewarder of those who diligently seek Him.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>By faith Noah, being divinely warned of things not yet seen, moved with godly fear, prepared an ark for the saving of his household, by which he condemned the world and became heir of the righteousness which is according to faith.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 11:27-33  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>27</dt><dd>Then they came again to Jerusalem. And as He was walking in the temple, the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders came to Him.</dd><dt>28</dt><dd>And they said to Him, “By what authority are You doing these things? And who gave You this authority to do these things?”</dd><dt>29</dt><dd>But Jesus answered and said to them, “I also will ask you one question; then answer Me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things:</dd><dt>30</dt><dd>The baptism of John – was it from heaven or from men? Answer Me.”</dd><dt>31</dt><dd>And they reasoned among themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ He will say, ‘Why then did you not believe him?’</dd><dt>32</dt><dd>But if we say, ‘From men’” – they feared the people, for all counted John to have been a prophet indeed.</dd><dt>33</dt><dd>So they answered and said to Jesus, “We do not know.” And Jesus answered and said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.”</dd></dl>

readings.title: Hebrews 11:8 11-16  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>8</dt><dd> By faith Abraham obeyed when he was called to go out to the place which he would receive as an inheritance. And he went out, not knowing where he was going.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>By faith Sarah herself also received strength to conceive seed, and she bore a child when she was past the age, because she judged Him faithful who had promised.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Therefore from one man, and him as good as dead, were born as many as the stars of the sky in multitude – innumerable as the sand which is by the seashore.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>These all died in faith, not having received the promises, but having seen them afar off were assured of them, embraced them and confessed that they were strangers and pilgrims on the earth.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>For those who say such things declare plainly that they seek a homeland.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>And truly if they had called to mind that country from which they had come out, they would have had opportunity to return.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>But now they desire a better, that is, a heavenly country. Therefore God is not ashamed to be called their God, for He has prepared a city for them.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Mark 12:1-12  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Then He began to speak to them in parables: “A man planted a vineyard and set a hedge around it, dug a place for the wine vat and built a tower. And he leased it to vinedressers and went into a far country.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>Now at vintage-time he sent a servant to the vinedressers, that he might receive some of the fruit of the vineyard from the vinedressers.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>And they took him and beat him and sent him away empty-handed.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Again he sent them another servant, and at him they threw stones, wounded him in the head, and sent him away shamefully treated.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And again he sent another, and him they killed; and many others, beating some and killing some.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Therefore still having one son, his beloved, he also sent him to them last, saying, ‘They will respect my son.’</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But those vinedressers said among themselves, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.’</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>So they took him and killed him and cast him out of the vineyard.</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Therefore what will the owner of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the vinedressers, and give the vineyard to others.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>Have you not even read this Scripture: ‘The stone which the builders rejected Has become the chief cornerstone.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>This was the LORD’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes’?” </dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And they sought to lay hands on Him, but feared the multitude, for they knew He had spoken the parable against them. So they left Him and went away.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 6:11-16  (Epistle Saturday After)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But you, O man of God, flee these things and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, gentleness.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>Fight the good fight of faith, lay hold on eternal life, to which you were also called and have confessed the good confession in the presence of many witnesses.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>I urge you in the sight of God who gives life to all things, and before Christ Jesus who witnessed the good confession before Pontius Pilate,</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>that you keep this commandment without spot, blameless until our Lord Jesus Christ’s appearing,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>which He will manifest in His own time, He who is the blessed and only Potentate, the King of kings and Lord of lords,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>who alone has immortality, dwelling in unapproachable light, whom no man has seen or can see, to whom be honor and everlasting power. Amen.</dd></dl>

readings.title: 1 Timothy 3:14-4:5  (Epistle Saturday After)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>14</dt><dd>These things I write to you, though I hope to come to you shortly;</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>but if I am delayed, I write so that you may know how you ought to conduct yourself in the house of God, which is the church of the living God, the pillar and ground of the truth.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifested in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen by angels, preached among the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up in glory.</dd><dt>1</dt><dd>Now the Spirit expressly says that in latter times some will depart from the faith, giving heed to deceiving spirits and doctrines of demons,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>speaking lies in hypocrisy, having their own conscience seared with a hot iron,</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>forbidding to marry, and commanding to abstain from foods which God created to be received with thanksgiving by those who believe and know the truth.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>For every creature of God is good, and nothing is to be refused if it is received with thanksgiving;</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>for it is sanctified by the word of God and prayer.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 12:15-21  (Gospel Saturday After)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>15</dt><dd>But when Jesus knew it, He withdrew from there. And great multitudes followed Him, and He healed them all.</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Yet He warned them not to make Him known,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Isaiah the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“Behold! My Servant whom I have chosen, My Beloved in whom My soul is well pleased! I will put My Spirit upon Him, and He will declare justice to the Gentiles.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>He will not quarrel nor cry out, nor will anyone hear His voice in the streets.</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>A bruised reed He will not break, and smoking flax He will not quench, till He sends forth justice to victory;</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>and in His name Gentiles will trust.” </dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 3:1-11  (Gospel Saturday Before)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>In those days John the Baptist came preaching in the wilderness of Judea,</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>and saying, “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand!”</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>For this is he who was spoken of by the prophet Isaiah, saying: “The voice of one crying in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the LORD; make His paths straight.’” </dd><dt>4</dt><dd>Now John himself was clothed in camel’s hair, with a leather belt around his waist; and his food was locusts and wild honey.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>Then Jerusalem, all Judea, and all the region around the Jordan went out to him</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>and were baptized by him in the Jordan, confessing their sins.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, “Brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the wrath to come?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>Therefore bear fruits worthy of repentance,</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>and do not think to say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father.’ For I say to you that God is able to raise up children to Abraham from these stones.</dd><dt>10</dt><dd>And even now the ax is laid to the root of the trees. Therefore every tree which does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.</dd><dt>11</dt><dd>I indeed baptize you with water unto repentance, but He who is coming after me is mightier than I, whose sandals I am not worthy to carry. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire. </dd></dl>

readings.title: Ephesians 5:1-8  (Epistle)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>1</dt><dd>Therefore be imitators of God as dear children.</dd><dt>2</dt><dd>And walk in love, as Christ also has loved us and given Himself for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for a sweet-smelling aroma.</dd><dt>3</dt><dd>But fornication and all uncleanness or covetousness, let it not even be named among you, as is fitting for saints;</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>neither filthiness, nor foolish talking, nor coarse jesting, which are not fitting, but rather giving of thanks.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>For this you know, that no fornicator, unclean person, nor covetous man, who is an idolater, has any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and God.</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of these things the wrath of God comes upon the sons of disobedience.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>Therefore do not be partakers with them.</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light</dd></dl>

readings.title: Luke 17:3-10  (Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>3</dt><dd>Take heed to yourselves. If your brother sins against you, rebuke him; and if he repents, forgive him.</dd><dt>4</dt><dd>And if he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times in a day returns to you, saying, ‘I repent,’ you shall forgive him.</dd><dt>5</dt><dd>And the apostles said to the Lord, “Increase our faith.”</dd><dt>6</dt><dd>So the Lord said, “If you have faith as a mustard seed, you can say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be pulled up by the roots and be planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you.</dd><dt>7</dt><dd>And which of you, having a servant plowing or tending sheep, will say to him when he has come in from the field, ‘Come at once and sit down to eat’?</dd><dt>8</dt><dd>But will he not rather say to him, ‘Prepare something for my supper, and gird yourself and serve me till I have eaten and drunk, and afterward you will eat and drink’?</dd><dt>9</dt><dd>Does he thank that servant because he did the things that were commanded him? I think not. </dd><dt>10</dt><dd>So likewise you, when you have done all those things which you are commanded, say, ‘We are unprofitable servants. We have done what was our duty to do.’ </dd></dl>

readings.title: John 20:11-18  (8th  Matins Gospel)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But Mary stood outside by the tomb weeping, and as she wept she stooped down and looked into the tomb.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>And she saw two angels in white sitting, one at the head and the other at the feet, where the body of Jesus had lain.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>Then they said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping?” She said to them, “Because they have taken away my Lord, and I do not know where they have laid Him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>Now when she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing there, and did not know that it was Jesus.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?” She, supposing Him to be the gardener, said to Him, “Sir, if You have carried Him away, tell me where You have laid Him, and I will take Him away.”</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Mary!” She turned and said to Him, “Rabboni!” (which is to say, Teacher).</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Jesus said to her, “Do not cling to Me, for I have not yet ascended to My Father; but go to My brethren and say to them, ‘I am ascending to My Father and your Father, and to My God and your God.’”</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Mary Magdalene came and told the disciples that she had seen the Lord, and that He had spoken these things to her.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Galatians 1:11-19  (Epistle Sunday After)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>11</dt><dd>But I make known to you, brethren, that the gospel which was preached by me is not according to man.</dd><dt>12</dt><dd>For I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it, but it came through the revelation of Jesus Christ.</dd><dt>13</dt><dd>For you have heard of my former conduct in Judaism, how I persecuted the church of God beyond measure and tried to destroy it.</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>And I advanced in Judaism beyond many of my contemporaries in my own nation, being more exceedingly zealous for the traditions of my fathers.</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>But when it pleased God, who separated me from my mother’s womb and called me through His grace,</dd><dt>16</dt><dd>to reveal His Son in me, that I might preach Him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately confer with flesh and blood,</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; but I went to Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to see Peter, and remained with him fifteen days.</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>But I saw none of the other apostles except James, the Lord’s brother.</dd></dl>

readings.title: Matthew 2:13-23  (Gospel Sunday After)
readings.contents: <dl class="reading"><dt>13</dt><dd>Now when they had departed, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream, saying, “Arise, take the young Child and His mother, flee to Egypt, and stay there until I bring you word; for Herod will seek the young Child to destroy Him.”</dd><dt>14</dt><dd>When he arose, he took the young Child and His mother by night and departed for Egypt,</dd><dt>15</dt><dd>and was there until the death of Herod, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Lord through the prophet, saying, “Out of Egypt I called My Son.” </dd><dt>16</dt><dd>Then Herod, when he saw that he was deceived by the wise men, was exceedingly angry; and he sent forth and put to death all the male children who were in Bethlehem and in all its districts, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had determined from the wise men.</dd><dt>17</dt><dd>Then was fulfilled what was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, saying:</dd><dt>18</dt><dd>“A voice was heard in Ramah, lamentation, weeping, and great mourning, Rachel weeping for her children, refusing to be comforted, because they are no more.”</dd><dt>19</dt><dd>Now when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,</dd><dt>20</dt><dd>saying, “Arise, take the young Child and His mother, and go to the land of Israel, for those who sought the young Child’s life are dead.”</dd><dt>21</dt><dd>Then he arose, took the young Child and His mother, and came into the land of Israel.</dd><dt>22</dt><dd>But when he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea instead of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there. And being warned by God in a dream, he turned aside into the region of Galilee.</dd><dt>23</dt><dd>And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, “He shall be called a Nazarene.”</dd></dl>
